HEADLINE: David Anderson, 60, Ex-Envoy to Belgrade

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 8

 BODY:
David Anderson, a United States Ambassador to Yugoslavia in the 1980's, died on July 4 in Berlin. He was 60.
The cause of death was a liver disease, family members said. 
 As Ambassador in Belgrade from 1981 to 1985, his main task was to help Yugoslavia cope with a deepening economic crisis by refinancing international loans.
He was born Jan. 3, 1937, in Kirkcaldy, Scotland, and came to the United States in 1952.
After earning a bachelor of arts degree from Union College in 1958, and a master's degree a year later from the Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy, he joined the State Department. His initial overseas posts included embassies in Belgrade, Yugoslavia; Bamako, Mali; Brussels and Bonn.
Mr. Anderson was a member of the United States delegation that negotiated the four-power Berlin Agreement of 1971 with the Soviets, British and French. The pact reduced cold-war tensions and helped pave the way for the unification of Germany.
After retiring from the Foreign Service in 1985, he was a visiting professor of international relations at Simmons College in Boston and in 1988 was named director of the Aspen Institute in Berlin, bringing together scholars and politicians from East and West.
Survivors include his wife, the former Doris Helen Heitmann of Berlin; two children from his first marriage, Natalie of Florham Park, N.J., and Scott of Silver Spring, Md.; his mother, Janet, of Pleasant Valley, N.Y., a brother, Alexander of Burlington, Vt., and two grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Mourning for North Korea Leader Ends, but Son Is Not Anointed

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: TOKYO, July 8

 BODY:
North Korea reportedly declared an end today to the official three-year mourning period for its late leader, Kim Il Sung, clearing the way for his son, Kim Jong Il, to assume full power.
But it is still not clear when, or even whether, Kim Jong Il will assume his father's titles as President of the country and head of the Communist Party. 
 Some experts predict that Mr. Kim will delay taking the posts for several months at least, because North Korea is suffering from a severe famine, and now is not a propitious time for a coronation.
North Korean diplomats have insisted that Kim Jong Il, who holds the title of supreme commander of the military, has always been fully in charge of the country since his father died at age 82 on July 8, 1994.
But out of respect for his father, they said, the younger Mr. Kim, who is 55, has held off assuming the formal titles until the three-year mourning period was over.
That time is now. "The mourning period is about to end," Kim Yong Nam, the Deputy Prime Minister and Foreign Minister, said in a speech today at a ceremony marking the third anniversary of Kim Il Sung's death, according to Radiopress, a Tokyo agency that monitors North Korean radio broadcasts.
"At this solemn occasion we restate our pledge from the bottom of our hearts to our father, the Great Leader," the minister was quoted as saying, speaking of Kim Il Sung.
The ceremony in Pyongyang, the capital, was held at the Kumsusan Memorial Palace, where Kim Il Sung's body has been preserved. Kim Jong Il was shown on North Korean television attending the ceremony, looking confident but not making a speech.
While those who spoke did not refer to Mr. Kim by any new titles, they pledged loyalty to his "monolithic leadership" as "the successor and incarnation" of his father.
North Korea watchers in Seoul and Tokyo say Mr. Kim might formally assume power on Sept. 9, the anniversary of the establishment of the North Korean Government, or on Oct. 10, the anniversary of the founding of the party.
But they said the inauguration might be delayed until next year if the severe famine worsened, the economy continued to deteriorate or efforts to improve relations with the United States, a key goal of the North Korean Government, did not bear fruit.
There is also some speculation that Mr. Kim might become party chief, the job with the real power in North Korea, but not the head of state, because that job involves too many public appearances for the notoriously reclusive man.
"He doesn't want to appear to the public," said Yu Suk Ryul, a professor at the Institute of Foreign Affairs and National Security in Seoul, which is affiliated with the South Korean Foreign Ministry. "He doesn't want to talk to foreigners."
Kim Il Sung ruled with an iron hand and a cult of personality for nearly five decades and groomed his son to succeed him. But Kim Jong Il lacks his father's charisma and credentials as a revolutionary, and there have been some doubts as to how firm his hold on power is. If he does not assume power soon, now that the mourning period is over, those doubts will grow.
"If nothing has happened by the end of October, that's significant," a Western expert said. "It means that they've really got problems and he doesn't feel confident that he could take them on."

HEADLINE: On Campus;
Average Pay for College Professors Rises Less Than Inflation Rate

BYLINE: By WILLIAM H. HONAN 

 BODY:
The average salary of college professors increased by 3 percent in the 1996-97 academic year, slightly less than the inflation rate, an annual survey by the American Association of University Professors showed.
The average salary for full-time professors was $59,851 at institutions that grant doctorates, $49,259 at institutions that grant up to a master's degree, $43,650 at baccalaureate institutions and $43,016 at two-year colleges. 
 Linda Bell, a professor of economics at Haverford College in Pennsylvania who is the author of the report, concluded that compensation in the last academic year had been "not so good." Dr. Bell found that average faculty members continuing in their jobs had seen a real increase, compared with the 1995-96 salary, of 0.2 percent, the smallest rate of increase in 15 years. But that increase did not keep pace with inflation, so the average faculty member actually experienced a decrease of 0.3 percent in salary, the report said.
 WILLIAM H. HONAN

HEADLINE: About New York;
From Milk And Mortar, Help and Hope

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZ 

 BODY:
A SIGN in Francisco De Leon's building warns: "No Trespassing. Tenants and Their Guests Only." Right. Mr. De Leon seldom entertains in his Washington Heights apartment, where he has lived on West 163d Street for 20 years. Drug dealers took over the decrepit building and the one next door years ago, conducting their business and settling their disputes without regard for anyone.
"People, our families, nobody wanted to come here," Mr. De Leon said. "This was no place to visit." 
 He walked over to a living-room window, where a bullet fired from the street ripped through the pane five years ago. The hole is still taped over.
"Sometimes, I did not think that I lived in New York," he said. "What's that place where people are always fighting? Bosnia. They had more peace in Sarajevo."
It was not an exaggeration. The two buildings between Broadway and Amsterdam Avenue represented perhaps the most abysmal conditions housing advocates and officials had ever seen. The buildings were falling apart and drug dealers entrenched in empty apartments outnumbered tenants. The city twice issued vacate orders, but Mr. De Leon could not afford to move.
It was a familiar scenario to Harold DeRienzo. In the 1970's, he joined his neighbors on Kelly Street in the Bronx to rescue three orphaned buildings from the wrecking ball. He has since repeated the process with increasing measures of policy know-how and financial savvy. He is now president of the Parodneck Foundation for Self-Help Housing and Community Development, which is helping Mr. De Leon and his neighbors restore their buildings.
IN June, Mr. DeRienzo's group helped the tenants get about $2.8 million in city grants and private loans to begin construction this summer. The tenants -- organized and represented by advocates from the Northern Manhattan Improvement Corporation -- bought the buildings for $1 from the last in a string of landlords. They are now waiting for the city to waive $500,000 in liens against the buildings for back taxes and unpaid water bills.
"When people who reside in buildings control the buildings, they will survive," Mr. DeRienzo said. "We go to meetings where they face desperate situations with very little hope. But people make it work. Self-help makes it a better city."
Not to mention a healthy one, which is why the foundation began. Sixty years ago, Meyer Parodneck, a Polish immigrant who grew up in poverty on the Lower East Side of Manhattan, formed a milk cooperative to help nourish urban youngsters. He got out of the nonprofit dairy business in the 1960's, to the delight of the large milk companies, which gave him $500,000 in return for agreeing never to compete with them again. Mr. Parodneck used that money to start a foundation that would give small grants and advice to community groups fighting the wave of abandonment that was sweeping poor neighborhoods.
"Having once been poor, that always stayed with him," said Mr. DeRienzo, who joined the foundation in 1982. "I used to sit down and have lunch with him. After he ate his sandwich, he would take his plate and brush off the crumbs into his tea and drink it."
Fittingly, the foundation has made its mark taking buildings others would have cast off and reviving them with gut rehabs and new tenants. Some of that work is accomplished through Community Assisted Tenant Controlled Housing, a citywide project that trains tenants to become the landlords of buildings they have renovated.
THE buildings on West 163d Street present a big challenge, not just because of the drug dealers, whom the police have been targeting. Mr. DeRienzo said that their future, and that of other similarly distressed properties, lies in a partnership among government, banks and nonprofit groups relying on investment, tax exemptions and tenant involvement.
"This project is being pieced together like a house of cards," he said. "You pull one card out and it all falls to the ground."
Although Mr. Parodneck died in 1994, his belief in self-help survives on West 163d Street. Cruz Ortiz, now president of the tenant group that owns the buildings, spoke optimistically about the future. She sat in the same cramped living room where her father suggested two years ago that perhaps she would be better off in a shelter.
"I did not come to this country to be homeless," she said. "I work. I can support myself."
And a few others, too.
"I don't feel like a landlord," she said. "I feel I have a responsibility for a better future for myself and the other tenants."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Borrowing By Consumers Rose in May

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 8

 BODY:
Borrowing by American consumers increased at a slower-than-expected pace in May as banks imposed tougher lending standards and consumers cut back on spending, the Federal Reserve reported today.
The level of consumer credit increased by $3 billion for the month, to $1.224 trillion, after rising by a revised $9.7 billion in April, the Fed said. Previously, the Fed said April borrowing increased by $7.6 billion. Before today's report, analysts had expected an increase of $5.6 billion during May. Consumer credit consists of automotive debt, credit card debt and personal loans, but not real estate loans. 
 Banks and retailers are being more conservative in their lending after personal bankruptcies soared past one million last year. Consumer borrowing increased rapidly in 1995 and early 1996, in part because of aggressive marketing campaigns by credit card issuers.
Fitch Investors Service Inc., a firm that rates debt securities, including notes backed by credit card loans, said on Monday that the number of credit card write-offs in May declined to $842 million from $846 million a month earlier.
The drop in write-offs, when a company concedes that customers will not pay their bills, followed six months of rising delinquency rates. Companies usually wait about 180 days before writing off an account.
Today's Fed report showed that the pace of consumer credit was rising at a 2.9 percent annual rate during May. That was slower than the 9.7 percent pace of borrowing in April.
By category, revolving loans, which include credit card borrowing, rose $700 million in May after rising by $5.4 billion a month earlier. Auto loans decreased by $1.7 billion in May after rising $4.5 billion in April and other types of personal loans rose by $4 billion after falling $100 million a month earlier.
In the last year, credit card use surged to an all-time high. Visa International said this week that total credit and debit card purchases on its payment network rose 23.7 percent, to $1 trillion, from $824 billion in the corresponding period a year earlier. Visa issuers increased the number of debit and credit cards 12.8 percent, to 572 million worldwide.

GRAPHIC: Graph: "Consumer Borrowing" tracks net change in total consumer installment credit outstanding, in billions of dollars, seasonally adjusted, from December 1995 through May 1997. (Source: Federal Reserve Board)

HEADLINE: SHARING IN THE HARVEST;
Urban Living Off the Land

SERIES: An occasional series.

BYLINE: By MOLLY O'NEILL 

 BODY:
YOU are about to enter the fourth dimension of grocery shopping.
Last month, The New York Times bought a $355 share in a program called Threshold Farm Community Supported Agriculture. And over the coming months, as writers for The Living Section cook with the weekly allotment of produce, you may glean the glories of abundance, the satisfaction of supporting a small local farm, the challenge of cooking within the limits of a short East Coast growing season, and the sense of a small town sort of community. 
 Before that, however, the idea of not having everything you want exactly when you want it could shade your perceptions.
Fear of possible deprivation defined my initial foray into a program in which city dwellers commission a local grower to supply them with high-quality produce for a 30-week growing season, and pay in advance. The fruits and vegetables can be incorporated into grain or bean-based dishes for vegetarian meals or used with meat, poultry and fish. In either case, the local pickings determine the dish. Members tend to rethink how they cook and what they cook.
By sharing a farmer's production costs, members aren't "buyers" as much as they are partners in planning crops and budgets and sharing the harvest, along with the vicissitudes of nature.
Like the environmental and health-food movements of yore, farm-to-table programs are loosely organized and fiercely local. There are various conferences, publications and umbrella organizations throughout the country, but small community groups, rather than a central one, establish and support the individual projects.
In the last 12 years, 600 projects have been started in North America. In New York City, six growers supply eight groups, or about 3,000 people, said Sarah Milstein, director of C.S.A. programs for Just Food, a nonprofit group in Manhattan that helps organize farmers and urbanites.
The movement was started by a group of women in Japan 30 years ago and was brought to New England in 1982. "Teikei," meaning "to tie together," is a common word in Japan, and when applied to agriculture it connotes "food with a farmer's face," Ms. Milstein said.
The program's appeal and its steady growth seem to be a confluence of appetite and health concerns, pastoral longings and political leanings. At the Threshold pickup site, Advent Lutheran Church, at 93d Street and Broadway, for instance, virtually all members interviewed supported the Mayoral candidate Ruth Messinger, were opposed to any change in rent-control laws and spoke highly of the virtues of local, organically grown produce.
In fact, the idealism of the shareholders sounded sanctimonious at first. The scuff of Birkenstocks through the church basement reminded me of why I stopped shopping in food co-ops 20 years ago. But even feeling like a cranky Rip Van Winkle, I was trudging a road toward one possible future of farming -- and cooking -- in America.
As thousands of small family farms have been razed for residential and commercial complexes across the country, more and more farmers have begun to market their produce directly to the public to trim costs and increase profits.
A grower selling directly from his farm stand or in a city-operated Greenmarket can make about 30 percent more than one who sells to a wholesale distributor. And C.S.A. farmers rely partly on volunteer labor and have consumers who pay in advance, so they whittle even more from their costs.
"At the stand, you have overhead and labor to consider," said Bill Halsey of Green Thumb Farm in Water Mill, N.Y. His family has operated a roadside stand at its farm for 30 years and sold in the Union Square Greenmarket for four years. "At the Greenmarket, you can sell a whole truckload one week, and then get rain the next and end up driving a full truck home," he said. The cost of business is also lower. "I pay $20 for a space with my C.S.A.," he said. "I paid $200 for my space at the Union Square market."
Community supported agriculture "lets you plan exactly what to plant and what to deliver and cuts about 18 hours from my workweek," he added.
In the last three years, Mr. Halsey has formed buying groups at his farm as well as in Brooklyn and Queens. "I have Sunday off now," he said. "Talk about an improved quality of life!"
But economic imperatives pale beside the ideological drive behind most growers.
"Not even a C.S.A. can pay me minimum wage," said Hugh Williams, who owns the eight-acre Threshold Farm in the Hudson Valley community of Claverack, N.Y. "But it allows me to grow food that is healthy for people and healthy for the planet. It allows me to forge a link between the country and the city. It allows me to live a beautiful, ethical life."
Ms. Milstein said that a farm did not have to be organic to be involved in the program, "but in practice the majority have been organic so far."
"People who buy from a C.S.A. want the kind of clean produce that is difficult to find elsewhere," she added.
In addition to the freedom of growing techniques, the financial security of prepaid shares allows farmers to set their own prices, said Daniel Lass, a professor of resource economics at the University of Massachusetts in Amherst.
"Conventional growers have to accept the price set by large food wholesale buyers," he explained. "Theoretically, C.S.A. growers calculate their annual costs and price their shares accordingly. C.S.A. allows the farmer to concentrate on growing rather than marketing."
Growers stand to make up to 50 percent more than if they sold wholesale. And consumers can save a lot. A 1996 study by Jack P. Cooley and Mr. Lass at the University of Massachusetts found that the food delivered for a $450 share would have cost up to $1,150 in a conventional grocery store, a local food market or an organic food market.
For shareholders, the program amounts to spending time to save money.
The New York Times's share, for instance, cost $11.83 a week for 30 weeks of enough produce to feed two people eating a standard American diet. During the week of June 9, my share would have cost an average of $17.21 from three organic produce markets surveyed in Manhattan.
But I spent half an hour on the subway going to the pickup site and 20 minutes (and $9) for a taxi back to midtown. I also performed two of the required six hours of volunteer work -- which can be done at the farm or the drop-off site.
On our first pickup date, June 10, I received food more suitable for two rabbits than two adults: a bunch of radishes, a bunch of green onions, a head of curly lettuce, two heads of red-leaf lettuce, four sprigs of thyme, four sprigs of dill, a small bunch of sorrel, four cups of baby spinach and two cups of mesclun.
As I packed our first share, I was embarrassed about not bringing my own recycled bag. Others had brought extra used paper bags for people like me; three people reminded me of the ecological importance of supplying my own bags in the future.
I asked how two people could live on lettuce alone.
"The season is off to a slow start," said Donna Garde, one of nine core members of the Threshold group who volunteers up to 10 hours a week. She offered cooking tips and ideas for using the vegetables.
In talking to people who have had a few years of farm-to-table cooking, I found that most supplemented their rations with root vegetables and food they had put away from the previous season while they waited for the season's first vegetables to ripen.
But I was struggling with more than lack of a larder. I was fighting some basic assumptions of modern urban dwelling. The limits I felt were not as much about early local produce; they were about the habits of entitlement.
In two weeks of trying to cook using the local seasonal vegetables, I was more aware of what the farm did not provide than what it did. When one of my colleagues assumed her scheduled pickups, I promptly sped to the more bountiful Balducci's.
But my conversion is not yet out of the question.
On my second pickup, I listened as Peter Mann, who is embarking on his third season, describe his "C.S.A. journey."
"At first it is a chore," he said. "Then it is a challenge. Then it is a new circle of friends. I work at the farm about 10 weekends a year. Sharing the vulnerability of the seasons, the connection with the earth, the weeding, the harvest -- it sounds weird, but its powerful, healing stuff."
Meanwhile, I was mentally adding the price of the cab ride to the cost of the second week's share -- a bunch of spring onions, two heads of green lettuce, two heads of red-oak lettuce, four cups of mixed lettuces, four sprigs each of thyme and dill, four cups of mixed greens for braising -- when Mr. Williams returned from his truck on Broadway, where the meter had expired.
He had a $55 parking ticket. I had had a $9 taxi ride. Together we were paying fines and fares to eat well in a town without pity.
I signed up for the annual potluck supper committee and made plans to spend a weekend weeding at Threshold Farm.
The Living Section will feature occasional articles on cooking with C.S.A. produce. More information on the program is available from Community Supported Agriculture of North America: (413) 528-4374.
 
Little Spring Soup
 Total time: 1/2 hour

 1 bunch radishes, cut wafer thin and chilled
 2 green onions, sliced wafer thin and chilled completely
 1/2 bunch peppery green, such as watercress or arugula, minced and chilled
 10 leaves lettuce, finely shredded and chilled completely
 1 cup minced fresh dill
 8 new potatoes, peeled
 2 cups whole milk
 3/4 teaspoon citric acid (also called sour salt)
 1 tablespoon butter
 Salt and pepper to taste.

 1. Combine the well-chilled radishes, onions, greens and lettuce with 1/2 of the dill; return to the refrigerator.
 2. Boil the potatoes in lightly salted water until tender. Meanwhile, place the milk in a nonreactive bowl, whisk in the citric acid and refrigerate for 10 minutes. If you can't find citric acid, omit it and use buttermilk in place of the whole milk.
 3. Combine the cold vegetables and the soured milk and return to the refrigerator. When the potatoes are tender, toss them with the butter and remaining dill, and season to taste with salt and pepper. Serve the soup cold with the hot potatoes on the side.
 Yield: 4 servings.
 Approximate nutritional analysis per serving: 215 calories, 7 grams fat, 25 milligrams cholesterol, 110 milligrams sodium, 7 grams protein, 30 grams carbohydrate.

 Spinach and Feta Pizza
 Total time: 30 minutes plus up to 2 hours of rising time

For the crust:
 1 package active dry yeast
 1 cup warm water
 3 to 3 1/2 cups all-purpose flour
 1/2 teaspoon salt
 1 tablespoon extra-virgin olive oil, plus some for oiling the bowl
 2 tablespoons fresh thyme leaves
 1/4 teaspoon freshly ground black pepper.
 
For the topping:
 2 cloves garlic, peeled
 1 cup minced green onions
 2 tablespoons olive oil
 1/8 teaspoon chili pepper flakes
 1/2 teaspoon salt
 8 cups spinach
 16 ounces feta cheese.
 
 1. To make the crust, dissolve yeast in the warm water. Add 1 cup of flour and the salt, and mix well. Stir in another cup of flour and stir until the dough becomes sticky.
 2. Dust a work surface with some of the remaining flour and knead the dough, sprinkling in the remaining flour as you knead until the dough no longer feels sticky, 5 to 10 minutes. Lightly oil a large metal bowl, add the dough, wrap tightly with plastic wrap and let the dough rise in a warm place until doubled in size, about 45 minutes.
 3. Punch dough down, knead in 1 tablespoon of olive oil, thyme and black pepper; cover and let rise until double in size, about 1 hour.
 4. Preheat the oven to 500 degrees. To make the topping, warm the whole garlic cloves and the minced onion in 1 tablespoon of the olive oil over medium heat. Season with the chili pepper flakes and the salt, and cook until soft, about 5 minutes. Add the spinach, toss, cover, reduce heat to low and simmer until tender, about 7 minutes.
 5. Drain the excess moisture from this mixture and chop the spinach, onions and garlic.
 6. Divide the dough in half and roll it out into two 18-inch circles. Brush each disk with a touch of the remaining olive oil. Divide the spinach in a thin layer over each pie, leaving a 1-inch border. Crumble the feta over the spinach, drizzle with the remaining olive oil and bake for 20 minutes, until the crust is golden.
 Yield: 4 servings.
 Approximate nutritional analysis per serving: 795 calories, 35 grams fat, 100 milligrams cholesterol, 1,890 milligrams sodium, 30 grams protein, 90 grams carbohydrate.

Spicy Spring Greens
With Chicken
 Total time: 25 minutes plus 40 minutes chilling time

 1 8-ounce can unsweetened coconut milk
 1 tablespoon butter
 2 cloves garlic, peeled
 1 1/2-inch piece of fresh ginger root, peeled and chopped
 2 green onions, minced
 2 heads lettuce, chopped
 2 cups spinach
 2 whole chicken breasts, cut in half
 Salt to taste
 2 teaspoons curry powder
 Freshly ground black pepper to taste.

 1. One hour before cooking, open the can of coconut milk and place in the freezer.
 2. Warm 1/2 of the butter over medium heat. Add garlic, ginger and onions, stir and soften for about 3 minutes. Add lettuce and spinach and cook, stirring constantly, for 2 minutes. Cover, reduce heat to low and simmer for 15 minutes.
 3. Pass this mixture through a food processor to make a puree, return to the pan and set aside.
 4. Warm the remaining butter in a saute skillet over high heat. Season the chicken lightly with salt and saute until golden on one side, about 5 minutes. Turn, reduce heat to medium low and cook for 5 more minutes. Sprinkle curry powder over chicken and toss to combine while cooking for 3 to 5 more minutes, until chicken is completely cooked.
 5. Return the spinach to high heat. Use a tablespoon to scoop 1/4 cup of the thick coconut cream from the top of the chilled container; the whey will have settled to the bottom. (The remainder can be stored, covered, in the freezer for up to 2 months.)
 6. Whisk the chilled coconut cream into the spinach. Adjust seasoning with salt and pepper and top with the chicken breast. Serve with basmati rice on the side, if desired.
 Yield: 4 servings.
 Approximate nutritional analysis per serving: 210 calories, 8 grams fat, 75 milligrams cholesterol, 130 milligrams sodium, 30 grams protein, 5 grams carbohydrate.

SECTION: Section A; Page 20; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 558 words

HEADLINE: NATO Plus Three

 BODY:
The grand declarations, rippling flags and bright sunshine in Madrid yesterday could not obscure the serious differences within NATO over how far and fast it should grow. Those divisions may ultimately defeat the purpose of expansion, which President Clinton heralded as the creation of a Europe that for the first time is undivided, democratic and at peace.
At American insistence, expansion will initially be limited to Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic. That restricts membership to the most qualified countries and limits the cost of expansion, which may help make this dubious plan acceptable to the Senate. A two-thirds Senate majority is required to approve the plan. 
 Most of NATO's 16 current members wished to add Romania and Slovenia as well. Weeks of negotiation were required to finesse the problem. In the end, a NATO communique made clear that additional members would be added in the future, and conspicuously noted that Romania and Slovenia were making progress toward admission. But no date for round two was set, and no explicit commitment was given to any country.
While this compromise may be diplomatically elegant, it only delays a potentially enervating membership fight. France, having bowed to the American preference in Madrid, will no doubt insist on Romanian membership next time the question comes up, most likely in 1999. Romania may have historic ties with France, but only last year did it shed the deadening regime that came to power after the fall of Communism. Politically, economically and militarily it is in no shape to join NATO.
If Romania is offered membership in the next round, how can NATO justify denying access to Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania? They are at the moment at least as democratic as Romania and more vulnerable to any future Russian security threat, the unspoken reason for expanding NATO in the first place. Yet Washington remains wary about adding the Baltic countries because their admission is anathema to Russia. Altogether, 12 countries want to join NATO, including Albania, Slovakia and Bulgaria, which to varying degrees are still suffering from Communist hangovers.
At some point, the addition of new members will weaken the alliance by putting in question the security guarantees that remain NATO's core. Americans, for instance, admire the courage of Poles, Czechs and Hungarians, who survived decades of Soviet rule. It is less clear whether most Americans see the defense of those countries as vital to American security. The case for placing an American nuclear shield over Romania or Slovenia may be even harder to make.
Wherever expansion stops, a new division in Europe will probably develop. Draw the line at Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic, and the rest of Eastern Europe will be left out. Push it farther south, and Bulgaria may still remain outside. Move it east, and it hits the Russian border. From any such division, economic and political isolation of those left outside is bound to grow.
Absent the cold war with its hard military boundaries, Europe has slowly been moving toward the state of unity and peace that Bill Clinton seeks. Russia, the giant in the East, is today more democratic and less threatening than at any time in its history. Expanding NATO now may well complicate, if not undermine, the transformation of Europe.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Clause in Rent Law Is Said to Allow Extra Rises for Some Apartments

BYLINE: By RANDY KENNEDY 

 BODY:
State housing officials said yesterday that a provision of the rent-regulation law signed last month by Gov. George E. Pataki will temporarily allow landlords to raise rents on vacant apartments in New York City more steeply than first expected.
Landlords are allowed under the new law to raise rents by roughly 20 percent on apartments that have been vacated, and the housing officials said that at least until the end of September, they could also apply a 9 percent increase that had previously been permitted under New York City rules. 
 Officials estimated that as many as 30,000 apartments in the city could turn over in the next three months and be affected by the provision.
Tenant advocates immediately disputed the interpretation and warned that landlords who took advantage of it could expose themselves to costly lawsuits.
When the rent bill was passed on June 19 after months of bitter political infighting, tenant advocates and Democratic lawmakers who supported rent protections said they believed that the new increase of roughly 20 percent would replace the smaller increases, set by the city's Rent Guidelines Board.
But since then, landlords' lawyers and officials at the state's Division of Housing and Community Renewal have been poring over the complicated language. In late June, groups representing most of the city's landlords began urging their members to add the increases together and to raise rents by either 27 percent or 29 percent, depending on the length of the lease, on vacant apartments.
And yesterday, after an internal memo circulated within the Division of Housing and Community Renewal was made public by tenant advocates, housing officials said that the landlords' interpretation appeared to be correct.
"The law is the law," said Harry Ryttenberg, a spokesman for the housing division. "When landlords call up to our information lines, this is what they're being told."
The memo, dated June 27, states that if a new tenant moves into a vacated apartment and signs a one-year lease, the landlord can raise the rent 27 percent above the old rent. According to the complex formulas under the new law, that essentially means a hike of 18 percent under the new law and the increase of 9 percent set by the city's Rent Guidelines Board last year.
For a two-year lease on a vacant apartment, the increase would be 29 percent -- 20 percent under the new law and 9 percent under the city guidelines. That 9 percent increase expires on Sept. 30, and the board recently voted not to allow an annual vacancy bonus for the next year.
But until the expiration, if an apartment becomes vacant, and the old tenant had paid $1,000 a month for the apartment, the new tenant would pay either $1,270 a month in a one-year lease or $1,290 in a two-year lease. Under a flat 20 percent increase, the monthly rent would be $1,200.
In addition, under the new law, if the previous rent was below $300, a $100 increase can be tacked on. And if the previous tenant had lived in the apartment for more than eight years, another increase could be added, calculated by the number of years the old tenant had remained.
The memo uses this example: a man who had occupied an apartment for 10 years, at $275 a month, vacates it before Sept. 30. A new tenant moves in and signs a one-year lease. The new rent is $275 plus a 27 percent increase, plus an additional six-tenths of one percent for every year the old tenant had lived there. Because the previous tenant had lived in the apartment for more than eight years, another $100 would be added. The new rent would be $465.75.
Billy Easton, executive director of the New York State Tenants and Neighbors Coalition, said yesterday that the overlapping increases would mean steep hikes in apartments for the poor and working class. He said that "landlords who do this risk having to pay treble damages" if the practice is struck down in court.
"And the Governor is risking ongoing political fallout if he doesn't move quickly to stop it," Mr. Easton added.
Landlords will almost certainly be sued over the higher increases, but landlord advocacy groups have instructed their members to take the larger increases anyway because they believed the courts would eventually rule in their favor.
"We're telling people to take the increase based on what we think is the clear language of the law," said Dan Margulies, executive director of the Community Housing Improvement Program, a group that represents smaller owners. "If they don't take it, and the state eventually rules it is alright, then the lower rent will stand. And it will be too late."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Securities Dip in Price

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities turned slightly lower in subdued trading yesterday, snapping a four-day rally.
The Treasury's 30-year bond slipped 2/32, to 100 20/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, was 6.58 percent, up from Monday's New York close of 6.57 percent. 
 According to GovPx, the bond pricing service, overall activity was light throughout the day. By 3 P.M. the $55.3 billion of securities traded was 22 percent below the average traded on a Tuesday in the third quarter of last year. Bill volume was 45 percent below that average trading last year, while note and bond volume was 10 percent below average trading last year.
With interest rates at five-month lows, a host of borrowers have lined up to take advantage of the low-rate environment. Some $13 billion of debt is expected to come to market this week. Canada, and the Associates Corporation of North America priced a combined $1.5 billion in new debt yesterday.
"There is some supply coming," said Tony Crescenzi, head of government bond trading at Miller, Tabak, Hirsch & Company, "and that is part of what is keeping bonds from gaining."
Wall Street securities firms making up the underwriting group managing bond sales often hedge against possible losses by selling government securities before the new debt issue is sold.
On the support side, bonds are being buoyed by the recent slump in gold prices, which suggests that investors are not overly concerned about inflation. Gold, which hit an 11 1/2-year low on Monday,is often purchased as a hedge against inflation.
Yesterday Canada priced $1 billion of five-year global bonds through underwriters led by the joint lead managers BMO Nesbitt Burns International Ltd., Merrill Lynch International and Salomon Brothers International Ltd. The issue was at a price to yield 6.247 percent, or about 8 basis points more than United States. Treasury securities with a comparable maturity. (A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.)
 The Associates Corporation of North America sold $500 million of five-year notes through the joint lead managers Chase Securities Inc. and UBS Securities. Rated Aa-3 by Moody's Investors Service and AA-- by Standard & Poor's, the issue was priced to yield 6.507 percent or about 35 basis points more than a five-year Treasury.
According to some market watchers, future borrowers include the Philip Morris Companies., which is planning to price a $1 billion global bond issue later this week through Merrill Lynch.
Today the Treasury plans to auction $8 billion of its new five-year Treasury inflation-protected securities, also known as TIPS. Roseanne C. Briggen, market analyst at MCM Moneywatch in New York, says the inflation-protected securities have been bought mostly by bond funds and pension funds, and since there has not been inflation they have underperformed the rest of the Treasury market.
"The economy is still strong, employment is low and the Fed is on hold," Mrs. Briggen said. "Over time they may prove to be a good buy and provide the hedge against inflation for which they were designed in the first place."
In when-issued trading, the five- year TIPS was offered at a price to yield 3.64 percent, up 10 basis points from Monday. Dealers often raise the rate on a new issue to make it more attractive to investors and lower the chances that they may be left with more inventory than they care to hold.

SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1911 words

HEADLINE: Remixing Trade and Diplomacy;
At Commerce Dept., No More Flash a la Ron Brown

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 8

 BODY:
As Commerce Secretary, Ronald H. Brown was a master at using powerful political symbols. Jetting around the world practicing what he called "commercial diplomacy," he often traveled with an entourage of big-name chief executives and insisted that the Air Force play the role of chauffeur.
"When that plane lands with 'The United States of America' emblazoned on the side," he said just a few months before his death last year on one of those missions, "and the Commerce Secretary emerges with America's top executives, it sends a message that we mean business." 
 William M. Daley, the Commerce Secretary for the last five months, also knows something about symbolism. So when he stepped off an airplane in South America a few weeks ago, he had a lot fewer chief executives with him, and the words on the side of the plane read "American Airlines."
Those contrasting approaches sum up the subtle changes in the Clinton Administration's approach to placing America's economic interests -- particularly the promotion of commercial exports -- at the center of the country's foreign policy agenda. Attuned to the controversies surrounding Mr. Brown's rich brew of business and politics, Mr. Daley has already altered the tone of the Commerce Department's trade missions, setting clear criteria for how companies are chosen and playing down the signing of big deals.
But altering the style of promoting exports abroad is only one example of how Mr. Daley and other Administration officials have tried to redefine commercial diplomacy. Anticipating that the Republicans leading the Congressional hearings on campaign finance that opened today will try to link the financing of the 1996 Presidential campaign to the Administration's trade policy, Mr. Daley has pre-emptively downsized his department.
Ten days ago he announced the layoff of 40 political appointees, and wherever he travels these days, he repeats the mantra that "there is no room for politics in the Commerce Department." It is a strategy meant to insure that should John Huang, the former Commerce Department official turned fund-raiser, end up testifying at the hearings under a grant of limited immunity from prosecution, the department could say that it had already carried out major reforms.
But the ripple effects of Mr. Daley's actions, in the minds of many inside and outside the Commerce Department, are wider than the Administration may have intended. A White House that once sought headlines for promoting American exports is these days often shying away from conspicuous displays of American diplomatic power to win contracts abroad.
Even the definition of commercial diplomacy, a phrase Mr. Brown's aides settled upon because they thought the word "commercial" would keep the State Department from interfering, is undergoing a shift. Speech by speech, Administration officials are putting less emphasis on export promotion and the creation of jobs in America as the goal. Far more often, they talk about using trade initiatives and American investment as ways to promote peace and stability, from Africa to Northern Ireland.
"Export promotion is still a big part of what we do around here," Mr. Daley said in a recent interview. "But we are also trying to show that there is much more that we can accomplish around the world pulling economic levers."
Mr. Daley has received enormous praise within the Administration for defusing a major trouble spot: On Capitol Hill, Republicans are no longer talking about dismantling the Commerce Department. "Bill has one of the most sound political antenna I've ever seen," said Stuart E. Eizenstat, who left a top Commerce Department job recently to become Under Secretary of State for Economic Affairs.
So far, however, Mr. Daley has not laid out the kind of well-articulated trade agenda that characterized Mr. Clinton's first term. And some fear that the Commerce Department is losing the sense of mission it briefly had. In a recent article in Foreign Affairs magazine, Jeffrey E. Garten, the Under Secretary of Commerce for International Trade during most of Mr. Clinton's first term, noted that the White House's enthusiasm for its prior strategy waned after the campaign investigations "raised a host of questions about whether America's commercial diplomacy, particularly in Asia, was for sale." Mr. Garten, now the dean of the Yale School of Management, wrote that the Administration had "lost its laser-like focus on the importance of foreign markets to the United States."
Mr. Garten's deputy at the Commerce Department, David Rothkopf, now a senior official at Kissinger Associates, the former Secretary of State's consulting firm, is even blunter. "In the way we once knew it, commercial diplomacy is nearly dead," he said.
The White House maintains that its focus on these issues is undiminished. "Commercial diplomacy is not dead because we can't just walk off the field," Mr. Daley insisted, sitting near a photograph of his father, the late Richard J. Daley, the legendary Mayor and political power broker in Chicago. (An older brother, Richard M. Daley, is Chicago's current Mayor.) "We have to conduct this kind of effort because it's clear that Helmut Kohl and Jacques Chirac aren't going to stop."
Nonetheless, some career officials within the Commerce Department say there is an absence of electricity where the center of the action was during the first term. Mr. Brown and Mr. Garten, for example, built what they called a "war room" on the department's fifth floor to coordinate Washington's activities -- from ambassadors to the C.I.A. to the President -- in tracking major building projects around the world and making sure that American businesses won their share.
Mr. Daley eschews the economic warfare analogies -- "the term 'war room' always bugged me," he says -- although he insists that "we are probably being as aggressive as we used to be in our advocacy center." His aides like to point instead to a new "compliance center," set up by Mr. Eizenstat, who says he was "stunned to discover when I arrived at Commerce that we were so busy negotiating trade agreements that we never tracked whether countries were abiding by them." But monitoring old trade accords, Mr. Daley's aides concede, does not make for many flashy headlines.
"What you are seeing is a difference in style between me and Ron," Mr. Daley said. "But times are also different. The American economy is booming. Some of the big projects around the world that we were so eager to get are slowing down a bit now." Moreover, he added, "I'm not sure that American companies need as much Government help to get a foot in the door as they did a few years ago."
The stylistic differences are particularly evident on trade missions. Mr. Brown made much of the pageantry of signing deals. One of his first big missions was to China in 1994, and he repeatedly touted it as leading to $6 billion in deals. But most of those were "memorandums of understanding," and many of the understandings quickly unraveled. The Entergy Corporation, for example, the utility holding company based in New Orleans, signed a $1 billion "understanding" to build a coal-fired power plant in Shanxi Province, along with the Lippo Group of Indonesia, then little known. But by 1995, it was clear that the deal was dead, said Cyril Guerrera, a spokesman for Entergy.
In fact, nearly three years after Mr. Brown's mission, the Commerce Department says only $1.66 billion of those deals actually came to fruition, while $3.2 billion more are officially described as still being "pursued" by American companies.
Acutely aware of that history, Mr. Daley was careful not to overpromise on his recent trip to South America, a much smaller market than China. He treated signing ceremonies as something of a sideshow, focusing instead on longer-range issues during stops in Chile, Brazil and Argentina. That is critical spadework for the Administration, which has lost a lot of credibility in Latin America for its failure so far to persuade Congress to give it the authority to negotiate extensions of the North American Free Trade Agreement, starting with Chile.
The Administration insists it will get that authority this fall, but Canada and Mexico, unwilling to wait, are beginning to strike deals of their own. For example, a separate free trade accord between Canada and Chile went into effect last Sunday.
Instead of taking along big-name chief executives on his South American trade mission, Mr. Daley traveled with lesser-known executives a few notches down the corporate ladder, selected according to a strict new set of criteria. Those rules limit participation to companies with a demonstrated interest in the region to be visited, and the final choices are made by a committee dominated by career officials.
The new rules are intended to avoid one of the big questions that still linger over Mr. Brown despite his death: How did corporate executives, some of whom were big political donors, get aboard the Secretary's plane? Mr. Brown's method of selection remains a mystery. "The list of participants on these trips just appeared from Brown's office," a senior Commerce official said recently.
Nonetheless, reams of documents on that issue made public over the last two years have yet to produce convincing evidence that any executives promised to make campaign donations in return for a seat on a mission.
These days, Mr. Daley is constantly treading a fine line. He has steered clear of any criticism of Mr. Brown. But that criticism is implicit in many of the changes he has made.
The political appointees laid off included several officials in the Secretary's office. Mr. Daley has said he will shrink the total number of posts filled by political appointees throughout the department by roughly 100, to about 250. His aides concede in private that the department became a dumping ground for the White House personnel office, saying that may explain how Mr. Huang, a former senior official of the Lippo Group, the Indonesian conglomerate run by the Riady family, ended up as a Commerce Department official dealing with Taiwan. Mr. Huang left the department for the Democratic National Committee in late 1995, after a meeting with President Clinton that is still a subject of the campaign inquiries.
If Mr. Daley has put out the political fires at the Commerce Department, however, he and the trade representative, Charlene Barshefsky, and Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright are just beginning to define new goals for the nation's foreign business and trade agenda. Ms. Barshefsky does the best job of the three in articulating long-term goals, but Ms. Albright has said little.
"A lot of this is new ground for Madeleine," one of her colleagues said, "and it's going to take a while for her to get her feet on the ground."
Six months into the second term, however, many issues that fall under the umbrella of commercial diplomacy are still under debate within the White House. No one has ever resolved the question of how deeply the intelligence agencies should get involved in economic espionage, an argument that has raged for several years now.
Nor, among other things, has the White House decided how hard to fight to preserve or reorganize Government agencies that provide low-cost financing for American exporters.
"This is all being revisited," one senior White House official said last week. "But very, very slowly."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Commerce Secretary William M. Daley, right, conferred with Francisco Dornelles, left, Brazillian Minister of Industry, Commerce and Tourism, and Melvin Levitsky, U.S. Ambassador to Brazil, during a trip to South America in May. Unkike Mr. Daley, Mr. Brown made juch of the pageantry of signing trade deals and metting with world leaders like China's President, Jiang Zemin. (Commerce Department Photographs)
 
Chart: "A Lower Profile"
Stung by controversy over former Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown's practice of mixing politics and business abroad, William Daley, the new head of Commerce, devoted his first trip overseas -- to Latin America in May -- to behind-the-scenes diplomacy. The trip deliberately lacked the high profile trade agreements and corporate contracts that Mr. Brown announced on his first important mission -- to China in August 1994.
 
BILL DALEY'S TRIP TO SOUTH AMERICA, MAY 1997
 
BUSINESS DEALS -- Only $2.1 million contract for a Florida company and a couple of grants totalling $1 million from the U.S. Trade and Development Agency were announced.
 
TRADE DEAL -- None The purpose of the trip was to lay the groundwork for expanding the North American Free Trade Agreement to include the rest of the Americas.

HEADLINE: Kenya's Hard Line: President Gambles on Crackdown

BYLINE: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr. 

DATELINE: NAIROBI, Kenya, July 8

 BODY:
By violently crushing pro-democracy demonstrations across Kenya on Monday, President Daniel arap Moi has gambled that opposition leaders seeking to rewrite the nation's Constitution do not have enough popular support to weather a brutal police campaign against them.
He is also wagering that Western powers will not abandon him just because his police tear-gassed and clubbed hundreds of protesters who were demonstrating peacefully to dilute the powers of the presidency and increase civil liberties. 
 Mr. Moi's calculation appears based on the notion that the opposition is too disorganized and splintered along ethnic lines to present a viable alternative to his Government, even if its human-rights record is less than perfect.
And on both counts, he is probably right, political experts and diplomats said today.
On Monday, nine people were killed in clashes at rallies across the nation in the worst political violence since 1991, when a series of similar protests finally persuaded Mr. Moi to end the one-party state and allow multi-party elections.
The police hardly needed to scatter the protesters with such force. After weeks of dire official warnings to citizens not to attend the rallies, the organizers did not draw the huge crowds they had hoped for. Most of the rallies planned in 56 towns across the nation attracted less than a thousand demonstrators.
Abroad, the response to the mayhem was muted. Several Western diplomats issued statements today deploring the violence on both sides and urging the Government to talk to the opposition about its demands.
In Washington, Nicholas Burns, the State Department spokesman, said that the violence was inspired by Kenya's "failure to take the essential concrete steps to create a free and fair electoral climate."
But no country made mention of more palpable pressure, like cutting off Kenya's lifeline of low-interest loans from the International Monetary Fund. One reason is a fear of taking sides in the elections, which Mr. Moi must call before the end of the year. Mr. Moi says he is willing to appoint a commission to consider amending the Constitution, but not until after the voting.
The streets of Nairobi and other towns returned to normal during the day, but as darkness fell tonight, students clashed with the police near the Nairobi University campus and gunfire was heard.
For most of the day, however, businesses reopened and the roads were full of traffic, despite the heavy presence of paramilitary police officers. Many workers returning to their jobs today said that while they supported the protesters in principle, they were weary of the looting and violence attending the demonstrations.
"It does worry us," Joseph Kwasi, 43, a shop clerk. "We have children at home, and we have to worry about them. The protesters are fighting for their rights, and this is what most Kenyans need, but the problem is, once the violence starts there is no boundary. Anybody can be hurt."
In news conferences today, opposition politicians and human rights advocates vowed to step up their campaign of civil disobedience on Wednesday after a period of mourning for the people who were killed. Police officials, however, said that it was unlikely that demonstrators would turn out in large numbers.
One problem for the opposition is that the violence has alarmed many middle-class Kenyans who might otherwise support them. Each time the police have broken up protests in the last two months, the demonstrators -- their ranks swelled by college students angry about high tuition costs -- have turned quickly to looting shops and stoning cars.
"A lot of people in the middle class are getting, I think, disillusioned with the fact that none of this violence is achieving any of its objectives," Anthony Nzuya, a Nairobi businessman, said. "The way to get these reforms on the table is not through street violence."
Mr. Moi has skillfully exploited these fears, repeatedly portraying the opposition leaders as bent on sowing anarchy and violence. Thus he has neatly sidestepped the fact the police have been brutal.
In addition, there are some cracks within the coalition of churches, human-rights groups and opposition party leaders who are pushing for reforms. While the clergy and human-rights advocates are trying to roll back repressive laws limiting civil liberties, the opposition politicians have another motive. They want to change electoral rules in the Constitution that make it hard for them to win. For instance, one proposed amendment would require a presidential candidate to get a simple majority, or face a run-off election. At present a President can be elected with less than half the vote, as long as he gets a quarter of the vote in five of the country's eight provinces. The provision, added in 1992, served to weaken the two largest ethnic groups, the Kikuyu and the Luo, whose members are crammed into two districts.
Mr. Moi, who comes from a small ethnic group, was able to get only about 38 percent of the popular vote in 1996. He won only because most of the Luo and Kikuyu were split along ethnic lines among three candidates.
Mr. Moi has other enormous advantages the coalition wants to end. He controls the official radio and television broadcasts. The electoral commission, which registers voters, is stacked with his appointees. Security laws left from the British colonial era give him sweeping powers to detain political enemies and break up public meetings and protests.
But these issues do not resonate with the vast majority of Kenyans, who are struggling with a sluggish economy, low wages, high education costs and widespread poverty.
Despite today's calm, the atmosphere remains explosive. If the opposition continues to call marches, and Mr. Moi sticks to his hard line, some diplomats fear a conflagration.
"There are three million people in Nairobi, most of them poor," said one diplomat in Nairobi, who spoke on condition of anonymity. "How many sparks do you need until something gets out of hand?"

HEADLINE: Low Bids on Atlantic City Road Please State

BYLINE: By ABBY GOODNOUGH 

DATELINE: NEWARK, July 8

 BODY:
The developers of a road and tunnel project meant to open the way for new casinos in Atlantic City's marina district received bids on the construction costs today, and New Jersey officials said the bids were in line with their own estimate.
John J. Haley, the State Transportation Commissioner, said the bids proved that the total project could be completed for $330 million, despite warnings from critics that costs could run as high as $500 million. Mr. Haley said the bids were low enough to insure that the state could move ahead promptly with the tunnel project. 
 The state is sharing the total costs with Mirage Resorts, which plans to build three casinos and 7,000 hotel rooms in Atlantic City's marina district over the next two years. The tunnel would provide direct access to that neighborhood from the Atlantic City Expressway, which runs between Atlantic City and Philadelphia.
Donald J. Trump, who owns several casinos in Atlantic City and has repeatedly criticized the state for helping to finance the tunnel, had warned that the cost of the project would run much higher than $330 million.
Mr. Trump has said it was unfair for the state to pay for a tunnel that would serve only visitors to the Mirage casinos, which will be several blocks from the boardwalk, where the city's other casinos are situated. But Mr. Haley said the bid amounts proved that Mr. Trump was wrong. They ranged in price from $190.6 million to $329.7 million and Mr. Haley said the lowest bid matched the state's own calculations.
"This is a giant step in terms of advancing the project," Mr. Haley said in a telephone interview. "The numbers we received today say it can be built within our project budget, and that's really good news."
The Mirage resort is part of a plan to revitalize Atlantic City's economy and transform the city into a major vacation destination. It is expected to create 30,000 jobs and hundreds of millions of dollars in casino revenues -- prospects that made the state eager to accept some of the financial burden.
After months of negotiations between Gov. Christine Todd Whitman and Stephen A. Wynn, the chairman and chief executive of Mirage, the two sides decided that the state would pick up about two-thirds of the $330 million bill. Both sides agreed they would not pay more than $330 million, and that any extra costs incurred during the construction would be picked up by the contractor.
The low bid of $190.6 million was submitted by the Yonkers Contracting Company of Yonkers, N.Y. The highest bid, $329.7 million, was submitted by the Schiavone Construction Company of Secaucus, N.J. A third company, the Perini Corporation of Framingham, Mass., set a price of $229.8 million.
Mr. Haley said Mirage and the State Department of Transportation officials would examine the offers and pick a contractor within 30 days.
In an interview yesterday, Mr. Trump, who has fought the tunnel plan in court, stressed that the bids covered only construction costs. He predicted that additional expenses -- like the purchase of land near the construction site -- would push the total cost closer to $500 million, an amount he said the state could not afford to pay.
But Mr. Haley insisted that Mr. Trump was wrong.
"I just don't know where he gets his numbers from," Mr. Haley said. "The construction numbers are what we hoped they would be, and I'm more confident than ever that we can deliver this project for the budgeted amount."

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
International Paper to Cut Staff by 10%

BYLINE: By DANA CANEDY 

 BODY:
The International Paper Company said yesterday that it would sell $1 billion in assets and cut 9,000 jobs, or more than 10 percent of its work force, as it seeks to improve profitability in an increasingly competitive industry.
The company, which is the world's largest manufacturer of paper and paper products, said that the bulk of its job cuts would come as workers were transferred when International Paper sold some units. 
 It said that more than half of the jobs to be eliminated would come from units already up for sale, and that more cuts would come from the sale of units yet to be identified. A smaller number of jobs are to be lost when production plants are closed. The company added that the cuts would not involve employees at its headquarters in Purchase, N.Y.
The revamping was cheered by investors, who sent the company's shares surging 9.6 percent. The stock, the biggest gainer after Procter & Gamble among stocks that make up the Dow Jones industrial average, rose $4.9375 a share, to $56.125.
To pay for the reorganization, International Paper said it took $535 million in charges before taxes, or $385 million after taxes, against second-quarter earnings. It also took a $150 million pretax charge, or $93 million after taxes, to add to its legal reserve. As a result, the company yesterday posted a loss of $419 million, or $1.39 a share, in the quarter, compared with a profit of $99 million, or 33 cents a share, in the quarter a year ago. Without the charges, the company earned $59 million, or 20 cents a share, exceeding analyst estimates of 15 cents a share.
International Paper's revamping reflects the growing need for paper producers to cut costs to offset price pressures that have been caused in recent years by an industrywide rise in capacity.
"What is happening at International Paper is true of everybody in the paper business," said Sheldon Grodsky, an analyst with Grodsky Associates, a brokerage firm. "The problem in the paper industry is that after about five years of recession, they came out of it for a couple of quarters and prices actually doubled in some grades in a matter of less than a year and immediately went down thereafter. So the industry has been exceedingly cyclical."
In response, International Paper said it would rid itself of any operations that did not contribute to meeting its financial goals. The company, which employs 87,000 people, has 27 mills in the United States and operations in 31 countries.
"We will be divesting or closing operations that no longer meet the company's financial or strategic objectives and utilizing plants and machinery to serve customers more efficiently," John T. Dillon, the company's chairman and chief executive, said in a statement.
"All of International Paper businesses are expected to meet specific performance objectives, including progress towards achieving an average 12 percent return on investment over a business cycle, having market leadership within their industry and developing technological superiority," Mr. Dillon added. "This improvement plan underscores the sense of urgency required for us to meet these commitments to share owners and customers."
To that end, the company plans to reduce its pulp and uncoated paper capacity by at least 400,000 tons. It expects to shut three production lines at a mill in Erie, Pa., close a mill in Woronoco, Mass., and a pulp operation in Lock Haven, Pa. About 460 workers will lose jobs as a result of those closings.
More than half the staff reduction -- involving about 6,000 employees -- will come from the sale of the company's imaging business facilities in the United States and abroad; its packaging business that makes industrial paper bags, and 175,000 acres of timberland in western Pennsylvania and western New York.
The company said that the moves announced yesterday would contribute to earnings this year and would have a greater impact next year, when most of the actions would be completed.
"There is a lot of room to sell off noncore assets," said Josh Kapp, an analyst with Smith Barney. "Whether it will result in a radically different company tomorrow, I'm not sure that will be the case. It's a step in the right direction. Obviously the market thinks so."

HEADLINE: U.S. Laments Takeover in Cambodia

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 9

 BODY:
After hesitating a day, the United States today condemned Cambodia's Second Prime Minister, Hun Sen, for using force to oust a rival from Government, but stopped short of cutting off $42 million in aid to the country.
Instead, the United States is working with Asian allies to coordinate pressure on Mr. Hun Sen to remove his troops from the streets and peacefully resolve the crisis with his opponents. 
 As the major power behind the 1991 Paris peace accords, which ended decades of war in Cambodia, the United States is in a critical position to help develop a consensus that could prevent further bloodshed.
But no one country holds a lever powerful enough to budge Mr. Hun Sen, officials say, and a joint response, which may yet include cutting off aid, would be more effective.
"Our position is that the overthrow of a duly constituted democratic government by military means is unacceptable, and we made that point strongly to the Cambodian Ambassador here and at the United Nations," a senior American official said. "We want to send a message to Hun Sen that we don't accept the legitimacy of what he's done and don't want to see another dictatorship emerge in Cambodia under the fig leaf of a coalition."
Today Mr. Hun Sen's forces began arresting political opponents, one of whom was killed.
The First Prime Minister, Prince Norodom Ranariddh, left Cambodia for France last Friday, before two days' fighting in which Mr. Hun Sen claimed full power. The two men had been sharing power uneasily since a 1993 election run by the United Nations.
After saying little about Cambodia's situation on Monday, the State Department spokesman, Nicholas Burns, today expressed "strong opposition to the use of force to change the results of the 1993 election and the use of force by the forces of Hun Sen to effectively rupture the Paris accords of 1991."
But Mr. Burns refused to call the events in Cambodia a "coup," apparently because American law requires the immediate suspension of aid if an elected Government is overthrown.
While defending the right of Prince Ranariddh's party to operate freely in Cambodia, other American officials said it would be unrealistic to require his return to office, given the antipathy between the two men.
One official also said Prince Ranariddh had been "playing with fire" in the days before he left Cambodia by trying to secure the political and military support of the Khmer Rouge, his old allies, against Mr. Hun Sen. Some Khmer Rouge factions have been trying to negotiate their return into the country's political life.
For now, American officials said, they are not yet ready to suspend aid to Cambodia -- as the Japanese have effectively done. Instead Washington is working on a coordinated response with the members of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, the United Nations Security Council and co-signers of the 1991 Paris accords -- Japan, India, Canada and Laos. On Thursday Asean members are to consider delaying Cambodia's entry into the group, which was supposed to happen later this month.
Prince Ranariddh is to arrive at the United Nations on Wednesday. Secretary General Kofi Annan said today that the events in Cambodia were regrettable and the United Nations would discuss what to do. State Department officials are to meet Prince Ranariddh here as well.
The United States, after consulting with other countries on Monday, today produced a set of principles on Cambodia: the use of force to overturn the 1993 elections is unacceptable; all Cambodian political parties must be allowed to operate freely, Khmer Rouge leaders should play no political role, free and fair elections should take place as scheduled in 1998 and the principles of the 1991 Paris accords must be upheld.
Human rights organizations, pointing to the organized and extensive round-up of opponents by Mr. Hun Sen's forces, said the American position should be stronger.
"There's the beginnings of a purge, with democrats fleeing for protection to foreign embassies," said Mike Jendrzejczyk, Washington director of Human Rights Watch Asia.
He also called for the immediate suspension of American aid. "It's the only effective lever they have over Hun Sen," he said.
But American officials said that is precisely why they want to use it to press Mr. Hun Sen to pull back. For more than a week, including meetings before the fighting broke out, the American Ambassador, Kenneth M. Quinn, had pressed senior Cambodian officials to refrain from using force and breaking commitments undertaken in 1991, the officials said.

HEADLINE: On NATO Coup, Russia's Shadow

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

DATELINE: MADRID, June 7

 BODY:
American officials were busy measuring themselves for cloaks of historical glory in Madrid this afternoon.
"We bridged a chasm in Europe," President Clinton said after NATO leaders had agreed to admit three Eastern European countries as members by 1999. Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright spoke of an "irreversible process" of alliance-building. The name of George C. Marshall and his economic recovery plan were much invoked, and there was a lot of talk about healing the wound left behind by Yalta. 
 It remained for Secretary of Defense William S. Cohen, a Republican, to utter the merest, tiniest hint that the self-congratulation might prove to have been premature, with the comment that "it's a long road to 1999."
Just where that road will lead, he might have added, is unclear. American diplomacy succeeded, where many thought it would fail, in achieving a common front in support of NATO expansion, in limiting it in the first instance to three countries and in persuading the Russians to go along, however grumpily. In that sense, today was a great day for President Clinton and the alliance, as he said.
But both at home and in Eastern and Western Europe, knotty problems remain that could undermine the stability the President seeks to establish.
In the largest, most profoundly strategic sense, it is not possible to know whether the reshaping of the alliance will make Russia more or less manageable in the decades ahead. Deputy Secretary of State Strobe Talbott, the leading Russian expert in the Administration, strongly supports the expansion policy, but he readily concedes that like NATO itself in its earliest days it represents a gamble.
After World War II, the West's bet -- "the bluff," as a senior American official called it recently -- was that the promise to use nuclear weapons to resist Soviet expansion would obviate the need actually to use them. Today's bet is that the promise of sending British or German or American troops to defend Warsaw or Prague against an unnamed enemy will not only make that unnecessary but will also help to entrench democracy and a free market system in Eastern Europe.
Ms. Albright made precisely that point this evening, arguing that "the most successful alliances are those that do not have to use force."
For their part, the Russians made the obligatory negative noises. However, it is not Russian rhetoric that worries some foreign-policy specialists but the possibility that a strident Russian nationalism, born of pride wounded and nerves frayed as NATO moves closer to Russia's borders, may arise in the next century.
"Enlargement may undermine the very security and stability they are seeking," Prof. Alvin Z. Rubinstein of the University of Pennsylvania wrote in the journal Problems of Post-Communism last month. "NATO expansion could result in a re-polarized Europe; Moscow may question its commitment to nuclear downsizing and cooperation, and Russia might turn away from accommodation with the West."
Nor is it clear that the consensus reached today can be re-created when it comes time to pay for the costs of expanding the alliance. Neither Hungary nor the Czech Republic, for example, is in any position to increase military spending enough to pay for the needed modernization of the two countries' largely obsolete forces. And it is not clear that Western European countries have the political will to increase their spending on NATO at a moment when their economies are not robust.
"It is more likely that British outlays on defense will decline in the years ahead than that they will increase," a minister in Prime Minister Tony Blair's Government said last week. Germany and France, struggling to meet the stringent criteria for European Union monetary union, are no more eager to discuss bigger military budgets. If this persists, it will increase pressure on the United States to spend much more than the $200 million a year now contemplated to reshape existing Western forces and retrain and re-equip Eastern European armies.
That is what happened with the peacekeeping force in Bosnia.
To achieve consensus on admitting only Hungary, the Czech Republic and Poland, the United States agreed to make a strong commitment in the communique not only to give early consideration to admitting Slovenia and Romania, which Italy and France had wanted to admit in the first round. At a news briefing tonight, Ms. Albright went so far as to pledge that "no European democracy will be excluded because of its position on the map."
That presumably includes not only Slovenia and Romania, but also the Baltic countries, all mentioned by NATO Secretary General Javier Solana, and Ukraine. Regardless of the communique, no support for such a sweeping expansion exists at the moment, and the German Chancellor, Helmut Kohl, gave the impression during a visit to Washington last month that he had no appetite for future NATO membership for either the Baltics or Ukraine. President Jacques Chirac of France has made the same point, and the Russians could be expected to issue more than routine protests over any effort to incorporate into NATO countries with large Russian minorities and with long borders with Russia.
Underlying all of this is considerable European irritation at the United States and a considerable American lack of faith in European capacities.
Lionel Jospin, France's new Socialist Prime Minister, has spoken bitterly in recent days about an American "tendency toward hegemony." Others have not been so blunt, but German and British officials returned from the economic summit meeting in Denver last month expressing distaste for what several of them termed American "triumphalism." The word has quickly become a synonym in editorial-page commentary in Europe for America's lone superpower status.
France remains semi-detached from NATO and insistent that it be given a major command role as a price for integrating its armed forces with the alliance. But no American President in the forseeable future could place American troops under French command (or the command of any European, with the possible exception of the British, with whom the tradition of close American cooperation is a long one). Neither the Pentagon, Congress or the voting public would accept any such thing.
"Without America, NATO doesn't exist," Prime Minister Romano Prodi of Italy said this week, but he pointedly added, "Europe cannot be denied its views on problems within its own region."
The problem with these complaints, from the American Government's point of view, is that Europe has had trouble getting its act together.
Europe's conspicuous failure to sort out the situation in Bosnia is cited as an example of this problem, and Bosnia may confound the Administration's attempt to persuade the Senate and the American people of the worth of NATO expansion.
Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., a Delaware Democrat who is here as part of a Congressional delegation, said that two problems might bedevil the ratification effort: the question of equitable sharing of the financial burden of expansion, and the future of Bosnia. He added, "Unfortunately at the very moment we will be voting on expansion, we will be debating what next in Bosnia." If the Europeans are not steadfast in Bosnia, he said, "it will be hard to get the votes."
Mr. Clinton said: "We have a ways to go to convince the American people of the momentous importance of decisions we're making here and the need for them to support it. And that is a job that I intend to take on when I get home."
