LENGTH: 1599 words

HEADLINE: 3 FORMER MEMBERS OF EASTERN BLOC INVITED INTO NATO

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY 

DATELINE: MADRID, July 8

 BODY:
Eight years after winning the cold war without firing a shot, NATO extended invitations today to three former adversaries -- Poland, the Czech Republic and Hungary -- to join the alliance in time for its 50th anniversary in 1999.
"This is a very great day, not only for Europe and the United States, not simply for NATO, but, indeed, for the cause of freedom in the aftermath of the cold war," President Clinton said after the decision was reached this afternoon. 
 Leaders of the three countries expressed gratitude and optimism that NATO membership would help preserve freedom for all of them, though they also want to join the European Union to help develop their market economies and they are unlikely to be admitted to the union in the next five years.
Even NATO, which has been preparing for enlargement since 1994, made its decision only after a vigorous debate today, led by France, about whether the alliance would be better served if Romania and Slovenia were included in the current round of expansion.
Expansion was seen by those who decided it as a historic step across the East-West divide that opened at the end of World War II, offering a framework of security and stability for Central European countries that chose the path of democracy and open markets after Communism collapsed in 1989.
Critics warned that enlargement cast a shadow over the future of relations with Russia, whose President, Boris N. Yeltsin, signed a "Founding Act" on relations with NATO in Paris in May.
"Despite the fact that we have signed a broad, balanced agreement with NATO, we still consider expansion the biggest mistake in Europe since the end of World War II," the Russian Foreign Minister, Yevgeny M. Primakov, said in Moscow after the allies reached agreement this afternoon. American diplomacy succeeded, where many thought it would fail, in achieving a common front. [News analysis, page A8.]
Enlargement will have to be approved by the United States Senate and the Parliaments of the other NATO members. No major problems are expected in Europe.
Senator William V. Roth Jr., the Delaware Republican who was here as chairman of the Senate's NATO observer group, hailed today's decision as "a historic step toward a peaceful, democratic and undivided Europe."
He added that limiting the enlargement to three countries at first would make it easier to control the cost, prospectively a major concern in the debate in the United States over approval of the decision. Congressional leaders at the meeting here predicted approval.
The Senate majority leader, Trent Lott of Mississippi, said in Washington tonight that if a vote was taken now, he thought it would get the necessary two-thirds majority. He added that he also felt that the measure would be approved next spring, although if the situation in Bosnia deteriorated, that might have an adverse effect on the outcome.
Allied leaders expressed confidence that the cost would be manageable but commissioned a detailed study. Clinton Administration estimates have put the cost at $35 billion over 13 years, with the United States share at about $2 billion. But the Congressional Budget Office predicts that total costs may be in the region of $125 billion, with Washington's share up to $19 billion.
Most of the day, the leaders debated about why two more applicants could not be admitted today, joining the Poles, the Hungarians and the Czechs.
Nine countries, including Canada and most of the big Continental European allies, including Germany, leaned toward including Romania and Slovenia as well but gave in to equally vigorous arguments by the United States and Britain for limiting the initial expansion to three.
President Jacques Chirac of France vigorously pleaded the case for including Romania and Slovenia to President Clinton, Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain and other leaders this morning.
This afternoon, Mr. Chirac held up agreement on a statement about future expansion until he was satisfied that the two countries would be at the top of the list when NATO leaders met again in Washington in the spring of 1999.
"Let us not risk destroying the cohesion or weakening the credibility of the alliance by excluding today these two countries that meet criteria that we ourselves set," Mr. Chirac pleaded.
But Mr. Clinton and Mr. Blair, supported by the Netherlands, Norway and Denmark, held out, and in the end the only consensus was for three new members -- the first since Spain, the host of this week's meeting, joined in 1982.
"NATO is a military alliance, not a political club," Mr. Blair argued, saying that the admission of three new countries more or less simultaneously was "a bold step, not a conservative one."
In the end, prodded by Mr. Chirac, all 16 leaders agreed to a statement that in Mr. Chirac's eyes put Romania and Slovenia on the fast track for inclusion after 1999.
"With regard to the aspiring members, we recognize with great interest and take account of the positive development toward democracy and the rule of law in a number of southeastern European countries, especially Romania and Slovenia," the leaders said. "The alliance recognizes the need to build greater stability, security and regional cooperation in the countries of southeast Europe, and in promoting their increasing integration into the Euro-Atlantic community."
Then, apparently in a gesture toward American insistence on not appearing to condemn the Baltic countries of Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania to remain forever outside the walls of the alliance, the leaders added: "At the same time, we recognize the progress achieved toward greater stability and cooperation by the states in the Baltic region who are also aspiring members."
In all, 12 countries have been seeking to join. The leaders of the three who will be the first to make it were already here today: President Vaclav Havel of the Czech Republic, a jailed dissident during most of the time that his country was a member of the Warsaw Pact; Prime Minister Gyula Horn of Hungary, a leader of his nation during Communism's final years, and President Aleksander Kwasniewski of Poland.
On Wednesday they and the nine leaders of those who are still waiting -- Albania, Bulgaria, Macedonia and Slovakia, as well as Romania, Slovenia and the Baltic countries -- will meet NATO leaders at their summit talks in a rectangular glass-walled conference hall at the northeastern fringe of Madrid.
Later this week, Mr. Clinton will go to Poland and Romania, while Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright will go to the Czech Republic. Secretary of Defense William S. Cohen will visit Hungary and Ukraine, with which the summit leaders plan to sign a cooperation agreement on Wednesday like the one concluded with Russia. Ms. Albright also plans to see Mr. Primakov in St. Petersburg and talk to leaders of the Baltic countries on the way to Prague.
Mr. Yeltsin, invited to today's meeting, decided to stay away and sent a Deputy Prime Minister, V. M. Serov, instead.
But NATO officials said Russia had asked the allies for a first meeting late next week of the permanent joint council set up under the NATO-Russia Founding Act and a foreign ministers' meeting in New York during the United Nations General Assembly meeting in September.
The new NATO, like the old, will have to contend with periodic disagreements between Europe and the United States, usually focused on the French, which told the allies today that reorganization of the alliance's military command structure to give more responsibility to Europeans had not gone far enough to suit them.
"Since the reasons behind the creation of the alliance have largely disappeared," Mr. Chirac warned, "our alliance would not durably survive with an unbalanced Euro-American relationship, both in the sharing of power in the military structure and in the political decision-making process."
Indeed, he cited American unwillingness to cede more positions of military command to European officers as the main reason why France was not yet ready to rejoin NATO's integrated military command. The United States has refused a request by Mr. Chirac to cede control of NATO's southern command in Naples to a European officer, who would direct the United States Sixth Fleet in combat operations, as part of the reorganized NATO military structure that leaders approved today.
But Mr. Chirac said that on the whole he was satisfied by today's meeting, which he called "another step in the right direction of constructing a European architecture of defense."
The NATO leaders hailed Spain's decision to do what France would not and join the NATO military structure, even though the key issue of which NATO command would control Spanish territorial waters around the Canary Islands is one of several technical military issues that the allies did not resolve. They hope to do so by the end of the year.
They did not change the ground rules that have kept the 31,000 NATO-led peacekeeping troops in Bosnia from moving more aggressively to apprehend the former Bosnian Serb leader, Radovan Karadzic, and other leaders indicted on war crimes charges by the international tribunal in The Hague.
Instead, they called once again on the local leaders to comply with their obligations under the Dayton peace agreement of 1995, including the requirement to turn over war crimes suspects like Dr. Karadzic and his military commander, Gen. Ratko Mladic.
"The point here is, on Karadzic and Mladic, that there is no statute of limitation on their crimes, and their day will come," Ms. Albright said.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Dow Sets Another Record, Rising by More Than 100
The Dow Jones industrial average hit its 32d record close of the year and its first above 7,900. It surged 103.82 points, or 1.32 percent, to 7,962.31, as investors remained optimistic about corporate profits and a stable economy. Broader market indexes also set records, with the Standard & Poor's 500 rising 6.55 points, to 918.75, and the Nasdaq composite index increasing 14.36 points, to 1,485.10.
 The Dow was bolstered by heavy demand for cyclical issues, like International Paper -- which announced that it planned to cut its work force and sell assets -- as well as Caterpillar and Du Pont. [Page D6.] 

Prices of Treasury securities fell slightly in quiet trading, with the yield on the 30-year bond rising to 6.58 percent from 6.57. [D16.]
 
Motorola Earnings Beat Estimates
Motorola continued its revival, announcing financial results for the second quarter that modestly exceeded analysts' expectations. The company's shares rose strongly in anticipation of the results, which were reported after the close of trading. But another high-technology company trying to regain its financial footing, Advanced Micro Devices, had disappointing earnings. [D4.]
 
Tobacco Deal Is Criticized
Clinton Administration officials reviewing the proposed settlement of tobacco litigation said that it would impose unacceptable limits on the Federal regulation of tobacco products. In the Administration's first extensive public comments on the proposal, officials said that the accord would dilute the F.D.A.'s authority to regulate nicotine and place impossible new burdens on the agency. [A1.]
 
Consumer Debt Up, but More Slowly
Tougher lending standards at banks and cutbacks by consumers pushed borrowing by Americans higher in May, but at a slower-than-expected pace. Consumer credit increased by $3 billion, to $1.224 trillion, after rising by a revised $9.7 billion in April, the Federal Reserve said. [D2.]
 
Coffee Prices Increase
A report by the Agriculture Department, which said a poor coffee crop in Colombia would keep world supplies tight, sent futures prices rising. Gold rebounded slightly after hitting an 11 1/2-year low on Monday. [D5.]
 
Dollar Soars Against the Mark
The dollar rose to a three-and-a-half-year high against the German mark. And the British pound hit a six-year high against the mark on expectations that the Bank of England would raise interest rates this week. [D5.]
 
Japan's Trade Surplus Up Sharply
Japan's current account surplus more than doubled in May, driven by demand for exports and a drop in consumer spending at home. The surplus rose 154.9 percent, to 906.8 billion yen, or $8.02 billion, though the gain was still smaller than expected. [D13.]
 
Ovitz's Latest Big-Budget Venture
Michael Ovitz, the former Hollywood superagent and ousted president of Walt Disney, can call himself a mogul again. So what if the latest movie he was involved in was only a six-minute documentary commissioned to help raise half a billion dollars for a new medical center at his alma mater, U.C.L.A.? [A12.]
 
The Health Cost of Business Travel
Foreign business travel may be hazardous to one's health, a study of World Bank employees strongly suggests. The study found that such travelers filed health insurance claims at a greater rate than stay-at-homes.
Edwin McDowell: Business Travel. [D2.]
 
Hurdles for Spike Lee Ad Venture
Six months after the director Spike Lee joined forces with DDB Needham Worldwide to open a joint-venture agency, their fledgling shop has already accumulated a robust roster of accounts with billings that they estimate at $35 million. But Mr. Lee says that he and his giant partner still confront challenges as they seek business from mainstream marketers.
Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D2.]

HEADLINE: MONEY AND POLITICS: THE WITNESS;
For Senators, The Answers Carry a Price

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 8

 BODY:
John Huang's surprise offer today to testify under a limited grant of immunity about his campaign finance activities presents the Senate Governmental Affairs committee with a dilemma: Should it accept an offer from the central figure in the Democratic fund-raising scandal at the risk of making any future prosecution against him virtually impossible?
And the members of the committee are also asking: Will Mr. Huang's testimony be so compelling that this is an offer worth taking? 
 For several months, Mr. Huang has refused to testify without full immunity, which, if granted, would protect him from criminal prosecution. But, Senator John Glenn, the committee's ranking Democrat, said today that Mr. Huang had agreed on Monday night to testify in return for immunity on several less serious matters. He would, however, waive protection against prosecution on such major issues as whether he violated laws against engaging in economic espionage, acting as an agent of a foreign government and improperly transferring classified information to a foreign government.
In making this offer, Mr. Huang's lawyer is moving into a murky legal area. In criminal cases, partial immunity is frequently granted.
But in this case, if Congress grants immunity for some potential legal violations, prosecutors might find it exceedingly difficult to demonstrate that any charges they bring are based on information independent of his Congressional testimony.
Testimony given under grant of Congressional immunity in the Iran-contra hearings later led to the overturning of the convictions of key witnesses -- Oliver L. North and John M. Poindexter -- and set high standards for future prosecutions based on Congressional investigations.
Republican lawyers on the committee and some outside legal experts argued today that selective immunity for Congressional witnesses did not exist. The offer has also raised concerns within the Department of Justice, which has been investigating whether Mr. Huang directed money from illegal foreign sources to the Democratic Party and, if so, whether he was part of a larger effort by the Chinese Government to influence American foreign and economic policy.
Justice Department officials would not discuss the case publicly today, but privately said they were concerned that any grant of immunity for Mr. Huang would hamper their ability to charge him with crimes.
A Justice Department spokesman, Bert Brandenburg, would only say that "so far, the Senate committee has shown an appreciation of the effects of immunity on future prosecutions."
Joseph E. diGenova, a former United States attorney and now a private lawyer, called Mr. Huang's offer "nonsense."
"There is a law of immunity and you can't start fooling around with what he says is immunized and what isn't," he said. "This is a clever and interesting ploy by Mr. Huang's lawyer," he said. "Once an order of immunity is given and Mr. Huang starts talking, nothing he says can be used by a prosecutor."
Alan Baron, the lawyer for the committee Democrats who negotiated the offer with Mr. Huang's lawyer, disagreed. "I feel comfortable the lawyers can craft something. We've got willing people on all sides," he said. Ty Cobb, Mr. Huang's lawyer, concurred.
Democratic members of the committee have balked repeatedly at Republican requests to grant immunity to several minor figures so they would testify against bigger players. To date, full immunity has been given to four witnesses, with Justice Department agreement, and negotiations continue for many others.
The decision to grant immunity to a witness requires a two-thirds vote of the committee.
A spokesman for Democrats on the Governmental Affairs Committee said Mr. Huang's offer to testify without immunity on the major issues showed that he had nothing to hide. "The implication of Mr. Huang's offer is that he is innocent," said Leonard Weiss, Democratic staff director for the committee.
The question facing the Republican majority, one Republican committee staff member said, is simple: How desperate are they for Mr. Huang's testimony?
"The allegations against Mr. Huang are serious," said the staff member, who insisted on anonymity. "Is Huang's testimony worth blindly accepting a deal and taking a prosecutorial pass on everything he's done? If you get six other witnesses to tell you 95 percent of the story, then you might not need the top guy."
Senator Fred Thompson, the committee chairman, said Mr. Huang first should give lawyers an indication of what he would say in return for any immunity grant. At the end of the four-hour hearing yesterday, Senator Thompson directed lawyers to meet with Mr. Huang.
Senator Glenn, too, said he would not commit himself to granting immunity without previewing Mr. Huang's testimony and soliciting the view of the Department of Justice.

LENGTH: 557 words

HEADLINE: Clinton Is 'Open' to Making the Well-Off Pay More for Medicare

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 8

 BODY:
In a subtle but significant shift, the White House said tonight that President Clinton was open to the idea of requiring affluent elderly people to pay higher Medicare premiums, starting next year.
In the past, Mr. Clinton has said he does not oppose an increase in premiums for high-income elderly people. But until now, he has urged Congress to defer discussion of the idea until this year's budget bill is passed. 
 The version of the budget bill approved by the Senate on June 25 would establish a "means test," imposing higher Medicare premiums on individuals with annual incomes over $50,000 and couples with incomes over $75,000. The House version includes no such provision, but House Republicans have said they might support it if Mr. Clinton sent a clear signal that he would go along.
Gene Sperling, assistant to the President for economic policy, said tonight, "The President is open to a high-income premium increase, but has not made a final decision."
Mr. Sperling said the President wanted to be sure that any move to increase Medicare premiums would not endanger bipartisan support for the budget-balancing bill.
Chris Jennings, a White House aide who coordinates health policy, said the Administration had questions about how the higher premiums would be collected. The regular premium, now $43.80 a month, is deducted from monthly Social Security checks. But Mr. Jennings said that procedure would probably not work for the proposed new premiums. He suggested that the "income-related premiums" should be collected by the Internal Revenue Service through annual income tax returns.
In addition, Mr. Jennings said, Congress would have to provide additional money to the Internal Revenue Service so it could assess and collect Medicare premiums.
Finally, Mr. Jennings said, the increase in premiums must not be so steep that it spurs affluent beneficiaries to drop out of the part of the Medicare program that covers doctors' services. Such defections would leave poorer, less healthy people in the program and could cause a sharp increase in their premiums, he said.
Under the Senate bill, the monthly Medicare premium of $43.80 would quadruple for individuals with annual incomes over $100,000 and for couples with incomes over $125,000.
The Congressional Budget Office estimated that the higher premiums in the Senate bill would generate $3.9 billion in revenue in the next five years and $19.6 billion in revenue from 1998 through 2007. These figures would be much higher if the premiums were collected by the Internal Revenue Service rather than the Department of Health and Human Services, the budget office said.
Administration officials said that only the Internal Revenue Service had the experience and expertise needed to collect higher premiums.
Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the Democratic leader, said that Mr. Clinton "would be willing to look at various ways of addressing progressivity in premiums," meaning higher premiums for higher-income beneficiaries.
But Mr. Daschle said the Administration still "strongly opposes" raising the eligibility age for Medicare. The Senate bill would gradually increase the eligibility age to 67, from 65, over the years 2003 to 2027.
House and the Senate negotiators plan to meet later this week to iron out differences between the two bills.

HEADLINE: New York State's Democrats See Party Adrift and Divided

BYLINE: By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

 BODY:
Everywhere Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan goes these days, he runs into Democrats who will vote for a Republican for mayor of New York this year. "Everywhere," Mr. Moynihan said, emphasizing each syllable.
Edward I. Koch goes a step further. He said he would vote for Rudolph W. Giuliani for mayor this November and George E. Pataki for governor the next. Mr. Koch, a three-term Democratic Mayor known for the occasional Republican dalliance, is not alone. Many Democrats in New York are saying the same things these days, if not so publicly. 
 At first glance, these defections might be dismissed as a bad but passing moment for the state party, a despondent reaction to what is shaping up as another inauspicious election: in this case, the attempt to prevent Mr. Giuliani from winning a second term.
But they are, in the view of an increasing number of Democrats and Republicans alike, the latest symptoms of a larger phenomenon.
The New York Democratic Party, once the pre-eminent national laboratory for Democratic ideas and candidates, is mired in its deepest rut in a generation, many of its own leaders say. It is bereft of money and high profile elected officials. It is out of power and plagued by such division and lack of party discipline that Democrats like Mr. Moynihan, the state's senior Senator, speak almost wistfully of the days when party bosses controlled who would run and what they would say.
At the heart of the problem is that the state's party, which once set the ideological pace for Democrats across the country, is today described by many members as adrift, struggling to reconcile its liberal traditions with an electorate moving to the middle. Suddenly, political leaders outside New York -- from Chicago to Philadelphia to the White House -- are taking the lead in reshaping the Democratic identity, largely by erasing its image as promoter of activist government and advocate for a welter of constituencies.
By contrast, party members and historians say, New York Democrats have resisted such changes. This week, leaders in Albany are fighting Republican efforts to pare welfare programs to conform to a law signed by a Democratic President. And the tug and pull of constituent groups continues to flare, most recently in the fight for the Manhattan borough president's office between a black city councilwoman, C. Virginia Fields, and a lesbian state assemblywoman, Deborah J. Glick.
"The most prominent figures of the party in New York are still wedded to a kind of liberalism that is rapidly falling into disfavor with Democrats in other parts of the country," said Alan Brinkley, a professor of American history at Columbia University. "There is a kind of rigorous, spirited, very powerful defense of the creations of the liberal past in New York that you just don't see in most other parts of the country. And it makes it very difficult for politicians to emerge who want to push the party in a different direction."
One result is that Republicans boast their strongest political lineup in 30 years: a Governor, a Mayor, an Attorney General and one of two United States Senators. And while there is optimism about defeating Alfonse M. D'Amato in the 1998 Senate race, most Democrats are pessimistic about winning back the mayoralty this year or the governorship the next.
That the state's Democratic Party is in trouble became apparent in 1992, when a divisive primary eased Mr. D'Amato's re-election. Mr. Pataki's victory in 1994 underscored the Democratic deterioration, particularly because Mario M. Cuomo left a party long on debt and division and short on talent and direction.
The current mayoral race has further stoked the anxieties of party members. Instead of being embraced as a hopeful sign of a Democratic resurgence, Ruth W. Messinger, the probable Democratic challenger, has become for many Democrats the latest symptom and symbol of the party's difficulties.
"She's a product of the Democratic Party, which is in disarray, and her campaign reflects that," said the Rev. Al Sharpton, one of her opponents in the mayoral primary, and himself a symbol for many Democrats of the party's problems.
Ms. Messinger's campaign provides almost weekly evidence of the breakdown in party discipline, with Democrats like Claire Shulman, the Queens Borough President, considering backing Mr. Giuliani. "It's a mystery to me that we have not been able to coalesce around the candidate and use New York City and this election to begin to rebuild the party," said State Senator Catherine M. Abate of Manhattan.
The squabbling between Ms. Messinger's black and gay supporters over whether she should support a black or a lesbian successor publicly reinforced the image of a party beholden to special interests.
Most of all, though, Ms. Messinger's difficulty in framing a message, something that her aides say she will begin to address with a major speech today, has been cited by many Democrats and academics as the latest sign of the party's most intractable problem: its lack of a clear ideological mission.
Mr. Cuomo, often blamed for the party's ideological torpidity, said: "That's what's wrong with the Democratic Party. It's not money, it's not people, it's ideas. What you need to have in the Democratic Party is a rationale."
What is perhaps most ominous for New York's Democrats is that being out of power makes it that much harder to regain their step. With so few in high office, there is no one to define the party's mission, to help raise money or to provide the government jobs parties need to groom leaders. "We have not produced a generation of serious public people who can get elected to office," Mr. Moynihan said.
 
Don't Count Them Out Just Yet
Politics is cyclical, and it would surely be a mistake to dismiss the Democrats, who outnumber Republicans 5 to 1 in New York City, as moribund. For one, the Democrats' difficulties are at least partly a tribute to Mr. Giuliani's perceived success both as Mayor and at blurring partisan distinctions in the city. Crime is down and segments of the city's economy are thriving, and polling shows that most New Yorkers credit Mr. Giuliani for that. His concentration on such issues has served to erase partisan lines, and a central part of his re-election strategy is to, in effect, make people forget that he is a Republican.
But while Democrats have been thrown off balance by Mr. Giuliani, there are no obvious Republican successors in line to replace him, which means that Republican dominance of New York City may be as term-limited as the Mayor himself. Moreover, a Democrat, rather than Mr. Pataki, might well have succeeded Mr. Cuomo had he recognized his growing unpopularity and not sought re-election.
The State Democratic Party has shown recent signs of vitality by erasing its debt and winning the fight over rent regulations, and creating an issue that it hopes to use against Mr. Pataki next year.
There are also at least a few potentially strong Democratic candidates in the wings, including Representative Charles E. Schumer of Brooklyn, City Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi, Senator Abate, State Comptroller H. Carl McCall and Public Advocate Mark J. Green.
"The mayor's race is driving people's perception of the state of the party, but that's New York-centric," said Judith Hope, chairwoman of the State Democratic Party. "I'm satisfied that we're doing a very credible job and we are positioning the Democratic Party so that good candidates for governor and Senate can win."
Jill Alper, the political director of the Democratic National Committee, pointed to the number of Democrats lining up to challenge Mr. D'Amato as evidence that New York's political fortunes are on the rise. "At some point, the party will have a candidate that gives it a message," Ms. Alper said. "I don't think that we're out of the hunt. I think the way to put it is we're in the hunt. It's a matter of time."
Still, these are just a few bright lights in a dark sky. It is equally revealing that by concentrating so aggressively on next year's races, Ms. Hope's party seems to be conceding this year's mayoral contest. And few Democrats are genuinely confident that the party can win back the governor's seat. That point has been underscored by Mr. McCall's continued public agonizing about whether he will challenge Mr. Pataki, and by Mr. Schumer's decision to run for Senate instead of governor.
Even the Democrats' greatest victory this year, Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver's success in preserving a system of rent regulations, ultimately served to point up the party's resistance to change. Party leaders were defending the status quo, declining to consider new ideas about a system that even many tenants conceded was in need of reform.
"Whether you like rent control or not, here is something that is being consistently repudiated everyplace else in the country," said Professor Brinkley of Columbia. "Even Cambridge, Mass., got rid of rent control."
 
There Were Giants In Those Days
In many ways, the New York Democratic Party is a prisoner of its own history. Any mention of the New York Democratic Party, political scientists note, inevitably conjures up figures like Franklin Delano Roosevelt, Mr. Cuomo, Robert F. Wagner and Robert F. Kennedy, all of whom are closely identified with the great liberal programs of the last 60 years.
Many Democrats argue that the party's history is more textured than that. Mr. Moynihan noted that he had been talking for years about the need for the Democrats to move away from unquestioning adherence to potentially flawed social programs.
Mr. Koch was elected Mayor by running deliberately against traditional liberalism, identifying himself with the death penalty and against what he described as wasteful social programs.
That said, it was Mr. Cuomo's elegant oratory -- rather than Mr. Koch's pragmatic governance or Mr. Moynihan's questioning of Democratic orthodoxy -- that captured national attention and came to define the face of New York Democrats.
Mr. Cuomo's power as a speaker was once a cause of celebration for his fellow Democrats. Today, he is often blamed by party leaders for freezing Democrats in ideological place. It was Mr. Cuomo who led the charge in 1992, when Mr. Clinton successfully argued during the Presidential race that to win, the party had to reclaim the middle class from the Republican Party, and that to do that, it had to move to the center.
Mr. Cuomo lost that battle, but New York Democrats have retained their reputation as among the most liberal in the country. That perception was at the heart of the attacks on Democrats in the 1994 gubernatorial and 1992 Senate race, and is already being used against Ms. Messinger by Mr. Giuliani and even by her Democratic opponents.
Ms. Messinger said the characterization of her as locked in her party's past was unfair, though she was unclear about exactly how she intended to expand the party's appeal as her candidacy unfolds. "What I'm focusing on is what we need to do, which is to re-emphasize the issues that unite us, because that's how Democrats define and create a government that works for everybody and not for some people," Ms. Messinger said.
 
Green Tries On A New Set of Stripes
At a fund-raiser in Manhattan the other night, Mark J. Green, the Public Advocate hoping to run against Mr. D'Amato, offered what was for him an unusual description of his political stripes. "Forget ideology," Mr. Green announced. "Forget stereotypes. I'm a practical advocate who cuts red tape and tries to make government smarter and smaller."
In other cities, leaders like Mayor Richard M. Daley of Chicago have tried to break with Democratic tradition. Mr. Daley, for example, has urged that that private companies take over some city services, and has set performance standards for public teachers and schools. Similarly, Mr. Clinton won election the first time by promising middle-class tax cuts and major reforms in welfare.
But in New York, it is Republicans who lately have framed the political debate, to the obvious frustration of Democrats. "Republicans like Giuliani and Pataki have co-opted our issues," Representative Nita M. Lowey of Westchester said yesterday. "What they have done is blur the differences between the Democratic issues and the Republican issues."
Several academics suggest that because the party was not accustomed to being out of power -- it hasn't been in almost 30 years -- it has been slow to respond to Republican success and provide a detailed alternative to the Republican agenda. Mr. Green's remarks the other night may have been one example of that. Similarly, when Mr. Cuomo was asked what candidates should be talking about, he responded: "Education, education, education."
The Democrat with the most prominent platform right now, Ms. Messinger, has yet to lay out a strong rationale for her candidacy, though her advisers say that is about to change. Several Democrats said that was a window into the difficulties the party faces in trying to reconcile its ideological past with the political reality that is New York today.
Ms. Messinger said she had already begun building a case against Mr. Giuliani and laying out a case for her candidacy.
"Listen to what I'm saying, look at what I'm doing," she said. "Look at what I've done and listen to what I promise to the people of this city: a mayor who makes education the No. 1 priority for the 21st century and knows very specifically how to change what happens in the classroom."
But more than a few Democrats say that Ms. Messinger, like her party, is rolling down a predictable road toward a predictable end. Mr. Koch archly recalled the post-election post-mortems of Democratic elders in recent Novembers.
"I've been to those meetings, where they discuss why did we lose," said the former Mayor.
He paused and laughed. "When Ruth goes down to defeat, there'll be another meeting."

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
Brokers Like Their Work

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Most out-of-work securities executives want to get back into the industry because they are not skilled enough at anything else and the money is good, a survey by Lee Hecht Harrison, a career services firm in Manhattan, has found.
The survey found that 87 percent of dismissed executives are trying to get another job in the industry. That is more than other industries, in which about a third of the people who lose their jobs look elsewhere. 
 "Some people in this industry don't have the transferable skills necessary to change industries," said George Mauze, general manager at Lee Hecht.
The survey also found that many Wall Street executives do not stay out of work for long.
"Brokerage and securities executives find new positions up to 25 percent faster than those in other industries," Mr. Mauze said, adding that more jobs are available now than in the early 90's.

HEADLINE: Jury Is Sworn in the Cosby Case

BYLINE: By BENJAMIN WEISER 

 BODY:
A jury was sworn in yesterday in the trial of Autumn Jackson, the 22-year-old woman charged with trying to extort money from Bill Cosby by claiming to be his out-of-wedlock daughter, and opening statements are scheduled for today.
Throughout the day, Ms. Jackson sat quietly at the defense table with her two co-defendants, as Judge Barbara S. Jones in United States District Court in Manhattan questioned potential jurors. 
 A computer systems analyst said he used to watch "I Spy," the old television show starring Mr. Cosby; he made the jury. So did an unemployed librarian, a former Air Force sergeant and a Nynex employee.
Afterward, Ms. Jackson's defense lawyer, Robert M. Baum, told reporters that "the issue in this case is the intent of Autumn Jackson."
In court, the defense continued to signal that it planned to show that she honestly believed she was Mr. Cosby's daughter and felt she had a legitimate claim to money.
Earlier in the day, Judge Jones ruled that Ms. Jackson's belief that she was legally entitled to money was not in itself a defense.
Moreover, the judge said, there had been no showing yet that Mr. Cosby had promised her any money or that she had earned any of his money. But the judge said the defense was free to try to show that Ms. Jackson's belief that she had such a claim indicated that she did not intend to extort Mr. Cosby.
The defense has said that what the Government calls extortion was a "lawful negotiation" in return for Ms. Jackson's relinquishing her inheritance claims or other rights as a daughter.
Mr. Baum said in court that Ms. Jackson had gotten legal advice before undertaking the activity that led to her arrest.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Touches 3 1/2-Year High Vs. Mark but Finishes Lower

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar touched a three-and-a-half-year high against the mark yesterday but later retreated and finished lower, under pressure from a wider Japanese trade surplus and cross-trading between the mark and other European currencies.
European currency dealings were driven in large part by heightened expectations of a rise in British interest rates. The Bank of England was widely expected to raise its base lending rate to 6.75 percent and possibly 7 percent from 6.50 percent today. 
 But some traders bet on an even bigger increase after The Financial Times of London suggested in an editorial yesterday that "a full percentage point jump might be better."
News early in the day that Japan's trade surplus more than doubled in May also hurt the dollar. But the dollar was confined to narrow movements, largely as the result of trading between European currencies and the relative lack of other news.
"We're sitting here with our hands folded," said Ben Strauss, a senior currency trader at the New York branch of Bank Julius Baer & Company in New York. "The markets are awaiting the British rate news."
Mark weakness against the pound and the Swiss franc indirectly helped the dollar reach an intraday high of 1.7656 marks, the strongest since February 1994, before it retreated to settle at 1.7599 marks in New York, down from 1.7613 marks on Tuesday. The dollar settled at 112.77 yen, down from 112.87 yen Tuesday.
The pound strengthened to a six-year high of 2.9775 marks but settled lower against the dollar at $1.6880, down from $1.6886.
The main event affecting the dollar was the news from Japan that the surplus in Japan's broadest measure of trade, which measures merchandise, services, tourism and investments, totaled 906.8 billion yen ($8.02 billion) in May, up 154.9 percent from May 1996.
It was the second consecutive monthly increase and underscored apprehension in the foreign-exchange market that the United States might seek to push the yen higher against the dollar. A more expensive yen would make Japanese goods and services more expensive abroad and narrow the trade imbalance.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Crude Oil Falls on a Report That Inventories Are Rising

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Crude oil fell after an industry group said United States inventories swelled 1.5 percent last week as imports rose and demand from refiners declined.
On other markets, copper dropped for a fourth day, reaching a four-month low, and corn rose. 
 United States crude oil inventories rose by 4.70 million barrels, to 322.7 million barrels in the week ended July 4, the American Petroleum Institute said after trading yesterday. Most analysts expected crude stocks to fall.
Crude imports have flooded the market in recent weeks, overcoming robust demand for gasoline during the vacation season.
"Prices are retreating because of the supply increases versus demand in crude," said George Gaspar, managing director of petroleum research at Robert W. Baird & Company in Milwaukee.
Crude oil for August delivery fell 27 cents, to $19.46 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange. August gasoline slid 0.69 cent, to 58.23 cents a gallon.
Copper slumped to a four-month low as a seasonal drop in demand allowed stockpiles to increase.
Demand for copper is falling in North America as the summer progresses and factories close or reduce output. Inventories have grown 11 percent since June 20, snapping four months of declines.
"The rise in stocks has not been gargantuan, but it comes after a period of prolonged draw-downs," said Michael Sones, a copper analyst at Banque Paribas in London. "Market sentiment has changed with the seasonal slowdown."
Copper for September delivery fell 2.55 cents, to $1.025 a pound on the Comex division of the New York Mercantile Exchange, the lowest since Feb. 3.
Corn jumped over concern that a heat wave forecast for the Midwest could harm development of the fall crop. Corn for December delivery, the first contract after the harvest, rose 7.5 cents, to $2.3725 a bushel on the Chicago Board of Trade.
Last week, the Department of Agriculture rated 75 percent of the United States corn crop in good-to-excellent condition. That was lower than many traders' expectations for an 80 percent rating, but up from 74 percent a week earlier.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Living Dangerously

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

DATELINE: JAKARTA, Indonesia

 BODY:
Pound for pound, Indonesia has to be the least understood country in the world. With 200 million people, it is the globe's fourth-largest nation and by far the largest Muslim country -- triple the population of Iran. It takes the same time to fly across the 17,000 islands and 300 different ethnic groups that make up Indonesia as it does to fly across the U.S. But ask most Americans about Indonesia and only three things are likely to come to mind: Bali, East Timor and "The Year of Living Dangerously," starring Mel Gibson.
The U.S. looms somewhat larger in Indonesia. The U.S. Congress has been one of the main forces pressing for improved rights for Indonesian workers, as well as for the much-brutalized people of East Timor. Human rights activists here say the U.S. spotlight has been crucial in keeping Indonesia's leaders focused on addressing abuses, even if progress is sporadic and at a snail's pace. 
 But in the wake of recent moves by Congress to block the sale of nine F-16 fighter jets to Indonesia and to freeze the training of Indonesian military officers in America -- because of Indonesia's occupation of East Timor -- Indonesians are beginning to fear that something new is going on: America is going from criticizing them for certain abuses to turning Indonesia into a pariah state -- another Burma, China, Iraq or Iran.
If that's where Congress is heading, it would be both wrong and stupid. Indonesia is too complex to be a pariah. It has probably the best macroeconomic management of any developing nation, along with mind-boggling corruption; it has political repression along with a tolerance for hundreds of independent nongovernmental human rights groups and a press that is unafraid to write about abuses; it has occasional church burnings, but the most popular Muslim leader in the country sent his daughter to study in Israel. As one banned newspaper editor here remarked to me: "The Indonesian Government is a police state about six hours a day. The other 18 hours you can negotiate with it, bribe it, ignore it or go around it." And strategically, Indonesia is the keystone of the Association of South East Asian Nations (Asean), which is the main counterweight to China and Japan in this region. Turning Indonesia into a pariah will produce a nationalist backlash here among the good guys, let alone the bad. Listen to Foreign Minister Ali Alatas.
"What we had hoped," Mr. Alatas told me, "was that public opinion would not forget Indonesia's constructive role in world affairs. We are not a pariah country that is looking inward or that deserves to be hit on one issue only. Yes, we have an issue, we have East Timor, but that's a complex issue with a long history that we are trying to resolve. We are a huge society in continual growth. It is not an easy country to govern and we have come very far.
"We are not causing the world problems because we have dreams of becoming a nuclear power," added Mr. Alatas. "We don't believe in that. Economically, we have been at the forefront of the North-South dialogue, but with a very rational voice. We are the biggest Islamic population, but we are not an Islamic state. Take all of these factors and I think, humbly, we don't deserve to be put into a corner and to say, 'You are a pariah nation and we must clobber you all the time because of East Timor.'
"You can criticize us about human rights; no country is beyond criticism on human rights," continued Mr. Alatas. "We would prefer that you don't criticize us by shouting from the roofs, but that you sit down and as a friend say: 'Look, we don't like the way you do things. You better change because you're getting in trouble.' But why link it to such things as IMET?"
IMET stands for International Military Educational Training. It is a program under which the Pentagon trains selected foreign military officers, in both military matters and human rights. After the 1991 Dili massacre in East Timor, IMET for Indonesian officers was suspended.
"Indonesia is a friend of the U.S., not an enemy," insisted Mr. Alatas. "It is important not to make it an opponent. Because an Indonesia that is feeling unjustifiably pushed around, an Indonesia that feels that Indonesia-bashing is going on, reaches a point where it says, 'Well, O.K., we've done what we can. If that is not understood then we'll just shrug our shoulders and continue on.' "

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Inflation Outlook Lifts Bond Prices

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices rose yesterday, bolstered by investor optimism that inflation would not soon accelerate. But that same sentiment weakened demand at an auction of new five-year inflation-protected securities.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond gained 7/32, to 100 27/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 6.56 percent, from 6.58 percent on Tuesday, and was the lowest since 6.54 percent on Feb. 18. 
 There was some profit taking to pull the market off its highs, said Kim Rupert, an economist at Standard & Poor's MMS, a market research and analysis firm in San Francisco. "But, by and large, players seem to be waiting as they believe prices can move higher with 6.50 percent targeted on the long bonds," she said.
With no current threat of inflation on the horizon, market participants had expected the Treasury's $8 billion auction of new five-year inflation-protected securities, or TIPS, to meet with soft demand. The Government has already sold $15 billion of 10-year inflation-linked securities and some traders say that investors have not been pleased with their performance.
Securities dealers preparing for yesterday's auction of the new five-year securities sent the yield up 15 basis points in when-issued trading over two days. Dealers often raise yields in advance of an auction to make them more attractive to investors. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
The five-year TIPS were awarded yesterday at a high yield of 3.744 percent, but retail demand was not overwhelming.
Analysts said that the Treasury market gained somewhat on relief that the auction was out of the way.
Over all, said Donald Fine, the chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management, "a combination of slack second-quarter economic growth, decelerating inflation, a steady monetary policy and notable progress in lowering the budget deficit has produced a significant rally in the bond market.
"And while many market observers feel that there is little in the near term that could upset this apple cart," he continued, "stronger economic growth during the third quarter, coupled with a flattening of the trend rate of inflation, could certainly produce some skittishness in bondland in the not too distant future.
"Indeed, judging from recent measures of buoyant consumer psychology, a rebound in retail sales should soon be forthcoming on the heels of the recent three successive monthly declines," Mr. Fine said. "In similar fashion, the deceleration in inflation is not likely to continue much longer in that the drag from declining energy prices has largely run its course."
A heavy corporate calendar yesterday also limited gains later. The Philip Morris Companies yesterday began selling $1 billion of global bonds due in 2005, with terms to be announced today through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch International.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Art museums stretch scarce marketing dollars with carefully targeted publicity campaigns.

BYLINE: By Glenn Collins 

 BODY:
WHILE giant consumer-products companies routinely spend millions of dollars on campaigns, the nation's most prestigious art museums are lucky these days to find several hundred thousand dollars to advertise their grandest exhibitions.
So museums in New York, Chicago, Philadelphia and everywhere have spearheaded a new trend, making their scarce resources go farther in innovative ways, including highly targeted newspaper, magazine and radio advertising. 
 Consider, for starters, the Art Institute of Chicago, which has designed a complex, multilayered campaign to draw museum-goers to its next mega-exhibition, "Renoir's Portraits: Impressions of an Age." The first major Renoir portrait retrospective, it features 65 works and is scheduled to open Oct. 21.
"We're hoping to attract 600,000 people to this show," said Eileen Harakal, executive director for public affairs for the museum, "so we're doing more, earlier, this time than with previous exhibitions."
Rejecting the notion of a last-minute advertising blitz this fall, the Art Institute began its campaign in April, six months before opening day. The museum first advertised in "Cultural Chicago," an insert created by the Illinois Bureau of Tourism that went to 250,000 American Express card holders and appeared in magazines such as Food & Wine and Travel & Leisure.
At the same time, the Art Institute focused on two million readers of small newspapers in the Midwest.
Then, last month, the museum took out full-page ads in The Chicago Tribune and other newspapers. Now, through July, ads will appear in local newspapers like The Chicago Reader, in national magazines like The New Yorker and on Chicago radio stations. In September, just before the show opens, national and local campaigns will return.
Officials of the Art Institute declined to discuss spending, but experts on institutional marketing budgets said the campaign could not have been accomplished for less than $300,000.
Another institution, the Metropolitan Museum of Art, has become the first museum to use focused ethnic marketing to publicize recent hit shows like "The Glory of Byzantium" and "Splendors of Imperial China." "We're doing very targeted metropolitan area advertising," said Harold Holzer, vice president for communications at the Met.
"Museums have had to become more sophisticated about marketing themselves, because they must make maximum use of scarce resources," Mr. Holzer added.
Generally those resources come mostly from the limited marketing budgets of the nonprofits, which have been augmented, in the case of the Art Institute, by Ameritech, and at the Metropolitan by companies like Alpha Banking Group, GTE and Texaco. At the American Museum of Natural History, Merrill Lynch was the advertising sponsor for last year's presentation of Leonardo da Vinci's scientific manuscript known as the Codex Leicester.
And in addition to arranging for highly selective newspaper, magazine and radio advertising, the Metropolitan has reached out to nontraditional marketing venues. "We have become ubiquitous on hotel videos," Mr. Holzer said, explaining that the museum has bought commercial time on tourist-oriented video programming shown in more than 100 hotels in Manhattan.
To reinforce the video message, the Met has invited more than 100 hotel concierges to the museum to explain the institution's coming events, and to load them up with brochures for tourists.
Increasingly the Met, the Art Institute and other nonprofit institutions are using discount programs for their ad pages in national magazines. These bargain-basement opportunities arise when major advertisers make expensive regional buys, leaving ad pages unfilled in other areas.
When that happens, many magazines offer the surplus space at a discount. The museums are now able to aim their ads so precisely that they can make buys as specific as a single ZIP code. Such ads have appeared in magazines from Bon Appetit and House Beautiful to Business Week, Time and U.S. News & World Report.
Such advertising "might cost $16,000 to $24,000, which is affordable for nonprofit institutions," said Michael LaPlaca, co-founder of LaPlaca Cohen Advertising in New York, which designed the Art Institute's Renoir campaign and represents the Metropolitan. "This is much more efficient than spending a lot more for scattershot advertising in other media."
The payoff for all of this increasingly sophisticated advertising is hardly theoretical: It amounts to millions of tourist dollars for museums and their cities. "Cultural tourism is becoming more important, and museums are more aware that people will travel to see a great art show," Ms. Harakal said.
Last summer, for example, Philadelphia benefited from the "Cezanne" show. The immensely popular exhibition of 170 works by the Impressionist master attracted 700,000 visitors to the Philadelphia Museum of Art and generated $60 million in revenue at hotels, restaurants, shops and local transportation.
Chicago has benefited from cultural tourism as well. In the summer of 1995, the Art Institute attracted 965,000 visitors to its retrospective, "Claude Monet: 1840-1926," and the museum's winter 1996 show, "Degas: Beyond Impressionism," attracted 480,000 visitors, even though it was not on view during the height of the tourist season.
The volume record holder, however, is the Metropolitan Museum in New York, where the "Splendors of Imperial China" exhibition last year attracted 426,757 visitors during a two-month run, the highest daily attendance of any museum show in the world in 1996, according to a study by The Economist.
The lesson of these spectacular successes is plain. "We're becoming more attuned to our audience," Ms. Harakal said, "and we're learning exactly where it comes from."

HEADLINE: Cry for Cambodia

 BODY:
The last thing Cambodia needed was the armed overthrow of its democratically elected Government. It had just begun to recover from a catastrophic quarter-century that included American bombing raids, the annihilation of one-seventh of its population during four years of Khmer Rouge rule, a Vietnamese invasion and a civil war. Now it faces new convulsions and executions and a likely withdrawal of most international aid.
Washington is still searching for a diplomatic euphemism to describe this week's military ouster of Cambodia's First Prime Minister, Norodom Ranariddh, by his coalition partner and longtime rival, Second Prime Minister Hun Sen. Simply calling it a coup would bring an automatic suspension of American aid to the country. The Clinton Administration fears such instant disengagement would reduce rather than increase United States leverage. 
 Whatever label Washington applies, Mr. Hun Sen's bloody seizure of power is an affront to democracy and a violation of the 1991 Paris peace agreement that ended the Cambodian civil war. Most of all it is a disaster for Cambodia. If Washington cannot get the coup leaders to back down, it should suspend American aid and work to persuade other countries to do the same. Japan, a major aid donor, has already cut off its assistance.
Mr. Hun Sen's actions came after Prince Ranariddh had begun making overtures to dissident leaders of the Khmer Rouge. Given the Khmer Rouge's responsibility for the death of more than a million Cambodians two decades ago, those overtures were cause for concern. But sending tanks against Prince Ranariddh's supporters and murdering leaders of his political party are not a legitimate response.
Despite its tragic history, current political infighting and serious corruption problems, Cambodia has recently been showing a surprisingly vital economy. Its citizens, long traumatized by war and dictatorship, had begun openly expressing political views, educating themselves on human rights issues and turning to newspapers increasingly willing to challenge Government behavior. Washington should be resolute in opposing Mr. Hun Sen's outrageous coup by making clear that unless he restores the elected Government he faces costly international isolation.

HEADLINE: Two Financiers To Form No. 1 Investment Bank in Russia

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, July 9

 BODY:
Combining Western financial expertise with Russian political and economic power, two of the nation's most influential financiers have joined forces to establish Russia's largest investment bank.
The new company will merge the Renaissance Capital Group with the International Company for Finance and Investment, which is now Russia's fifth-largest bank. 
 The merger will also formalize the alliance between Boris Jordan, the ambitious 31-year-old American who founded Renaissance Capital, and Vladimir O. Potanin, the 37-year-old former head of Uneximbank, the parent company of the Russian bank.
For Russia's leaders, eagerly awaiting the country's long-delayed economic turnaround, the announcement of the merger is an important sign that at least some Russian bankers believe there is real money to be made by investing at home.
"Russia needed a Russian-controlled international investment and merchant bank," said A. Robert Towbin, who is the managing director of Unterberg Harris, an American investment bank and brokerage firm, and the former president of the Russian-American Enterprise Fund, which was established by the United States Government to encourage the development of Russia's market economy.
"The image in the West is that Russia is the place of flight capital," Mr. Towbin added. "This says to the world that there are Russians with equity capital who are investing in Russia."
Indeed, the announcement comes at a critical time in Russia's economic development. After six years of economic decline, inflation has been brought under control. Economic reformers occupy top slots in the Government of President Boris N. Yeltsin. The Moscow stock exchange has soared.
Still, the economy has yet to show sustained growth. Key reforms of the tax system, housing and agriculture have yet to be carried out. Much of Russian industry has yet to be restructured. Direct investment in Russian companies is anemic.
The new bank, MFK Renaissance, will have equity capital of $400 million. It will manage more than $1 billion in funds and will have total assets of more than $2 billion. The bank plans to employ about 600 people.
Mr. Jordan will serve as president and chief executive. Mr. Potanin will become the chairman. Each side will own 50 percent. The merger is expected to be formally completed within six months.
The relationship between Mr. Jordan and Mr. Potanin goes back several years, when Mr. Potanin helped Mr. Jordan get his big start. Mr. Jordan, grandson of a Russian immigrant, was sent to Russia in 1992 by the CS First Boston Corporation. He left that company in 1994, along with other investment bankers and traders, to establish Renaissance Capital.
Mr. Potanin's Uneximbank provided important start-up capital and acquired a minority stake in Renaissance Capital.
"They were the only people we found that thought the way we did, were transparent enough and were of the generation we wanted to be associated with in Russia," Mr. Jordan recalled in an interview.
Uneximbank's effectiveness in restructuring former Soviet enterprises remains a matter of considerable debate among economists here. But there is no doubt about Mr. Potanin's ability to wheel and deal his way to the top of Russia's new financial elite.
A graduate of the Moscow State Institute of International Relations, Mr. Potanin worked at the Foreign Trade Ministry at the start of his career. As president of Uneximbank, he pioneered the "loans for share" privatization arrangement in which powerful banks lent money to the Russian Government in exchange for shares of some of the country's most valuable assets. Mr. Potanin became a first deputy prime minister last year but returned to Uneximbank after one of many Cabinet shake-ups.
Today, Uneximbank is the custodian of 38 percent of Norilsk Nickel, which produces one-fourth of the world's nickel. Uneximbank also owns 85 percent of Sidanko, Russia's fourth-largest oil producer, and it is trying to put together a bid for a 25 percent share of RAO Svyazinvest, the huge Russian telecommunications company.
Russia's investment community abounds in skeptics, who say Mr. Jordan was driven to the merger out of fear that he was losing his competitive edge or out of pressure from the powerful Uneximbank. Others challenge Mr. Potanin's business acumen.
"They are trying to gain muscle with closer collaboration with Potanin," Anders Aslund, an expert on the Russian economy at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, said of Renaissance Capital. "I am skeptical of Potanin as a business manager."
Mr. Potanin, for his part, insisted that MFK Renaissance would help attract investment to ailing Russian companies and facilitate their restructuring. And he said that Renaissance Capital's Russian coloration would ease the merger.
"It is not a 100 percent foreign firm," he said. "There is Russian participation in Renaissance. And let's not forget that Boris Jordan is Russian even through he is an American citizen."
For his part, Mr. Jordan said that MFK Renaissance now needs to find new clients within Russia. "You have to build a business that has a large domestic client basis," he said, so that it can help direct "domestic flows to domestic corporations and international flows to domestic corporations."

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
The split over punitive awards in getting the bad guys.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
IN last month's proposed tobacco settlement, cigarette manufacturers apparently got what they coveted most: immunity from punitive damages. And while anti-tobacco groups are now at each other's throats over whether they exacted a sufficient price in return, everyone agrees that the potential for sky-high punitive damage awards in individual injury suits immensely strengthened their bargaining power. "It's the lever that brought the tobacco industry to the table," said Michael Pertchuk, a former chairman of the Federal Trade Commission who now heads the Advocacy Institute in Washington, a nonprofit group closely linked to the anti-smoking coalition.
This is not the first time the specter of unbounded and unpredictable awards has driven corporate defendants to settle, or that legislation was needed to ratify a settlement. "The structure is very close to the lead paint agreement in Maryland," noted Donald Gifford, dean of the University of Maryland Law School, who represented Maryland in the negotiations in that case, in which landlords accepted responsibility for compensating victims and financing a lead paint cleanup program in return for protection from future individual suits. 
 But specialists in business law are deeply divided over the role that unpredictable damages awards in general and punitive damages in particular should play in civil justice. Trial lawyers and many consumer groups argue that punitive awards can stop the bad guys when compensatory damages alone are insufficient. "It's the appropriate response in a capitalist society," said Joan Claybrook, the president of Public Citizen, the consumer lobbying group.
By contrast, conservative legal scholars view punitive damages as the enemy of rational judgment, forcing defendants to settle claims without regard to the merits. "To play the game, you have to bet the corporation." warned Michael Horowitz, the director of the Hudson Institute's Project for Civil Justice Reform.
Start with some basics. The primary goals of damage awards in injury suits are deterrence and compensation. At least in theory, parting with cash induces defendants to exercise greater care and makes victims whole.
But what if a manufacturer of shoddy products knew the risks and decided it was cheaper to pay off the occasional claim? Damages in excess of compensation might be needed to change the pattern.
In recent decades, noted Lester Brickman at Yeshiva University's Cardozo Law School, economists have refined this logic. If an intentional injury or fraud is unlikely to be detected -- say, the use of substandard concrete in bridge construction -- some multiple of actual damages is needed to achieve the "optimal" level of deterrence.
The catch is that punishments meted out by courts may not fit the crime. In a now-famous case -- the first punitive damage case to be overturned by the Supreme Court -- a rural Alabama jury awarded $4 million to the owner of a BMW whose paint job had been retouched before sale. Less frivolously, courts have nailed auto makers with multimillion-dollar damages in injury cases with the intent of forcing them to build safer cars. "National policy on auto safety shouldn't be set by six randomly selected jurors in Georgia," Mr. Brickman argued.
But some scholars think the issue has been blown out of proportion. Theodore Eisenberg at the Cornell Law School, who analyzed punitive damages in the country's 45 largest counties, found that they were rarely awarded in cases that did not involve egregious, intentional injury. And when they were awarded, the sums were typically a reasonable multiple of compensatory damages.
George Priest at the Yale Law School is not persuaded. "Punitive damages are not a serious problem in most states," he acknowledged, because trial judges and appellate courts adequately discipline jury awards. But he said, "there are severe problems in a few pockets" -- notably Alabama and West Texas.
Even occasional excesses, moreover, may have a large impact on corporate behavior. While the Supreme Court did vote 5 to 4 to throw out the judgment against BMW because, in the words of Justice Stephen G. Breyer, the award was "grossly excessive," Mr. Horowitz of the Hudson Institute argued that "the law remains wildly undeveloped." And for better or worse, defendants with deep pockets often cut their losses.
In Maryland, landlords faced awesome potential liability from lead paint damages. And in 1994, after losing a handful of individual suits, they agreed to settle. The deal satisfied no one completely. But it beat decades of litigation in which "a few children and their lawyers would get full compensation," Mr. Gifford said.
Manufacturers have long fought for limits on punitive damages in product liability cases, and would have gotten them last year if President Clinton had not vetoed Federal legislation. But populist water runs deep in America. And many still see the potential for huge damage awards as a check on corporate power. Big Tobacco's willingness to pay $300 billion-plus in compensation rather than risk continuing the fight in court is likely to reinforce that view.

HEADLINE: Dow, Hit by Program Sales, Slides 119.88

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA 

 BODY:
The stock market plunged yesterday in a frenzied session marked by heavy program trading.
The late afternoon bout of computer-driven selling helped undermine a session that many Wall Street analysts thought would carry the Dow Jones industrial average above the 8,000-point level for the first time. 
 Instead, the Dow -- which had closed at 7,962.31 on Tuesday -- rose as high as 7,990.58 in early trading, before surrendering to afternoon losses. At the end of trading, the Dow was down 119.88 points, or 1.51 percent, to 7,842.43. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index lost 11.21 points, or 1.22 percent, to close at 907.54.
The selloff, which had the Dow falling by 167 points in late trading, came on a day when there was little economic news.
Analysts said that investors might have been affected by reports of a large asset allocation shift at several large brokerage houses. That move, they said, may have touched off additional selling, and upset a market that has been prone to huge momentum swings.
"So much of our market is based on momentum," Edward Collins, a trader at Daiwa Securities, said. "So when several firms changed their asset allocation models, that created some selling into an early rally."
Morgan Stanley was one of the investment houses said to be involved in the large asset allocation trading. But officials there declined to comment.
Other analysts said that the market downturn was created by investors keen to take profits, or perhaps by those who had grown worried about a market that had seen the Dow soar 25 percent since mid-April, when it began climbing after a monthlong downturn.
"What you saw was a classic bull market correction after an extended run-up in which the news couldn't get any better," Charles Pradilla, an analyst at Cowen & Company, said. "There are some portfolio managers who look around and say: 'That's a huge move. What can get better?' "
Birinyi Associates, a market research firm in Greenwich, Conn., tracked 13 large programs yesterday, including one that sold a basket of about 390 S.& P. stocks just after 2:45 P.M., when the Dow began sinking.
"It was a very volatile, up-and- down day," said Jeffrey Rubin, an analyst at Birinyi, noting that there were seven "buy" programs and six "sell" programs. "The last hour was heavily impacted by program trades."
In recent months, fears of inflation have eased on reports of a decelerating economy and inaction on the part of the Federal Reserve policy makers, who in March had raised the target on short-term interest rates.
With earnings prospects strong and the economy robust, investors have sent the Dow and other stock indexes to record after record close with the kind of momentum that some thought could send the Dow above 8,000 in a year when few on Wall Street expected it to reach 7,000.
But with the Dow up about 22 percent in just over six months this year, some analysts are worried that the market is getting ahead of itself. Huge price swings have added to the concerns, even though many analysts point out that with the Dow near 8,000, a move of 100 points is a smaller change in terms of percentage.
"We made a run at the 8,000 level and we failed," Joseph Yurman, a managing director at Robertson Stephens, said from the floor of the New York Stock Exchange. "I've seen this happen hundreds of times with a historical number. And 100 points is just a normal thing -- it's handled very easily down here on the floor."
For the Dow, it was the 21st session this year in which the blue-chip average had a move of 100 points or more. Prior to this year, there had been just 15.
"We have to acclimate ourselves that we're near 8,000, not at 4,000, where we were a few years ago," Mr. Pradilla said.
Although the Dow and S.& P. 500 had sizable losses, declines in the broader market were not as severe.
On the Big Board, there were 1,725 losing issues and 1,145 advancing issues. Volume was heavy at 592 million shares.
Technology issues fared much better yesterday, with the Nasdaq composite index setting a record for the fifth consecutive session.
The Nasdaq rose 1.53 points, to 1,486.63, helped by shares of computer companies after Motorola -- which is traded on the Big Board -- reported better-than-expected earnings late Tuesday.
Shares of Motorola rose 3 1/2, to 86; Intel gained 3, to 152 5/8; 3Com rose 2 9/16, to 52 5/8, and Ascend Communications rose 2 3/8, to 48 1/2.
Wells Fargo, which warned investors about weak second-quarter earnings, fell 18 3/8, to 260 5/8. Drug and financial stocks were weak yesterday.
Of the Dow's 30 component stocks, 26 lost ground yesterday, led by J. P. Morgan, down 3 1/8, to 106 3/8, and Merck, which lost 2 3/4, to 101 3/16. I.B.M., however, rose 7/16, to 96 3/16 -- a 52-week high.
