HEADLINE: THE NATO SUMMIT;
In Clinton's Words: 'Building Lines of Partnership and Bridges to the Future'

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from President Clinton's opening statement at a news conference yesterday on the NATO summit meeting, and from his exchange with reporters, as transcribed by the Federal Document Clearing House, a private transcription company:
 
OPENING STATEMENT
This was a unique conference. There have been conferences of great powers in Europe many times before, but today, with our meeting of the Euro-Atlantic Partnership Council, we had 44 nations -- big and small, new democracies and established ones -- meeting to chart a common future of freedom and security -- not large powers writing the destiny of small ones without regard to the impact of their decisions on ordinary citizens, but nations dismantling blocs of power, building lines of partnership and bridges to the future. 
 Many tongues were spoken at our table today, but the language was the same, the language of democracy in the pursuit of a common dream of a Europe, undivided, free and at peace.
NATO is at the heart of that vision. What happened here this week represents a lot of work over the last 3 1/2 years. Yesterday we made NATO stronger and ready to meet challenges of a new century by further streamlining its command structure and giving Europe a greater security role within NATO. Then, in a historic turning point, we extended invitations to new members for the first time since Spain joined NATO 15 years ago. And we opened the door to other members in the future.
Today we strengthened our ties to NATO's Partners for Peace and continued to reach out to new ones with the agreement with Ukraine. Together with the historic NATO-Russia Founding Act in Paris this spring, we now see a new and broader and deeper alliance.
Let me say as an American I was very pleased to be joined by a bipartisan delegation of our Congress from both houses, and very pleased that Senator Roth was the spokesperson for the parliamentarians from all the NATO countries yesterday supporting our expansion decisions.
Next year I will ask the United States Senate to ratify changes to the treaty governing NATO so that we can bring in the new members by the 50th anniversary of NATO in 1999. I hope this week and the publicity it has received back home in America will help to stimulate discussion and debate among the American people about this historic decision. And I hope that when the American people hear the arguments, they, too, will strongly support the enlargement of NATO.
This is going to make all of us stronger and more secure. The new allies will help us to better defend the territory of members and reduce the chances that any of the territory will be violated. Bringing in new members will help to lock in the gains of democracy in those countries, and the free market gains they are already achieving. The example of these new members will help to encourage others to aspire to membership and to continue their democratic reform and their efforts to settle disputes with their neighbors.
Finally, it will help to erase the artificial line drawn across Europe by Stalin after World War II. NATO enlargement, however, will not be cost or risk free. No important decision ever is. But for the American people, clearly, the costs will be far less in lives and money to expand the bounds of democracy and security than it would be if we had to involve our people in another conflict in Europe. . . .
 
QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS
Q. Mr. President, Radovan Karadzic continues to stir up trouble in Bosnia to the point of endangering the new President there and the democratically elected Government. Do you think that NATO peacekeepers should aggressively pursue him? Would you favor some kind of paramilitary operation to apprehend him?
A. First, let me say, we support Mrs. Plavsic and what she's trying to do. We oppose the unconstitutional efforts to restrict her authority. We appreciate the fact that, even though we don't agree on everything, she has stated her adherence to the Dayton accords and is trying to follow them.
And second, we believe that Mr. Karadzic and all the other indicted people who have been accused of war crimes should be arrested and subject to trial.
Third, in terms of the S.F.O.R. members themselves, clearly our mandate is to arrest people who have been accused of war crimes and turn them over for trial if that can be done in the course of fulfilling our other duties and if the commanders on the ground believe the risk is appropriate. As to whether anything beyond that could or should be done, I think it would be inappropriate for me to comment at this time. . . .
Q. French President Chirac earlier today suggested that France is not going to spend any money to expand NATO. He said that the new members should pay the bill themselves, which raises two interesting questions. If France isn't going to spend any money to expand NATO, why should the United States taxpayers be forced to spend what probably would be $2 billion over the next decade or so to expand NATO?
And the second related question is, these new countries are relatively poor and have limited hard currency. Why should they -- why should the United States and the other NATO allies be encouraging them now to spend their limited resources for high-tech weaponry, which may be good for U.S. and European defense contractors, but probably could be used more effectively to develop their own economic infrastructure, especially at a time when you yourself say there is no serious external threat to these countries?
A. Well, first of all, the weapons they would have to buy would be conditioned, more than anything else, on what kinds of missions they believe they will be called upon to undertake.
If they, for example, are sending their troops to Bosnia, if there is some future of Bosnia or some other peacekeeping role, as NATO troops, we would want them to be as well-armed as possible to protect themselves. . . .
Secondly, one of the things that I believe that I noted at this meeting was that there had not been a great deal of work done in many countries about what the costs were. I think some people in the United States have grossly overestimated the costs of NATO expansion.
I do believe that the nations involved should pay most of the cost themselves. But it's not just a question of that. There will be joint training to be done, just like there is in Partnership for Peace. But it will conducted at a higher level. There will be joint planning to be done. . . .
Q. Mr. President, NATO expansion has critics in the United States, and not only on the grounds of cost. Some say it risks isolating Russia or weakening and diluting the Western alliance. Do you feel the need to launch a public-relations campaign in the United States on behalf of this initiative? And if so, what will you do?
A. Well, I think a lot of our campaign has already begun, because of the widespread awareness at home. Because all of you are here and telling them at home what we just did, I think that a lot of the work has begun. But I do think, yes, that we all have a job to do, as Senator Roth said yesterday. But I and our Administration have a job to do with the American people and with the United States Congress.
I disagree that we are isolating Russia. You can only believe that we're isolating Russia if you believe that the great power territorial politics of the 20th century will dominate the 21st century, and if you believe that NATO is inherently antagonistic to Russia's interests and that Russia inherently will have to try to exercise greater territorial domination in the next few years than it has in the last two. I dispute that.
I believe that enlightened self-interest, as well as shared values, will compel countries to define their greatness in more constructive ways, and the threats that we will share, that will be genuine threats to our security, will compel us to cooperate in more constructive ways. . . .
Q. [Unintelligible] And will the Ukrainian-NATO charter give any guarantees of security for Ukraine?
A. I think it enhances the security of Ukraine just as I believe the NATO-Russia agreement enhances Russia's security and enhances NATO's, because it commits us to cooperation rather than conflict.
In terms of what we would do in the Black Sea, let's note one thing, that Ukraine and Russia have recently agreed to settle their differences, which is a huge, positive thing from our point of view.
To us, that was our biggest concern in the Black Sea was the argument between Ukraine and Russia. And we're gratified that there's been an agreement that will resolve it when it's implemented. And in terms of what we do with our exercises, that depends upon what we think the appropriate thing is under the circumstances. And I have no evidence at the time which would cause me to change my position.
Q. Mr. President, you had a meeting with Ukrainian President Leonid Kuchma today. What did you say to him? And what do you think about the state of economic reform in the country, which was the point of your concern recently?
A. Well, first of all, I congratulated him on the agreement, President Kuchma, on the agreement between the United States and NATO. Secondly, I reaffirmed our determination, which was stated again at Denver, to help Ukraine deal with the closure of Chernobyl and develop reasonable alternative sources of energy.
The third thing I did was to urge him to continue to support economic reform. This is the most difficult thing of all, because when a country goes from a Communist economy to a free market economy, almost always there's a period in which things are actually harder for ordinary citizens. And the voters may vote out the reformers. And it's a difficult thing.
But in the end, which doesn't take very long, the economy grows much more. And I told President Kuchma that if he could find a way to support the reforms and enact them in this year, that I would do everything I could to see that the World Bank, the International Monetary Fund and the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development supported Ukraine to minimize the problems for the people in Ukraine and to speed up the day when the economy will genuinely be growing again.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1966 words

HEADLINE: U.S. Job Machine Absorbing Fresh Workers

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

DATELINE: LOUISVILLE, Ky.

 BODY:
The hailstorm that did so much damage to roofs here a little more than a year ago pulled Antonio Rodriguez into the labor force. Kneeling on the lawn in front of a white clapboard home recently, he cut strips of asphalt shingles while four other young men lugged the shingles up a ladder and nailed them in place. Soon after, the team moved on to the next damaged roof.
Mr. Rodriguez, traveling from Mexico, settled here five years ago, but making a living came hard. Stints as a day laborer alternated with longer periods of idleness in which he rarely even looked for a job. "My friends offered me work sometimes," he said. And then the hailstorm, and the prospering Kentucky economy, brought Mr. Rodriguez full blast into the labor force. 
 About 18 months ago, the American labor force, which is everyone working or actively seeking work, began to grow at a rapidly accelerating rate. By early this year, it was expanding at nearly twice the rate of other years in the 1990's, although in recent months the growth has eased a bit. What's more, the labor force is continuing to grow considerably faster than the working-age population.
The result is that about four million more workers have been fed into a growing economy since the start of 1996. Hispanic people are the biggest contingent, but younger women and men over 55 also figure prominently among the new entrants.
Many are being pulled into the labor force by employers who are offering better pay than the minimum wage and -- with the unemployment rate hovering at 5 percent or below -- are less choosy than they once were about whom they hire. Mostly the new people are entering at relatively low pay, like Mr. Rodriguez, who is earning $50 a day.
Indeed, companies are recruiting among those ignored in the past: mothers at home with their children, older men who had retired or had been laid off, students, immigrants, people with criminal records. State officials here who help former prisoners get jobs say companies now reject fewer convicted felons. And tens of thousands of welfare recipients are being pushed off the rolls and into work by changes in the Federal welfare system.
"There is a huge and chronic reserve of working-age people in this country," said Mark Zandi, chief economist at Regional Financial Associates, "and when conditions are right, or they are pushed, they come into the labor force. That is happening now."
One of the big national economic issues is how long the American labor force, now numbering 129.4 million workers and 6.8 million people actively seeking work, can continue growing at this faster rate. During the 1980's, similarly strong labor-force growth started shortly after the recovery began and lasted for five years, helping to keep the economy expanding without the inflation that can result from labor shortages. This time, except for a brief spike in 1992 as the nation came out of recession, the above-normal labor-force growth only kicked in during the fifth year of recovery, and could continue to the end of the century.
"Millions of people are out there willing to enter the labor force without bidding up wages very much," said Alan Krueger, a Princeton labor economist. "This implies that the unemployment rate can remain low without the inflation that usually accompanies low unemployment."
Much of the labor force growth is in Eastern states, with their big concentrations of immigrants and people on welfare, and in prospering Southern states like Kentucky that are producing many new jobs. As workers shift from one sector to another in pursuit of better jobs, new workers move in to fill the empty slots. Often they are Hispanic people like Mr. Rodriguez, who have accounted for 28 percent of the labor force growth in the last 18 months, and are clearly among the nation's most mobile workers these days.
In Kentucky, for example, new auto plants -- particularly Toyota's sprawling factory in Georgetown 75 miles east of here -- have attracted networks of parts suppliers in recent years, offering thousands of new jobs at $10 an hour or more. They have hired many people who have shifted to the new factory work from lower-paying jobs in construction and tobacco fields. Hispanic people, drawn to the state in the last decade, have led the way in replacing them.
"It happened gradually, but one day you wake up and you notice," said James F. Thompson, a regional administrator for Kentucky's Department of Employment Services.
Mr. Rodriguez had come here to visit a friend from his hometown of Guanajuato. The friend stayed and Mr. Rodriguez did, too, in time marrying an American and applying for legal status. And as jobs have opened up in construction, steady work has made Louisville his home.
For the nation as a whole, the Labor Department counts 67 million working-age people -- 16 and older -- neither holding jobs nor seeking them. Most are out of the work force willingly: as students, retired people, mothers with young children and older women who rarely worked outside the home. Many are now being drawn in, while others find themselves forced to enter.
From this pool, Nadirah El-Amin made the transition in June. Ms. El-Amin, 43, and 16 other black women on welfare, graduated in late June from a 13-week course at the Y.W.C.A. in Manhattan where the women were taught the latest office computer software. The goal is to land office jobs that pay enough (at least $23,000 a year) to get by in New York without too much privation.
By graduation, only five had been offered such work, but the rest, including Ms. El-Amin, began an anxious search for jobs before they are forced off welfare in August and into whatever minimum-wage work they can grab. "I am putting on my happy face to look for a job," said Ms. El-Amin, who has a year of college and last worked as a salaried school aide in the early 1990's -- taking a $4,000 buyout in 1994 as an alternative to layoff. "If I don't find an office job soon," she said, "this training won't be worth beans."
Men over 55 are also entering, or more precisely re-entering, the labor force in unusual numbers. Jobs are now easier for older people to find, particularly in such physically less demanding work as security guards, clerks, stadium ushers and cashiers.
Sometimes they go head to head with the young, as Thomas Ball, a 70-year-old former appliance repairman, has done here in Louisville. Hoping to earn extra money to pay expenses on his car, which he uses for Red Cross volunteer work, Mr. Ball applied to United Parcel Service last fall for a Christmas season job at its huge distribution center here. He did not get the seasonal job, but in early January U.P.S., short-staffed, hired him as a permanent part-timer, earning $8 an hour on a 2:45 A.M. to 7 A.M. shift.
Mr. Ball was delighted by what he viewed as recognition of his youthful vigor. "The younger people might outlift me on a dead lift," he said, referring to U.P.S.'s loosely enforced requirement that each employee have the strength and agility to lift 70-pound boxes. "But at the end of four or five hours, I'm still working steadily and they aren't."
Edward Nelson, 47, also sees his situation as unusual. He is a regular at Labor Ready, a nationwide temporary help agency that opened a storefront recruiting office in Louisville last year near a public housing project. Across the country, temp agencies are playing big roles in drawing people into the labor force, and Labor Ready is in the thick of this process, its storefront sign here announcing, in colored block letters, that there is work "today" for anyone who walks through the door.
That is not quite true. From the two dozen men and women who gather at 6 A.M., Corry E. Branson, the office manager, makes his selections of people to go out as a plumber's helper, or to touch up rust spots on cars at an auction lot, or as a laborer at a mall construction site. Some he ignores, judging them too listless or unreliable. Others in whom he has confidence fare well, including Mr. Nelson. For a month now, he has gone each morning to Anita Spring Water, where he packs bottled water, earning $6 an hour.
He is surprised at Mr. Branson's trust. "They don't know at Anita that I have a criminal record, not unless they asked Corry, and they haven't," said Mr. Nelson, who finished a three-year prison term in March, for stealing $2,000 from an office safe to finance, he says, a new life after getting a divorce.
Corry Branson sees the felony as a nonissue. "You do a good job and your past won't haunt you," he said. "We don't ask about criminal records unless the customer asks, and they don't ask these days."
United Parcel Service, in its quest, operates several notches up the ladder of potential jobholders waiting in the wings. With 14,000 employees in Kentucky, it is the state's largest employer. Like most American companies, U.P.S. says its full-time jobs, those that pay upward of $25,000 a year, with health insurance, are relatively easy to fill, very often through promotions. Part-timers are the hard part. U.P.S. operates its largest distribution center at the airport here, sorting and shipping packages on 170 flights a day. That effort absorbs 7,500 part-time employes. How the company finds people to fill these jobs -- using standard corporate tactics -- helps to explain why the labor force is growing so fast today.
College students once held 70 percent of the U.P.S. jobs, which start at $8 an hour. Their youthful strength and flexible schedules made them favorites. "If you had 10 people lined up for 10 jobs, and 9 were students, you picked the 9 students first," said Patrick O'Leary, U.P.S.'s work force planning manager.
Now U.P.S. has fewer than 4 college students in any 10-person lineup. With an unemployment rate of only 4 percent in the Louisville area -- similar to the 5 percent or less nationally in recent months -- the students find work elsewhere, just when the company has added 500 part-time jobs. So Mr. O'Leary's people are out recruiting full blast, even running job fairs in parking lots and hiring biplane pilots to drag help wanted signs across the sky.
The U.P.S. distribution center increasingly accommodates young mothers like Dawn Overall, 26, whose children are 6 and 3. To get such women back to work, U.P.S. offers them a choice of schedules. Ms. Overall, who re-entered the labor force at U.P.S. in late 1995, is about to move from days to a four-hour night shift, having decided to work while her children sleep.
"I came here to prove a point to my husband, who thought I couldn't do this work; I was too prissy," said Ms. Overall, who, as she spoke, heaved boxes from a conveyor belt into a plastic and aluminum shipping caisson that would later be loaded on a plane. "But now I don't want to work anymore and he is making me. He insists on the money. We are building a house."
But for all the hiring problems of a company like U.P.S., Kentucky still harbors tens of thousands of people outside the labor force who resist re-entry. Most live 100 miles away, in the rural counties of Eastern Kentucky, where coal fields once offered employment. Rather than travel far from home, they survive on support payments and by scrounging, neither working nor searching for work.
To lure these people, the state government has organized a recruiting effort, particularly on behalf of the new auto parts suppliers. Ted A. Beebe, a field office manager for Kentucky's Department of Employment Services, is part of this effort, often working with local ministers.
"We recruited seven people last month for one auto parts company," Mr. Beebe said. "They had to commute two hours each way, and after two weeks four stopped coming. Two, however, are still there, working."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Hispanic people, younger women and older men have been having success breaking into the labor force in recent months. HEADLINE: Judge Upholds Law Making Gender-Motivated Crime a Civil-Rights Violation

BYLINE: By NINA BERNSTEIN 

 BODY:
A Federal judge in Tennessee has "quite reluctantly" upheld the constitutionality of the Violence Against Women Act of 1994 in the case of a Knoxville woman accusing the wealthy and prominent man she is divorcing of violating her civil rights by beating and raping her during their marriage.
The decision was the latest in a series of closely watched rulings on the constitutionality of the Federal law that made crimes motivated by gender a violation of civil rights. Two earlier decisions also upheld the constitutionality of the law's civil provisions, while another found the law was an unconstitutional Federal intrusion into state matters. The question is widely expected to make its way to the Supreme Court, where the reach of Federal authority has become a deeply divisive issue. 
 "The court must note its extreme discomfort with the sweeping nature" of the Violence Against Women Act, Judge James H. Jarvis, of the Eastern District of Tennessee, wrote in the decision issued late Tuesday in Laurel Knuckles Seaton v. Kenneth Marshall Seaton. "While there is no doubt that violence against women is a serious matter in our society, this particular remedy created by Congress, because of its extreme overbreadth, opens the doors of the Federal courts to parties seeking leverage in settlements rather than true justice."
Nevertheless, Judge Jarvis found, the law passed muster under the commerce clause of the Constitution. Under well-established legal precedent, he found, the court was limited, in its review, to determining whether "a rational basis" existed for Congress to conclude that violence against women sufficiently affects interstate commerce to allow the Federal Government to invoke its regulatory authority.
At the same time, he added, "this court must again express its deep concern that the Act will effectively allow domestic relations litigation to permeate the Federal courts."
He refused to accept Federal jurisdiction over various accusations made under state law against Mr. Seaton.
Under Federal law, Ms. Seaton is seeking compensatory and punitive damages from Mr. Seaton of $40 million to $87 million, said her lawyer, Norman A. Pattis.
"His trial will speak to the nation of what men can do to women," Mr. Pattis said. "Where do most acts of gender-motivated violence occur? They occur in the context of a marriage."
Mr. Seaton, whose lawyers declined to comment, is the president and owner of KMS Enterprises, with holdings that include Family Inns of America, a motel chain in nine states; a cable television station; a weekly newspaper, and Christian Ministries Inc. In court papers, he denied all accusations.
According to the complaint, Ms. Seaton, a lawyer from a prominent legal family in Kentucky, met Mr. Seaton on a blind date in late 1991, and married him on Valentine's Day 1992, in an abrupt nighttime ceremony performed, she said, after he "fraudulently obtained" her signature on a prenuptial agreement.
When her father died, the complaint says, Mr. Seaton forced her to leave a family gathering after his funeral, in what became a pattern of isolating her. She says he forced her to give up her law practice, and she became increasingly depressed as he abused and humiliated her.
The case is similar in some respects to Doe v. Doe, the Connecticut case that was the basis last year of the first Federal District Court ruling on the constitutionality of the Federal law. The plaintiff said her husband had repeatedly threatened to kill her and had beaten her and forced her to be a "slave."
Her husband's lawyers argued that the civil rights provision was "an open and sweeping invitation to the Federal Government" to interfere in almost any area.
Two years ago, in United States v. Lopez, the Supreme Court ruled that a Federal law banning the possession of guns near schools exceeded Federal authority to regulate interstate commerce, the first such ruling since the New Deal.
But unlike the gun law, the anti-violence law was passed after four years of Congressional hearings on the pervasive impact of gender-based violence on the economy, the judges in both the Doe and Seaton cases noted. The hearings included states' assessments that their judicial systems were not protecting female victims of such crimes. Congress found "that gender-based crimes and fear of gender-based crimes restrict movement, reduce employment opportunities, increase health expenditures, and reduce consumer expending, all of which affect interstate commerce and the national economy," and that about half of rape victims lost their jobs or were forced to quit after the crime.
Judge Jarvis concluded that "Congress was hardly unreasonable in creating a civil rights remedy to correct such deficiencies."
His decision joins an opinion issued on June 23 by Mark W. Bennett, a Federal district judge in Iowa, that also upheld the law, and took jurisdiction of its state claims.
In that case, Jane Doe v. the Rev. Gerald Hartz, a woman sued a priest at St. Lawrence Church in Carroll, Iowa, accusing him of groping and kissing her when she arrived at the church for evening Mass. The suit also named the church, the bishop and diocesan officials as defendants, charging that they knew Father Hartz had a problem with sexual abuse. Besides damages, the suit seeks an injunction preventing the priest's assignment to parish work.
Father Hartz, 62, who denied the accusations, was later charged with improperly touching a 13-year-old girl at St. Lawrence Catholic School. Those charges were dropped after he resigned as a parish priest and the complaint was withdrawn.
Both Judges Bennett and Jarvis rejected the reasoning of Judge Jackson L. Kiser, chief judge for the Western District of Virginia, who found the law unconstitutional in Brzonkala v. Virginia Tech, the case of a Virginia Polytechnic Institute student who accused two football players of raping her. That decision is on appeal to the Fourth Circuit.

HEADLINE: 13 Arrests in Sting at Police-Run Auto Shop

BYLINE: By SELWYN RAAB 

 BODY:
It was a new auto repair shop in Brooklyn and its owners openly suggested to several of their customers that they were willing to do anything to make money.
But the owners were undercover investigators with two goals: to disrupt the Gambino family's activities in Brooklyn and to expose any police corruption in tow-truck operations. 
 After a 17-month investigation, law enforcement officials said yesterday that the sting had led to the arrest of 13 people linked to a Gambino crew on charges including loan sharking, illegal gambling, auto insurance fraud and trafficking in marijuana and bootleg cigarettes.
The authorities also said they found no evidence of police misconduct. The Police Department uses a computerized rotation system for calling tow-truck operators to remove disabled vehicles, and the officials said they were concerned that police officers might be taking bribes and allowing vehicles to be towed out of turn.
The officials said the undercover investigators showed up at more than 70 auto accidents without authorization and asked officers for permission to tow disabled vehicles. All 100 officers passed the integrity tests by ordering the unauthorized operators to leave.
Towing is a highly competitive business in New York City and a company can charge more than $100 for towing and storing a vehicle and then seek to do the repair work.
"This investigation exposed the corrupt activities of organized crime in our community," said the Brooklyn District Attorney, Charles J. Hynes, "and demonstrated, at the same time, that police officers are doing their duty with honesty and integrity."
In January 1996, the District Attorney's office began Operation Tip Tow by opening Shop Right Collision at 80 Georgia Avenue in the East New York section of Brooklyn. Four investigators from the District Attorney's office and the Police Department's Internal Affairs Division, the unit that investigates police corruption, acted as owners and managers of the shop. Three of the investigators had experience in auto repairs and the agents hired two employees who were unaware of the sting.
"They let it be known that they were hustlers," said Dennis R. Hawkins, Deputy District Attorney in Brooklyn, "and would engage in a variety of activities, including illegal gambling, working on stolen cars and insurance frauds."
Mr. Hawkins said the investigators were approached by people who said they were connected to a Gambino gang known as the Canarsie Crew. According to the charges, a defendant, Jack L. Slofkiss, 61, told the investigators that he handled loan-sharking activities for the Canarsie Crew's capo, Nicholas Corozzo.
Mr. Slofkiss was arrested on state charges of usury, accused of lending $6,000 with an annual interest rate of 260 percent. In an unrelated case, Mr. Slofkiss was indicted in January on Federal racketeering charges.
Law enforcement officials said Mr. Corozzo had been designated last year to succeed John Gotti as the Gambino boss, but the promotion was sidetracked when he was indicted in December and in January in racketeering cases.
The repair and tow shop was closed in May with a business loss of about $75,000. "It was worth the cost," Mr. Hawkins said. "It gave us a look into the midlevel workings of organized crime."

HEADLINE: Hearing on Flight 800 Crash Will Consider Cause and Compensation

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 9

 BODY:
Nearly a year after 230 people died in the explosion of Trans World Airlines Flight 800, the House Aviation subcommittee plans a hearing Thursday to determine why the cause has not been found and what can be done to improve safety until that happens.
The committee will also explore whether Congress should countermand a Supreme Court decision that puts damage awards in crashes like this one under the control of a 77-year-old law written to help the widows of shipwrecked sailors. 
 The law, the Death on the High Seas Act, allows for "economic damages," like the loss of the wages of a breadwinner, but not for loss of companionship, for pain and suffering, or for punitive damages. Relatives of several passengers will testify that the statute needs to be changed.
As the July 17 anniversary of the explosion approaches, officials at two Federal agencies have been busy describing their efforts to solve the mystery and their disagreements with each other over how to proceed.
One agency, the National Transportation Safety Board, which investigates air crashes, has called for changes in fueling procedures to reduce the risk of explosions. Investigators say they believe an explosion in the main fuel tank made Flight 800 crash, although they still cannot say why. The Federal Aviation Administration, which regulates airline safety, will explain why it has been cool to the recommendations.
The safety board and the Federal Bureau of Investigation had disagreed earlier in the investigation, but the F.B.I. has since assumed a much smaller role. The F.B.I. has recently said that it is now less likely that the plane was brought down by a "criminal act," in the form of a bomb or missile.
The safety board is expected to announce that it will hold a full-scale hearing scheduled to begin Dec. 8 and last six days. The board usually holds such hearings near the scene of the crash, but this one will be in Baltimore, because hotel rooms and hearing space are easier to come by there during the holidays.
James E. Hall, the board chairman, and Bernard S. Loeb, the chief aviation safety engineer, will also describe the work the board has done, including retrieving more than 95 percent of the Boeing 747 from the water off Long Island.
The board has also begun flying a nearly identical plane, leased from Evergreen Airways, to determine when conditions are present that could support an explosion.
The Aviation subcommittee, chaired by Representative John J. Duncan Jr. of Tennessee, is considering a bill on the applicability of the Death on the High Seas Act. Representative Joseph M. McDade, a Republican from Pennsylvania, has introduced an airline disaster relief bill that would allow families to sue under the same rules that apply to crashes on land. Mr. McDade's district includes Montoursville, Pa.; among the passengers on the plane were students from the Montoursville High School French club. Under the high seas law, Mr. McDade said, compensation for the teen-agers' deaths would be minimal, because they were not breadwinners.
If the plane had crashed on land or within three miles of shore, the families could sue for "noneconomic damages," like the loss of loving relationships, or pain and suffering. The high seas law applies in this crash because of a Supreme Court ruling in January 1996 in connection with the crash of Korean Air Lines Flight 007 in 1983.

Sheik Vows to Guide Qatar From Coup to Democracy
After toppling his father two years ago, Sheik Hamad bin Khalifa al-Thani of Qatar has called for municipal elections by the end of the year and said he expected that women would be allowed to vote. The moves are unprecedented in the Gulf region and reflect Sheik Hamad's cautious determination to avoid violence by dissidents. A8

Forces loyal to First Prime Minister Hun Sen arrested scores of opposition officials as they continued their purge against rivals. Soldiers openly ridiculing "human rights" seized the opportunity to settle private disputes as pessimism spread across the country. A6

Kenyan Police Club Students
Riot policemen moved to close the University of Nairobi in Kenya, clubbing students and forcing them to flee. At least 20 were reported injured, and one was in a coma. Students had earlier marched to the morgue to collect bodies of colleagues they heard had been killed by police squelching a pro-democracy protest on Monday. President Danial arap Moi has refused to discuss electoral reform until after elections, which he must call before the end of the year. A3

President Clinton's choice to be the new commander of forces deployed in the Persian Gulf, Lieut. Gen. Anthony Zinni of the Marine Corps, told a Senate committee that he believed United States troops in Saudi Arabia were being regularly watched by terrorist groups. He said increased vigilance had already thwarted some planned attacks, but declined to be specific. A12
 
Dollars, Centimes Worry NATO
President Clinton and leaders of other NATO countries discussed the cost of the alliance's eastward expansion. Estimates have varied widely but NATO military and political experts said they would produce a definitive estimate by the end of the year. President Jacques Chirac of France said his country did not expect its contributions to rise at all, but warned against rocketing costs because of arms companies plying new and aspiring members with overly sophisticated weapons. A partnership charter between NATO and Ukraine was also signed. A14

Two Israeli border guards were wounded near the West Bank town of Nablus when a remote-controlled bomb exploded next to their vehicle, military sources said. The guards were escorting a bus carrying students from a Jewish religious institute through an Israeli-controlled sector of the West Bank. Fire bombs were thrown and shots fired at Jewish settlers in and around Hebron.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
With World Selloff in Gold, Stocks and Funds Suffer, Too

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA 

 BODY:
For gold investors, these are hardly the best of times.
With the price of gold near a 12-year low, gold-mining companies are struggling with high production costs, gold stocks are depressed and mutual funds that invest in gold miners are all but crying uncle. 
 "If this isn't the most pessimistic period for gold, it's pretty close to it," said Harry Bingham, a manager of institutional gold portfolios at Van Eck Associates. "In this kind of environment, gold shares go down faster than the price of gold."
But the sharp plunge in the price of gold, and of gold shares, could be coming to an end, some analysts argue, simply because it has descended to such bargain levels that it may be poised for a revival. The price of gold fell to $319 an ounce on Monday, the lowest level since December 1985. Yesterday, after a small rebound on Tuesday, gold for August delivery fell $2.10, to $318.90, on the Comex division of the New York Mercantile Exchange.
"We've seen these kinds of capitulations before, and they've always been buying opportunities," said Vahid Fathi of ABN-Amro in Chicago. Several other analysts also believe that the decline in gold prices has been exaggerated.
But the damage has been enormous. From early in 1996, the price of gold has plunged 24 percent.
Gold stocks have suffered similar losses. The shares of the Barrick Gold Corporation, the largest North American producer, have fallen 26 percent this year.
And since January, the average gold mutual fund is down 28 percent. While the Dow Jones industrial average soared 16.5 percent in its biggest second-quarter gain since 1938, gold funds dominated the list of the 10 worst-performing mutual funds.
The U.S. Global Gold Fund, for instance, lost 22.2 percent of its value in the second quarter.
Analysts attribute the devaluing of gold to a number of factors, including the easing of inflation jitters. Traditionally, gold has been regarded as a "safe harbor" investment in times of inflation; with prices tame, the allure of gold has diminished.
Investors were also alarmed by the scandal involving Bre-X Minerals, a Canadian company whose purported Indonesian gold strike had sent its shares soaring, only to plunge when the site was found to contain nothing worth mining. The scandal contributed to the slide in gold stocks and funds.
Most recently, there have been widespread fears that central banks are prepared to sell large portions of their gold reserves. After the Australian central bank said last Thursday that it had sold 167 metric tons and bought United States, German and Japanese Government bonds, gold prices plummeted.
Many investors who had used gold funds as insurance against a stock market downturn have begun to pull their money out. At the start of the year, gold funds had $7.9 billion in total assets. But losses and net redemptions have reduced that to $6.2 billion, according to AMG Data Services.
Some other analysts, taking the contrarian view, see opportunity in such pessimism, expecting that gold can only go up at this point. "Investor sentiment has been so negative," said Leanne Baker of Salomon Brothers. "I mean how much more negative can it get?" She said she did not expect a "wild rally" in gold shares, but added that she did view this as a good time to buy.
On Tuesday morning, in a call to clients, she told them that the selloff in gold shares had been overdone. Because the cost of mining gold is already very high, she said, depressed prices make the mining uneconomical, and as a result, some gold producers may have to shut down, limiting the supply of gold and eventually lifting prices.
Analysts said that the speculation that central banks would sell some of their stocks was also exaggerated, pointing to a pledge by South Africa, which said yesterday that it would not sell reserves. Furthermore, demand for products that use gold, like jewelry, remains strong.
But while Ms. Baker and other analysts expect a turnaround in prices, they say that investors ought to remain cautious and selective, focusing on companies with the soundest operations.
Some cited Barrick Gold of Toronto, which has fared better than most, in part by hedging against a drop in gold prices by locking in sales around $420 an ounce.
Peter Munk, Barrick's chairman, called the selloff in gold shares a knee-jerk reaction to the slide in the commodity price.
But he also said that the difficulties would breed a Darwinian consolidation in the industry, much like an earlier shakeout in the steel industry. "There is going to be a period of rapid consolidation," he said. "And it will end with a couple of really good producers."
Even before such a consolidation, however, the stage may be set for a recovery. "Typically, gold is a metal you want to focus on when everyone hates it," Ms. Baker of Salomon said. "And this is just that time."

HEADLINE: World Gets Plea to Act On Cambodia

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, July 9

 BODY:
Cambodia's United Nations representative asked all governments today not to recognize what he called the "military junta" in Phnom Penh, but to consider imposing economic sanctions on the country, which relies on aid for more than 60 percent of its budget.
The representative, Prince Sisowath Sirirath, was outlining the strategy of Cambodia's deposed First Prime Minister, Prince Norodom Ranariddh. He said at a news conference here that Hun Sen, the Second Prime Minister, who seized power over the weekend, was in "flagrant violation" of Cambodian laws and international agreements. 
 He said Cambodia's Foreign Minister, who is loyal to Prince Ranariddh, would ask an emergency meeting of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, on Thursday to reject Phnom Penh's application for membership until the elected Government has been restored.
[Just before Asean opened its meeting on Thursday, the Philippine Foreign Affairs Secretary, Domingo Siazon, said to journalists, "Everything related to Cambodia will be discussed, including membership," Agence France-Presse reported.]
At the United Nations today, Prince Sirirath tried to make the case for renewed international intervention in Cambodia, where the United Nations spent more than $2 billion in 1992-93 to set up a democratic government. It may be very difficult to engender much interest in spending more money there.
Prince Ranariddh planned to arrive in New York tonight. He plans to meet on Thursday with Secretary General Kofi Annan and the presidents of the Security Council and General Assembly before going on to Washington to meet with members of Congress and State Department officials.
Prince Sirirath said armed royalist party followers of Prince Ranariddh were in hiding and plotting to capture the Cambodian city of Battambang, near the Thai border, to establish a center of resistance. Envoys abroad are lobbying for international pressure on Mr. Hun Sen, a Communist and former Khmer Rouge regional commander who led a Vietnamese-occupation government in Cambodia before the 1993 election.
When Mr. Hun Sen lost that election to Prince Ranariddh and threatened a coup, a "two-headed" prime ministership was proposed to avoid violence. The United Nations official in charge of Cambodia during that period was Yasushi Akashi of Japan, who was criticized for encouraging the formation of the coalition and then leaving considerable military and police power in Communist hands and at the disposal of Mr. Hun Sen. This week Mr. Annan told diplomats that he was thinking of sending Mr. Akashi back to Cambodia.
Prince Sirirath is under some pressure from Hun Sen supporters in his mission here, as are diplomats in other embassies around the world, including Washington. His deputy, Ouch Borith, has circulated a statement by Mr. Hun Sen blaming Prince Ranariddh for creating the crisis by negotiating with a faction of the Khmer Rouge in the hope of gaining its support before elections scheduled for May 1998.
Prince Sirirath said today that these accusations were odd, since Mr. Hun Sen had won over Ieng Sary, a Khmer Rouge leader, and several thousands of his followers last year through a promise of amnesty for Mr. Ieng Sary and those talks were not considered illegal or treasonous. That is the charge now leveled at Prince Ranariddh and his party, Funcinpec, an acronym for the name, in French, of the royalist organization called the National United Front for an Independent, Peaceful, Neutral and Cooperative Cambodia.
"You cannot call the Prince a traitor," Prince Sirirath said.
Prince Sirirath and Prince Ranariddh, the son of Prince Norodom Sihanouk, are from different branches of the royal family.
An American analyst of Cambodia, who asked not to be identified because some of his colleagues are in the country and could be endangered, said that Mr. Hun Sen's explosive reaction to Prince Ranariddh's talks with another Khmer Rouge leader, Khieu Samphan, may reflect problems that Mr. Hun Sen is facing within his own Cambodia People's Party, where he has come under criticism for high-handedness. A return of more Khmer Rouge leaders and guerrillas to the political mix could split Mr. Hun Sen's leftist following, this analyst said.
The Khmer Rouge still have a powerful appeal for those who distrust Vietnam, Mr. Hun Sen's former patron. Mr. Hun Sen will be under international pressure to "kiss and make up" with Prince Ranariddh, the analyst said, but added that this would be very hard for the former Communist leader to do.

HEADLINE: President Gives Nudge To Deal on Budget Bill

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 9

 BODY:
With a new push from President Clinton, House and Senate negotiators meet on Thursday in the first of many sessions intended to wrap up agreement this month on legislation to balance the Federal budget and help preserve Medicare for millions of baby boomers.
Then on Friday, lawmakers from the two chambers will start ironing out their differences on a tax bill, which was described today by Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the Democratic leader, as "probably the single most important piece of legislation" in this Congress. 
 Congressional leaders said they hoped to send final versions of both bills to Mr. Clinton by early August.
The tax bill has provoked a fierce ideological struggle as Republicans and Democrats argue over the proper distribution of tax cuts to wealthy people, middle-income families and the working poor.
The two parties agree on a surprisingly large number of provisions in the budget bill, which would make the biggest changes in Medicare since the health insurance program for the elderly was created in 1965. But President Clinton and Congress disagree on many of the details, and lobbyists will swarm outside the rooms where lawmakers from the two chambers negotiate.
The budget and tax measures, though packaged as separate bills, are politically interrelated. Robert D. Reischauer, former director of the Congressional Budget Office, said: "Republicans won't send the spending bill to the President unless they have an assurance that he will sign the tax bill. The tax-cut locomotive is pulling this train, as far as Congress is concerned."
One of the biggest issues in dispute is whether to charge higher Medicare premiums for elderly people with higher incomes, as the Government would do under the budget bill passed by the Senate last month.
At a news conference in Spain, where he was attending a NATO conference, Mr. Clinton confirmed today that he might support such a change -- not as part of some future effort to address Medicare's long-term financial problems but as part of this year's budget bill.
"I have never been opposed to means-testing Medicare," he said. His comment may embolden House Republicans to join senators of both parties in support of a means test.
But Mr. Clinton said he opposed another provision of the Senate bill, which would gradually increase the age of eligibility for Medicare to 67, from 65, over the years 2003 to 2027.
R. Bruce Josten, senior vice president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, denounced this proposal today, saying it would impose hundreds of millions of dollars in new costs on employers that provide health benefits to retirees.
The final push to balance the budget comes against the backdrop of a strong economy generating so much tax revenue that the Federal deficit will fall sharply, even without action by Congress.
President Clinton predicted in February that the deficit for the current fiscal year would be $126 billion. In May, when he and Congressional leaders agreed on a plan to balance the budget, they assumed that this year's deficit would be $67 billion. Now Administration officials say the robust economy may push the figure below $50 billion.
But economists said some of the strength of the economy and of the stock market was a response to the bipartisan commitment to reduce the Federal budget deficit. Interest rates are relatively low and markets are vibrant, in part, because investors believe that the Government's fiscal condition is good and is improving, the economists said.
Mr. Daschle said the forecasts of lower deficits would not reduce pressure on Congress to balance the budget.
"Now that the end is in sight," the Senator said, "it may even have enhanced the pressure to finish the job. We can't let up now."
Here is a summary of the many important issues on which the House and the Senate disagree:
CHILDREN'S HEALTH CARE The House set aside $16 billion to provide health care or health insurance for half of the nation's 10 million uninsured children in the next five years. The Senate set aside $24 billion, stipulated that states must use the money for insurance and guaranteed comprehensive benefits, including hearing and vision services and mental health care in most cases.
Governors strongly prefer the House version, saying it would enable them to cover more children because the average cost for each child would be lower. But the American Academy of Pediatrics and the Children's Defense Fund favor the Senate bill.
President Clinton supports a 20-cent increase in the cigarette tax, which is now 24 cents a pack. But unlike the Senate, he would devote all the new revenue to children's health insurance. His proposals would provide a total of $31 billion for coverage of children in the next five years.
MEDICAID FOR DISABLED CHILDREN The House would allow states to provide Medicaid for 30,000 disabled children who will soon lose Supplemental Security Income benefits under the 1996 welfare law. The Senate version of the budget bill includes no such provision.
Mr. Clinton says that House and Senate negotiators should require states to provide Medicaid to these children. He says that such coverage is required under the bipartisan budget agreement.
NEW MEDICARE OPTIONS The House and Senate versions of the budget bill would both increase the health insurance options available to elderly people in all parts of the country. In theory, they could enroll in the standard Medicare program, in health maintenance organizations or in health plans owned and operated by doctors and hospitals.
On both sides of the Capitol, lawmakers want to reduce huge geographical variations in Medicare payments to H.M.O.'s in different parts of the country. The Senate measure is more generous to health plans in rural areas, but over the next five years, it would freeze or even reduce Medicare payments to H.M.O.'s in some big cities like New York, Miami and Los Angeles.
The Administration and the managed care industry say the Senate bill would force many H.M.O.'s to cut back coverage of prescription drugs and other benefits.
Under current law, Medicare beneficiaries dissatisfied with an H.M.O. may drop out of the health plan and enroll in the standard fee-for-service program with just one month's notice. Under the House bill, elderly people could eventually be locked into an H.M.O. for nine months at a time. The Administration prefers the Senate bill.
TAXES The Administration is pressing for changes that it says would shift some benefits of the tax cuts away from the wealthy. For example, the White House wants to make more low-income working families eligible for the $500-a-child tax credit. It also wants to limit the cut in capital gains taxes, imposed on profits from the sale of stocks, real estate and other assets.
Studies by the Treasury Department found that about two-thirds of the benefits of the House and Senate measures would go to the wealthiest 20 percent of taxpayers. But Republicans say that the tax cuts should be concentrated on those people who pay most of the taxes, and that their plan is not skewed to the wealthy in any case.
Because of Mr. Clinton's veiled threats to veto the tax legislation if it is not changed, Republican leaders have agreed to give the Administration a seat at the table.

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
Venture Capital Meeting

BYLINE: By DAVID W. CHEN 

 BODY:
More than 400 people attended the first day of the two-day New York City Venture Capital Conference yesterday to hear business pitches, discuss trends in venture capital financing and mull the state of New York's new-media industry.
The attendance eclipsed the two-day total from last year's inaugural conference, which had 280 delegates. There has been a growing interest in New York as a hub of new-media and Internet-related companies: for example, the amount of money invested in New York City software, electronics and multimedia companies jumped 125 percent, to $111.3 million in 1996 from $49.5 million in 1995, according to a survey conducted earlier this year by Coopers & Lybrand, the accounting and consulting firm. 
 The conference had been proposed by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, said Charles Millard, president of the New York City Economic Development Corporation, one of the conference's organizers. And Mr. Giuliani opened the proceedings with a speech telling the delegates that New York had become much more friendly to business under his leadership.
Other sponsors were Coopers & Lybrand, the Prospect Street Investment Management Company, Strategic Research Institute and Brobeck, Phleger & Harrison. The conference continues today at the New York Hilton in Manhattan.
 DAVID W. CHEN

HEADLINE: Senate, in a Rebuff to Clinton, Votes to Delay Base Closings

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 9

 BODY:
Casting doubt on the future of the military base-closing process, the Senate voted overwhelmingly tonight to delay the next two rounds of closings until the Government could study the economic effects of past and future shutdowns.
By voting as it did, the Senate ignored the wishes of President Clinton and military leaders who have argued that the closings -- of bases still to be determined -- were central to their efforts to pare the Defense Department budget and allow military officials to shift money from base operations to weapons systems. 
 Some members of Congress saw the lopsided 66-to-33 vote as an ominous sign that legislators were no longer willing to endure the political pain for themselves and the economic pain for their constituents that the base closings have sometimes caused.
The vote was also an expression of the doubts among many lawmakers that the closings were achieving the kinds of savings that the Pentagon and the White House had projected.
The Senate took its stand by approving an amendment blocking the Defense Department from conducting two more rounds of base closings that were scheduled for 1999 and 2001.
Clearly hoping to win the support of many of his colleagues, Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the Republican majority leader, distributed a state-by-state list just before the vote of military installations that might be shutdown in either of the next two rounds.
"I just want to ask my colleagues, whether they be from California or Connecticut or Georgia or Minnesota or my own state or any other state, take a look at what is on this list," Mr. Lott said from the floor of the Senate.
"Think of what you have already been through, and think of the impact it would have on the military if some of these facilities should be threatened once again with being closed. Do you want that?"
The amendment, which is part of the military authorization bill for 1998 that the Senate began debating on Monday, would not save those bases that had previously been approved for closing.
The House of Representatives, on June 25, took what amounted to the same action when it passed its version of the military bill, which also excluded authorization for future base closings.
The Clinton Administration had lobbied for the base closings and the Joint Chiefs of Staff had backed the idea, too, saying that it would free billions of dollars in savings that could go toward improving weapons systems.
An amendment sponsored by Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, and Senator Carl Levin, Democrat of Michigan, would have authorized the 1999 and 2001 base closings.
But that plan was derailed by Senator Byron L. Dorgan, a North Dakota Democrat who with the backing of the Senate's top leadership -- Mr. Lott and Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the minority leader -- successfully offered a substitute amendment that blocked the action.
But the opponents in the Senate of the next round of base closings cited a recent Government Accounting Office report that concluded that the Defense Department "cannot provide accurate information on actual savings."
Using that as the basis of his argument, Mr. Dorgan proposed that the next scheduled base closings be delayed until the Pentagon had time to develop "accounting techniques" to accurately measure the costs and savings from previous and future rounds of base closings.
The Pentagon is also instructed to prepare a report, which must be reviewed by both the Government Accounting Office and the Congressional Budget Office and submitted to Congress.
The amendment set no specific date for completion of that work, only specifying that the Pentagon must submit its report to Congress "in a timely manner" so that the lawmakers will have adequate time to consider whether to authorize a round of base closings in 2001.
Base closings have been a highly politicized issue since Congress created the Base Realignment and Closure Commission, and both sides in the debate today focused on that fact.
"It's always difficult to close bases,"Senator Levin said. "But we've made a politically tough decision even tougher."
But Senator Lott argued that the base-closing process was flawed from the start.
"I have always been opposed to this approach," he said just before the vote. "It is one more example of Congress not being able to deal with the tough issues of what we need in terms of facilities in this country and passing the tough decisions off to others, in this case the commission."
A spokesman for the Defense Department said Defense Secretary William S. Cohen was disappointed with today's vote.
"The Secretary believes we must cut unneeded bases if we are to have the funds for modernization of weapons systems in the coming years," said the spokesman, Capt. Michael Doubleday. "We will continue to work with the Congress on this extremely important issue."
Mr. Levin said several factors worked against the Administration and supporters of base closings, including President Clinton's own political posturing on the issue.
Under the base-closing procedure, the President must either accept or reject the full list of targeted sites. He cannot modify the list.
But in 1995, the year before his re-election bid, Mr. Clinton tried to reverse the expected loss of thousands of jobs from the base closings ordered for two large Air Force maintenance centers in California and Texas, both states rich in electoral votes.
Mr. Clinton proposed a plan to save the jobs -- at Kelly Air Force Base in Sacramento, Calif., and McClellan Air Force Base in San Antonio -- by converting them to private sector jobs under a program known as "privatization in place."
"That's not privatization in place," Senator Don Nickles of Oklahoma, the Republican majority whip and Mr. Lott's second-in-command, railed today. "That's electoral politics. It's a real shame that he introduced electoral politics in the base closure process." 

CORRECTION-DATE: July 12, 1997, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about a Senate vote to delay military base closings transposed the locations of two bases in some copies. Kelly Air Force Base is in San Antonio; McClellan Air Force Base is in Sacramento, Calif.

HEADLINE: $25 and Under

BYLINE: By Eric Asimov 

 BODY:
For anybody wearied by the heavy, gloppy fare served at many Chinese takeout mills, Wu Liang Ye may reawaken the dormant appreciation of Chinese food.
Wu Liang Ye is part of a restaurant chain in China with three branches in Manhattan: this one on East 86th Street, another at 338 Lexington Avenue near 39th Street and the third at 36 West 48th Street. Each is slightly different in menu and atmosphere, but all specialize in lively, robust and even delicate Sichuan dishes that are notable for their freshness and meticulous preparation. 
 Cold noodles with spicy sesame sauce is one of those signature Sichuan dishes that New Yorkers fell in love with before it degenerated into a tasteless takeout disaster, prepared hours in advance and kept refrigerated in its container until given away as an enticement. Wu Liang Ye's version ($3.25) offers an opportunity to retaste this dish; the noodles firm, not gummy, the sauce nutty and sweet, not cloying, and spicy enough to set the mouth aglow. It's like tasting farm-fresh eggs after years of the store-bought variety.
Incidentally, Wu Liang Ye is not blind to the economics of home delivery; it has a takeout menu, complete with cold noodle incentives. I can't say how the food tastes at home, but the restaurant has not allowed the takeout market to govern its dining room.
The noodles set the tone for other dishes. Sliced conch with spicy red oil ($5.95) is delicious but unusual. The conch is firm and chewy, almost the texture of pig's ears, but nutty and appealing. A fragrant broth with chunks of firm, white fish, tiny white mushrooms and pickled cabbage ($6.95) is filling enough to be a meal itself.
I tried four kinds of dumpling; each was excellent. Crystal seafood and asparagus ($3.75) is a lovely combination, cool and savory, served in a little triangular packet. Crystal shrimp dumplings ($3.95), as fragile as roses, go perfectly with the soy-and-vinegar dipping sauce. Steamed pork dumplings in red-hot oil ($2.95) are as delicate as daisies folded in half, while steamed seafood dumplings ($4.50) are light and thin skinned.
The stars of the main courses are shredded tea-smoked duck with ginger ($13.25), offering a marvelous contrast between the lively ginger and the slightly smoky, dry meat and crisp skin, and double-cooked fresh bacon in chili sauce ($7.95), slices of reddish pork resembling Canadian bacon that have been both simmered and braised, offering another contrast between the rich pork and the peppery sauce. Bean curd with spicy sauce ($6.95) is a huge bowl of food, the cubes of tofu served in a sauce full of caramelized garlic, ginger, minced pork and pepper. Not every dish was so inspiring. Chicken with garlic sauce ($7.50) was well prepared but routinely flavored.
Service is swift and pleasant. The dining room itself is plain, with a mirror around the circumference serving as the main decoration. That's O.K. The focus here is food, and it certainly beats sitting at home eating starch and grease from cartons.

Wu Liang Ye
 
215 East 86th Street, Yorkville, (212) 534-8899.
 
Best dishes: Cold noodles with sesame sauce, sliced conch, soup with fish fillets and pickled cabbage, crystal seafood and asparagus dumplings, crystal shrimp dumplings, steamed pork dumplings in hot oil, steamed seafood dumplings, tea-smoked duck with ginger, double-cooked fresh bacon with chili sauce, chef's bean curd with spicy sauce.

HEADLINE: Still a Race for Mayor

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Contrary to Gail Collins's conclusion that I want to "concede the mayor's race" (Editorial Notebook, July 10), my opinion, often stated, is that the mayor's race will narrow dramatically after the September primary and that the Democratic nominee has a very good chance to win. 
 Ruth Messinger is only 10 points behind Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani in current polls, about where Mr. Giuliani was at this time in the 1993 contest with Mayor David N. Dinkins.
The facts are compelling. According to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, there are 30,000 more unemployed New Yorkers today than a year ago, and our unemployment rate is now twice the national average. The quality of public education has deteriorated while school violence has escalated. This is the real record of Mr. Giuliani, which the upcoming campaign will reveal.
 
JUDITH HOPE
Chairwoman, New York State
Democratic Committee
New York, July 10, 1997

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Germans Back a Strong Mark, And Dollar Is Mostly Weaker

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar ended mostly weaker yesterday after top Bundesbank officials surprised the currency market by calling for a strong mark and Britain's central bank increased interest rates.
The remarks by Hans Tietmeyer, the president of the Bundesbank, and Franz-Christoph Zeitler, a member of the central bank's policy-making council, caught traders off guard because they had expected the mark to continue weakening. Many scrambled to buy the currency afterward. 
 The mark had been hitting a series of three-and-a-half-year lows against the dollar and six-year lows against the pound for the last few weeks, with no signs of discontent from the Bundesbank.
"The Bundesbank's been real quiet," said John McCarthy, senior vice president for foreign exchange at ING Capital Markets in New York. "So this caught the market a little bit by surprise. It certainly took the steam out of the dollar for the time being."
The Bank of England's decision to raise its base lending rate by a quarter percentage point, to 6.75 percent, had been widely expected and initially caused a flurry of pound selling by traders who wanted to secure profits from the currency's strength.
But the pound quickly strengthened again on speculation that the British central bank was likely to raise rates in a gradual series of small increases to thwart inflationary pressure in Britain's economy.
The dollar traded as low as 1.7461 marks before settling at 1.7515 marks in New York, down from 1.7599 marks Wednesday. The pound rose to $1.6886 from $1.6880.
The mark's strength against the yen indirectly helped the dollar end higher against the Japanese currency. The dollar traded at 113.18 yen in New York, up from 112.77 yen.
The comments by Mr. Tietmeyer and Mr. Zeitler at a Bundesbank conference in Aschau, Germany, quickly overshadowed the Bank of England's interest rate decision.
Mr. Tietmeyer stressed what he called the importance of mark strength leading up to Europe's monetary union in January 1999.
Mr. Zeitler reiterated the Bundesbank's desire for a strong mark and said the dollar's recovery from postwar lows against the mark two years ago had been corrected.

HEADLINE: Jobless Claims Shoot Up

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 10

 BODY:
The number of American workers filing first-time claims for jobless benefits shot up by 40,000 last week to the highest level in more than a year. Much of the increase may have been caused by the closing of automobile plants for annual retooling, a Labor Department official said today. New applications for unemployment insurance totaled a seasonally adjusted 377,000, highest since 403,000 in the week that ended on March 30, 1996. The jump was the largest since a 44,000 advance in the week that ended on March 23, 1996. Many analysts had expected a rise of only 2,000. The four-week average of new weekly jobless claims rose 9,500, to 348,500.

HEADLINE: Salinas: Plenty of Smoke, No Smoking Gun

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
More than a year after Carlos Salinas de Gortari left Mexico's presidency, a secret Central Intelligence Agency report assured American officials that there was no hard evidence linking him to the scandals that had soiled his administration.
"We do not at this time have a 'smoking gun' that implicates former Mexican President Carlos Salinas de Gortari in influence-peddling and graft," the document began. 
 But in its next breath, the C.I.A. assessment, dated Dec. 27, 1995, raised serious doubts about the integrity of the Harvard-trained economist whom Washington had once hailed as the beacon of a new political generation in Latin America.
"Circumstances and fragmentary reporting strongly suggest such involvement," the report continued, referring to Mr. Salinas's possible participation as President in the corrupt activities of his relatives and aides.
Caution in such appraisals is nothing new. But in recent years, as the character of Mexican politicians become an important issue in Washington, American officials say reports on the subject have often raised ambiguity to an art form.
The C.I.A. report, a copy of which was made available to a reporter, includes some intriguing allegations. But even in its details, the document underscores the limited effort American intelligence officers seem to have made to sort out such accusations.
The former Mexican President has never been charged with any crime and denies knowing anything of the misdeeds with which his elder brother has been charged.
Mr. Salinas did not return telephone calls today.
The C.I.A. report does not delve into those issues in detail. Rather, it synthesizes what several American officials described as a typical mix of assertions by confidential informants and circumstantial evidence.
"A very few intelligence reports, from sources of varying reliability, link former President Salinas to illegal activities, although none ties him directly to narcotics trafficking," the document states. "Salinas's hands-on approach to governing during his tenure as President makes it unlikely that he had no knowledge of his brother's affairs or the shady dealings of other close associates."
The report goes on to recount a series of charges:
*An informant of "undetermined reliability" had reported that before the sale of Government-owned banks by Mr. Salinas's administration in 1990, Raul Salinas and other members of the President's family used inside information to invest heavily in financial instruments that later jumped in value.
*During the race leading up the election of his successor in 1994, Carlos Salinas pressured the campaign of his own party's candidate, Ernesto Zedillo, "into hiring Ana Paola Gerard -- who was widely rumored to be his mistress -- at an exorbitant salary."
*An investigation into "alleged narcotics links of former Agriculture Secretary Carlos Hank Gonzalez highlighted a relationship, which Zedillo's investigators felt cast suspicion upon the former administration, between Hank, Carlos Salinas and another prominent family suspected of laundering drug money." The report attributes the information to the intelligence service of another foreign government.
When such charges reached the C.I.A. is unclear. But there is little indication that American intelligence officers made much of an effort to determine their veracity.
By the time that agency officials compiled the report, for example, the relationship between Carlos Salinas and Ms. Gerard was more than a rumor. Ms. Gerard, 36, a former presidential aide, was about to give birth to Mr. Salinas's daughter.
