HEADLINE: When Electricity Goes Private;
Deregulation May Change New York Power Authority

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS 

 BODY:
NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y.
Just four miles downstream from the oohs and aahs of Horseshoe Falls is a man-made wonder that never draws a throng of tourists -- the Robert Moses Niagara hydroelectric power plant.
Every second, 253,000 cubic feet of water are delivered to the plant by giant tunnels. The water then plunges hundreds of feet through 13 conduits, spinning giant turbines that turn out 2,400 megawatts of electricity in peak periods -- about 10 percent of New York's total. 
 As spectacular as it is, the Niagara plant is only one piece of an intricate network of plants and transmission lines operated by the New York Power Authority, a wonder in its own right that dates back to the Depression era. By the early 1950's, the public agency was generating and delivering low-cost electricity across the state. Today, it provides crucial relief to companies struggling to stay in business and helps scores of municipal electric systems keep their costs down. In New York City, for example, the authority supplies the power for most public buildings, street lights and the subways.
Now, though, as the state's utility industry braces for deregulation, a debate is breaking out over the agency's role -- whether it should change or whether the power authority should have a role at all.
It is a debate being played out, too, at similar agencies in many states and at such huge Federal power systems as the Tennessee Valley Authority and the Bonneville Power Administration in Oregon. The issue, in short, is what should become of government-owned utilities in an era when free markets are all the rage.
In New York, private utility companies want the role of the power authority -- the biggest such agency in any state -- to change radically. When deregulation opens the state's doors to outside utility companies, possibly as early as next year, and consumers get to pick among suppliers, market forces will come into play for the first time. A continued large role for the power authority, which supplies a fourth of the electricity in the state and owns 35 percent of the high-voltage transmission lines, would only distort that market, the utilities contend. They point to the artificially low rates the agency provides and the advantages it enjoys, including low-cost financing and an exemption from taxes.
But others, including many who work for companies that get their power from the agency, say it will always be needed to keep parts of the state's economic landscape from withering.
"If it weren't for the authority, this wouldn't be here," said Mark Young, the director of energy for Praxair, a producer of industrial gases, walking recently through one of the company's plants in a decaying industrial area along the Niagara River.
Praxair uses vast amounts of electricity, which it gets from the power authority for a fraction of what private utilities charge. The low-cost power has helped Praxair keep 1,500 jobs in the area, Mr. Young said.
Gov. George E. Pataki, the State Legislature and the New York Public Service Commission are just starting to grapple with the particulars of the authority's future. It is clearly going to be a daunting job.
The goal is to find the right fit for the huge and largely independent agency in what will be a remarkably different industry. New York's seven privately owned utilities, which until now have been restricted to their own corners of the state, will soon be able to do business in other parts of New York and in other states. At the same time, utilities and hundreds of other energy marketers will be pouring in from out of state.
Making things particularly complicated is the fact that the power authority sells and delivers electricity to three upstate utilities even as it competes with them for customers. The three -- Niagara Mohawk Power, New York State Electric and Gas and Rochester Gas and Electric -- resell the power without a profit to some rural customers.
"Sorting out the various roles that the authority has played as supplier, competitor, regulator and partner is a very complex and intricate process," said Gary J. Lavine, senior vice president of legal and corporate relations at Niagara Mohawk.
Beyond these roles, politicians have often called upon the authority during energy emergencies. For example, it helped to shore up the finances of Con Edison in the mid-1970's by acquiring and completing two plants.
As regulators, politicians and the utilities struggle to find common ground regarding the agency's fate, difficult questions about the deregulation process are being exposed, and delays in the transition to full competition appear to be very likely.
"It's going to be very difficult to create a level playing field," said John F. O'Mara, the chairman of the Public Service Commission, which will oversee the transition.
"There are speed bumps that are going to be tough," added Clarence D. Rappleyea, the power authority's chairman and chief executive.
The debate has already made for strange bedfellows in Albany.
Some powerful Republicans, who generally call for shrinking government, want to make sure that the agency's role as a catalyst for economic development is protected. Many of the agency's biggest such efforts have been upstate, a largely Republican stronghold.
For their part, some Democrats, who usually oppose privatization, want large parts of the agency to be sold off, using the proceeds of perhaps $2 billion to help utilities get out from under certain high overhead costs and lead eventually to reduced rates for residential customers.
Various scenarios have arisen.
Because the authority already owns a third of the state's transmission system, it has argued that it would be a natural candidate to take over the rest, a position that has won some support from Republicans.
In running the system, the agency would make sure that any party wanting to sell or buy power would have fair and open access to the transmission grid, Mr. Rappleyea said. But to operate the grid as a neutral party, the authority would have to spin off its generating plants, some industry experts said.
Besides the hydroelectric marvel near Niagara Falls, these include two nuclear plants: the James A. FitzPatrick, on Lake Ontario near Oswego, and Indian Point 3, in northern Westchester County. The properties, especially the Niagara plant, would presumably be attractive to big new players coming into the state, including the Enron Corporation of Houston and the Southern Company of Atlanta.
But Mr. Rappleyea and Mr. O'Mara, both appointees of Governor Pataki, say that it makes little sense to sell off plants that produce some of the lowest-cost power in the state when the goal of deregulation is to reduce rates. The Niagara plant is so valuable to economic development, Mr. O'Mara contends, that a separate public agency should be created to keep it in the state's hands.
Others are not sure that the authority -- or a version of it -- can remain a force under deregulation.
"It's awfully hard to figure out how the authority participates in what is supposed to be a fully competitive market," said Harvey Shapiro, the president of the Energy Association of New York State, the trade and lobbying group for the state's private utilities. "You really can't have a tax-subsidized entity as a competitor."
Larry Shapiro, the senior lawyer for the New York Public Interest Research Group, a consumer advocacy organization, said that if the private utilities were forced to truly compete, and rates were reduced for all customers, then the agency's role could be sharply cut back.
"The way to make this take place is largely by dismantling the power authority," he added.
For now, at least, the authority certainly has an edge. Niagara Mohawk, for instance, charges the average industrial customer 9.1 cents a kilowatt-hour. The power authority charges 4 cents or less a kilowatt-hour to its newer customers, who qualify for assistance by showing they are in danger of closing a plant or cutting back sharply and who guarantee to keep a certain number of jobs. But those who signed on years ago, under statutory provisions for cheap power for certain industries, are paying just a little more than a penny.
Those numbers explain why the agency is attractive to consumers and distressing to utilities.
Both sides of this two-edged sword became evident in a recent conflict between the authority and Niagara Mohawk, which has seen many of its industrial customers leave its system to lower their rates.
Caught in the middle was Patrick Lemaire, whose family has built an empire of paper mills in Canada. Mr. Lemaire has spent the last 10 years and $35 million from his parent company, Cascades Inc. of Quebec, to revive a mill here in one of the buildings that used to house mills of the Kimberly-Clark Corporation. As recently as the 1950's, 38,000 workers were employed in those buildings and the nearby operations of other companies.
But rising labor costs, taxes and electric rates resulted in wide-scale closings and cutbacks. Only 6,800 workers remain in the area, which is littered with crumbling buildings.
In this grim landscape, Mr. Lemaire's Cascades Niagara Falls Inc. has been one of the few signs of revival. His mill, which makes cardboard from recycled materials, employs 140 people.
A downturn in demand several years ago, however, forced Mr. Lemaire to find ways to cut costs, particularly of electricity.
Mr. Lemaire tried without success to get relief from Niagara Mohawk. Eventually, the company was accepted as a new customer of the power authority. Mr. Lemaire, who was under pressure from the parent company to consider closing the mill and had already laid off 30 workers, agreed to invest $10 million in the business in return for lower rates.
But then Niagara Mohawk decided to make a stand, refusing to deliver the agency's cheaper power to the mill. It also threatened to cut off 36 other plants in the area that were being supplied by the agency.
The power authority was taking away too many major customers, Niagara Mohawk complained, citing an eroding revenue base that was threatening its solvency.
Under the prodding of Governor Pataki and Mr. O'Mara, the two sides reached a compromise. Niagara Mohawk agreed to deliver the cheaper electricity, and the authority promised to make up some of the revenue lost by the utility if more companies quit its system.
Mr. Lemaire is counting on the cheap power for years to come.
"The millions we were giving away for expensive power," he said, "we're putting back in the mill."

HEADLINE: An Unfettered Internet? Keep Dreaming

BYLINE: By Eli M. Noam; Eli M. Noam is professor of finance and economics at the Columbia Business School and director of its Institute for Tele-Information.

DATELINE: CARMEL, N.Y.

 BODY:
These have been heady days in Washington for that marvelous medium, the Internet. First, the Supreme Court, in Reno v. A.C.L.U., struck down restrictions on indecent content, overturning a law passed virtually unanimously by Congress.
The Clinton Administration had strongly supported those restrictions. But only a week after the Justices ruled, a White House group led by Ira Magaziner issued an equally vigorous opinion that advocated a largely hands-off policy by Government regarding business conducted on the Internet. 
 Is there any consistency here? In a way, yes. Both Administration positions play to the gallery. And just as the defense of regulated morality on the Internet, though popular, proved to be a failure, so will the call for unregulated Internet commerce fail.
This is not because of meddlesome bureaucrats, but because the Internet will become too successful to be treated differently from the rest of society and the rest of the economy. Since the Internet has moved from techie preserve to office park, shopping mall and entertainment arcade, it is sheer fantasy to expect that it will be left a libertarian island in a world full of jealous competitors and conflicting public objectives.
The Internet is not the only priority in any country. The United States, for example, has long worried about crime, Communism and children. That has led it to seek regulatory rules on pornography and encryption, and the wiring of schools for the Internet championed by Vice President Al Gore.
Similarly, Bavaria cares about hate speech and public morality, and sets rules accordingly. For the French, language and culture are the priorities, and Internet services originating in the country must be in French. Singapore worries about order. And so on.
We may disagree with these concerns, but don't we have our own? Most of the White House paper tells state and foreign governments, not Washington, to mend their ways.
For all the rhetoric of an Internet "free trade zone," will the United States readily accept an Internet that includes Thai child pornography, Albanian tele-doctors, Cayman Island tax dodges, Monaco gambling, Nigerian blue sky stock schemes, Cuban mail-order catalogues? Or, for that matter, American violators of privacy, purveyors of junk E-mail or "self-regulating" price-fixers? Unlikely. And other countries will feel the same on matters they care about.
Thus, for better or worse, each society will apply its accumulated wisdom, misconceptions, preferences and interest group muscle to the rules governing transactions over the Internet. And these rules will not be very different from those applied to the rest of society.
It is easy to engage in generalized anti-government rhetoric but hard to remain consistent. The Internet industry, too, has been selective in its libertarianism at home.
It liked subsidies from the Pentagon and National Science Foundation that created the Internet in the first place, and the N.S.F. money that is helping to develop the next-generation Internet II. It fought for regulated cheap access to phone networks. It supports subsidies for school and library Internet access. It exhorts the Federal Government to carry a big stick internationally to protect its software against pirates. Most of this makes sense, but it is not exactly the free market.
Internet enthusiasts have a fallback hope: "You cannot regulate the Internet." The idea is that clever kids can always find a way to run electronic circles around any restriction, so why even try to regulate? The fallacy is to focus on the electronic bits, which indeed are very hard to control.
Communications are a matter not just of signals but of people, institutions and physical hardware; the arm of the law can reach them. A government will go after static and physical elements if it cannot reach mobile or intangible ones.
For example, instead of taxing transactions over the Internet, which will prove difficult and inefficient, a government might tax the physical delivery -- a "U.P.S. tax." Instead of controlling information, it might mandate hardware to do so, like the V-chip in television sets.
It seems that the new medium is like an inkblot test, an electronic blob into which all project their own fantasies, hopes and fears. Traditionalists find the dark forces of degeneracy. Libertarians detect the heavy hand of government. Leftists discover the sharing community, devoid of the material avarice of private business. Internationalists expect the global village.
This kind of dreaming is common for new and fundamental technology, and it is usually wrong. The reality will be more mundane: the Internet will be enormously important, but it will not create a new regulatory system. It's nice to dream of it as a global force of liberation, but it may also have the unintended opposite effect, if more controls are levied on people and property instead of on transactions and information.
The White House, commendably, says all the right things. But if we watch what it does to its own sacred cows, not what it tells others to do, we should not expect a deregulatory revolution.

HEADLINE: NATO Action Reflects Shift In Tactics

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 10

 BODY:
Planning began weeks ago for the British military operation that led to the arrest of a Bosnian Serb war-crimes suspect and the killing of another, marking an important shift in NATO strategy, prompted in part by the new British Labor Government of Prime Minister Tony Blair, American and British officials said.
Today's action, executed under NATO command and with American logistical and intelligence support, follows a year of adamant opposition by United States officials to the use of NATO troops to pursue war-crimes suspects. It is a sign of the new aggressiveness in carrying out the mandate of the troops in Bosnia that Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright insisted on, despite the Pentagon's reluctance. 
 Both Mr. Blair and President Clinton approved today's operation. British officials said the arrests "were the first ones, but not the last ones." One of the two men, Simo Drljaca, was killed after he fired a pistol at a British soldier.
But today's actions also represented another important change, officials said. Previously, NATO commanders have been reluctant to put their forces at risk by moving to arrest indicted war criminals, some of whom are heavily guarded.
But the British, who first deployed troops in Bosnia five years ago, have been more willing than most countries to take strong action. Britain, the second-largest contributor to the peacekeeping force -- the United States has 7,800 troops -- brought in special forces to reinforce its 5,300 peacekeepers.
Today's action might not have occurred if Gen. George Joulwan, overall NATO commander, were not leaving his post, senior NATO officials in Brussels said today. His successor, Gen. Wesley Clark, the chief military aide to the Bosnia peace negotiations, was officially sworn in today in Stuttgart.
General Joulwan has been adamantly opposed to the idea of peacekeepers trying to arrest war criminals. Gen. John Shalikashvili, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, by contrast, said on Wednesday: "For the Dayton Agreement to have a good chance, the international community will have to come to grips with the necessity of bringing war criminals to justice in The Hague."
He promised to "make every day count" before American troops are scheduled to withdraw from Bosnia in July 1998.
Officials said planning for today's operation began in earnest shortly after Britain and the United States both reviewed their Bosnia policies in May, and allied Governments began discussing how to arrest at least some war criminals, fearing that the whole effort in Bosnia could founder otherwise.
Both of the men who were sought today had been indicted secretly in March by the war-crimes tribunal.
While American officials insisted that today's operation represented no change in the formal mandate of NATO-led troops, they also said that Mr. Clinton's language on the issue had hardened on Wednesday in his news conference in Madrid.
"Our mandate is to arrest people who have been accused of war crimes and turn them over for trial," Mr. Clinton said, "if that can be done in the course of fulfilling our other duties and if commanders on the ground believe the risk is appropriate."
One senior American official said, "That is a more robust statement and this is a more robust action today. The authority has always been there in the mandate, but the willingness to exercise it has changed."
A senior British official said: "There is a deep commitment, certainly, in the new British Government, to bring these people to justice."
But senior American officials admitted that the sealed indictments do not address the question of how to arrest the most prominent, infamous and public targets like the former Bosnian Serb leader, Radovan Karadzic, and the military commander, Gen. Ratko Mladic.
An American official said that today's action, coupled with efforts to isolate the parties diplomatically and economically, would increase pressure on other suspects.
While there seems to be no immediate plan or intention to seize more prominent suspects, the Clinton Administration hopes political leaders in the Serbian republic within Bosnia will turn over suspects and, more generally, cooperate with the Dayton accords, the official said.
"What it's doing is putting the bad guys on the run," the official said.
Mr. Clinton was alerted on Wednesday while in Madrid that the arrests might happen today, and he and his aides were contacted on Air Force One by General Shalikashvili to tell them what had occurred.

HEADLINE: U.S. to Report To Congress Nafta Benefits Are Modest

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 10

 BODY:
Four years after a bitterly divisive debate over how a free-trade pact with Mexico and Canada would affect American workers, the Clinton Administration will report to Congress on Friday that the North American Free Trade Agreement has so far generated modest benefits for the United States.
The report provides ammunition to both supporters and critics of the trade pact, and is unlikely to defuse the coming debate over the Administration's plan to extend free trade throughout the hemisphere. 
 "The facts point to only one conclusion: Nafta hasn't measured up," said Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the Democratic leader in the House and one of the most insistent critics of the agreement. "Before we proceed with further trade negotiations we need to insure that trade results in real progress for the broadest cross section of people."
The Administration report, the White House's first formal assessment of the trade agreement since it went into effect in January 1994, said exporters in many industries like textiles, transportation equipment and electronics had benefited from the reduction in Mexican tariffs and that the direct benefits to the American economy would mount over time.
The report said that the pact stimulated greater exports to Mexico, despite the deep financial crisis that engulfed Mexico in 1995 and turned a small American trade surplus with the country into a deficit that reached $17.5 billion last year.
The pact also increased United States exports to Canada during the last three years, the report said, although the trade deficit with Canada doubled from 1993 to 1996, to $21.7 billion, because of a surge of imports from that country.
But the Administration, which fought hard for approval of the pact despite strong opposition from labor unions, environmentalists and other Democratic constituencies, found only sketchy evidence that the agreement had helped American workers.
The Administration said studies it commissioned suggested that 90,000 to 160,000 American jobs relied on increased exports to Mexico that have come as a result of the pact.
The report did not provide -- or even try to provide -- a precise accounting of how many American jobs might have been lost as companies moved manufacturing to Mexico to take advantage of lower wages there. Official said there were largely unsolvable problems in generating an accurate estimate of job losses. But the report said the number of people whose jobs were lost to Canada or Mexico was probably somewhere between 32,000, the number of those who applied for unemployment and retraining benefits under Government programs for workers displaced by changing trade patterns with those countries and nearly 100,000, those who were certified by the Government as eligible for those programs, which often cover workers not directly affected by Nafta.
While the Administration reiterated its long-held position that export-oriented jobs paid better than the national average for production workers, the report did not directly address whether the new jobs were better paying than those lost as companies shifted employment to take advantage of the new trade rules.
The trade agreement "has made a modest positive contribution to the U.S. economy in terms of net exports, G.D.P., employment and investment," said the report, which the Administration is required to submit to Congress.
While upbeat about the long-term outlook for the trade pact, the Administration report largely avoided the kinds of sweeping claims made on its behalf in 1993 when President Clinton rallied support over the intense opposition of critics who contended that free trade with Mexico would send jobs streaming south of the border. Supporters argued at the time that the agreement would create hundreds of thousands of jobs even after accounting for jobs lost; critics said the effect would be precisely the reverse.
The Administration's conclusions are largely in line with those of the last major study of Nafta, issued last year by researchers at the University of California at Los Angeles. The U.C.L.A. study found that the trade pact's effect on employment in the United States was probably a "moderately positive number."
But critics of Nafta, including unions, industries subject to greater competition and environmental watchdogs, continue to argue that the pact has been harmful to American interests and that it is a flawed model for the Administration's plans to extend free-trade agreements throughout the hemisphere.
"Wages and living standards have seen downward pressure in all three countries, and workers' rights and bargaining power have been weakened," said a report issued recently by a coalition of opponents of the pact.
"For the average citizen of any of the three signatory countries, Nafta has been a failure," said the opponents' study, which was compiled in anticipation of the Administration's report by groups including the labor-backed Economic Policy Institute, the International Labor Rights Fund, Public Citizen's Global Trade Watch and the Sierra Club.
The Administration said a study commissioned from DRI/McGraw Hill, the economic consulting firm, found that exports to Mexico from the United States last year were $12 billion higher than they would have been without Nafta, after factoring out the effects of the Mexican economic crisis of 1995. The corresponding increase in imports from Mexico because of the trade pact was $5 billion, the study found.
The Administration also cited a study by the Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas that found a $7 billion increase in American exports attributable to Nafta, and a $4 billion increase in imports.
The report said that based on figures from the first four months of the year, Mexico would likely pass Japan to become the nation's No. 2 trading partner, behind Canada.
The report said tariff reductions and other market-opening steps would be phased in over the next 12 years, so it might be too early to assess the accord's full impact.
It said that the short-run effect was to increase United States gross domestic product by $13 billion last year, a small amount in an $8 trillion economy. Gains could increase to $40 billion a year in the long run, it said.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Makers of Oil-Drilling Gear Agree to a Combination
Reading & Bates and Falcon Drilling, two of the world's largest suppliers of oil drilling rigs and other equipment, said that they were merging in a stock deal. 
 Reading & Bates said the merger would create the world's largest fleet of ships that drill for oil in deep water, and the deal comes as demand for such ships is surging amid discoveries of large fields of oil in the deep water of the Gulf of Mexico. The new company would have a market value of $5 billion. [Page D16.]
 
Fund Assets Top $4 Trillion
Assets in stock, bond and money market mutual funds topped $4 trillion in June for the first time. About $18 billion in new cash flowed into stock funds, and for the first six months of the year a total of $111 billion was added to such funds. Market Place. [D4.]
 
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 44.33 points, closing at 7,886.76, as investors continued to buy on dips in prices after Wednesday's plunge of 119.88 points. [D5.]
 
Treasury securities were little changed. The yield on the 30-year bond remained at 6.56 percent. [D14.]
 
Markdowns Lift Retailers' Sales
The arrival of a heat wave lifted apparel sales and helped retailers report strong sales for June. The results, however, were achieved in part because of heavy discounting after a weak spring. [D2.]
 
J. P. Morgan Earnings Lower
Lower revenue from bond trading cut quarterly earnings at J. P. Morgan by 15 percent, but revenues rose 1.7 percent. At First Union, the big commercial bank in Charlotte, N.C., growth in fee income at the capital markets group sent profit up 11 percent. [D2.]
 
Compaq Profit Up, but Stock Falls
Compaq reported earnings that beat estimates, and announced the first in what it said would be a series of price cuts. But apparently the results were not strong enough: The stock fell after its recent run-up. [D2.]
 
Diet Centers Reconsider Drugs
Some diet centers that had hoped that prescription diet pills would provide a quick fix for their sagging sales are reconsidering their positions on dispensing the medications after a combination of two such drugs was linked to a rare heart ailment. [D2.]
 
Supercomputer Controls Rejected
The Senate rejected a proposal to tighten control of the sale of supercomputers to China and Russia and instead voted for further study. There has been lively debate over the issue because of disclosures that Chinese and Russian nuclear weapon facilities have acquired American supercomputers without Federal licenses. [A9.]
 
Screening Out Sex and Violence
Starting in October, the most extensive system yet to alert television viewers to violent or sexual content will be in place, and a year or so later, watchers will be able to buy sets that at the touch of a button can screen out any shows deemed objectionable. [A1.]
 
Rate Cuts Seen at Niagara Mohawk
Customers of Niagara Mohawk Power, the New York State electric utility, could have reduced rates by early next year as a result of an agreement the utility reached that allows it to renegotiate its high-cost contracts for electricity with most of its independent power producers. [B5.]
 
Tapes May Have Been Altered
Parts of tape recordings in a Texaco race discrimination case may have been erased, Federal prosecutors said. [D2.]
 
Palladium Down as Supply Grows
Palladium prices fell 4 percent after Russian exports resumed for the first time this year, ending an impasse that depleted stockpiles and sent prices to 17-year highs. [D11.]

HEADLINE: NYC;
'77 Blackout: The Heart Of Darkness

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN 

 BODY:
MANY New Yorkers, possibly most by now, are too young or too new in town to remember the night when the light went out in the soul of the city. It was 20 years ago this weekend, a time when some were getting ready to say Kaddish for New York. What else do you do before burying someone except recite the Jewish prayer for the dead?
On the night of July 13, 1977, the power failed across the city for the second time in 12 years. The two blackouts, however, could not have been more different. The one in November 1965 is recalled with affection, a gentle moment when New Yorkers lived up to their self-image as a tribe that makes triumphs of adversity. 
 July 1977 was the heart of darkness.
Within minutes, ordinary people who had been sitting on stoops turned into raging mobs in one neighborhood after another, from Tremont Avenue in the Bronx to Jamaica, Queens. They looted hundreds of stores, carting off anything they could grab with two hands. They set fires. For the devastated Bushwick section of Brooklyn, this was but a prelude to weeks of repeated arson. The craziness was so widespread that 4,000 people were arrested in the blackout, which lasted 25 hours in some areas.
It was a summer when it truly looked as though New York might have had it. A deranged serial killer known as Son of Sam filled people with terror. A fiscal crisis tore away relentlessly at city services. And now rioters, warped by greed and unfocused anger, were ripping apart their own neighborhoods.
"We are without God now," a priest told worshipers at the time at St. Barbara's Roman Catholic Church in Bushwick.
THE aim here, though, is not to journey down a dark branch of memory lane, but to celebrate New York's remarkable ability to restore its soul.
As terrible as that summer was, the city did not die. In many respects it is now far stronger, the result of political will, beneficial immigration and raw grit on the part of veteran residents. Just as obviously, big problems have not disappeared. And given stubborn poverty and an unemployment rate that is twice the national rate, who can say that New York is more than a flick of a Con Edison switch from fresh chaos?
Bushwick is a good place to see both the grimness and the hope.
No one will mistake that northern Brooklyn enclave for paradise. Easily one-third of its 100,000 people are on welfare, or at least they were before the new Federal law began hacking away at the rolls. Drugs are a persistent problem, as is unemployment. Shuttered stores, boarded-up apartment windows and garbage-strewn lots testify to the failure of Broadway, Bushwick's main commercial street, to bounce back fully.
"It just hasn't recouped from that blackout," said Eli Bey, a construction worker. "It's taken 20 years for businesses to start up again."
STILL, new businesses are there, like the discount store and a Dunkin' Donuts that went up a few months ago on Broadway, near Lexington Avenue.
Though many of them are still unoccupied, new two-family houses dot nearby Grove, Menahan and Bleecker Streets. Hope Gardens, a Housing Authority apartment complex built alongside old wood-frame row houses, is distinctive for its three-story buildings and is regarded by many as a gem of low-density development. Plans are on the boards for dozens more apartments, variously financed by private builders, the city and the office of the Brooklyn Borough President.
In the 1970's, Bushwick lost 45,000 residents and more than 10,000 housing units. That hemorrhaging has been stopped and partly reversed. The local police precinct headquarters, the 83d, reports that major crimes are down by 40 percent in the last two years.
Msgr. John Powis, the pastor at St. Barbara's for the last eight years, can see the changes, both on the street and from his pulpit. Where 20 years ago the church typically drew 200 worshipers on a Sunday, it now boasts of 1,400. "It's like a proclamation that life can triumph over death," Monsignor Powis said.
Earl Tipton, a letter carrier who lives in Bushwick and delivers its mail, sees attitudes changing, with people increasingly convinced that poverty, however deplorable, is no excuse for rioting. "They're not just thinking about themselves," he said on his route the other day. "They're thinking about their kids and teaching them how to be better people."
So are the bad days banished forever? For all his hopefulness, even Mr. Tipton will not go that far. "If the lights go out," he said with a sigh, "it could be 1977 all over again."

HEADLINE: House G.O.P. Renews Drive To Ban Sampling for Census

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 10

 BODY:
Undaunted by an embarrassing retreat last month, House Republicans revived their effort to ban statistical sampling in the 2000 census today, asserting that the method was an effort by the Clinton Administration to increase the political strength of traditional Democratic voters like blacks and Hispanic Americans.
"Statistical guessing is nothing more than a risky scheme that is ripe for political tampering," said Representative Dennis Hastert, Republican of Illinois, using what has become his party's favorite term for sampling. Mr. Hastert heads the House Government Reform and Oversight subcommittee, which has jurisdiction over the Census Bureau. 
 Statistical sampling allows conclusions to be drawn about a large population without actually contacting each person. It is widely used in public opinion polls, marketing surveys and sociological research, and is used by the Census Bureau to estimate figures like the country's unemployment rate. But the bureau's proposal to use the method for the first time to gauge the country's population and, therefore, to apportion Congressional seats has raised a storm of political and legal fights.
The opening shot in the renewed fight over the issue came today when a subcommittee of the House Appropriations Committee voted to provide the bureau with the $100 million that it needs to finance its normal operations in the next fiscal year, but said none could be spent on sampling.
The subcommittee also voted to prohibit the bureau from spending an additional $282 million that has been appropriated to prepare for the 2000 census until Congress determines what method will be used: an actual head count, or a head count supplemented by sampling.
The total appropriation of $382 million is $27 million more than the Census Bureau has requested. Republican leaders said the additional money should allow the bureau to prepare to conduct a count without sampling.
"What I am trying to say to the Administration is that if you can convince the people's representatives here in the Congress that sampling is the best way to go, the money's there for that," said Representative Harold Rogers, the Kentucky Republican who heads the subcommittee. "If you can't convince the peoples' representatives that that's the best way to go, the money's there for an actual count."
The fight is essentially a reprise of a seemingly arcane issue, but one that has enormous political ramifications. At issue is the Census Bureau's proposal to try to count as many of the country's households as possible through traditional methods like mailed forms, telephone interviews and door-to-door visits. The bureau wants to then count a fraction of the remainder and use that figure to extrapolate for the total population.
Republicans have belittled the method, saying it could subject the census to political manipulation, even though it has been endorsed by outside experts, like the members of the National Academy of Science.
A subtext of the fight over sampling is the fear among some Republican political strategists that it will increase the numbers, and therefore the political strength, of rural residents, blacks, Hispanic Americans and the poor -- groups that for the most part tend to vote Democratic.
Last month, House and Senate leaders attached an amendment banning sampling to a $8.4 billion spending bill that included money to help victims of flooding in California and the Midwest. But the Republicans were forced to withdraw the amendment after President Clinton vetoed the measure and publicly accused them of tying up disaster relief with an extraneous political issue.

HEADLINE: Clinton Cheers Exultant Poles, And Vice Versa

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WARSAW, July 10

 BODY:
Nearly eight years after the fall of Communism, President Clinton celebrated Poland's new ties to the NATO military alliance today, telling a jubilant, flag-waving crowd, "Poland is coming home."
Thousands of people poured into the cobblestoned Castle Square and side streets to catch a glimpse of the American President a day after the conclusion of a NATO summit meeting in Madrid where the Western alliance -- founded to counter the Soviet threat -- invited Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic to join its ranks. 
 "Now Poland is joining NATO," Mr. Clinton called out as the sun broke through early evening clouds to illuminate the waving Polish and Americans flags and a large banner proclaiming, "Thank you America."
"Poland is taking its place in the community of democracies," Mr. Clinton said, a translator relaying his words to the crowd, which broke out repeatedly in delayed applause. "Never again will your fate be decided by others. Never again will the birthright of freedom be denied you. Poland is coming home."
Mr. Clinton's triumphant tour through Warsaw carried enormous emotional resonance in a city where the walls remain pockmarked with bullets, the scars deliberately left untouched as a reminder of the Nazi occupation.
Flanked by Russia and Germany, and overrun repeatedly throughout its history, Poland was invaded from the east and from the west in 1939, when the Soviet Union and Nazi Germany signed a secret pact dismembering the nation.
At Yalta in 1945, in what Poles have long considered the ultimate betrayal by the West, the Soviet Union, the United States and Britain divided Europe into Western and Soviet spheres of influence, putting Poland under Moscow's domination.
"Fifty years ago what we see before us was a sea of ruins," said Aleksander Kwasniewski, the Polish President, himself a former Communist, who spoke before Mr. Clinton's address and who had campaigned hard for Poland's inclusion in NATO. "Before Polish wounds even began to heal, the Iron Curtain fell down, isolating our country."
Mr. Clinton, looking ahead, said, "Now we come here to celebrate history's most precious gift -- a second chance."
It was the end of the cold war and the rapid collapse of the Soviet empire that led NATO to open its doors to create an expanded framework of security and stability for Central European countries that chose the path of democracy and open markets.
And in the streets along Mr. Clinton's motorcade route were signs of just how much Poland has changed since 1989 when a Solidarity activist, Tadeusz Mazowiecki, formed the country's first non-Communist Government in more than 40 years.
Now the Stalin-era Palace of Culture and Science shares the Warsaw skyline with a Marriott hotel, an IKEA furniture store and bright signs advertising Fiat, Sony and Hyundai. The motorcade passed by fast-food restaurants like Burger King and McDonald's and English-language billboards.
The throngs in Castle Square gave a special whoop of welcome for Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright, whose family fled Czechoslovakia when the Communists took power. They cheered as Mr. Clinton ended his address with shouts of "Sto lat!" the traditional Polish toast that means "May you live 100 years." And they cheered again as hundreds of red, white and blue helium balloons were released into the sky.
One appeal from Mr. Clinton, however, drew no applause at all: his call for Poland "to reach out to all of your neighbors, to the East as well as to the West, including the people of Russia."
"You must continue to build in tolerance what others destroyed in hate," Mr. Clinton said.
The NATO alliance has gone out of its way to portray its expansion eastward into the former Warsaw Pact nations as no threat to Russia, saying it is intended to bring stability to Europe in a period when the East-West divide no longer exists. NATO has signed a separate charter with Russia to bring it closer to the alliance and calm its fears of the expansion.
But some of Mr. Clinton's listeners had no doubt that they considered NATO to be insurance against the possibility of a resurgent Russia. Artur Ceran, a 40-year-old economist, was trying to explain how his country would benefit from joining NATO, when Anna Sienkiewicz, 65, a retired engineer, interrupted him to state her view succinctly. "We are farther from the Kremlin," she said. "That's the benefit."
For others it represented inclusion in the West. "I'm happy that we joined NATO -- our first step toward Western culture after 50 years of Communists," said Slavamir Kowzan, 35, who was wearing a shirt emblazoned with the American flag. "Everybody's proud right now to be here at this historic moment."
Poland chose to use the day to showcase figures from the military who will be working with their Western counterparts. Mr. Clinton descended from Air Force One to be greeted by an honor guard of Polish troops who served as part of United Nations forces in Haiti and Bosnia.
At Castle Square he was welcomed by a young Polish officer who studied at the United States Air Force Academy and by Boleslaw Kukielka, a veteran of World War II who fought in an American tank against the Germans as a member of the Polish II Corps.
"We share 200 years of military tradition of fighting for freedom," he told the President.
Before Mr. Clinton spoke, he was welcomed by a beaming Mr. Kwasniewski to the Presidential Palace, the building where the Warsaw Pact was formally created in 1955 and where in 1989 the Communists and Solidarity opposition held the round-table talks that brought Poland back to democracy. Mr. Clinton later attended a dinner in his honor at the palace.
American officials said the two Presidents discussed the progress of Poland's economy, the new Constitution that is being adopted and the tasks that lie ahead for Poland as it modernizes its 230,000-strong armed forces to make them compatible with NATO forces.
Mr. Kwasniewski also made a gracious gesture of national reconciliation, paying tribute at Castle Square to all those he said had furthered the cause of NATO membership for Poland, including Mr. Mazowiecki and Lech Walesa, the Solidarity founder who became the first popularly elected President of Poland in 1990. Mr. Kwasniewski defeated Mr. Walesa in 1995.
Mr. Walesa was sitting in a place of honor in the front row of the audience in Castle Square. He spoke briefly to Mr. Clinton and at one point embraced Senator Barbara Mikulski, a Maryland Democrat of Polish descent who was traveling with the President.
Mr. Clinton, who is to travel to Romania on Friday, vowed to the crowds that NATO's expansion would continue. "Other nations are counting on you to show the contributions new members can make," he said. "You did not walk through NATO's door to see it shut behind you. That door will stay open."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Throngs in Castle Square in Warsaw gave President Clinton an enthusiastic reception before his speech welcoming Poland to closer ties with the West. NATO voted this week to invite Poland to join the alliance. (Associated Press)(pg. A6)
