HEADLINE: Union Plan Sees Buyouts Saving Jobs

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
New York City's largest union of hospital workers has proposed an innovative deal that would use at least $100 million from its pension plan to offer early retirement incentives for older workers as a means of guaranteeing job security for younger ones.
The union, 1199, the National Health and Human Service Employees Union, has made the proposal to Mount Sinai, Columbia-Presbyterian and 28 other nonprofit hospitals because it fears the city's financially squeezed hospitals will make large-scale layoffs when its current contract expires next June 30. 
 "There is no need to lay off the health-care workers who are presently working," said Dennis Rivera, 1199's president. "Our polls show that 10 to 15 percent of our members are either going to retire in the next three years or can be encouraged to retire early, and if that happens we should be able to provide job security to the remaining workers."
The older workers would be offered a lump sum payment of $20,000 to retire early.
Bruce McIver, president of the League of Voluntary Hospitals, the hospitals' bargaining group, appeared receptive to the idea and did not immediately reject it. But he said the hospitals were still studying the proposal and he did not have a "clear sense of how this thing will go."
"The union's big concern is the expiration of the employment security provisions on June 30," he said "But everything in this world has a price."
Mr. McIver said he wanted to make sure the proposal did not take too much money out of the pension plan, forcing the hospitals to contribute more. He emphasized that the union's proposal needed management approval because the pension plan is jointly managed by the hospitals and the union.
The union's current four-year contract gives unusually strong anti-layoff protections to all employees hired before September 1992.
Mr. Rivera, whose union represents 36,000 nurses aides, food workers and others at the 30 hospitals, said health-care experts have said those institutions need to reduce their work force by 5,000 to 10,000 employees to survive in an era when the rise of managed care is squeezing hospitals.
He predicted that 4,000 to 5,000 workers would take advantage of the plan and that that, along with attrition, would make further layoffs unnecessary.
But Mr. McIver said, "This proposal would obviously minimize the need for layoffs to a certain degree, but I don't think it could prevent layoffs."
When 1199 negotiated the current contract three years ago, it agreed to a far smaller version of the same plan, taking $10 million from the pension fund to finance 500 early retirements. In that agreement, the union allowed the hospitals to reduce their contributions to an employee benefits plan because it included millions of dollars of excess contributions.
Harold Loeb of Buck Consultants, a specialist in employee benefit plans, said many companies use pension plan surpluses to encourage employees to take early retirement by offering them more generous pension benefits.
But Mr. Loeb said it was much rarer for companies and unions to agree to take money from overfunded pension plans and use that to finance lump-sum payments as incentives for early retirement.
According to Mr. Rivera, his plan would include more incentives than a $20,000 lump sum. It would provide health insurance for those who take early retirement and, for those who retire early, it would shorten the number of years needed to qualify for a full pension.
Mr. Rivera said, "We have the eighth-largest institutional pension fund in the country, and we want to use it to eliminate the pressure on the hospitals to lay off people. In return, we'll have better morale in the institutions and greater job security for those who remain."
His union is widely respected for negotiating innovative contracts, like the current one in which the workers won strong job security in exchange for a one-year wage freeze and a cut in the hospitals' contributions to their benefit plans.
That contract states that for workers hired before September 1992, there could be layoffs only if hospitals close. If a hospital says layoffs are needed because of poor fiscal conditions, a council of labor and management representatives is to negotiate any layoffs.
Mr. Rivera said he was also pressing the hospitals to extend the same solid job protections to workers hired after September 1992. Under the current contract, workers hired after that date can be laid off, but if they lose their jobs, they are entitled to supplementary unemployment benefits, health insurance and free job retraining. In addition, they are promised the first jobs when positions become available at hospitals covered by the contract.
As part of the deal, the union also wants the hospitals to agree to a plan in which thousands of workers in the hospitals' fastest growing segment -- walk-in clinics -- would join the union.
In an unusual move, the union has prepared a glossy brochure arguing that it is important to negotiate a new contract long before the current one expires. It says that the union has to take further steps to protect job security in light of hospital mergers, shorter hospital stays, the rise of managed care organizations and cuts in Medicaid and Medicare.
"Our worst fears have come to be reality with recent developments," says the brochure, which seeks to mobilize the workers to fight for continued job security.
Mr. Rivera said he hopes to negotiate a new contract by the end of this month, but Mr. McIver said there was no need to set a deadline so long before the current contract expires.

HEADLINE: Producer Prices Drop Again; Inflation, for Now, Has Died

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 11

 BODY:
Prices paid by producers fell for a record sixth consecutive month, the Government reported today, in the strongest sign yet that inflation has virtually disappeared from the American industrial landscape.
Despite a robust economy, little if any inflation was visible anywhere in the production pipeline, with raw materials, partly processed materials and finished goods all fetching prices lower in June than they did a year earlier. It was one of the few times in the 50-year history of the Producer Price Index that inflation had been so thoroughly subdued and particularly remarkable because the unemployment rate is only 5 percent, close to its lowest levels in a quarter century. In the past, inflation has generally disappeared among manufacturers and other producers only during recessions or when the economy has been especially weak. 
 Perhaps because it was simply a further extension of recent trends, the report generated only a muted response in the financial markets. Interest rates on long-term bonds retreated slightly while the 30-stock Dow Jones industrial average rose 35.06 points to climb back over the 7,900 mark.
Moreover, many experts believe the economy will rebound during the second half of the year, which might cause the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates just to be sure that inflation remains subdued.
"It is time to call in Sherlock Holmes, for we now have the case of the missing inflation," said Joel L. Naroff, a senior economist in Philadelphia for the First Union Bank. "If anyone can find it, it has to be Holmes -- for the Bureau of Labor Statistics has completely lost the scent." Some economists called the absence of inflation a long-overdue payoff for years of painful corporate downsizing and restructuring that cost many people their jobs.
"There's been this enormous structural change as firms continue to cut costs while profits are high -- and that's never happened before," said James E. Annable, chief economist at the First National Bank of Chicago-NBD. "We've become the most competitive economy in the world."
A variety of forces account for the utter lack of industrial inflation at a time when the economy has been growing at such a healthy clip, economists said. Among them are the inroads made by cheap foreign goods, low labor costs, a stronger dollar and the falling price of oil. Above all, though, they point to corporate revamping, driven by an increasingly competitive marketplace and unrelenting pressure on corporate executives to deliver better results to shareholders.
These pressures have forced managers to continue to pursue increased efficiency, requiring a lot of investment in new machinery and technology that has helped raise the nation's industrial capacity and prevented strong demand from creating the bottlenecks and supply squeezes that in the past often led to higher prices. Even though the economy is in its seventh year of uninterrupted growth, American industry operated in May at 83.7 percent of capacity, well below the 85 percent level often associated with price pressures.
While consumer prices continue to advance at a slow pace, most of that increase is coming from the service sector, where such forces are not as pronounced.
Given the difficulty of raising prices of most goods, the economy appears to be able to operate at a lower level of unemployment without producing higher inflation.
Mickey D. Levy, chief economist at Nationsbanc Capital Markets in New York, has been one of those who expected inflation to remain under control and now, he says, "more and more people are becoming convinced that you can have healthy growth without generating inflation."
And labor costs, which account for more than two-thirds of the average company's outlays, are not being driven up by the tight labor market because improved productivity has neutralized such pressure.
Rather than passing on higher costs, companies try to preserve profits by holding the line on wages and benefits while seeking a larger share of their markets, doing so typically by raising output and charging attractively low prices.
"For the foreseeable future, inflation is dead," said Paul Huard, senior vice president of the National Association of Manufacturers.
In June, according to today's report, the Producer Price Index for finished goods edged down one-tenth of 1 percent to bring the drop for the first half of the year to an annual rate of 3.4 percent. This reversed an equal increase in the second half of 1996.
An increase in the price of energy, the first this year, roughly offset a decline in food, with "core" finished goods that exclude these volatile items up one-tenth of 1 percent.
Mystifying some analysts, the price of computers climbed six-tenths of 1 percent in June, a category that has long been one of the biggest sources of price restraints. But that was clearly an aberration. For the last 12 months, computer prices dropped 21.5 percent, the report showed. Other industries that have produced significant year-over-year price declines include the paper industry and oil refining.
Other sizable annual declines included 22.3 percent for fresh fruits and melons, 17.2 percent for eggs. 4.9 percent for dairy products, 5.9 percent for gasoline, 2.3 percent for household appliances, 2.4 percent for autos and 3 percent for heavy trucks.
Among the larger increases were 30.4 percent for roasted coffee, 4.2 percent for machinery used in oil and gas fields, 4.8 percent for beef and veal and 3.6 percent for tobacco products.
Goods at the intermediate stage of production, like a bolt of cloth or sack of flour, were unchanged during June and four-tenths of 1 percent lower over the latest 12 months.
Nondurable items, like paperboard, used in factories showed no overall change. However, durables used in manufacturing, like refined copper, rose three-tenths of 1 percent and rose more than twice as much in the first half of the year as they fell in the second half of 1996.
As for raw materials, officially called crude goods, their decline was 3.3 percent for June and 5.4 percent over the latest 12 months. Crude items other than food and energy advanced four-tenths of 1 percent last month.

HEADLINE: News Summary

 BODY:

INTERNATIONAL 3-5
 
A Promoter of Democracy Stirs Up Authoritarians
George Soros's foundations have lavished vast sums on promoting democracy in the former Communist world. His operation in Belarus has been suspended because of hostility from President Aleksandr Lukashenko, but Mr. Soros has vowed not to back down. 1
 
Romanians Cheer Clinton
President Clinton was greeted warmly by Romanians despite having blocked their country from joining NATO in the first round of expansion. He vowed that they would join the military alliance if they continued reforms initiated by President Emil Constaninescu, with whom he appeared in Bucharest. 3
 
A Senate Signal on Bosnia
The Senate approved a military authorization bill that sent a clear signal that it wants ground troops out of Bosnia by June 30, as President Clinton has promised. But unlike the House, the Senate did not cut off aid for the peacekeeping mission. In Bosnia, security for the leader of the Bosnian Serbs, Radovan Karadzic, and other senior officials was increased to protect them from any further attempts by NATO troops to arrest those charged with war crimes. 3
 
5 Shot in West Belfast
Unidentified men in a Catholic section of Belfast shot two police officers and three British army soldiers on patrol. The wounded were taken to hospitals but were not gravely hurt, the police said. The Irish Republican Army did not claim responsibility for the shooting, which came a day after Protestant Orange Order officials agreed not to stage their patriotic marches in Catholic areas. 3
 
Rwanda Undermines Kabila
Rwandan officials have taken credit not just for supporting but for planning and directing the insurrection that ousted the dictator Mobutu See Seko from the giant neighboring country formerly known as Zaire. The claims were surprising because Rwanda was not expected to undermine the political position of Laurent Kabila, who is now President of the country he renamed Congo. Mr. Kabila's critics have often described him as a puppet of Rwanda. 5
 
Cambodia Seeks More Aid
The United States and several other nations suspended aid to Cambodia, but their embassies in Phnom Penh received requests from the new de facto government of Hun Sen for financial help. Despite an international consensus to condemn Mr. Hun Sen's coup, diplomats considered it a fait accompli and lamented the apparent failure of a $2 billion effort to foster democracy. 5
 
Sierra Leone Under Pressure
The Commonwealth of Britain and its former colonies suspended Sierra Leone's membership until the junta that seized power in May is replaced by an elected government. The civilian President, Ahmad Tejan Kabbah, fled the country after a coup led by Maj. Johnny Paul Koromah. (Reuters)
 
NATIONAL 6-9
 
House Ends All Arts Funds, Threatening Interior Bill
A day after voting to abolish the National Endowment for the Arts, the House stripped the agency of its remaining $10 million to cover shutdown costs. That vote and another on limiting road-building subsidies for logging companies raised fears among some House members that the Interior Department spending bill, which includes the arts endowment, would become hostage to disgruntled factions. 1

No Ruling on Huang Immunity
A testy, three-hour meeting between lawyers for John Huang, the central figure in the Democratic fund-raising scandal, and lawyers for the Senate committee investigating campaign finance abuses ended with Republican and Democratic counsels clashing over whether Mr. Huang should be granted immunity to testify. No decision was made. 1

Revival in Nation's Cities
Local governments have apparently recovered from nationwide recession and deep cuts in state and Federal aid thanks to strong economic growth and conservative fiscal practices. In an annual survey released this week by the National League of Cities, more than two-thirds of 338 responding cities reported that they would be better able to meet their financial needs in the current fiscal year than in the previous one. 1
 
New Spinal Surgery Tried
Researchers in Florida performed the nation's first transplant of fetal tissue into a person with a spinal cord injury, an effort that they hope will pioneer a new approach to arresting and possibly reversing disability. 9

Court Bars Term Limits
The Massachusetts Supreme Court struck down the state's term limits law barring politicians from seeking re-election after two terms in office. The court unanimously ruled that the law, which was enacted by voters in a 1994 referendum, was unconstitutional. 6

Gephardt Urges Investment
Representative Richard A. Gephardt, pushing for an economic policy distinct from the Clinton Administration's and one he could banner as a Presidential candidate, said in an interview that he is comfortable with the budget being in only "rough balance" because the nation's top priority should be investment and growth. 8

Speaker Wants End to 2 Taxes
Speaker Newt Gingrich proposed cutting taxes every year and abolishing, not just reducing, capital gains and inheritance taxes. 8
 
Pathfinder Misses Signal
In a mistake that cost the Mars Pathfinder mission a full day of operations, flight controllers tried to radio new instructions to the spacecraft at a time when its receiver was off. Hearing nothing, the lander and its rover did nothing for a full Martian day. 7
 
NEW YORK/REGION 23-26
 
Union Offers Plan to Expand Job Security to All Workers
New York City's largest union of hospital workers has proposed an innovative deal that would use at least $100 million from its pension plan to offer early retirement incentives for older workers as a means of guaranteeing job security for younger workers. 23

Hotel Executive Sentenced
A former executive of the ITT Sheraton Corporation was sentenced to 15 months in prison for taking "hundreds of thousands of dollars" in kickbacks from a produce wholesaler, according to Mary Jo White, the United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York. The executive, Richard Nicoletti, a 46-year-old Queens resident, was responsible for buying fruits and vegetables for several hotels in New York and New Jersey that are owned by ITT Sheraton, including the St. Regis in Manhattan. 25

$1 Billion Estimate on Casino
Donald J. Trump said he had decided to sell one of his Atlantic City casinos. Mr. Trump, whose company, Trump Hotels & Casino Resorts, owns 3 of the 12 casinos in Atlantic City, predicted that he could sell Trump Plaza for as much as $1 billion. He said he would use the money to decrease his company's $1.7 billion debt. 26

ARTS 11-22

New Life for a Flop
The ill-fated 1976 musical "1600 Pennsylvania Avenue" by Leonard Bernstein and Alan Jay Lerner was one of the greatest flops in Broadway history, closing after only seven performances. Now a stripped-down version of the work, called "A White House Cantata," is being given a second chance in London. 11

HEADLINE: Gephardt Faults Effort To Balance the Budget

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
Pushing for an economic policy distinct from the Clinton Administration's and one he could banner as a Presidential candidate, Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the House minority leader, says it is all right if the budget is only in "rough balance" because the nation's top priority should be investment and growth.
In an interview this week, Mr. Gephardt belittled what he described as the obsession of the Administration and the Republicans with a budget that is strictly in balance, the goal of negotiations now taking place. To help pay for the public investment that Mr. Gephardt considers essential to achieve more robust growth, he would endorse a budget deficit ranging up to 1 percent of the gross domestic product, the total value of what the nation produces in a year. 
 The deficit for the current fiscal year is already below that level, thanks in large measure to a humming economy that has generated more tax revenue than anticipated. A slowdown in the coming months would raise the deficit again. So will rising Medicare costs. In those situations, Mr. Gephardt would invoke his 1 percent guideline, rather than balance the budget with cutbacks in spending that he considers essential if the economy is to grow as fast as it did before 1973.
"I am not sitting here advocating let's go back to $300 billion deficits, or 5 percent of G.D.P. or 3 percent," he said. "That is not a good idea. But on the other hand, what we can't do is get into this idea that if we are not at absolute, utter, strict balance each and every year, the sky is going to fall in."
The interview represented a fresh attempt by Mr. Gephardt, a Missouri Democrat serving his 11th term in Congress, to position himself against Vice President Al Gore for the Democratic Presidential nomination in 2000. "I want this to be the Democratic economic policy alternative," Mr. Gephardt said of his proposals -- not only for the Presidential election but for the Congressional elections next year as well.
He called for public investment on a greater scale than the Administration advocates. And he proposed diverting some of the gasoline tax from its present purpose, reducing the deficit, to a new function, making payments on state and municipal bonds that finance public investment. The bonds would pay for public investment, and the gasoline money, totaling $7 billion a year, would be used to repay the bonds. The repayments would support about $70 billion in bond issues. President Clinton also favors tax policy to finance public investment. The President's college tax credit is in this vein.
Mr. Gephardt has gradually stepped up his effort to separate his positions from those of the Administration. He had previously taken issue with the White House on welfare changes, the North American Free Trade Agreement and the China trade policy, which he termed insufficiently tough. And he voted against the budget resolution, the broad outline negotiated by Mr. Clinton and Republican leaders in recent months, calling it unjust -- although he joined Mr. Gore on Thursday in opposing Republican tax proposals.
But Mr. Gephardt's new stand on the deficit was a clear departure from the Administration's public position, which is to balance the budget to the dollar by 2002.
"I think getting people to understand rough balance is important," Mr. Gephardt said. "In other words, getting people to understand this issue in terms of percent of G.D.P. rather than strict balance. Your personal budget is not in strict balance. You borrow money to buy a house, to buy a car, to buy an appliance, to buy a camera, to buy a lot of things that you think are important to your family and its success."
The governments of all the major industrial nations except the United States use a percentage of their gross domestic product in judging whether their budgets are out of hand. Most consider them sufficiently in balance if their deficits are less than 2 or 3 percent of the G.D.P. The thinking is that an economy can grow enough -- produce enough additional wealth -- to pay this deficit, just as a salary increase makes a family's home mortgage or its credit card debts easier to pay.
But in the current effort in Washington to pass legislation that would balance the budget to the dollar, neither the Administration nor anyone in the Republican-controlled Congress has invoked the G.D.P. standard as a legitimate alternative. Still, many economists quietly favor this standard, including some of Mr. Clinton's advisers.
Given the nation's current $7.8 trillion economy, Mr. Gephardt's 1 percent deficit ceiling would be $78 billion, slightly above the projected deficit of $67 billion for the fiscal year that ends on Sept. 30. By Mr. Gephardt's new standard, then, the budget is already in balance.
In the interview, Mr. Gephardt called for a broad array of public investments -- in education, health care, child care, infrastructure -- all intended to increase the nation's productivity and thus the growth of the economy to at least 3 percent a year and perhaps as much as 3.5 percent. That would be well above the 2.1 percent annual average that has prevailed in the 1990's.
Administration officials also call for greater economic growth, but they see Mr. Gephardt's leap to 3 percent or more as wishful thinking. They share with him the view that the right set of investments, chiefly in education, and the right sort of corporate practices can raise productivity and growth, but not by as much as Mr. Gephardt has in mind.
Productivity is a measure of how much a worker, with modern tools and machinery, can produce in an hour. The more each produces, the greater the nation's overall economic growth. For decades the economy grew at more than 3 percent a year, on average, and then the rate fell back to less than 2.5 percent in 1973, when productivity faltered. The Administration embraces this lower growth figure in all its calculations, taking the view that while 3 percent or 3.5 percent growth might be possible in the future, getting there will come very slowly.
Whatever the future holds, between now and the next Presidential election the upper limits of economic growth should be tested, Mr. Gephardt said. The economy can be pushed in this period to 3 percent growth without causing the inflation rate to rise, he added. But getting to 3 percent means putting pressure on the Federal Reserve not to raise interest rates beyond their current levels, Mr. Gephardt argues. The Administration avoids pressuring the Fed.

HEADLINE: Greenport's Rough Rider;
Bold Mayor Forces Change (Even on the Willing)

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS 

DATELINE: GREENPORT, N.Y.

 BODY:
This tiny port on Peconic Bay has been kind of quiet since the wild bootlegging days of Prohibition came to a close. That is, until David E. Kapell, a former professional bass guitarist with a taste for Panama hats, was elected Mayor in 1994.
First Mayor Kapell, 48, disbanded the eight-member village Police Department. Then he abolished the village court and sold the local water utility, all to slash the village budget by 35 percent and local property taxes by 50 percent. And, in an effort to make Greenport more attractive to young families, he is remaking the village waterfront with a 3.4-acre park complete with a marina, amphitheater and carousel. 
 Mr. Kapell's energy rarely flags, especially when he does not get his way. After an effort to deny a pension to the village's volunteer firefighters failed, Mr. Kapell accused several firefighters of exploding fireworks and screaming anti-Semitic slurs outside his house. No one was charged, despite his call for an investigation, a rare defeat.
"I break all the village political rules in the book," Mr. Kapell said in an interview. "You drop the bomb and wait for the fallout."
With his mixture of charm and ruthlessness, Mr. Kapell has broken the mold of past Greenport mayors, who presided passively over a decaying economy while waiting for Albany or Washington to do something. But opponents -- and even some supporters -- wonder whether Mr. Kapell's take-no-prisoners attitude means the loss of a brand of consensus politics pleasing to neighborly villagers who would rather trade fish stories than punches. And several former and current village officials accuse him of using his office to benefit his real estate business and friends and of spreading rumors about his opponents to bring them to heel.
"David has really done a good job as Mayor," said Thomas Wickham, former supervisor of the Long Island Town of Southold, which includes Greenport within its jurisdiction. "But he will stop at nothing to promote his interests: concocting sex scandals and lawsuits, hounding and harassing people with phone calls at home, anything against people who are not 100 percent supportive."
A registered Republican who ran for Mayor on an independent party ticket whose name he says he cannot remember, Mr. Kapell is a hard man to pin down ideologically. He looks to Ross Perot as a model for shaking up the political system, and he admires Lincoln for his moral strength. He says he has no ambition for higher office. But he does have a foreign policy. He found a town in Romania, the Black Sea port of Mangalia, willing to exchange students with Greenport and provide cobblestones for the waterfront project in return for an old ambulance. He says he eventually wants to bring Romanian cognac-making skills -- cognac is the Mayor's favorite drink -- to the nearby East End wineries to expand profits and create jobs.
Nevertheless, even some of his supporters say Mr. Kapell's tactics are pretty rough for a port of only 2,100 full-time residents, plus another 1,000 or so weekenders.
"He's a Rudy Giuliani type," said Walter Gezari, president of a Greenport manufacturing firm and key supporter of Mayor Kapell. "If some neck needs to be stepped on, Dave will crush it and chop it off immediately."
Troy Gustavson, the executive editor and co-publisher of The Suffolk Times, a weekly newspaper, said that Mr. Kapell had personally called him late in 1996 to suggest that the paper consider an article on a possible extramarital affair of two members of the village board of trustees who opposed his waterfront plan. The two trustees went to the paper to deny the rumor, Mr. Gustavson said, and an article never ran.
Asked about the incident, Mr. Kapell said, "I'm not going to comment on that." In a separate interview, he said: "They say I'm bull-headed and a little Napoleon. In a small town, things get personal, and I regret that."
Much about David Kapell's life is unconventional. His father, the acclaimed classical concert pianist William Kapell, died in a plane crash when David was only 4. He grew up in Manhattan, never finished college and played bass in various rock and blues bands in his 20's. After going through what he described as an "emotional nadir and catharsis," which he refused to detail, he gave up his music career to work as a dishwasher and eventually managed several restaurants.
In 1977, Mr. Kapell and his wife, Eileen, the daughter of his Manhattan apartment building's superintendent, moved to Greenport, where he entered village government as a planner and eventually opened a real estate and antiques business. He first ran for mayor in 1994 to fill out the term of a predecessor who had resigned after a police scandal, in which one officer was charged with tipping off drug dealers and another was found having sex with a girlfriend on the police chief's desk.
Mr. Kapell pressed for a village vote to disband the force, and after the referendum succeeded, sued the town of Southold to provide Greenport with extra police protection. In 1995, Mr. Kapell ran unopposed for a full four-year term.
With his ever-present hat or cap and soft smile, Mr. Kapell cuts an avuncular figure with the public. Walking between his real estate office and the village hall, Mr. Kapell greeted everyone he passed by name, chatted with a teen-ager from a troubled home he says he has tried to guide, and even waved politely to a woman he described as the village's one streetwalker.
Once he reached village hall, however, Mr. Kapell's charm turned muscular. At a meeting with several state officials visiting to discuss a new drainage project, he dropped the startling suggestion that he might build a wall across a state road that runs through the village if Albany didn't begin to maintain it better.
Mr. Kapell concedes his original motivation for entering politics was partly personal: His real estate business was not doing well, and he thought shaking up the local government would improve the village's economy. But his critics say he has overstepped the line between self-interest and village concerns.
Barbara E. Heaney, a village trustee, said Mr. Kapell has been promoting a change in zoning regulations to permit the conversion of empty space over storefronts into artist lofts so the Vitale Building, a property he manages in Greenport, can be divided up for more rental space.
In response, Mr. Kapell said, "I support the initiative and will continue to support it and if it helps the Vitale Building, hallelujah!" But he added, "I don't place my personal interests over the interests of the community."
Mr. Kapell's detractors also say he has opposed proposals to include commercial properties on his waterfront project because of his friendship with E. M. Kontakosta, the owner of several major storefronts across from the new park. But Mr. Kapell said a pristine park without stores would beautify the village, and do far more for the local economy.
"The last thing Greenport needs is more stores, because you'll just have more vacancies," Mr. Kapell said.
Mr. Kapell said he had not had any business relationship with Mr. Kontakosta for 15 years, and he denied that any of his decisions as Mayor were made for his gain or the gain of friends. He conceded that real estate prices do go up when he does a good job. But he added that for the $17,000 a year he earns as Mayor, he has been forced to spend an inordinate amount of time on village business and given up a lot of business to preclude conflicts of interest.
"If you are afraid of alienating people you can't be in a leadership position," Mr. Kapell said. "You're bound to ruffle feathers when you make change, but I'm ready for reconciliation with anybody, anytime."

HEADLINE: Metro News Briefs: NEW YORK;
Monitor of City Finances Is Leaving for London

 BODY:
Rosemary Scanlon, who has served for four years as the special monitor of New York City's finances in the office of the State Comptroller, announced yesterday that she was resigning to become a private financial consultant in London. 
 Ms. Scanlon, whose title is Deputy State Comptroller for New York City, will analyze municipal public policy for a consortium of three British universities. Her present position was created during the fiscal crisis of the 1970's as the official state watchdog of the city budget. She previously served as chief economist of the Port Authority.

HEADLINE: PRACTICAL TRAVELER;
A Strong Dollar Spurs Travel

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR; STEVE LOHR is a business-news reporter for The Times.

 BODY:
IF you want to save money, stay home. If you venture out, the best travel values for the money are likely to be found in the world's most efficient consumer economy, the United States.
Still, pocketbook parochialism has certainly not deterred Americans from traveling abroad in record numbers. The Commerce Department estimates that Americans will make 54 million trips abroad this year, continuing the increase of recent years. Sheer wanderlust may play a part, but the numbers are rising mainly because more people can afford it -- courtesy of the healthy American economy. 
 But the continued strength of the American dollar has helped as well. Travel experts agree that changes in a currency's value over the course of several months, or even a year, do not usually have much effect on travelers. But a steady rise in the value of the dollar over a couple of years, they say, is noticeable.
That is the situation today in many countries. The dollar is worth roughly 20 percent more than it was two years ago in most European countries including Germany, France and Switzerland, according to the research department of American Express.
There are exceptions. In Britain, the most popular European destination for Americans, the dollar is worth no more than it was two years ago. In Turkey, by contrast, the dollar buys more than three times as many Turkish liras as it did in the summer of 1995.
In some countries, the longer-term trend is most important. In Italy, for example, the dollar is worth about 10 percent more than it was a year ago, not such a big move. But the dollar has risen 60 percent against the Italian lira since the fall of 1992.
"Italy has fallen off the list of expensive places to go," observed James V. Cammisa Jr., a travel analyst in Miami.
Yet taking an even longer view, a decade or more, today's dollar looks pretty feeble. At recent exchange rates, the dollar purchased 113 Japanese yen, 1.73 German marks and 5.84 French francs, and those are solid gains over the rates two years ago of 85 yen, 1.40 marks and 4.92 francs. Then again, the recent dollar rates are far below the levels reached in the mid-1980's. In 1985, the dollar purchased 262 yen, 3.45 marks and 10 francs.
 
Cheaper Sushi
So Japan, for example, has not dropped off the list of expensive places to go, despite the dollar's 33 percent rise against the yen in the last two years.
But because Japan has a negligible inflation rate, the stronger dollar translates into greater purchasing power for travelers. The sushi lunch in the small restaurant in the Tsukiji district, famous for its fish market, will cost in yen roughly what it did two years ago -- making it cheaper for the American whose dollars buy a third more yen than in 1995.
In a country with high inflation, like Turkey, the dollar's gains do not translate into proportionately lower prices for American tourists. A Turkish carpet is cheaper for Americans than it was two years ago but not at the fire-sale discount suggested by the huge swing in the dollar rate, from 43,200 liras two years ago to 145,600 liras recently.
And a stronger dollar means little to American travelers in countries that are "dollarized," meaning that many prices and hotel rates, especially for tourists, are either formally or informally set in dollars. Among others, China, parts of Latin American and the former Soviet bloc, even Israel, fit that category.
So where are the attractive prices apt to be found? Mainly in business establishments that compete for local customers instead of tourists.
Local restaurants, for example. Ed Perkins, the editor of Consumer Reports Travel Letter, a monthly newsletter, recently visited Germany, Italy and Czechoslovakia. "The hotel rates were still pretty high," Mr. Perkins said. "But the dining costs were remarkably modest compared with a couple of years ago."
Arthur Frommer, publisher of 167 guidebooks and long a champion of affordable overseas travel, says the stronger dollar makes this a particularly good time to go to Europe. "The southern tier European nations of Italy, Spain, Portugal and most of all Turkey have become especially good values," said Mr. Frommer."
At an Italian trattoria, he says, a good meal -- a pasta, small meat course, vegetables, fruit for dessert and a glass of wine -- need not cost more than $15 or so. To save on lodging, he favors guest houses, small hotels and bed-and-breakfasts. "The places with elevators, big lobbies and bathrooms in most rooms are going to cost you more."
Foreign cities, he adds, are much like New York or other big American cities. Prices range from extravagant to bargain basement. Breakfast at hotel restaurants in Manhattan can easily cost more than $10 but, as Mr. Frommer notes, the West Side drugstore counter he favors offers eggs, coffee and toast for $1.89: "There is a budget life abroad just as there is in the United States."
 
Avoiding Fees
Tourists, of course, are charged more than the so-called interbank rates published daily in major newspapers. These rates are set by foreign exchange dealers on bank trading floors; they buy and sell millions of dollars worth of pounds, marks and yen with each telephone call.
The goal for travelers is to get as close to the interbank rate as possible. First, put as much of your overseas spending on credit cards as possible. American Express, Mastercard and Visa, for example, usually charge card holders just 1 percent or so more than the interbank rate when foreign purchases are translated back into dollars on monthly statements.
Second, be careful in dealing with local currency shops abroad. These exchange bureaus routinely have signs offering what seem to be extremely attractive rates, but the advertised rates are often the "sell" rates, meaning the amount of local currency you need to buy dollars when converting your leftover francs into dollars as you head home. The "buy" rate -- or the amount of local currency you can buy with a dollar -- is much less favorable. Also, make sure to ask about added-on fees for transactions.
Bank cards used in automated teller machines in America increasingly work in major banks overseas, especially Europe and Mexico. "If you haven't traveled in the last year, you'll be surprised at how easily American bank cards work in much of Europe," noted Mr. Perkins of Consumer Reports Travel Letter.
The rate on ATM machines is similar to those on credit cards -- 1 percent or so above the interbank rate -- but ask about fees. There is usually also a fee of $3 or so for each transaction. To minimize the fees, it makes sense to use one's ATM card for fewer, larger transactions.
One practice to avoid, if possible, is using credit cards to get cash advances overseas, says Rob Rosenblatt, a vice president of American Express. Cash advances abroad combine three charges -- the surcharge above the interbank rate, the transaction fee and the financing charge on the loan, which is what a cash advance is.

HEADLINE: ART VIEW;
How a Proto-SoHo Thrived in Old New York

BYLINE: By Holland Cotter 

DATELINE: SOUTHHAMPTON, N.Y.

 BODY:
IT'S A RULE OF THUMB IN commercial real estate: location is everything. And that consideration has been very much on the mind of the New York art world in the last few years, as galleries move from SoHo to Chelsea, from Prince Street to Grand, wondering where the center of economic gravity will fall.
But similar concerns were at work in the 19th century, too. Antebellum New York wasn't exactly an art town, yet. The dense infrastructure of museums, galleries, dealers and publications in place today was still far in the future. Artists lived here and there around the city. And when it came to promoting and selling their wares, they were pretty much on their own. 
 But when America's first art movement, the Hudson River School, took off, a Manhattan businessman named James Boorman Johnston had an idea. He bought a plot of land on the north side of 10th Street between Fifth and Sixth Avenues in Greenwich Village and hired a smart young architect (Richard Morris Hunt) to design a building devoted entirely to the business of art.
Johnston's groundbreaking venture, a kind of proto-SoHo under one roof, has been the stuff of art historical footnotes up to now. But this summer it is taking center stage on Long Island at the Parrish Art Museum here. "The Tenth Street Studio Building: Artist-Entrepreneurs From the Hudson River School to the American Impressionists," a cornucopia of a show of some 50 paintings and nearly 100 vintage photographs, documents and artifacts, is on view at the museum through Aug. 10.
When the Studio Building opened in 1858, it was the place for ambitious American artists to set up shop and be seen. Its inaugural roster of renting tenants included such competitive luminaries as Frederic Edwin Church, Sanford Gifford, Martin Johnson Heade and Emanuel Leutze. The bullish Albert Bierstadt and the temperamental Winslow Homer were soon to follow.
At the time, the romantic notion of a "brotherhood of artists" was still in the air, and the building, with more than a score of studios, was conceived as a combination think-tank, exhibition space and fraternity house. Meals were served on the premises; social interchange was fluid. Residents visited each other's studios regularly, offering professional critiques and gossip. And, in an era when American art was charged with both aspirations and tensions surrounding its spiritual and political goals, the atmosphere of intellectual ferment must have been strong.
Such abstract concepts are only obliquely touched on at the Parrish, however. The show's curator, Annette Blaugrund, the new director of the National Academy of Design (where "The Tenth Street Studio Building" will open on Aug. 21), has other, more material things on her mind: namely, the Studio Building's function as a well-oiled marketing tool.
The basic story can be found right there in Hunt's floor plan. The individual studios were arranged around a high-ceilinged central hall in which all the residents could exhibit fresh-from-the-easel paintings in a continuously rotating group show. This display let artists try out new ideas on an audience of their peers. But more important, it gave New York's rising class of merchant art collectors the opportunity to do some comparison-shopping at a glance.
In fact, access to the Tenth Street Studio Building's exhibition hall and studios was shrewdly regulated. Open houses were organized and advertised; the artists themselves dropped personal notes to promising clientele.
Such handwritten invitations, along with newspaper illustrations of receptions, are among the ephemera gathered at the Parrish. And Ms. Blaugrund has supplemented them with other related materials -- engraved advertisements for the city's few auction houses and art galleries, self-published catalogues and brochures -- to give an artist's-eye view of Manhattan more than a century ago.
THEN AS NOW, THE ART world was in constant flux. Certain Studio Building tenants -- Bierstadt, Church -- made it big and moved to the country; others faded into obscurity. And with the Gilded Age of the 1880's, a different, more theatrical style of salesmanship developed.
The trend is crystallized in the figure of William Merritt Chase, who moved into the building in 1878. Chase was cast in the mold of a celebrity artist right from the start. As a painter, he had dazzling if facile gifts, but his real selling point was his personality: urbane, ambitious, intent upon clearing out a space for himself wherever he went.
That's literally what he did at the Studio Building. He commandeered the central exhibition hall, which had once been a communal showcase, and turned it into his own studio, fitting it out with a Moorish-style tent, copies of works by Velazquez and Hals, a pileup of exotic tchotchkes, and pots of palms, ferns and peacock feathers.
The Parrish has a special link to Chase -- he lived and taught on Long Island -- and the show catches something of his extravagant, grandstanding spirit. Under the eye of the interior designer John Christensen, one of the museum's galleries has been transformed into a meticulously cluttered, although miniature, evocation of Chase's digs, hung with a dozen or so of his own paintings of his studio interior.
One or two of these adroitly brushed works are among the liveliest pieces in the exhibition. Among the other highlights are one of Heade's signature paintings of orchids and hummingbirds, a modest-size South American mountainscape by Church, and a charming Worthington Whittredge image of a single tall window looking out on the Hudson River. (All three works are on loan from the New-York Historical Society.)
But "The Tenth Street Studio Building" isn't a masterpiece show and doesn't pretend to be. Many of the paintings, while technically polished, are only mildly inspired, confirming that a century ago, as now, art in New York was a mix of the good, the bad and the opportunistic.
In the latter category falls the work of John George Brown, a Studio Building resident whose genre pictures of New York street urchins -- Norman Rockwell creations before the fact -- were geared to wealthy collectors who prided themselves on being self-made men. One might also include here James Carroll Beckwith's promotional portrait of Chase himself as a self-confident dandy in spats and a chic, full-length fur coat.
Whatever one thinks of Chase, he was the last real star produced by the Studio Building, which survived into the 20th century and finally fell to the wrecking ball in 1956. (An apartment building, at 45 West 10th Street, now occupies the site.) By the time of the demolition, of course, many other art communities had sprung up: in Greenwich Village itself, in Lower Manhattan, on the Lower East Side. And they continue to appear, from Chelsea to Williamsburg.
Whether history will remember the building's artists primarily for the how-and-why of their commerce, or for the aesthetic ideas they generated, only time will tell. Ms. Blaugrund's show takes the narrower focus: it concentrates on art's unexalted economic bottom line, but turns it into an engagingly detailed, all-American story in which past and present share some turf.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 12; Column 1; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 2471 words

HEADLINE: The Wilted Chrysanthemum

BYLINE: By Frank Gibney; Frank Gibney is the president of the Pacific Basin Institute. His most recent books on Japan are "Senso" and the revised edition of "Japan: The Fragile Superpower."

 BODY:

JAPAN
 A Reinterpretation.
 By Patrick Smith.
 385 pp. New York:
 Pantheon Books. $27.50.
 
 SHADOW SHOGUNS
 The Rise and Fall of Japan's
 Postwar Political Machine.
 By Jacob M. Schlesinger.
 366 pp. New York:
 Simon & Schuster. $26. 
 During the century since Lafcadio Hearn published "Japan: An Attempt at Interpretation," three generations of Americans -- scholars, journalists and public officials -- have tried their hands at describing and explaining Japan's singular nation-society to their countrymen. These two books are the latest. Written by knowledgeable journalists, they offer fresh and valuable insights into a country that most Americans -- rather like wintertime climbers to the summit of Mount Fuji -- seem to find ever more misty the closer they get to it. And in content and message, the two are interestingly complementary.
"Japan: A Reinterpretation" is the more ambitious -- and a stimulating, provocative book it is. No bit of academic microhistory this. Patrick Smith paints with an extremely broad brush. From the spirited prologue to the very useful bibliography in the back, the author, who ran the International Herald Tribune's Tokyo bureau, has set out to show us the real Japan, as distinct from "the Orientalist 'Japan' Americans conceived after the war" and "still read about in our newspapers."
Smith's reinterpretation centers on events since 1945. His objective is to rebut "the intellectual chicanery" of what is commonly termed the Chrysanthemum Club -- a group of American scholars who, in Smith's words, are "uncritical apologists for Japan," writers who have deliberately smudged over the realities of a troubled, questing country. In its place they have substituted a contrived and sanitized "paradigm" of a democratic, hard-working and pro-Western Japan, one that has amply justified the hopes of its successful postwar American occupiers. Edwin O. Reischauer, a longtime Harvard professor and for six years the United States Ambassador to Japan, is singled out as the club leader. A product of America's World War II "victory culture," as Smith describes it, Reischauer offered a "modernization theory" that Smith denounces for presenting an image of "contented conformity" in Japan that is totally at variance with the facts.
By contrast, Smith finds a Japan with its "political and social systems . . . in turmoil," its people struggling to re-create themselves by altering the relationship between repressed individuals and the "enveloping web" of duties and obligations that makes their society so group oriented. Here he holds that the American connection with Japan has proved not a help but a hindrance. The trouble began, in his view, when the American occupation ceased its efforts to democratize Japan in favor of a "reverse course" that sacrificed long-term political reform in the interests of building up economic Japan as a subservient cold war ally. The result was the emergence of a single-minded "Japan Inc., the name we gave to the obsessed nation we created."
Far from pushing any real Japanese democracy -- Smith repeatedly tells us there is no such thing -- the MacArthur occupation put back in place much the same arrogant bureaucratic establishment that had managed the Pacific war. Thus American power insured that "the enduring desire of ordinary Japanese for individual autonomy" would remain unsatisfied.
There is some justice to this criticism. Yet I find it hyperbolic to say there is no democracy in Japan. By whatever standards -- universal suffrage, rule of law, basic human rights included -- Japan's modern democracy is a fact. Its processes just happen to be different from ours. There are pluses and minuses on both sides.
There is no doubt, however, that the Japanese, still reeling from the collapse of their inflated "bubble economy," are now gripped by a widespread cultural and political malaise. A long-suffering public is beginning to complain. In a sweeping tour of contemporary Japan, Smith shows us a society of studious role-players ("every Japanese wears a mask"), a people whose sedulously fostered group loyalties conceal deep loneliness. He has a good reporter's eye. He obviously developed a wide acquaintanceship among Japan's political leaders, business people and cosmopolitan intelligentsia. Unlike most Japanologists, who concentrate with boring intensity on economics, Smith gives the reader a really interesting look at Japan's writers and educators. He presents a cultural dimension normally neglected.
Inevitably, the usual suspects are rounded up -- the sarariman (salaryman) literally dying from overwork, the neglected modern woman, the corrupt politicians and bureaucrats, the everyday people (and leaders) suffering from amae, or dependency syndrome. All are treated with understanding. Newer aspects of Japan are also highlighted. Following the work of the Australian scholar Gavin McCormack, Smith underlines the failings of the "construction state," where lavish, generally corrupt and dubiously useful public works projects once primed the economic pump. And he shows how the bonds of corporate loyalty, once the wonder of American business-school professors, are now loosening.
Smith summarizes recent Japanese disclosures to demonstrate that Emperor Hirohito, far from being a helpless figurehead, actively prosecuted Japan's aggressive war. He could have been tried as a war criminal, had the American occupation not actively intervened, in the interest of what it termed "stability," to hold him publicly blameless. Here is one area where Chrysanthemum Club scholars indeed helped whitewash history. Smith, on the other hand, can go overboard in the interests of revisionism. To imply that Hirohito's expertise in marine biology gave rise to the germ-warfare excesses of the Imperial Army's ghastly Unit 731 in China is, by any standard, a little much.
Which brings me to an inescapable keredomo, the "but" or "however" with which Japanese like to preface critical reservations. In his eagerness to argue that "American scholarship was . . . thoroughly in the service of official ideology," Smith plays a bit fast and loose with history himself. He incorrectly dismisses the Meiji achievement, a real cultural revolution, as merely a "transition" from one absolutism to another. The American occupation, which modern Japanese commentators still refer to, after Meiji, as Japan's Second Opening, he sees as equally a failure. Hardly so. The reverse course set in Washington in the late 1940's checked some but by no means all of the occupation's democratic reforms. In any case, no country can be continually reformed by military occupation; by 1951 it was time to go.
Nor did the reverse course render Japanese unions of today "more or less useless," as Smith maintains. (Modern American unions have got into much the same fix without the benefit of anybody's occupation.) The fact is that the reforms in labor law effected by the occupation are to this day a guarantee of labor rights in Japan. As to Japanese labor's powerlessness after 1947, I didn't really get that sense in the 1970's when, as the chief executive of a Japanese company, I was blockaded in my office for long hours -- along with thousands of Japanese company presidents in similar situations -- by union demonstrators whose gains in wages and security guarantees through that decade were without comparison anywhere in the world.
Reischauer was indeed, as Smith observes, preoccupied with Marxists -- and he was right to be. Scholarly opinion in Japan in the 1960's, as well as much of the country's labor leadership, was dominated by a crusty bunch of high-button-shoe Marxists. And Americans -- scholars, diplomats and journalists alike -- were dominated by a cold war mentality. That is to say, we thought the Soviets were out to destroy us. We lacked the "enlightened" attitude of the ever-skeptical post-cold-war 90's. As an ambassador and a scholar, Reischauer did America and Japan good service. If he erred on the side of the establishment -- and he often did -- I would prefer his measured explanations to the wild cries of some of our current revisionists.
But enough of criticism. I may not share Patrick Smith's optimism about the abilities of younger Japanese to re-create themselves. I certainly do share his concern about the need for a new, honest Japanese nationalism to replace the internationalist me-too mentality of a tired political leadership. And Smith is right to denounce the perpetuation of an outmoded Japanese-American security relationship. It does a disservice to both countries. In sum, Smith's 1997 reinterpretation of Japan may be a good bit rougher than Lafcadio Hearn's turn-of-the-century original, but it is knowledgeable and thought-provoking.
Jacob M. Schlesinger, who worked in The Wall Street Journal's Tokyo bureau from 1989 to 1994, takes a much narrower focus in "Shadow Shoguns," and his book has perhaps a heavier impact on the reader for that. As he describes it, "this is the story of Japan Inc. as political machine. It chronicles the political culture of a nation obsessed with economic advancement and the distortions to democracy and capitalism that accompanied what the world called Japan's economic 'miracle.' It is about the ambitions of colorful, domineering politicians -- the dynasty of machine bosses known as 'shadow shoguns' -- who skillfully rigged the seemingly faceless, selfless system for their own gain."
Washington lobbyists, Moscow mafiosi and Beijing party bosses stand back. Even Mobutu Sese Seko might be a bit envious. Here is the longest running big-time political sleaze serial of the past quarter-century.
Schlesinger's book makes a point of contrasting omote Nippon, the "front Japan" of the dynamic high-tech metropolitan belt along the Pacific coast, with ura Nippon, the "back-country" of underdeveloped farms and villages along the historically neglected Japan Sea to the west. He personalizes the contrast, beginning with the story of Kakuei Tanaka, the country boy from the western prefecture of Niigata, who parlayed the heavy support of local ura Nippon voters into control of a behind-the-scenes network of political payoffs and cronyism that took Tokyo and the rest of "front Japan" by storm. The Tanaka machine dominated Japanese politics totally, from its leader's selection as Prime Minister in 1972 until the majority Liberal Democrats finally lost an election in 1993.
Unlike most postwar Japanese prime ministers, relatively suave bureaucratic products of the Tokyo University law faculty, Tanaka ("Kaku-san") was rough, tough and very obviously commercial. He went straight from high school into the contracting business, where he proved an alert and ruthless competitor. From there it was an easy jump into politics. He turned the stored resentment of his ura Nippon constituents into big votes -- and they never deserted him. Schlesinger quite justly calls him "Japan's first true, successful populist." Swimming in the muddy waters of construction industry politics -- and getting richer by the day -- he speedily became one of the decision makers in the majority Liberal Democratic Party. Fast-moving and a quick study -- he was called "the computerized bulldozer" -- he smashed the more sedately corrupt politics of his elders when he became Prime Minister.
In office he was fluent and forceful (I can vouch that an hourlong interview with him felt like being run over by a verbal truck), and he set forth an ambitious plan to "remodel the Japanese archipelago" by moving a good part of Japan's industry and work force from the overcrowded Tokyo-Osaka-Nagoya area to the back country. The plan proved immensely popular but fatally flawed -- since Tanaka's contractor friends had private information about what was to be built and where. Meanwhile the corruption spread. Ultimately one of his scams went international. The 1974 Lockheed bribery scandal forced Tanaka from office and ultimately got him a jail sentence (which, thanks to long appeals and illness, he never served).
The most extraordinary thing about Tanaka, however, was his resilience. For more than a decade after his public disgrace, he virtually ran the Liberal Democrats -- and hence the Government. As skillful in behind-the-scenes politicking as he had been on center stage, he employed his brazen "money-power politics" to link business, bureaucrats and politicians (even from the opposition parties) in a self-serving alliance.
Yet by 1987 a weak and ailing Tanaka was shoved aside by his three closest supporters in the party -- Shin Kanemaru, Noboru Takeshita and Ichiro Ozawa. Running the old Tanaka faction in his name, they kept power through ever more sophisticated varieties of influence-peddling. (Japan's largest contractor, for example, the Shimizu Corporation, kept no fewer than 57 of Japan's leading politicians on its annual subsidy list.) Why did the long-suffering Japanese public put up with the machine? The answer, Schlesinger tells us, lay in two popular articles of faith -- a belief in continually escalating prosperity and a commitment to the nation's isolation from any large, troubling international decisions, thanks to American protection.
In the end, conditions forced both these perspectives to unravel. At the same time, scandals surfaced that were simply too big to be ignored. Takeshita, who became Prime Minister in 1987, had to resign under fire in 1989. (He was arguably the worst of Japan's postwar prime ministers, which is saying a lot.) Kanemaru, the crude but wily "don" who succeeded Tanaka as Japan's behind-the-scenes king maker, was arrested for tax evasion in 1992, after investigators found a huge supply of unexplained cash (gold bars included) in his possession. Ozawa, for his part, turned reformer. It was he who finally toppled the Liberal Democrats from total power. Schlesinger calls him "a kind of Japanese Gorbachev."
This is a book that was waiting to be written, and not only has Jacob Schlesinger done it, but he has also produced a fine job of political reporting. Like Patrick Smith, he is rather optimistic about Japan's future. A new electoral system, adopted under reform pressure, will ultimately end the old unhealthy scaffolding of party factions. For now the cozy world of bureaucracy-business-politics crookery is in pieces. It would be hard to put anything like Tanaka & Company together again. Yet the story of this warped political genius and his clever machine henchmen holds lessons for us all. American readers should not dismiss it as remote or exotic. For despite all the cultural differences, the political problems of this equally technologized, equally media-saturated and equally morally riven society are very close to our own.

HEADLINE: Stripped Bare

BYLINE: By A. O. Scott; A. O. Scott is a writer whose reviews appear in The Nation.

 BODY:

 CHARACTERS
 ON THE LOOSE
 Stories.
 By Janet Kauffman.
 142 pp. St. Paul:
Graywolf Press. Paper, $12.95. 
 It is a curious paradox that while the 1980's are generally recalled as a time of excess, the literary manner most often associated with the period is minimalism -- curt fictional bulletins from the ordinary world, delivered in clipped and affectless prose. While Janet Kauffman's two earlier collections, "Places in the World a Woman Could Walk" and "Obscene Gestures for Women," belonged to this mode, they were distinguished by their stringent wit and their clear-eyed feminism. And while much minimalist writing felt forced and evasive, Kauffman's careful, unadorned style seemed to fit the world of struggling farm families she wrote about. Her best stories managed, with remarkable economy, to be at once funny and haunting.
 Raised on a tobacco farm in Pennsylvania and for many years a farmer herself, Kauffman is now pushing her work in more experimental directions. "Maybe because I'm farming less," she notes on the back cover of "Characters on the Loose," her latest collection, "I think I'm farming language more." But this time her efforts have produced a meager harvest.
 The root of the problem is evident in the jacket copy that follows her observation: "In this collection," we are told, "language, like ground, occupies physical space. For Kauffman, this is in many ways a feminist claiming of territory." But in what ways? Authors are entitled to theorize about their own work, but in too many of these stories Kauffman presses a none-too-precise theoretical agenda at the expense of narrative technique.
 There is, for example, the story called "Signed Away," which asks, "If you think about Emily Dickinson biking the new trail, well, would she do it?" (Insert the word "just" and this might be a treatment for a highbrow Nike commercial.) The answer seems to be that she would, and that the experience would go like this: "On the way out of town, she has words with herself. She letters, she says. A litter the language. Born with. What portion of me. Riding the Ordovician folds. Wheel and while. Time before tock." A litter indeed.
 Granted, most of the stories don't approach this level of syntactic meltdown. "Nightmares for Everybody," "Girl Games" and "Eureka in Toledo, Weather Permitting" seem rambling and anecdotal at first, as they present mildly eccentric characters held together by loose familial and affective bonds and caught up in the rhythms of lower-middle-class Midwestern life. But in each Kauffman twists quotidian reality a few degrees to reveal unspoken depths of intensity and emotion. And then there are two stories -- "Unhoused, Among the Trunks of Trees" and "What Lies Ahead," placed together for maximum effect -- in which the placid surface of daily life yields suddenly and inexorably to horror, disclosing a world both utterly real and absolutely mysterious.
 Unfortunately, much of the rest of "Characters on the Loose," when it is not gratingly self-conscious, feels slack and diffuse. The book's central, longest and most ambitious entry manages to be all these at once: "26 Acts in 26 Letters" is best described as an effort in literal pornography -- it describes sexual acts performed by the letters of the alphabet. There are illustrations (recalling a manual of typography), though they don't really correspond to the acts described, which exploit the curves, openings and appendages of the characters.
 The point seems to be to drive home the two meanings of the book's title: since both the people in stories and the letters out of which they are made are called characters, the idea of characters "on the loose" conjures a vision of language and its creatures liberated and at play. But like most puns, this one becomes less interesting the more you think about it.
 Loosed from the bonds of narrative precision, psychological insight or social observation, the characters in many of these stories become mere names, whose only purpose seems to be to occupy space on the page. Since Kauffman is a writer so clearly gifted with the capacity for precision, insight and observation, this is especially disappointing.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 19; Column 2; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 339 words

HEADLINE: Books in Brief: Nonfiction

BYLINE: By Bill Kent 

 BODY:

THE GREAT LOBSTER WAR
 By Ron Formisano.
 University of Massachusetts,
 cloth, $35; paper, $14.95. 
 In 1956, some 4,000 of Maine's lobster fishermen decided to stage a "tie-up" -- that is, they refused to fish -- in protest of a 5-cent reduction in the dockside price, to 30 cents a pound, offered for their catch. They formed the Maine Lobsterman's Association and tried to persuade the rest of the state's estimated 5,000 full- and part-time lobstermen to help break the price-fixing policies of the dockside fish dealers' cartel. What could have passed as a tiny tempest in a lobster pot became a wonderful waste of time and tax money when the dealers, hearing of threats of violence against lobstermen who continued to fish, complained to the Justice Department, which then indicted the dealers as well as the association and its crusty founder, Leslie C. Dyer, and charged them with violating antitrust laws. After describing the tangled economic, cultural and family ties binding dealers and lobstermen, Ron Formisano, a University of Florida history professor, supplies a play-by-play analysis of the often hilarious trial, in which sly, taciturn lobstermen blithely flummoxed four furiously dedicated Federal prosecutors -- one of whom couldn't stand the sight of a lobster. Though a jury of equally taciturn Maine landlubbers convicted Dyer and the association, the Government refused to set punishment, choosing instead to extract its pound of fish from the dealers. In his strident and jargon-filled analysis, Formisano tries to wrest far more significance from this courtroom circus than it's worth: despite improvements in fishing technology and the establishment of a few fishing collectives, the dealers still set prices and lobstermen have little choice but to take what they can get. Still, this often charming David-and-Goliath tale is useful for its refutation of the myth of the ruggedly independent Yankee lobsterman, who is revealed here as one more victim of a captive market. Bill Kent
