SECTION: Section 2; Page 1; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk 

LENGTH: 2334 words

HEADLINE: Land of the Cineplex, Home of the Cassette

BYLINE: By PETER M. NICHOLS 

 BODY:
AMERICANS ARE WATCHING MOVIES ANY way they can, in theaters or at home, by VCR, cable or satellite dish. Most people prefer to take in a movie without leaving the house, and they're getting only cozier and cozier with that notion. At the same time, if a film is strong enough, people are turning out in large numbers at the multiplex. And with the continuous flood of movies out there, they know they had better hurry before most are whisked off the big screen and reformatted to fit their television sets.
They're so swamped with cinematic "product," in fact, that they might be forgiven for not fully recalling everything they see. "The one with the guy who makes stupid faces," was how Gene F., a 66-year-old retiree from Norfolk, Va., referred to "Liar Liar" with Jim Carrey. 
 Gene was among 1,347 people who responded to a recent New York Times/CBS News poll on America's movie-watching habits. The results are as fragmented as the population is diverse. Indeed, the multiplicity of choices and tastes in viewing behavior helps explain the escalating competition among movie-industry players -- from studio heads and theater exhibitors to video, cable and satellite operators, all elbowing for position.
This summer, theater attendance is up or down depending on the movie, but the overarching impression one gets from the poll is that in a country where some people are as familiar with movie grosses as with their grocery bills, watching movies has become something of a national pastime. Asked how many films they had watched during the preceding month, respondents frequently said they had watched several in theaters and several more on video and cable. "I go to all kinds, doesn't matter," said William Lee, 27, from Coronado, Calif. Discharged this week from the Navy, he was one of several dozen people interviewed afterward, some on the condition that their full names not be used. "I like the crowds, watching with others," he said. Mr. Lee also frequently rents videos, but Mike Nordstrom, a 48-year-old teacher from Farmington, N.M., watches movies only on video, to the tune of seven tapes or more a month. "We get what we need to get out of a film on a small screen," he said. Meanwhile, Jim Knight, 34, from Scranton, Pa., says he rarely goes to theaters, seldom rents videos and waits for most everything on premium cable. Counting his children, he said, he and his family watch at least three movies a day.
Mr. Nordstrom and Mr. Knight's viewing habits underscore a homeward tilt to movie watching. The poll found that 64 percent of Americans prefer watching movies at home. Sixty-five percent of the respondents had rented at least one video in the preceding month, and 16 percent had rented seven tapes or more. Eighty-two percent had seen at least one movie on "regular," or noncable, television in that time, and 22 percent had seen seven or more.
Richard T., 53, from Wallingford, Conn., said he went to the movies twice in the previous month but rented seven or more videos. "My home system is as good as a theater," he explained.
He'd get an argument, of course, from the 31 percent who said they preferred going to a theater. Susan Hughes, a homemaker in her 30's from Atlanta, rents videos but prefers theaters for mysteries and comedies. "It's the crowds, the atmosphere," she said. "If something's funnier to them, it's funnier to me." Patricia W., a 52-year-old grandmother from Frederick, Md., took the family to the theater revivals of all three "Star Wars" films earlier this year. "It's the magnificence of the large screen," she said. And for Gene from Virginia, theatergoing is a "social thing"; he goes with his golfing buddies. "We don't see a movie just because it's the hot one," he said. "We go to the movies just to go to the movies."
Though they may be in the minority, theatergoers are still in very large company. In 1996, in fact, there were 1.34 billion theater admissions, the largest since 1959. But homebodies are everywhere. Judy Thorburn, 56, from Portland, Ore., said she never went to theaters or video stores but watched a dozen movies a month via her satellite dish and borrowed tapes from her daughter, who collected them.
Home or theater -- the dichotomy kicks up dust all along the movie distribution trail. "Theaters will never be supplanted by home entertainment, but clearly the home is growing at a pace theater will never be able to maintain," said Bill Sondheim, president of Polygram Video.
 
Catch Them Now, Catch Them Later
Studios obviously want people to see movies in theaters, but they'll settle for later. Ideally, they'll catch them at both the megaplex and at home, maybe even several times for the same movie. But the timing has the movie business on edge. Theater people are worried that movies are going to video too quickly. The once-standard lag time of about six months from theater opening to video release has shrunk to an average of 5 months and 23 days. Video, in turn, which typically gets exclusive use of movies for 30 to 60 days, is worried that films are moving to cable pay-per-view too quickly.
Facing waits of as long as six months, premium cable channels, the last stop, are worried that movies aren't moving fast enough.
Video is particularly worried about losing its head start over pay-per-view. Studio video divisions bring in three times the revenues of their theatrical counterparts, helping bail out many a hugely expensive box-office flop. Still, rentals are down from the mid-1980's, when the VCR was relatively new and people raced home with armloads of cassettes as if they had struck gold at Sutter Creek. This year, too, dealers complain that poor movies aren't helping the rental market.
Nevertheless, "for a great night with the family, there's no place like home," argues a commercial from Blockbuster, the nation's largest video chain. Unless it's the multiplex.
"No matter how magical the technology, people don't want to be umbilically connected to an electronic box seven nights a week," said Jack Valenti, chairman of the Motion Picture Association of America, the studios' trade organization. Mr. Valenti is a theater man himself. "When my kids were younger, we had everything in my home, but, hell, they wanted to go out and see a movie."
Home viewing, however, gets points for practicality. "It's a matter of consumers' disposable time and income," said Michael Karaffa, executive vice president of New Line Home Video. "All of video's fundamental principles of the 80's still hold: convenience, low cost."
In the Times poll, which was conducted in the spring and has a margin of error of plus or minus 3 percentage points, 59 percent of respondents said they hadn't been to a theater during the month. Twenty percent of them said tickets were too expensive. (The national average admission is $4.41, said William Kartozian, president of the National Association of Theater Owners, though prices in cities like New York can climb to $9.) Three percent said there was no theater nearby. Twenty-two percent said they had no time, and 11 percent said they had no interest.
Only 10 percent said they didn't like the movies -- too violent, too much sex, too trashy. Richard, from Connecticut, said he wasn't impressed with what he had seen recently: "Dumb. No plot lines anymore." Ms. Hughes from Georgia said she was reading more and seeing fewer movies. "They just aren't as interesting as they used to be," she explained.
In the main, though, respondents were positive about what they were seeing. "The state of the art is excellent," said Patricia from Maryland. "Acting is better. The sound is beautiful."
 
Now You See It, Now You Don't
One problem for theater people is that there just may be too many movies, especially during the summer and the holidays. If a film doesn't succeed immediately, it is yanked off the screen to make way for the next movie, which yields to the next, and so on. That irked some respondents. "It takes a while to build an audience, but they come and go so quickly," said Deidre Lee, 53, from Austin, Tex.
Blame the economics. "Production and marketing costs are so high on the theatrical end, we have to move up our cash flows," said one studio executive. That's one way of saying that a movie is going nowhere in theaters, so to have any hope of recouping the $70 million it took to make and promote it, it's necessary to get it into video stores fast before people forget all about it.
Now there is a new wrinkle to the rush to video. Consumers increasingly want to buy and not just rent the biggest movies -- an "Independence Day," say -- which they can then watch more than once. To make the most of that inclination, the megahits are released to theaters in late spring and early summer to strike the mother lode at the megaplex and then be ready for sale during the holidays. In these special cases, the theater-to-video window has been narrowed to between four and five months.
Renters have always played a waiting game for movies, but these days faster exits from theaters are raising expectations even further, creating a circular effect: since audiences know a movie will be on videotape shortly, they have less reason to run to a theater to see it, and with turnout at the theaters thus dampened, the movie's exit to video is hastened all the more.
Some respondents said they routinely waited for "smaller" movies. Ms. Hughes said she automatically waited for certain kinds of films. "Romances, the sappy stuff, particularly if it's going to a tear-jerker," she explained.
Every now and then a good movie falls by the wayside in theaters because the sheer glut of new films makes it impossible for people to see everything they would like to. Video people habitually mention "The Shawshank Redemption," a 1994 prison drama, as a classic example of a movie that didn't get the theater run it deserved -- even though the film was nominated for an Oscar as best picture. Later on it caught fire at home, where it had a chance to build good word-of-mouth.
 
No Matter What, Theaters Are Crucial
Still, a movie's theater run generally remains the bellwether of its success later on in other formats. "If a movie doesn't work theatrically, it won't work in other markets," said William Mechanic, chairman of Fox Filmed Entertainment. "The tendency now is that if you didn't see it in a theater, you're not going to seek it out on video or TV unless that movie is a fairly successful one that you hadn't heard about and that by the time you got there, it was gone," he said.
Some respondents to the poll would argue with that statement. At home, where the rental tab can be less than half that at the megaplex, viewers take chances. "If it looks like it's not going to be that good in theaters, I'll rent it," said Troy G., 24, from Evanston, Ill. So does Richard, from Connecticut. "I like the flops," he said. "Like that one about water," he said. ("Waterworld.")
Pound for pound, there may be no more amenable movie watcher than Ms. Lee from Texas, who said she watches just about everything (four movies in theaters and four on video during the poll month). She made it her business, for example, to go to the theater to see "Secrets and Lies," "Shine" "Sling Blade" and the other smaller films nominated for the bigger Oscars this year. That's more than can be said for the many members of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences who watched nominated films on videotape.
Ms. Lee, who has a 19-inch television screen, said she preferred to see "more substantial" films in theaters. " 'The English Patient' wouldn't look good on a small screen," she said.
Of course, much solid dramatic fare plays well on video, too. "We were delighted by the small films recently," said Mr. Nordstrom, the videophile from New Mexico. He and his wife planned to see the Oscar films and other more esoteric movies. "We avoided the whole Jane Austen thing, but the Shakespeare stuff we'll watch, like the Richard one with Ian McKellen," he said.
Most respondents said they went to theaters for "big" action and dramatic films with elaborate special effects that couldn't be replicated at home. "People don't have 10-foot wall screens," Mr. Valenti noted.
Still, home screens are getting larger. Nineteen percent of the poll's respondents said they had screens larger than 30 inches, and many who didn't said they had plans to upgrade. The impending arrival of digital and high-definition television also brightens the home vista considerably.
 
Dishes Are Offering Even Bigger Helpings
Another lift comes from satellite services. Ten percent of the poll respondents said they owned a dish. Now, in some five million homes, satellite services like DirecTV, Primestar and Echo Star are touted as the hot new way to take one's movies, though there is evidence that subscribers aren't watching as many as it was thought they might. Satellite operators talk about eventually serving up hundreds of movies on hundreds of channels. Industry analysts say that that size offering won't come about until satellite use becomes more widespread.
Whether by satellite, cable or other means, such plenitude is euphemistically referred to as "near video on demand." If one can't order up any movie, there is still more than enough choice to satisfy the average viewer. Last month a cable service in the New York area said it was planning to offer 1,000 movies. Subscribers have heard promises like that before, but even the talk makes video dealers nervous.
"If I had a larger choice, I would definitely stop going to the store," said Patricia, from Maryland. Video, however, is countering with a new technology of its own: the digital video disk, the five-inch CD with a movie on it that propels the quality of sound and image far beyond the videocassette.
"They just want everybody to go out and buy a new system," said Heather Murphy, a 25-year-old Eugene, Ore., woman. No argument there, for sure.

SECTION: Section 9; Page 7; Column 1; Real Estate Desk

HEADLINE: In the Region;
Along the Jersey Riverfront, a Resurgence of Housing

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
MANY of the barren patches that still remain on New Jersey's Hudson River waterfront are beginning to fill up with housing as a second wave of construction rolls across the 18-mile shoreline.
In this redevelopment effort, which began 18 months ago and is now gaining momentum, developers are trying to capitalize on an improving residential market and what they say is a pent-up demand for housing at the water's edge. 
 Work is under way or will soon begin on projects totaling 2,682 units, most of them luxury rentals, according to the ACI Real Estate Group in Jersey City. And hundreds more are in various stages of planning for the riverfront, where 20,672 units could be built.
For riverfront towns, some of which missed out on the last building cycle, the hope is that the activity will or spur the revival of their stretch of the Hudson's west shore.
"The riverfront is coming back," said ACI's president, Robert P. Antonicello, adding that it has not yet regained its image a decade ago as the "gold coast" when several projects, some quite grand, were progressing. Though not all were realized 3,500 residences, mostly condominiums, were built before the recession hit and construction slowed to a snail's pace through 1995.
Not only are the new projects mostly rentals -- for which financing is more readily available than for for-sale housing, experts say -- but they are smaller in scale. Many are in Jersey City, including two rental towers totaling 786 units at Newport, the huge mixed-use center. And developers of two recently completed and fully leased rental projects in the city are or soon will be developing additional riverfront rental buildings.
But the activity has spread to other Hudson County towns. In West New York work has begun on The Landings, a 276-unit rental, and will soon begin on Jacob's Ferry, a 464-unit town-house condominium, the only for-sale project announced so far in this wave of development.
In Hoboken, work is to start on 196 rentals. And the city also expects to name a developer in the next month for the residential portion of the project it plans on the waterfront land its owns. That portion calls for up to 522 residences.
The wave of development has also has moved into Edgewater in Bergen County where 430 residences are under way, including the 266-rental River Club project, and an equal number of units are planned.
James W. Hughes, dean of the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers University, said that the riverfront's rebound was "benefiting from the stable job growth and economy of the state, which is in its 62d month of recovery." In addition, he said, there was a ripple effect from Manhattan's strong housing market and improving image.
Today's waterfront is also more accessible thanks to road and transportation improvements that have been or are being made. Construction began in April on the first half of the 20.5-mile light-rail system that will run from Bayonne to Ridgefield Park. The line, according to New Jersey Transit, overseer of the state's mass transit system, will improve property values by 10 to 30 percent and spur more development.
THE initial 10-mile light-rail stretch, from Bayonne to Jersey City, will not be completed until 1999. Still, developers say it will enhance the marketability of their projects.
So will the new ferry terminal in Weehawken that will be linked to the rail line. Construction is expected to start in the fall of 1998 on the project, which is being developed by the local Arcorp Properties, owned by Arthur E. Imperatore. Its subsidiary, New York Waterway, runs the existing terminal and operates five trans-Hudson ferries and plans to operate a sixth.
William Becker, a housing consultant in Teaneck, said the waterfront could absorb about 1,000 rentals a year for the next three years. After that there could be an oversupply, he said, adding that by then the market could support more for-sale riverfront housing.
The rental vacancy rate hovers between 1 to 2 percent, said Mr. Antonicello of AC!, and rents have risen. On average, the rent for a typical 1,000-square-foot, 2-bedroom apartment is $1,750 a month, up $200 from a year before. he said.
Those factors, developers said, gave them the confidence to move ahead. The pace of production is steady but not aggressive for the demand on both sides of the river, "keeping the market from stumbling," said Allen F. Goldman. He is a vice president at the Applied Companies of Hoboken, which alone or with partners is involved in three riverfront projects, including Port Liberte in Jersey City, made up of condominium apartments. .
Evidence of the market's strength is the pace of leasing at the company's second building at Portside in Jersey City. The project (its first 229-unit building is leased) was revived from the 80's and is the first of the new developments.
Since leasing began three weeks ago at the nearly completed second building, 132 of its 295 studio to three-bedroom units have been leased. Rents for the apartments, ranging from 571 to 2,036 square feet of space, are $1,115 to $3,550, 8 percent more than those in the first building, Mr. Goldman said.
Leasing also is under way at the 340-unit rental the Lefrak Organization of Rego Park, Queens, is building at Newport. Deposits have been taken on 102 of the studio to 2-bedroom apartments, which range in size from 520 to 1,500 square feet, but can be combined. Rents range from $950 to $2,800.
"Manhattan is the magnet and it is drawing increasing attention to the Hudson's west bank," said Richard S. LeFrak, the company's president. Banking on that the company started work on a second building with 446 units, to be similar in size and price to the ones in the first building.
This time around, analysts and developers agree, the demand from professionals who work in Manhattan or in the millions of square feet of riverfront office towers will continue and increase as Manhattan rents rise. They are the riverfront's "bread and butter," said Jeffrey B. Albert, vice president at Avalon Properties, based in Wilton, Conn., with offices in Princeton. Mr. Albert added that the influx of people from Manhattan, is expected to stay steady at 15 to 20 percent.
HIS company just finished leasing Avalon Cove, a 504-unit mid-rise project just south of Newport. The 1- to 3-bedroom apartments, including penthouses, rented for $1,110 to $4,550, the highest rents achieved so far. Avalon is planning an adjacent 269-unit building, which it will lease at comparable rents.
Those are the renters Applied also expects to draw to the Shipyard, the 1,165-unit project with a park at its core that the company is planning on 45 acres at the northern end of the waterfront in Hoboken. Mr. Goldman said construction will begin in September on the first 196 units, including 26 loft-like apartments.
Rents for the 1- and 2-bedroom units, ranging in size from 820 to 1,200 square feet, will be $1,450 to $1,950, he said.
Some developers expect to draw new faces. "People who work in northwestern New Jersey also will make the reverse east- west commute since little luxury rentals are being built in that sector of the state," said Marshall B. Tycher, president of the Roseland Property Company of Roseland.
His company is dividing the 100 waterfront acres it owns in West New York, where 4,000 units could rise, into parcels to develop itself and sell to other builders. Roseland is developing the first five-acre parcel into 276 one- and two-bedroom rentals, which are scheduled for completion by the fall of 1998.
Others say more empty-nesters from the suburbs, families and affulent immigrants will also be drawn to the riverfront and that some will be ready to buy. That is what the state's largest developer, K. Hovnanian Enterpises of Red Bank, is betting on for its first riverfront project.
In the next two months the company will start 464 for-sale town houses on 20 acres in West New York that it bought from Roseland. The 2- and 3-bedroom units, each with a garage, will have 1,240 to 2,300 square feet. Prices at Jacob's Ferry are expected to start in the low $200,000 range, said Gabriel Pasquale, senior marketing and sales adviser for the company's Northeast region.
"With rents going up the market is prime for for-sale housing," he said, adding that the vision in 1986 of what the waterfront "was supposed to be is now coming to fruition."

SECTION: Section 13CN; Page 1; Column 1; Connecticut Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 1494 words

HEADLINE: Not a Lot of Crime but There's an Officer on the Beat

BYLINE: By JACK CAVANAUGH 

 BODY:
MOST people who live in the coastal enclave of Rowayton like to think of their village, bounded on the west by the Five Mile River and on the south by Long Island Sound, as an independent entity. And why not? After all, Rowayton has its own post office, fire station, library, school, banks, churches, restaurants, beach, marinas and Civil War-era cannon. It even decides how some tax money is allocated.
Despite all these things, Rowayton is not an independent community. It is a village within the City of Norwalk. And that arrangement occasionally becomes rancorous, as it did a few years ago when a group of Rowaytonites began a secessionist movement because of their anger over a city revaluation they contended would disproportionately raise their property taxes. Like other secessionist moves in the state in recent years, the Rowayton effort died aborning. 
 "That was a waste of energy, and all it did was create ill feeling," said Randall Avery, the chairman of the Sixth Taxing District, which allocates tax monies to the library, the Rowayton Civic Center, the volunteer fire station and Bayley Beach, which is solely for Rowaytonites. "But we still feel that there is a disproportionate return of tax money to Rowayton considering how much we pay in taxes to the city."
Now, though, Rowayton, which has a population of 5,000, has some balm in the form of its own police officer, albeit for only part of each day. The officer is Joseph Jensen, himself a Rowaytonite and member of the Norwalk Police Department, who since May 1 has been assigned to Rowayton as part of the department's community policing initiative.
The announcement that Mr. Jensen was being transferred from South Norwalk, which has the highest crime rate in the city, quite a bit of it violent, to Rowayton, which has very little crime, raised some eyebrows. The Norwalk newspaper, The Hour, said in an editorial that the move appeared to be a ploy by the Mayor, Frank J. Esposito, to curry favor with Rowayton voters during an election year.
Specifically, the editorial said, "That seems to be the only clear explanation for him agreeing to move a police officer to one of the city's wealthiest, safest enclaves. Rowayton has so little crime Barney Fyfe's crime-fighting skills would not be challenged. Putting an officer on such quiet streets cannot be the intent of community policing, unless City hall believes that, next to South Norwalk, Rowayton has the city's most significant crime problems."
Both the Mayor and the Norwalk Police Chief, Harry W. Rilling, scoffed at The Hour's criticism. "They're missing the point," said Mr. Esposito, a Republican who is seeking a sixth two-year term this year. "We've said for some time now that our goal was to extend our community policing program from South Norwalk throughout the city. And Rowayton seemed like an ideal place to start because it has a business center and we've been having some problems there."
Mr. Esposito was alluding to complaints from some residents about an increase in the number of trucks trying to circumvent traffic on Interstate 95 by driving along Route 136 which extends from Martin Luther King Boulevard in South Norwalk through a residential area of Rowayton and into the heart of the village.
"That's one of the reasons we picked Rowayton," Mr. Esposito said. "And, besides that, there have been more housebreaks in outer areas of the city."
But neither the Police Department nor any Rowayton civic leaders or residents interviewed felt there had been any upsurge in crime in Rowayton, which has the flavor of a Cape Cod village.
"The crime rate in Rowayton is relatively low," Chief Rilling said. "But, because it's a self-contained community, we felt that it was a natural place to expand community policing. And in doing so we did not reduce our commitment to South Norwalk, where, at any given time, we have between 10 and 15 officers on duty. What we're trying to do where is improve the quality of life for people throughout the city of Norwalk."
There has been no criticism from civic leaders in South Norwalk. "We can't say we'll be underserved by the transfer of the officer," said Robert Burgess, the executive director of Norwalk Economic Opportunity Now, an agency based in South Norwalk that is supported by the city, state and Federal governments. "We always welcome having more community police officers in South Norwalk," Mr. Burgess said, "but we're not going to say that other areas shouldn't have them, too."
Until Officer Jensen was assigned to Rowayton on a regular basis, the community was essentially patrolled by police radio cars that also covered a part of South Norwalk. As a result, townspeople rarely got to know the police officers who went in and out of the village, usually without getting out of their radio cars.
"It's going to be different with Officer Jensen," Chief Rilling said. "Not only will he make himself known in the community by getting out and talking to people, but he'll also attend community meetings and other functions where he thinks his presence can help establish a better relationship. He'll also set his own hours. And at times, if he feels it's necessary, he will work in plainclothes in his own car, rather than a radio car."
Though he appears to have spent most of his time in his radio car to date, Officer Jensen has made his presence known in the Rowayton Avenue business district.
"He has stopped in now and then," said Louis Froelich, a former chief of the Rowayton volunteer fire company in his hardware store, which is among a cluster of small shops on the avenue. "It's a good feeling, knowing he's around."
A few doors away, Carla Mortelliti, the owner of Carla's Flower Box, said that there had been two attempted break-ins at her shop in the last year, but that her burglar alarm frightened away the would-be intruders. "A lot of people think this is just a sleepy little town where there's no crime, but it sometimes happens," Ms. Mortelliti said.
Next door, Mike Czegledi, the proprietor of Midway Cleaners, also welcomed having a police officer in town. "This is not exactly a high-crime area, but we still need protection," Mr. Czegledi said.
Mr. Avery, the Taxing District chairman, said that he and some other Rowayton residents had asked that a police officer be assigned to the village for some time. "There was a rash of commercial break-ins in 1995 and the speeding along Route 136 is terrible from about 7 to 9 in the morning," Mr. Avery said. "Having an officer here on a regular basis is bound to help."
The police and residents of Rowayton who were interviewed said that most of the crime in the village involved break-ins, or attempted break-ins, in homes and commercial establishments and thefts from sail boats and yachts tied up at boatyards and marinas on the Five Mile River.
To combat the boat thefts in particular, marina and boatyard owners have at times hired off-duty police officers and security guards.
Indeed, Chief Rilling said that Officer Jensen has worked as a security guard in Rowayton while off-duty in past years. "He really knows the community and its people, so we think he's perfect for the job," the Chief said.
Some merchants along Rowayton Avenue said they have yet to meet, or even see, Officer Jensen. But his presence has been felt, at least by some motorists.
"I've been told that a lot more citations have been given out since he got here," said John Cagnina, the chairman of the Rowayton Civic Association's land use committee. "That seems to indicate that he's getting out of his car and walking around. That's good, because having a community police officer is the closest thing to the concept of the old cop on the beat."
Mr. Jensen said he has given out dozens of moving violation tickets along with scores of written and verbal warnings to truck drivers and other motorists speeding on Route 136 and on Wilson Avenue, where through trucks are not allowed. And his quick response to a 911 call from a merchant on Rowayton Avenue led to two arrests last month.
"A lady, who had cashed a bad check for $400 the day before, came back in the store to try to cash another check the next day," said Vinny Taliercio, the owner of the Rowayton Market, which is in the heart of the village. "I immediately called 911 and they radioed Officer Jensen who got to the store in a couple of minutes and arrested the woman and a guy waiting outside in a car."
Officer Jensen smiled at the recollection. "Actually, I got there a minute after I got the call," he said.
Mr. Jensen, who has been a Norwalk officer for 14 years, occasionally works a 3 to 11 shift -- "That way I get to know what's going on a little better." -- also recently arrested a young man for narcotics possession in the rear of the Rowayton School. "By working different hours, people who might be inclined to cause trouble never know when I might come around," he said.

HEADLINE: SUNDAY, JULY 13, 1997;
BOISE NOISE

 BODY:
One byproduct of New York City's plunging crime rate was a proposed economic-development ad campaign comparing New York's per capita crime rate to that of relatively tiny Boise, Idaho. New York's lower rate excited the Martin Agency, the Richmond, Va., company that won the account in 1996. A mock-up for its $12 million campaign showed a tough New York businessmen with a line announcing that his city's safety rates right up there . . . with Boise. Alas, focus groups didn't buy it, perhaps sensing that per head comparisons don't always mean much. New York had 984 homicides in 1996; Boise had 1. The idea, and the Martin Agency, were quietly rubbed out.

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY;
New on the QE2: Your Broadway Debut

BYLINE: By Ray Cormier 

 BODY:
The Queen Elizabeth 2 is offering a chance for passengers to be in the show on a trans-Atlantic crossing this fall.
The cruise, called Broadway Goes to Sea, sails from New York on Oct. 13 and arrives in Southampton, England, Oct. 19. In between, passengers can observe Broadway professionals rehearsing a musical, and even audition for and play a few small parts. The cruise will culminate with a performance in the ship's 532-seat theater. 
 Which show will be staged and what parts may be available for passengers will depend on the professional cast, said Edward Strauss, the musical coordinator for the Broadway revival of "A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum." Mr. Strauss will be leading the music on the cruise.
Among the Broadway veterans scheduled to participate are Faith Prince (Miss Adelaide in "Guys and Dolls"), Lewis J. Stadlen (Senex in "Forum") and Mark Linn-Baker (Hysterium in "Forum").
The cruise package, $3,399 to $18,449, includes a cocktail party with the stars at Sardi's, tickets to two musicals (one in New York and one in London) and economy-class air fare back to the United States.
Information: Pied Piper Travel in New York, (800) 874-7312 or (212) 239-2412, or White Travel Service in West Hartford, Conn.; (800) 200-7447 or (860) 233-2648. RAY CORMIER

HEADLINE: Surviving, Thriving in Camden

BYLINE: By ANDY NEWMAN 

DATELINE: CAMDEN

 BODY:
THE phone inside the trailer is ringing. Dave Moto snakes an arm in the window and picks it up. "Good afternoon," he says smoothly, "Kea'Boos Enterprises." It is his erstwhile security guard, who has been missing for four days, along with Mr. Moto's wallet. She wants to know what's going on.
"Nothing," he says. "Not a damn thing." He tells her she cannot have her job back and slams the phone down. 
 The new night watch, Denise Williams, who has been napping in the trailer, emerges. "I told you, soon as she got broke, she'd be back," Ms. Williams says.
Mr. Moto fumes, but only for a minute. It's not as if this is a shocking turn of events. He has been through 100 employees since he moved his bottomless inventory of refrigerators, televisions, acrylic landscapes, torque wrenches, truck tires, stuffed animals and lawn mowers in every possible state of repair into a cavernous defunct factory in East Camden. He's been burglarized 15 times in 18 months.
Last year, the landlord fell afoul of the fire code, and the city shut off the water and electricity, so now the lights in Camden's biggest used-stuff store brighten and dim in concert with surges of deafening gas generators (Mr. Moto is on his sixth generator, the first five having been stolen). No heat in winter. No air-conditioner in summer, except the ones he sells.
Still, he has worked his way to the top of Camden's junk heap, first running one stall in the flea market around the corner, then two, then five, then seven, then moving into the football-field-size former Diversified Foam plant. His business, which on any given day also involves cleaning office buildings, fixing cars and installing sewer drains, feeds his extended family, some of whose members are also his employees, and it is growing. "There's no telling how far you can go if you keep investing your money back in it," he says.
Just about everything you read about Camden, national symbol for urban decay, is true. It is indeed the poorest city in the state and one of the poorest in the nation, ravaged by drugs and crime, its citizens and woefully inept municipal government vastly dependent on state and Federal handouts, its once mighty manufacturing base all but vaporized, its row house neighborhoods punctuated by long, silent stretches where vacant shells and empty lots outnumber inhabited homes.
But what you read about Camden, a city of 85,000 people without a mall, a movie theater or even a bowling alley, tends to ignore the fact that life and community and commerce persist and even, sometimes, thrive, in numerous forms, however makeshift or marginalized. People work and worship and play with their kids, hang out with friends, go to the park. There are neighborhoods that are actually pleasant, and even in the rougher districts, many people (though not most) stay because they want to. For better or worse, it's home.
 
A Desolate Strip, A Hopeful Barber
After six months of searching, Rich Colon has been reunited with his barber.
"I didn't get my hair cut till I saw him again," said Mr. Colon, 27, resplendent in the barber's leopard-skin chair cape on a recent Saturday morning. "I was a bad case."
The barber, who identified himself only as Ron -- he said there were still a few details to sort out before he was ready to publicize his shop -- grinned as he put a few finishing buzzes on Mr. Colon's Caesar (shaved sides, square lines, very short bangs). Ron had been working for a barber on the other side of town, in East Camden. Then he seemed to vanish, but last month he took over a vacant barber shop on Broadway, much closer to Mr. Colon's South Camden home.
The shop, an agreeable old two-chair parlor with white wooden counters and brown, patterned linoleum, is on a typically desolate stretch of what was once Camden's main drag, across from an empty lot and catty-corner from four abandoned buildings. On the plus side, Ron said, he is the only barber for blocks around, and the storefronts on either side of him are occupied, by a pharmacy and a doctor. "I like the atmosphere here," he said.
Not that there aren't problems. "A guy got killed last week, right across the street," he said. "They tried to rob him, then they shot him in the head and ran him over. I haven't had any trouble, but after closing hours, you try to get out of here fast."
Ron, 28, plans to move above the shop with his wife and baby daughter to "They tried to rob him, then they shot him in the head and ran him over. I haven't had any trouble, but after closing hours, you try to get out of here fast."
Ron, 28, plans to move above the shop with his wife and baby daughter to be near his business, "in case anything happens."
"It's like anywhere you go," he said. "You got to keep your eyes open."
Outside a public school half a mile away, a dazzling peacock of a woman in a blue headdress and gold cat's-eye glasses sees her two white-robed daughters off to karate class. The woman, Nzinga House, is a seamstress, and she is modeling one of her own outfits, a festive blue-and-white print with lavender ruffles that seems two parts African princess and one part Southern belle.
"I get a lot of positive comments," said Ms. House, 33, who works out of her living room. "I just wish I had a lot of positive cash flow to go with it. But my people only want to wear their own clothing in February" -- Black History Month. "I've got to get them unbrainwashed."
She likes the karate class because, for at least a few hours a week, she doesn't have to worry about what her daughters are wearing. "Most of the clothes kids wear now is that hoochie-coochie stuff," she said. "I want them to look like girls, not little sexy-women. Like I'll show them a J. C. Penney catalogue and they'll say, 'Mom can you make that?' and I do but I make it lower."
The class, taught by Beauford Sloane El, a custodian at the school and a fourth-degree black belt, is as much about discipline and respect for self and others as learning how to throw or block a punch. The 30-odd students (among them Mr. Colon's 5-year-old son) end every sentence with "sir" and recite the Five Codes of Tang Soo Do by heart: "Be loyal to your leader, obedience to parents, honor friendship, always finish what you start, choose sense of honor."
Most of the kids stay focused, but Khiara and Djenne House, 8 and 7, respectively, spend most of the class looking around, slacking off and trying to draw the attention of Mr. El, a big-bellied man with a rumbling voice. Eventually he walks over to Djenne, pushes her shoulders down and places her hand on her ankle. She beams.
"Huuuuhhh, hah!" he shouts. "Reach! Grab! Anything you do, you do your best!"
Gears shift abruptly.
"Wuk, Yah! Meditate!" he yells, a spiritual drill sergeant. The students fall to silent contemplation.
 
'I Want Them to See That We Care'
Small things count. Every morning, Aida Pagan pours water across the sidewalk in front of her house and brushes it clean with a broom. "You have to do this," she said. "Otherwise, it just gets terrible. I like to see everything nice and clean, because I live here, my kids live here and I want them to see that we care. It's that obvious."
Ms. Pagan's house, immaculately whitewashed and dressed in two shades of green trim, is one of the showpieces of North Camden, just about the only neighborhood in the city where the perennial promises of renewal seem to be coming true. When she and her husband, a contractor, bought it in 1990 for about $5,000, it was like most of the houses in North Camden after the 1973 riots: a torched shell. "You would stand in the basement and you had a skylight," she said. "You could see floor after floor."
Not only did their friends back in Philadelphia think they were crazy for trying to fix it up, their new neighbors did too. But they took a chance -- not that they were reckless: Ms. Pagan's husband, Michael Datil, encased the front of the house in nearly a foot of concrete to keep out stray bullets -- and they have stayed long enough to see their block turn around.
Around the corner on State Street, two long blocks of mansard-roofed row houses once known as Lawyers Row have been reclaimed, largely through the efforts of community groups like the North Camden Land Trust. The trust has bought and fixed up over 100 units of affordable housing, 76 of which are occupied by families who are building up equity in a sort of lease-to-own arrangement for $285 a month.
Dion Wiles, a foreman for the company doing most of the renovation and a fledgling homeowner himself thanks to the land trust, said, "It's a slow process, but for anyone who had seen this part of Camden 10 years ago, it's just been dramatic. It's a flip, the total opposite." Like many residents of State Street, Mr. Wiles said he had no intention of moving away. (For homeowners, Camden's property values provide another compelling reason to stay put. "You can put $70,000 into fixing up a house and it's worth $40,000 the day you open it," said Daniel Joyce, community outreach director for Guadalupe Family Services, a nonprofit group based in North Camden.)
The two blocks of State Street that have been renovated are practically idyllic, with old-style street lamps and newly planted trees. On one porch, a woman gave two small children a bath with a watering can as they sat in a tiny wading pool. Down the block, James Lee McCain, a retired farm laborer, sat on his porch and watched kids play in the pink-and-blue jungle gym across the street.
"I do love this place," Mr. McCain, 53, said as smells of peanut butter sandwiches and marijuana smoke mingled and drifted over from neighboring porches. "There's so much to see."
 
A Place of Their Own: Frijoles and Quesadillas
Still of the afternoon. A 3-year-old girl and her mother sit in a bright Mexican restaurant on Federal Street in East Camden, the city's most ethnically mixed neighborhood. The girl, Jennifer Cruz, won't touch her taco. She goes to the counter, climbs up on a stool, reaches into the candy jar and pulls out a lollipop shaped like a roast chicken and heavily dusted with chili powder. "No!" Jennifer's mother, Minerva, cries. Too late.
"All she likes is hot stuff."
A man who appears to be retarded walks in, pats the big barrel-shaped jug of papaya water on the counter and brays like a donkey. The co-owner, Marcela Zapata, smiles and pours him a glass.
Business, say Mrs. Zapata and her husband, Eloy, has been only O.K. since they opened Mexico Lindo a year ago. Mrs. Zapata's cooking -- fragrant bowls of frijoles charros, a rich bean-and-bacon soup, fresh mushroom and spinach quesadillas, several varieties of homemade salsa -- is definitely not the problem. Nor is the location, a relatively stable shopping strip near the edge of the city, a few blocks from Route 130. The name of the city is.
"I give out flyers in the suburbs," said Mr. Zapata, 45, who was a police officer in Mexico City and a construction worker here before starting the restaurant. "Cherry Hill, Pennsauken. People are interested, but as soon as they hear Camden, they say, oh, no, Camden, crime, drugs, you know."
Even so, and even though they spend nearly every waking hour in the restaurant -- 13 or 14 hours a day, seven days a week -- it has been worth it. "In a factory, you're not working for anything," said Mrs. Zapata, 32, who made brakes in Glassboro before this. "This is working for the future, for my kids. This is mine."
A Camden teacher, Maria Kulp, comes in to celebrate the last day of school on her way home to Willingboro. There is no authentic Mexican food in Willingboro, says Mrs. Kulp, who comes from Guadalajara.
"Rico, rico, rico," she says, digging into a ham, avocado, jalapenh.
Mrs. Zapata chats up her customer."Are you married, senora?" Mrs. Zapata asks. Yes, she replies.
"You should bring your husband here."
Around the block, at a Vietnamese restaurant called Kim Do, Huyen Tran, 8, and her mother, Sen Tran, are celebrating the third grader's appearance on the honor roll. Huyen, pretty, chubby and shy, dips her spring rolls into a big bowl of peanut sauce and slurps a sweet drink made with beans and coconut milk.
"When we first got to this country I moved to Trenton, but I didn't like it," Sen Tran said. "I moved here because there are more people from my country" -- somewhere between 1,000 and 4,000, depending on whom you ask -- "and if my kids don't understand something in school they can ask a friend, O.K., what's this mean in Vietnamese. They can learn from each other."
Though parents in Camden lament that there is nothing there for their children to do, the gradual decay of the city -- much of it now has the overgrown feel of a small old Southern town -- provides endless recreational opportunities for resourceful youngsters. Two blocks in from Route 30 in East Camden, 11-year-old Rafael Flores and his friends drove Go Karts and dirt bikes around the tire-strewn parking lot of an abandoned bus depot.
"We had these tires set up in a track but people drive cars over it and mess it all up," he said. It did not seem to make much difference.
"I like Camden just the way it is," Rafael said. "I don't care what people say. We can play here and the cops don't ever bug us."
 
Before You Criticize, Come Spend a Day
Citizens of Camden are acutely aware of the city's reputation in the outside world, and they can be understandably defensive.
"People can't say nothing about Camden unless they've been here," said Ms. Pagan's 16-year-old son, Luis. "They can say it's bad or they can say it's good. The only way they're gonna find out is to just spend one day in Camden and see how it is."
Gloria Lyons, Plan Coordinator for Save Our Waterfront, an offshoot of the North Camden Land Trust, still holds on to a 1992 Time magazine article, "Who Could Live Here?" that portrayed Camden as a place beyond saving: "Many American cities have sinkholes that are just as run-down, burned out, crime ridden and drug infested," the article said. "The difference is that this describes all of Camden, not just part of it."
"That story gave no hope," Ms. Lyons said. "Any young person that was beginning to shape their lives and get some kind of direction as to what they wanted to do after high school, this killed it. The only good thing a completely negative article like that does is that it probably helps generate more support from foundations. But it does nothing for the morale of those of us who are working, who do have half a brain."
In 1995, when the city broke its record for murders (58, for a murder rate more than quadruple New York City's that year), the papers and television tracked each killing as if it were the latest jump in the stock market.
"It was like people were rooting it on," said Juan Aguilar, a 23-year-old Web site designer in New Brunswick who grew up in Camden and is trying to open a branch office of his company here. "It was really, really weird."
Being a white person in Camden -- there are about 12,000 -- means always having to explain yourself to friends who live outside the city.
"When I tell people I live in Camden there's always a pregnant pause," said Bill Schwarzman, a 67-year-old insurance underwriter who has lived on a tree-lined block in the far reaches of East Camden, almost in Pennsauken, since 1989.
"Always a pregnant pause. People say, do you have any white people in your neighborhood? I say, yeah, but I live in Camden. There are Hispanic people on my block. There are black people on my block. There are Jews -- O.K., there are Jew," he said, referring to himself. "And Catholics, and all different kinds of people, but we all get along."
 
Street Bazaar On Broadway
Down on Broadway, outside the bus station, business is so slow that even the hustlers get hustled. A man in a blue tank top approaches the table where Oumar Le is selling sunglasses and bootleg cassettes and makes him an offer.
"I'm talking about a substantial opportunity," the man says. "I'm talking about a thousand dollars a month part time." He's talking about delivering the Philadelphia Inquirer. Although the man buys a pair of mirrored shades and leaves a three-dollar tip, Mr. Le is noncommittal.
"I don't understand English, so how can I sell newspapers," he says, in French, after the man drives off. Mr. Le, who is from Senegal, recently relocated his stand from Brooklyn at the recommendation of relatives who live in Camden. Ca va? he is asked.
"Ca va peu," he says, "and I don't know why. I'll give it two more weeks and if it doesn't pick up I'm leaving."
A few minutes later another man comes by, flicks his wrist and unfurls a cascade of flavored condoms. "I got grape, root beer, strawberry." The vendors, sitting under a tree next to the Vietnamese fruit salad cart, politely decline.
"We're all married," says Abdul Zbabir, who sells bootleg Tommy Hilfiger T-shirts. "If I use a condom with my wife, she'll say where were you last night and make me go sleep on the couch for two weeks. Sleep on the couch and go to Cooper Hospital in the morning. And get me a receipt."
Back at Kea'Boos, a dodgy-looking is trying to sell Dave Moto a matching pair of rugs. They are about the size of bath mats and look suspiciously mass-produced, but he insists they are real Oriental rugs, worth $80 apiece. He'll take $20 for both.
"What am I gonna sell them for if I pay $10 for a rug like that?" Mr. Moto says. After several minutes of haggling, the man settles for $11.
No transaction is too small for Mr. Moto, 38, now in his fourth year in the junk business. A former maintenance man for Best Western Motels, Mr. Moto (the name is indeed Japanese; he is of black, Irish, Japanese and American Indian descent) got his start as a laborer at the 15-stall flea market around the side of the building he now occupies. Soon he graduated to fixing lawn mowers for one of the vendors.
After he saved some money, he opened a bike repair shop at the flea market. Early on, an old junkman named Zack gave him some priceless advice. " 'Dave,' he said, 'if you want to be successful in this business, all you have to do is invest $100 a day in it.' That's what I did, every day. Buy more product, more stuff. And if I made $500 one day, I spent $300 back." Soon he had three stalls. A friend got him a job doing demolition on a big building and Mr. Moto was told he could take home anything he could carry.
He hauled away cabinets, washing machines, dryers. He rented warehouse space and sold appliances out of it. When the motel where his wife, Ida, was head of housekeeping upgraded its decor, Mr. Moto got the contract to haul the old furniture out.
"I sold all my appliances to a guy for $5,000 and moved in everything from the motel. A guy came into the flea market looking for beds. I said not only beds, I have furniture and everything, a whole warehouse complete. He paid me $10,000, hauled everything away and I didn't have to touch nothing."
In December 1995, he opened Kea'Boos, named for his 14-year-old daughter, Kakia, and his 13-year-old son, David Jr., better known as Boo. The store has provided an endless series of challenges, but nothing a skilled junkman cannot handle.
"There used to be a stairwell in back that went up to the second floor, and the thieves used to get up on there and kick the windows out and cut through," Mr. Moto said. "So I bought a welding torch and I burned the steps off and scrapped the steel to buy the wood to cover the windows."
No steady source of electricity means no computer, which means no way to keep track of what's in stock. Which can cause problems in a big room where all the merchandise other than the big-ticket items -- rows of washing machines, heaps of toilets and sinks, a pile of mattresses leaning against the wall like a string of dominoes caught in mid-fall -- appears to be filed under "miscellaneous."
In the front corner of the store, within a few square feet and in no discernible order, were a set of pylons, an inflatable Christmas tree, a fluorescent lamp with its bulbs painted red, Snuggles the fabric softener bear pinned under a leaning heap of strollers, a pink baby doll caught under half a lawn mower and several empty heart-shaped Russell Stover candy boxes.
"If somebody comes in and asks for something, we know if we've bought it before," he said, "but often times we can't find it."
On the whole, though, business is pretty good. "You never get rich," he said, "but it's better than being out on the corner. "
The operation is very much a family affair. Mr. Moto has set up a brother with two of his old stalls in the flea market and another brother and Mrs. Moto help run the big store. Boo, when he's not repairing engines or hammering together a working bicycle chain out of the parts of several defective ones, runs an Italian ice stand.
On a recent Saturday, Boo tore into the parking lot in Rafael Flores's Go Kart, which he had just bought for $150. He said it was worth $700. "The back rim is bent, and it needed a chain, and the carburetor needs fixed," he said. "But I can fix it."
 
A Preacher's Call To Self Esteem
Sunday means church, for just about everyone. At St. Joseph's Pro-Cathedral, about 300 worshipers attend the 10 A.M. Vietnamese mass, sandwiched between the 8:30 English mass and the 11:30 Spanish mass.
In a spare, dingy apartment in South Camden, a worn 32-year-old woman struggling against the H.I.V. virus , on-and-off drug addiction and the disintegration of her family, considers her options.
It is the day of the Puerto Rican parade, and she wants to go, but she is afraid she will start drinking or maybe worse. So she walks over to Antioch Baptist Church, a fortress-like black church across the street from a housing project.
The preacher, Anthony Gardner, seems to speak directly to her.
"We are by no means our faults!" Mr. Gardner thunders to a chorus of amens. "I don't care if you have experienced in your own life drugs and alcohol, the Lord has a purpose for you."
Mr. Gardner, a superhero-like figure in a white cape with yellow trim, struts and bobs like a prizefighter, sweat pouring down his face, horizontal folds in the back of his neck tightening.
"You are more than what the television says about you," he says. "You are more than what the newspapers write about you. I'm more than what society says I am. I'm more than what the police department says I am. I'm more, I'm more, I'm more!"
Afterward, the woman is one of a half-dozen people in the church who come to re-commit their lives to Jesus.
"I'm just asking everyone to just please help me and pray with me," she says in a small voice. "I'm really missing my children a lot. I'm not with them now, my parents have my children. I have to stay clean, I need the power to just stay clean and strong." She is escorted to a side room and offered counseling and information on treatment programs.
"I'm going to go home and cook something to eat," she says as she leaves. "I have a roommate, she's there, I just want to go home and let her know what happened in church today."
Across town, Ms. Pagan and Mr. Datil are having some relatives over for a post-parade game of dominoes and a few beers. Four or five years ago, Mr. Datil says, he did not feel safe enough to set up the domino table on the sidewalk. "Now it's calmed down a lot," he says.
He points out his wife's father, in front of his house across the street, and her sister and brother-in-law. "The best security is family," he says. "Everybody watching your toes."
Two little girls chase each other down the block with water guns.
"They shouldn't be running in the street like that," he says, and lays down another tile.

SECTION: Section 9; Page 1; Column 2; Real Estate Desk

HEADLINE: Rental Fever: Temperature Drops -- a Bit

BYLINE: By DENNIS HEVESI 

 BODY:
NEW YORK CITY'S free-market rental fever of a year ago, fueled by tales of 30 percent increases, bidding wars, broken promises and C.I.A.-like credit checks -- many of them true -- has abated. A bit.
It's not that rents have plummeted or demand has slackened, as they did during the real estate recession of the early 90's. But a broad-brush portrait of the rental scene would have to be painted in varied shades, with red-hot spots for certain niches of the market, and cooler hues for others. 
 In Manhattan, surveys compiled by leading residential rental brokers -- subject to the caveat that their samples are limited to their own deals in their favored income sectors, mostly at the high end of the market -- display a spectrum of rent fluctuations. The borough has benefited from a burst of new construction and conversion of office space, helping, in part, to temper the rental frenzy. So most of the price shifts over the last year were in the range of 3 to 5 percent increases, depending on the type and location of the apartment, sprinkled with decreases of 2 to 5 percent in certain categories. But there were also some extremes -- a 34.1 percent leap, for example, in the price of a one-bedroom apartment in the posh precincts between Park and Fifth Avenues.
In the other boroughs, according to impressions offered by community-based brokers, rents have edged up in lock step -- with rates in more affluent neighborhoods like brownstone Brooklyn an incremental level below Manhattan -- to the point where would-be renters in working-class communities clamor for any decent two-bedroom apartment going for less than $1,000 a month. In poor neighborhoods, where all that the free market will bear are prices just below or barely above regulated rents, construction of new apartments remains severely constrained and, as a result, vacancies are scarce and hundreds of thousands of people pay more than half their income for rent.
An unusual opportunity to scan the rental landscape was offered recently by the release of Census Bureau statistics compiled for New York City's 1996 Housing and Vacancy Survey, a voluminous report that will serve as the statistical foundation for city housing policy until the next study is completed in three years. Among a host of other kinds of data, the survey sampled unregulated rents throughout the city.
Using those statistics, researchers at the Center for Real Estate and Urban Policy at the New York University School of Law calculated the median, or midpoint, of all rents in 1996 for each of the five boroughs and in 49 smaller areas, and then compared them to median rents compiled for the 1993 Housing and Vacancy Survey.
Although the rents surveyed last year are, by definition, not quite up to date and the breakdowns by apartment size can be skewed (by inadequate samples and by some survey subjects either declining to disclose or understating their rents), the data offer a generalized view of the direction of free-market rents over the last three years, particularly since the recession of the early 1990's.
According to the N.Y.U. calculations, the median unregulated rent for apartments of all sizes in Manhattan, both above and below 96th Street, rose 17.3 percent, from $1,000 in 1993 to $1,173 in 1996. In Brooklyn, the median unregulated rent rose 8.7 percent, from $575 in 1993 to $625 last year.
Median rents for all sizes of apartments in the Bronx rose from $600 in 1993 to $650 in 1996, an 8.33 percent increase. In Queens, the increase was 7.69 percent, from $650 in 1993 to $700 in 1996. And on Staten Island, the jump was 7.83 percent, from $575 to $620.
The comparison of median rents by apartment size throughout the city shows a wide, if not surprising, range of change over the three years -- from a drop of 5.88 percent for a studio in the Bronx (from $425 to $400) to a whopping 66.67 percent increase (from $1,200 to $2,000) for a three-bedroom in Manhattan. A seemingly counterintuitive finding that two-bedroom apartments in Manhattan dropped 10 percent (from $1,500 to $1,350) was largely attributable, the N.Y.U. researchers said, to a decline in median rents above 96th Street.
In the last 12 months, the churning of the rental market has played out against a backdrop of political posturing and fierce infighting over the future of rent regulation, which, after all the turmoil, was left relatively unscathed by the State Legislature. Of the 2,027,000 apartments in New York City, 1,123,000 are regulated by the state or the city and 576,000 are unregulated.
The regulation debate had some effect on the free market, said Susan Wachter, a professor of real estate economics at the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School. "There was some warehousing of apartments by landlords in anticipation of potential deregulation," Dr. Wachter said, citing anecdotal reports. "This may be why we haven't seen big gains, even though the stock market is going strong."
The vagaries of the market have been visited upon Larry and Denise Shapiro -- he an architect, she a television marketing and licensing executive. With their sublease on Madison Avenue expiring, the Shapiros at first considered buying an apartment, but decided that sales prices were too inflated at this time and would come down in a few years. So, over the last four months, they looked at somewhere between 50 and 75 rental apartments, usually with their 5-year-old son, Reed, in tow.
"We set a ceiling of $4,000 a month, which we thought was very high," Mrs. Shapiro said.
Most agents, Mr. Shapiro said, "told us, 'For just a thousand dollars more, or two, we can find just what you want.' "
What the Shapiros wanted was a large "classic six" -- a three-bedroom or a two-bedroom with a maid's room -- to accommodate their Steinway grand, their dining-room table, Mr. Shapiro's great-grandmother's partners' desk (the kind that seats two people facing each other) and a very sizable sofa.
"At the beginning, they told us don't worry, there would be plenty of apartments available in our price range," Mrs. Shapiro said. "Then we started to get nervous. I was amazed at how many agents would not listen to our needs. After giving them very specific details about our search -- classic six, west of Lex, prewar, prime lease -- they would come back to us with white-brick buildings on Second or First, or sublets of co-ops."
"And they came back with things that were $5,000, $6,000 even $8,000," Mr. Shapiro said.
Eventually, the Shapiros found something close to what they wanted. And by the end of this month, they will move into a large, prewar classic six (a bit out of their preferred location) on East 96th Street.
"I have to say we feel lucky to get the apartment with the specs we wanted," Mrs. Shapiro said.
"And for what's considered an affordable rent these days," Mr. Shapiro said. The rent: $3,800 a month, or $200 lower than the original ceiling.
The Shapiros will, however, have to cut that big sofa in half to get it through the door.
Observers of the city's real estate market often see a dichotomy between Manhattan -- powered by the surging financial markets -- and the other boroughs. As the Wharton School's Dr. Wachter pointed out: "The stock market last year obviously had an incredible year. The real estate market moved in a similar way, though not quite as dramatically. So, given the huge increases of last year, this has been a year of slight retrenchment. But I think this is a bit of a breather, just a breather."
At the same time, as Arthur Margon, acting director of the Real Estate Institute at New York University, said: "The strength of the economy is not uniform, so there are significant parts of the population that are not enjoying the economic growth of the past couple of years. And in neighborhoods where those people are looking for housing, the market rent can't go up very much because the potential tenants don't have the increases in income to support it."
But the market might also be seen as a malleable whole with potent forces exerting varying degrees of pressure at any given moment.
Certainly, a force in the market has been the record profits on Wall Street, and, more specifically, the jump from $6.1 billion to $8.1 billion in year-end bonuses paid to financial workers in 1995 and then in 1996.
The big profits on Wall Street, along with momentum in the national and regional economy, have spurred increased employment in the city, said John L. Weiting, the regional commissioner for the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics. Over the 12-month period ending June 1, the city added 51,000 jobs in the private sector, a larger gain than the 44,000 recorded in the prior 12-month period. "A lot of the increases have come in business and management services, in entertainment," Commissioner Weiting said, "and we're still seeing increases in health services."
The so-called FIRE sector -- finance, insurance and real estate -- also saw an employment increase, of about 6,000 jobs, in the last year, "and that reversed a decline in the prior 12 months," Mr. Weiting added.
Another factor in housing demand was increasing population. There were sharp declines in New York City's population between 1960 and 1980. But between 1980 and 1990, according to the Census Bureau, the city's population grew 3.5 percent, from 7,071,639 to 7,322,564. And the influx -- largely attributable to the city's immigration explosion -- has continued during the 90's.
According to City Planning Department statistics, based on Immigration and Naturalization Service data, 1.25 million immigrants have settled in the city since 1982, with the rate rising in recent years. During the 1980's, about 86,000 immigrants settled in the city each year; that increased to 112,598 in the first half of the 90's.
At the same time, while showing some improvement, housing vacancies remain low. According to the Housing and Vacancy Survey, the number of vacant apartments in the city rose from 70,345 in 1993 to 81,256 last year. That constitutes an increase in the vacancy rate from 3.44 percent to 4.01 percent, with 5 percent the statutory level for declaration of an official housing emergency -- a condition that has existed since the end of World War II.
And while housing construction did increase last year, it was nowhere near the 40,000 new units that some scholars contend are needed to replenish the city's stock each year. According to the Planning Department, building permits for the construction of 8,632 units were issued in the city in 1996 -- a significant increase over 1995, when 5,135 permits were issued, and certainly an improvement over the 4,466 permits in 1994, the city's worst year for housing starts in a decade.
"It's encouraging to see that the numbers are beginning to show real improvement and, hopefully, that trend will continue and even accelerate," said Joseph B. Rose, chairman of the City Planning Commission.
Citing the 40,000-unit-a-year goal as "extremely ambitious and, frankly, not realistic," Mr. Rose nevertheless agreed that the 4,466 units started in 1994 constituted "a very serious situation, not just in terms of supply at the given moment, but also in the long-term health of the city's housing stock."
"A major goal of this administration has been to spur new production," Mr. Rose said, "and we'd like to get over 10,000 units a year. In fact, we're already beginning to see, especially in Manhattan, production that will affect the marketplace." Forty percent of the new housing in the city last year was in Manhattan.
AND so, even if the housing market is viewed as a whole, the dichotomy between housing activity in Manhattan and the other boroughs does exist.
According to "Housing Conditions and Problems in New York City," a study by Michael Schill and Benjamin Scafidi of the N.Y.U. Law School's Real Estate Center, 27 percent -- or 525,750 -- of the city's households pay more than half their income for rent.
"Problems of grossly unaffordable housing were particularly prevalent in the Bronx, where one third of all renters pay more than half their income for rent," Professor Schill said. The Federal Government definition of affordable housing is a household that pays no more than 30 percent of its income for rent. "Therefore, the 1996 survey suggests that affordability problems among renters have reached crisis proportions, particularly for poor people," Professor Schill said.
Much of the city's new housing construction has been in the Manhattan financial district, where city tax abatements have made it possible for developers to convert outdated office space into residential property.
"The downtown market, of course, has seen new construction in the Wall Street area," said Nancy Packes, president of Feathered Nest, a leading rental broker in Manhattan, "and it has been met with demand and price levels which, I think, far exceeded most people's expectations. At 25 Broad and 45 Wall, the prices are almost the same as the Upper East Side."
A large studio at 25 Broad Street, a building called the Exchange, where occupancy is to start in September, is renting for $1,850, while a two-bedroom is starting at $2,500, and a three-bedroom with 2 1/2 baths is starting at $4,800. At 40 Wall Street, studios are starting at $1,300; one-bedrooms at $1,650; two-bedrooms at $2,770, and three bedrooms at $3,100.
In general, Ms. Packes said: "The Manhattan market is up reasonably, but not hugely, in the studio and one-bedroom categories. But the two-bedroom category is showing far more substantial increases, and I think that's due to the fact that there is demand for two-bedrooms in the sales market, which is depleting the supply of available two-bedrooms for rent."
Feathered Nest issues quarterly reports on its sales in the luxury market. Except for two extreme examples, its most recent survey showed that price fluctuations in the second quarter of this year, as compared to the end of 1996, ranged from a decrease of 4.3 percent for a studio in a non-doorman building on the Upper West Side (from $1,450 to $1,425) to an increase of 16.8 percent (from $4,925 to $5,750) for a three-bedroom unit in a doorman building on the Upper East Side. The two extreme examples, both between Park Avenue and Fifth Avenue, were the 34.1 percent increase (from $2,125 to $2,850) for a one-bedroom apartment in a non-doorman building, and a 17.2 percent decrease (from $5,100 to $4,225) for a two-bedroom unit in a doorman building.
"There's been very little change in the past year," said Cathe LeBlanc, managing director of the rental division for the Corcoran Group. "What we saw in the last quarter of '96 was a leveling and a dip in rents. But then the strong economy in the financial, entertainment and law industries created a much stronger demand than we anticipated. Those industries did more hiring than the real estate market anticipated, so we've seen an increase in price in the last three months."
A comparison of Corcoran reports for the second quarter of this year and the second quarter of 1996 shows only small fluctuations in rents. For most high-end apartments in Manhattan below 96th Street, the reports indicate, the rents of studios increased 3.3 percent (from $1,248 to $1,290) over the last 12 months, while they dropped 3.6 percent (from $5,984 to $5,767) for three-bedroom apartments.
Navigating the Manhattan rental market recently were three college buddies -- Jay Abramovitz, Aaron Davis and Jason Sobol -- all 22 years old, all from Harvard and all swept up in the Wall Street hiring wave. They hoped to find strength in numbers: $1,000 apiece.
That's what the three June graduates decided each could afford for a three-bedroom unit. "I was glad to have two good friends with me entering into this apartment-hunting process," said Mr. Davis, who grew up in Roslyn, L.I.
"To be honest, it was a little depressing at first," said Mr. Abramovitz, a native of Columbus, Ohio.
The three young men spent four intense days in the city last month, trudging from apartment to apartment -- 10 in all -- between 60th and 80th Streets on the Upper West Side. Eventually, they had to set their sights on a somewhat smaller apartment a bit farther north -- a two-bedroom with a large living room on West 96th Street, renting for $2,500. "A nice bonus," Mr. Abramovitz said.
Three guys, two bedrooms? "They actually advertise it as a two-bedroom convertible," Mr. Abramovitz said. The solution: installation of a temporary wall, dividing that spacious living room, at a cost of $800.
IN other parts of the city, post-recession rental pressures were readily apparent in the Housing and Vacancy Survey data compiled by the N.Y.U. researchers.
In Queens, the median rent for all sizes of apartments in one statistical area (Forest Hills-Rego Park-Kew Gardens-Woodside) rose 15.38 percent, from $650 to $750, between 1993 and 1996. In another (Middle Village-Ridgewood), the increase was 21.74 percent, from $575 to $700.
Rental units are relatively scarce on Staten Island, but those few also recorded increases between 1993 and 1996 -- 13.64 percent, from $550 to $625, on the North Shore; 8.33 percent, from $600 to $650, in the middle of the island.
The Borough Park section of Brooklyn, according to the N.Y.U. data, experienced a 21.5 percent increase for all sizes of apartments over the three years, from $535 to $650. Bay Ridge was unchanged, at $600. But in Brooklyn Heights-Fort Greene, the increase was 8.57 percent, from $700 to $760.
Katherine Lilly, owner of Realty on the Greene in Fort Greene, put the changes in her community into far broader context: "The big increase that you saw last year wasn't so big, as opposed to just the market correcting itself from the huge drop in the early 90's. Because, in reality, I think, the rents last year and this year were maybe slightly higher than the market in 1988 and '89 -- probably the height before the market collapsed."
But in less affluent communities of the city, rent increases squeezed against the wall of scarce vacancy.
"The thing that we're looking at in particular," said David R. Jones, president of the Community Service Society of New York, an advocacy group for the poor, "is the steady diminution of rental units in the lower end of the market."
Using the new Housing and Vacancy Survey statistics, the Community Service Society has calculated that 112,000 housing units renting for $500 or less in 1993 had surpassed that mark by last year, "which represents, I'm afraid, 20 percent of the stock of those units," Mr. Jones said.
"A large number of those units," he said, "are the only ones available for people who are either working poor or on public assistance -- neither of which group has seen an increase in wages or benefits to meet this kind of rent increase."
The N.Y.U. data shows that in Ocean Hill-Brownsville, median rents increased 12.1 percent, from $535 to $600, between 1993 and 1996. In Manhattan, above 96th Street, the increase was 10.19 percent, from $530 to $584.
And in the Bronx -- rebounding from the boarded-up desolation of the 70's, yet still pocked by poverty -- the statistical area that includes Morrisania, East Tremont, Highbridge, University Heights and South Concourse saw a 40.85 percent jump in median rents over the three years, from $426 to $600.
Earl Washington is president of United Realty Services, based on the Grand Concourse near Yankee Stadium. "A lot of people are rediscovering the Bronx, in proximity to Manhattan," Mr. Washington said. "And so there's a steady stream of people looking for a two-bedroom apartment for less than $1,000 -- and my market is low- to moderate-income persons."
"Fordham Hills, which is a very nice co-op," Mr. Washington continued, "is doing rentals at about $1,000 a month for a two-bedroom apartment. And that's again, working people."
