HEADLINE: COPING;
The March of the Empty Suitcases

BYLINE: By ROBERT LIPSYTE 

 BODY:
THE summer people have arrived. They are cluttering the streets, walking slowly, looking stupid. They are smoking in the subway and drinking red wine in the park. The young ones are nearly naked. Many are barefoot. The old ones are in clashing plaids. All are slung with sacks filled with water, hard currency, caps, jackets, inflatable back rests and maps they will pull out and unfold anywhere, halting traffic. I hate them. I wish they would go home.
Why? Because they are on vacation and I am not? Because their currency is harder than mine? Because they feel free to saunter, saunter, in my neighborhood? Real people don't saunter unless they are being walked by dogs. Where do these summer people think they are, Western Europe in the 50's and 60's, Asia in the 70's, Eastern Europe in the early 90's? They point at a scruffy man staggering under a load of seltzer in plastic bottles and they say something in hard currency about his native clothing. Who do they think I am, local color? 
 "It's worse than you think," said my friend Jonathan Kandell, the travel writer. "They didn't come here to make fun of you, which would at least be a valid cultural statement, or even to take in the sights. They came to buy clothes at one-third the price they'd pay in Europe.
"Go down to Century 21 and find out what's going on. There's a reason the salespeople speak a smattering of five languages. These people you hate are secretaries from Stuttgart and unemployed from Paris. They come with empty suitcases. They get Armani, Versace, Ralph Lauren, and sell it when they get home. Pays for their vacation. Sometimes they come with orders."
Now I am really steamed. It was bad enough when the Eurotrash arrived, rich kids and their natural predators, art dealers, and began turning SoHo and 57th Street into theme parks. Now their poorer cousins have arrived, the economy class, and they are turning the city into a shopping mall.
Just look at them in the Union Square Greenmarket, shaking berries into their mouths. They point at a 25-year-old blond woman at the Seven Pines cut-flower stand and say something in hard currency about natives. Was this the way I once looked at people in Les Halles?
"Relax," said Ruth Levine, the flower seller, who just quit her $40,000 publicity job at Simon & Schuster. "It's O.K., I'm having fun. This is a great mind wash, and the people are interesting. I sometimes felt like a baby sitter in publishing, and I just didn't believe in all the books I was selling. I believe in delphiniums. And just smell this rose."
Ms. Levine is taking a poetry course at the Writer's Voice at the West Side Y.M.C.A. while she decides what to do next. She had worked in publishing publicity since graduating from New York University in 1993. She says she really likes the farmers at the market, especially after four years of "well-bred adults taking endless marketing meetings and treating each other like kids." And she thinks it's fun talking to the summer people.
Grumbling, I head home, refusing to jump off the sidewalk for a delivery biker from Zen Palate, the overpriced, undertasty vegetarian restaurant near Union Square. In a dark moment, I imagine him plowing into a grove of summer people, scattering them to the Beth Israel emergency room. Mayor Giuliani would visit them and finally declare war on sidewalk bikers, encouraging the Departments of City Planning and Transportation's greenway network to promote cycling. My current favorite Council member, Andrew Eristoff, has been making dawn raids to stencil "No Bikes" on Upper East Side corners where his constituents have been mowed down.
Now I feel guilty wishing harm to innocent travelers. Maybe I just want them to share local anxieties. They were oblivious to the rent control panic or to the possibility that Sammy the Bull Gravano, 20 summers after Son of Sam gave his name to a law denying criminals profits from their books and movies, may be getting more hard currency from the tales of his murders than are all his victims' families.
And summer people will never share with me the joy of watching Barney's on West 17th Street close forever. Hateful attraction. That was where my mother took me for extra roomy pants at the Extremely Fat Boys Shop. How I loved the demolition of S. Klein's On the Square. That was where we shopped at the Crisco Kid Shop (for boys who were fat in the can).
So how can I hate the summer people when I feel so sorry for them? They don't live here. Eventually they will have to go home. But I must also be true to my scruffy, fat, native, soft-currency self. When one summer person stopped traffic last week to unfold a map and ask, "Where Niketown?" I could answer only, "The one in the South Bronx or the one on Staten Island?"

HEADLINE: HEALTH CARE;
A Small-Scale Start, Perhaps, for a Children's Insurance Program

BYLINE: By KIT R. ROANE 

DATELINE: PATERSON

 BODY:
A state-subsidized children's insurance program called Children First, envisioned by Governor Whitman 18 months ago, is expected to start in September, officials said last week.
But the program, with $5 million in seed money allocated by the Legislature in June, will begin only in a limited way because full financing to cover the 100,000 children eligible remains uncertain. 
 The program would start by offering policies to the parents of 5,000 children under the seed grant. To insure all the eligible children, the state would require Federal block grant money, donations by large corporations and health maintenance organizations in the state, or profits from the proposed national settlement with the tobacco industry, none of which is certain at this time.
"Seventeen percent of our charity-care dollars are spent on children, so we know that if we can insure kids, it will do some good here," said the Health Commissioner, Len Fishman.
The program is part of a larger state initiative to deal with an estimated 1.1 million uninsured New Jerseyans. Care for them has usually come through a network of charity hospitals, their bills partly covered through $453 million from the state's Unemployment Insurance Fund and matching Federal grants. The rest is covered by hospital revenue.
But the mandate to use the Unemployment Insurance Fund for charity care will lapse at the end of the year, leaving state health officials scrambling for other permanent and cost-effective financing.
Children First is one of these, and a 36-member panel of health experts, lawyers and business leaders was commissioned last month to find others.
"We need to put some order in chaos, so that we are not chasing a patchwork of funds after every election year and people are given the sort of health care that assures them some semblance of health," said Sister Jane F. Brady, who runs St. Joseph's Hospital and Medical Center here and sits on the committee.
As with all publicly administered charity care in the state, there are many uncertainties left to wade through in Children First. Until recently, there was no source of money for the program; a proposal to raise the cigarette tax last year failed in the Legislature. And the state has continued to resist any structuring of the program until it figures out its share of the $16 billion recently promised by President Clinton for a national children's health care policy, and what strings will be attached.
Governor Whitman is also waiting for news from the proposed $368 billion national tobacco settlement, which is to be split among the states if it ever passes Congressional muster. She has pledged at least $100 million from any settlement to help pay for low-income health care in New Jersey.
With little known about either the financing or structure of Children First, the corporations and H.M.O.'s expected to contribute to the program have been reluctant to commit themselves.
"We have members who participate in other states' programs who would be willing to participate here if there was just some more flesh on the bone," said Paul R. Langevin, a spokesman for the New Jersey H.M.O. Association, whose members insure more than 90 percent of the state's residents in commercial managed-care plans.
According to the Department of Health and Senior Services, Children First would emphasize preventive health care, offering comprehensive medical coverage. It would be open to families with incomes below 250 percent of the Federal poverty level ($39,000 for a family of four, for example) who cannot receive health coverage through employers or a public program. Those families who qualified would be enrolled in an H.M.O., paying a monthly contribution of between $5 and $15.
Health care experts said the state was likely to use the administrative structure of Health Access New Jersey to sign up applicants and track their progress. That two-year-old program provides subsidized health insurance for people who cannot afford a policy.
Although the original goal was to broaden it to cover all those who use charity care, the program is being phased out by the state in favor of Children First.
One of those hoping to enroll his son in this latest incarnation of subsidized care is Slawomir Winsiewski, who laid out his troubles as an uninsured worker while waiting for 10-year-old Jakub to see a doctor at St. Joseph's.
His tale began last fall with the loss of a job at a warehouse and the insurance that it provided for Jakub, who has cystic fibrosis. When that job ended, he did not find another until spring.
Although he now works 60 hours a week as a landscaper for a large company, his family still lacks company-sponsored insurance. And making less than $20,000 a year, Mr. Winsniewski cannot afford private insurance on his own.
"It's tough," he said, shaking his head. "It's really tough."

HEADLINE: LOOKING BACK;
The Darkest Hours of a Dark Time

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
THE dinner with the police brass was going well. The East Harlem Community Corporation, a local community action group, wanted to thank the commanders of the 23d and 25th Precincts for help with a local festival.
But as Roberto Anazagasti, a subway signalman and the group's volunteer chairman, raised his glass of sangria for another toast, the lights went out in Ponce de Leon, a Spanish restaurant in East Harlem. People gasped. Then a strange scratching, twisting sound could be heard. Someone was pulling the iron gate off the store next door. "The looting had begun," Mr. Anazagasti said. 
 In Port Chester, 20 miles north, Arthur Hauspurg, the president of Consolidated Edison, was playing tennis when the court's lights began to flicker, then dim. "I thought it was a local problem," Mr. Hauspurg recalled. But when he got home, his wife had packed a bag full of sandwiches. Con Ed had called. "She knew it was going to be a long night," Mr. Hauspurg said.
Twenty years ago tonight, shortly after 9:30, Con Ed suffered a huge power failure, plunging nearly nine million people in the city and Westchester County into darkness. But unlike the big Northeast blackout, on Nov. 9, 1965, when there was little civil disturbance, and something like a Battle of Britain camaraderie prevailed in New York, the 1977 blackout led to widespread chaos and looting in the South Bronx, Harlem and especially in Bushwick, Brooklyn, the city's hardest-hit neighborhood.
Explanations for the looting varied, most of them centering on the weather. The 1965 power failure struck on a chilly autumn afternoon, and most people stayed indoors. But the 1977 blackout hit on one of the hottest nights of the year, when school was out, tempers were short, and people were milling around the streets.
But it also seems clear, from the vantage point of 20 years, that the city had reached a psychological low point in 1977. The economy was bleeding jobs, and the city's population was shrinking. An underclass -- troubled, volatile and violent -- was growing. New York had narrowly averted bankruptcy the year before, and City Hall continued to slash services. Time magazine had depicted Mayor Abraham D. Beame on its cover as a beggar with a tin cup.
"In 1965, in many parts of the city, the blackout was almost a party," Mr. Hauspurg, 71, said. "New York laughed its way through that blackout. But in 1977, the whole social scene had changed in the intervening years."
Robert R. McDonald, the director of the Museum of the City of New York, sees the 1977 blackout as coming at the worst possible time. "There were already great strains on social cohesiveness, the Vietnam war, racial tensions, and then this demoralizing downturn in the economy," he said.
"What the blackout underlined was a loss of control, a loss of faith in technology that we have just now begun to climb out of. If any good came out of the blackout, it was a realization that everyone was vulnerable and that in the end everyone had to somehow attempt to work together."
That was what Mr. Anazagasti said he tried to do in the 25 hours the power was out. He drove through the streets of East Harlem with a bullhorn, trying to shame the looters, to little effect. "I get emotional when I remember this," he said last week, sobbing softly. "I said it was wrong, please stop. I yelled, 'No es parte de la cultura nuestra' ('This is not part of our culture'). "
In Bushwick, a third-year medical student, Carl St. Martin, was studying his internal medicine textbook by the bare light bulb in his living room when it and the rest of the lights went out. A few minutes later, as Mr. St. Martin talked to neighbors, he was startled to see a man carrying a large couch on his back and another man trying to take it away from him. "Get away from me!" the first man was saying. "They got plenty of stuff up there." The man was referring to the stores on Broadway nearby, where looters were massing.
Mayhem was spreading, Dr. St. Martin recalls, and he dashed to Wyckoff Heights Hospital to volunteer in the emergency room. "The looters were looting other looters," said Dr. St. Martin, now 42 and a neurologist in Forest Hills, Queens, "and the fists and the knives were coming out."
The looting in Bushwick persisted the next day, when Artemio Santiago, the manager of what was the George Foti clothing store at 1273 Broadway, two blocks from Dr. St. Martin's apartment, arrived at 9:30 A.M. to open for business.
"We were good until about 1 o'clock," recalled Mr. Santiago, 57 and a salesman at Brooks Brothers on Madison Avenue in Manhattan. "All the other stores just had windows, but we had an iron gate. But pretty soon we were the only store left, and they pulled down the gate." The store, he said, lost $200,000 in inventory. "I felt like it was my own place," Mr. Santiago said, "like I lost everything."
In Manhattan, Dr. Robert Holzman, an assistant hospital epidemiologist at Bellevue Hospital Center, had other worries on the blackout's second day.
"All I thought about was water," said Dr. Holzman, 57 and now Bellevue's chief epidemiologist. "The pumps that provide water were down. My job means infection control. We needed water to wash our hands with, our instruments with. We needed water for the toilets. The first thing I did was to organize bucket brigades to get water to the places we needed it."
The Mayor's office set up a joint command post with One Police Plaza. The police had a functioning backup power system. But with the photocopy and mimeograph machines out, a single secretary had to pound out news releases on a manual typewriter five at a time, one original and four carbon copies.
At first, Mr. Beam said, he did not realize the extent of the emergency. Facing a re-election challenge, he had been addressing a group of the elderly residents at Co-Op City, the huge apartment complex in the Bronx. "I was in midsentence of some speech," Mr. Beame, 91, recalled."And I thought the auditorium going pitch black was just a temporary thing." But aides quickly hustled him into a car for a frenzied drive to City Hall.
Characteristically, Edward I. Koch, who defeated Mayor Beame in the Democratic primary that September and won the general election two months later, sees the power failure in political terms. "The blackout in 1977," Mr. Koch, 72, said with a chuckle. "Ohhhhhh! The one that got me elected."
Mr. Koch described New York as at a nadir in 1977, with Mayor Beame unwilling or unable to bring order to an increasingly chaotic city. "People were ashamed of being New Yorkers," Mr. Koch said, explaining that he backed the deployment of the National Guard to keep peace during the blackout, a move that Mr. Beame vetoed as potentially dangerous because armed guardsmen might provoke more confrontations than they quelled.
Mr. Anazagasti, now the general manager of Nuevo el Barrio, a housing advocacy group, says the blackout helped New York, if only as a wake-up call for the most blighted neighborhoods. "We began to view looting for what it is, self-destructive," he said. "You cannot trash the supermarket in your neighborhood because tomorrow your kids will not have milk to drink."

Luce, chairman of Con Edison, faced a state hearing a few days afterward. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times); Looters in Bedford-Stuyvesant. (The New York Times); The city's image suffered in London. Chart: "TIMELINE: Blackout Diary"
Some major moments in New York's blackout of 1977:
 
9:34 P.M., July 13 Power fails after lightening strikes Con Ed electrical transmission line in Westchester.
 
11:00 Corrections Department, fearing a breakout at the Bronx House of Detention, calls for emergency Police Department assistance.
 
11:30 Gasoline generators light parts of City Hall.
 
1 A.M., July 14 Hundreds of people are under arrest on looting charges at police station houses, which resemble department stores, with looted appliances, furniture and clothing stacked in muster rooms. More than 3,300 people are eventually arrested.
 
1:30 A.M. Con Ed begins sporadic service restoration, in Jamaica, Queens.
 
10 P.M. Calm is restored to hard-hit areas of Brooklyn, including Bushwick, Crown Heights, Bedford-Stuyvesant and Brownsville.
 
10:40 P.M. Con Ed reports service has been restored to all its 2.8 million residential customers. Lower Manhattan and the Upper East Side are the last neighborhoods to be relighted.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: HUDSON RIVER WATERFRONT;
$12 Million Helps Restart Plan for Pier

BYLINE: By BERNARD STAMLER 

 BODY:
The redevelopment of Pier A at the Battery has been on the drawing board in one form or another for a decade. Delays stemmed from financing difficulties and the reluctance of a developer, Wings Point Associates, to include certain businesses on the refurbished pier.
"We didn't want any chain stores or restaurants," Carole Taylor, a partner in Wings Point, said. "But chains are what's bankable." 
 The project remained stalled in the Koch and Dinkins administrations, Ms. Taylor said. But then the city's Economic Development Corporation obtained $8 million in Federal bond guarantees and a $4.2 million grant from the State Office of Parks, Recreation and Historic Preservation for a visitors' center, and Southern California Edison agreed to be an equity partner.
That cleared the way for work on a new $26 million design that includes a catering hall, restaurant, gift shop and the tourist center.
On June 18 ground was broken at the pier, which was built in 1886 and whose three-story Victorian shed, a city landmark, was headquarters for the police harbor unit and an Ellis Island ferry terminal. The project is scheduled to be finished in two years.
"Don't expect another South Street Seaport," said Ms. Taylor, explaining that the developers, now called WPA/Edison, were looking for far less of a shopping atmosphere.
Ms. Taylor said the company held a 49-year lease and would pay rent to the city based partly on income from the businesses. The first year's rent is expected to total $750,000, Ms. Taylor said.
Tenants who have already been chosen include Abigail Kirsch of Tappan Hill for the catering center and Billy and Anita Long, who run a supper club, Metropolitan, in Glen Cove on Long Island, for the first-floor restaurant.
Ms. Taylor said several shops had expressed interest, but she declined to be more specific.
She said the Harbor Park Visitors' Center would focus on museums, landmarks and other attractions around New York Harbor, including Snug Harbor on Staten Island, the Fulton Ferry Landing in Brooklyn and Battery Park. Pier A will also be headquarters for Op Sail 2000, on the Fourth of July in three years, Ms. Taylor said.
"Our goal is to entice New Yorkers downtown," she said.
Charles Millard, the president of the Economic Development Corporation, sees the catering hall as setting Pier A apart from other waterfront attractions.
"It's going to be beautiful," Mr. Millard said. "In 20 years, we'll all be reminiscing about the wonderful weddings we attended there." BERNARD STAMLER

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
Waiting for Boomers To Discover the Road

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD 

 BODY:
THIS is the time of year when America's love for the wilds finds its fullest expression, when all that a family needs is some blue sky, towering mountains, crystal rivers and, perhaps, a fully equipped kitchen with microwave, two showers, a queen-size bed and a satellite dish offering phone, television and Internet connections, all mounted on wheels.
The recreational vehicle, or RV, is as much a part of summer in this country as bug spray and dripping ice cream cones. And it has evolved from those rugged trailers with lumpy beds to genuine motorized homes, often packed with luxuries and selling at average prices of $40,000 to $60,000, with some running to more than $250,000. 
 The only thing that has not evolved as much, analysts say, is the profile of the typical RV buyers: an older couple who travel without children and are principally interested in avoiding Northern winters. Winnebago Industries, based in Forest City, Iowa, says its customers are typically 50 to 70 years of age. That is both the bane and the promise of the industry, particularly for Winnebago, the company that gave these vehicles their identity but is now struggling.
Sales slipped slightly for the nine months through May 31, to $336.8 million, from $364.3 million for the same period a year earlier. And sales have remained disappointing in the current quarter, the company says. Other RV companies include Fleetwood Enterprises and Coachmen Industries, which have also had disappointing performances this year.
Winnebago -- named after an Indian tribe -- says it has diagnosed the problem and found a solution: selling more RV's to the generation that once would have laughed at them but now desires the comforts they afford. The company feels that baby boomers, some of whom are turning 50 and finding their joints creakier than in the past, are the market of the future.
Indeed, an estimated nine million baby-boomer families have the income range and areas of interest that fit the RV buyer profile, the industry says, even though few of them have so far bought RV's.
But analysts, while acknowledging the possible growth of this market, are skeptical.
"Those factors will come into play at some point in the future, but I don't see them as instrumental right now," said Guy Nielsen, an analyst at Nutmeg Securities in Westport, Conn. "Demand is less than robust now."
In fact, many sectors of the leisure industry have contended that aging baby boomers will expand sales, but few have seen strong results yet.
"You know, the great thing about demographics is that everyone claims the numbers are in their favor," said Mark Greenberg, who manages the Invesco Strategic Leisure fund, based in Denver.
For Winnebago, such skepticism and the industry slump have translated into a lackluster stock. From a high of nearly $13 in February 1994, the stock has done a crabwalk for years, going mostly sideways to lower. It closed on Friday at $6.75, or just 7.3 times its earnings per share.
"When you think of motor homes or RV's, you think of Winnebago," said Gary Goldstein, an analyst at the Seidler Companies in Los Angeles, who lives in an RV with his wife and travels about 42 weeks a year. "I don't have a clear idea of how they lost that franchise, but they just about have."
Its rivals have suffered, too. Coachmen stock climbed past $28 a share last fall and winter but closed on Friday at $19.125; Fleetwood shares, near $37 last fall, are now $30.0625.
But Winnebago has high hopes -- especially for its baby-boomer card. "This is going to materialize, no question, but over maybe five to six years," said Bruce D. Hertzke, Winnebago's president and chief operating officer. "We have a few more people toward the 50-year-old end of our age range, but there are also more buyers at later ages."
The company has taken other steps to rebuild. Its founder, John K. Hanson, died last year, and with his passing Winnebago has sold off several divisions, like electronics and advertising, that are unrelated to motor homes. Now, "our real emphasis is on the 1998 model launch," Mr. Hertzke said.
He said Winnebago had strengthened its position in so-called C-class vehicles, the midsize RV's priced at $35,000 to $65,000. The focus now, Mr. Hertzke said, will be the more lucrative high end of the market, the A class, where prices begin at $40,000 and rapidly escalate to $250,000. These large, luxurious vehicles are now often enhanced with what is known as a slide-out -- a part of the vehicle that slides out when parked, creating a far larger room inside.
The Hanson family's ownership of about 43 percent of Winnebago has been a drag on the stock price, and it has been unclear how the holding will be managed after Mr. Hanson's death. Company officials are hoping that once the family decides whether it will sell shares, and, if so, how many, investors will have less fear that a huge amount of the stock may be dumped at any time.
Mr. Hanson, who founded the company on the back of a failed trailer company in 1959, retired in 1972 but returned to rebuild it when it was faltering in 1979 and again in the late 1980's. Until his death at age 88, he had a hand in its operation, analysts said, meaning that for the first time its current management has a free hand in running it.
"The company is really in a transition," said Mr. Nielsen of Nutmeg Securities. "They're finishing their first year without Mr. Hanson. We need a little more time to see what they'll do. They know they need to come out with some really new products, not just some cosmetic changes."
One company goal is to promote the benefits of RV's to all who will listen. "It's a cheap way to have a second home for many of these people," Mr. Goldstein said. "You save on everything."
WINNEBAGO and other companies in the industry have also formed the Go RVing Coalition. The group began a $15 million advertising campaign earlier this year to reinvigorate the slumping market by luring baby boomers. The slogan is "Wherever you go, you're always at home."
The industry has a long way to go, however. Sales reached $12.4 billion last year, but growth has lagged so far this year, in spite of the strong economy. Add in the uncertainty over whether boomers will embrace the RV, and analysts remain leery of Winnebago's stock.
Even Mr. Goldstein, despite his own enthusiasm for the RV life, said: "It's a big maybe whether or not they can really turn things around, and until I see something positive, I'm holding back."

HEADLINE: INVESTING WITH: Jeff Poppenhagen;
Pioneer Growth Fund

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:
THE Standard & Poor's 500-stock index is roaring ahead this year, leaving many mutual funds behind. But not all.
Investors who tapped into the large-cap growth sector through the Pioneer Growth fund, for example, have been well-rewarded. The fund had a return of 26.4 percent through June 30, compared with 20.6 percent for the S.& P. And for the 12 months through June, the fund had a return of 50 percent, beating its benchmark by more than 15 percentage points, according to Morningstar Inc., the fund trackers in Chicago. 
 The fund's three-year returns through June also look very good, largely as a result of the recent returns earned by the fund's current manager. In that period, Pioneer had an average annual return of 35.5 percent, beating the index by nearly 7 percentage points, Morningstar said.
Jeff Poppenhagen, the fund manager since February 1996, says "dominant franchise" is the key concept in the fund's approach. "I try to buy dominant franchise businesses," Mr. Poppenhagen said from his office in Boston. "Nearly all the companies in the portfolio are market leaders."
That strategy is particularly successful these days, he said. "If you're the largest in the industry, you're generally the lowest-cost provider of those goods or services, which is very important in this kind of environment where there's little pricing flexibility on the part of the company."
Why are prices in such a bind? "The huge bull market over the last seven years has created lots of capital, which is looking for a return," he said. "So you're getting competition among companies and you can't just push through price hikes -- you have to go for volume business."
Mr. Poppenhagen looks for companies whose earnings can grow 15 percent a year in the next decade. And he is not afraid to pay a lot. "You might pay a little more today, but you're better off down the road," he said. He has his limits, however. He generally won't pay more than twice the market multiple -- now about 23 times earnings -- for a stock.
Mr. Poppenhagen expects his companies to be able to reinvest capital at a very profitable rate. He aims for a return on incremental investment, which he defines as the amount above maintenance capital expenditures and research and development costs, of roughly 20 percent on a moving-average basis.
The reinvestment is often used for expansion overseas, he said, where, over all, competition is less intense and companies can grow faster. That is the case, he said, with one of his favorite holdings, the Wm. Wrigley Jr. Company. "In China, Wrigley's is considered an innovative franchise company even though we don't consider a stick of gum innovative here," he said.
According to Morningstar, the portfolio's average price-to-earnings ratio was 31.4 as of March 31, the latest data available. At that time, the portfolio had an average price-to-book ratio of 6.9 and its price-to-cash flow was 20. All the ratios were higher than those of the S.& P.
But Mr. Poppenhagen does not use many of the usual statistics to decide when to buy or sell stocks. Instead, his holdings are dictated in part by his commitment to running a tight ship: he holds only 33 or so stocks in the portfolio at any time. "I won't add companies, so I'm forced to sell when I find something more compelling," he said.
Turnover averages 38 percent to 40 percent a year, less than half the average for domestic stock funds. Still, he said, "every once in a while, you have to own up to the fact that the management, the company or the industry isn't as good as you thought."
Technology companies are the biggest chunk -- one-third -- of the portfolio. Consumer nondurables, like clothing makers, are at 21 percent; financial stocks, 17 percent, and service industries, 11 percent. The fund's largest holdings are Dell Computer, 6.3 percent; Intel, 5.9 percent, and Microsoft, 5.7 percent. And the average weighted market capitalization of the companies in the portfolio is now $35 billion, much larger than it was before Mr. Poppenhagen's arrival.
Mr. Poppenhagen, 35, joined Pioneering Management, the fund's sponsor, last year. He had been a portfolio manager with Transamerica in San Francisco from 1991 to 1996, and with Farmers Group before that. One of his recent adjustments, he said, was extracurricular: He had to sell his sailboat, a Coronado 25, when he moved to Boston, but hopes to buy another boat soon.
 
Going Global With Gum
Mr. Poppenhagen is buying shares in big global consumer products companies because, he said, "in the important global markets, returns and growth rates are increasing faster and competition is less intense."
Wrigley, the chewing gum maker, holds about 50 percent of the market in the United States but 70 percent to 80 percent in international markets like Britain, Germany and China, he said. The company, he said, gets about 55 percent of its revenue overseas, and is "really starting to grow their international units well over 10 percent a year, even though the U.S. business is slightly down."
Over all, the unit sales growth rate for the entire company is about 7 percent to 8 percent a year, "a really big number, considering world G.D.P. growth is 3 to 4 percent," Mr. Poppenhagen said. He predicts 1998 earnings of $2.80 a share, if the company raises its domestic prices; if not, he predicts $2.65 a share. That would be an increase of 19 percent or 13 percent, respectively, over 1997 projected earnings of $2.35.
Moreover, Wrigley has a large amount of free cash flow, and that should grow as the company's worldwide capital spending plan starts to slow in the next 18 months or so, he said. Its stock closed on Friday at $70.25.
 
A Champion of Marketing
Mr. Poppenhagen also likes Nike, the footwear giant, which he says earns 45 percent of its revenues overseas. The company's domestic business is growing at a slim 5 percent to 6 percent a year, but Mr. Poppenhagen said the international units could probably grow at 30 percent a year. That would yield an overall growth rate of 17 percent to 18 percent a year, he said.
Moreover, Nike's long-term market position is enviable, Mr. Poppenhagen said, and its marketing is inspired. "It has great brand awareness, which they can leverage internationally," he said.
The company also has tighter control over its distribution than any other company in the athletic shoe industry, he added.
In the near term, however, Nike is having some product shortages and order cancellations, so its outlook over the next few years is a little unclear, Mr. Poppenhagen said. The resulting weakness in the share price -- the stock closed on Friday at $58.75, down from a 52-week high of $75.75 on Feb. 13 -- creates a buying opportunity, he said.
He forecasts 1998 earnings of $3.25 a share, up 16 percent from projected earnings of $2.80 for 1997.
 
Alone at the Top Overseas
Like Nike, the McDonald's Corporation has been having difficulties -- in this case, with what Mr. Poppenhagen calls the "flap over the ill-fated Campaign 55 promotion," referring to the company's failed 55-cent sandwich campaign. Moreover, McDonald's has been facing increased competition from Wendy's and Burger King, he said.
"I think those concerns overlook just how powerful their global franchise is," he said, adding that McDonald's does 60 percent of its business overseas, and it faces little or no competition in many foreign markets.
The return on investment in developing markets is very high, he added. Mr. Poppenhagen's best guess for what he calls the "cash-on-cash rate of return on investment," which does not take into account depreciation and other noncash expenses, is upward of 20 percent in developing markets.
More than 70 percent of the company's planned capital expenditures have been allocated to overseas, and Mr. Poppenhagen said the international business alone was worth the price of the stock today. The shares closed on Friday at $49.9375.
"In five years, the company will do 75 percent of its business abroad," he said, "and its domestic business will become less important every day."
He sees 1998 earnings of $2.75 a share, up 14 percent from the projected $2.42 for 1997. He said he could not predict the impact of last week's management shake-up at the company, intended to revitalize its United States business. In any case, he said, his investment decisions were not based on the company's domestic sales.

HEADLINE: European Integration;
Guns, Yes; Butter, Maybe

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
THE glow around the celebration of the expansion of NATO with President Clinton hailing a new Europe that is "undivided, democratic and at peace for the first time since the rise of the nation state" -- lasted for about three days last week.
Then, before the President re-boarded Air Force One bound for home, the carping began. The French said they wouldn't pay a centime to help integrate Poland, the Czech Republic and Hungary into the club. And others in Western Europe, while less adamant, made clear that they couldn't pay to defend the new NATO members at a time when their national deficits were already threatening to delay or sink the launching of a common European currency 18 months from now. 
 The Eastern Europeans weren't all that ecstatic either. With NATO expansion under way, they have already returned to a more concrete and immediate concern: getting into the European Union. This week, the union is expected to release a report calling for delay and caution before 10 countries now applying to become new members are admitted. It's one thing to pledge that you will defend the nations of Eastern Europe with blood, guts and missiles. But open markets further to their goods and help subsidize their farm goods? Well, that's serious business.
"Welcome to the new world," one of President Clinton's top economic advisers said. "It's easier these days to get countries to agree to link their armies than it is to integrate their economies."
 
Two Europes

Of course, this was all supposed to happen together. Security and prosperity are all of a piece, Mr. Clinton's aides have argued throughout the debates on the wisdom of NATO expansion. And up to a point, that is perfectly good logic. NATO membership carries with it an aura of stability, and so, faced with the choice of where to put their money, investors are now somewhat more likely to favor an auto plant in Poland or a software operation in Hungary.
Earlier this year, the White House even enlisted its economic team to make the case for an expanded North Atlantic Treaty Organization. "Our strong economic relations with Europe could not have evolved over the past 50 years if not for that continent's security and stability," Lawrence H. Summers, the deputy Treasury Secretary, said in April. Just the expectation that the military alliance was starting to expand, he argued, has helped "lock in Central Europe's practices of market democracy," fueling Hungary's privatization drive.
Hoping to be part of a future round of expansion, he argued, Romania has opened itself to investment from the West and Estonia has lowered its protectionist tariffs. Bulgaria dumped leaders "who had run the economy into the ground," and the Bulgarians now say that new reforms are linked to their interest in joining NATO.
But the fact is that expanding NATO in these times of peace has relatively little impact on the lives of ordinary citizens, either among the old members or the new. True economic integration, however, carries with it big costs, thanks to Europe's byzantine system of agricultural subsidies, which assures that farmers in all member states get the same guaranteed prices. That could mean major transfers of money from West to East. Western Europe is also balking because the new applicants would increase the population of the European Union by 30 percent, but would expand its economic muscle by only about 4 percent -- not exactly the kind of great addition China made on July 1 when it added a tiny bit of population and got a world-beater of a business center in Hong Kong.
The problem now is that the same three countries that were the first to join NATO are probably also the three in the best shape to join the European Union. That raises the specter of two Europes -- one protected and prosperous, one unprotected and struggling.
"The way these things work in real life is that you have to do your security relationships and economic relationships in tandem," said Robert Zoellick, a former senior official in the Bush Administration and a supporter of NATO expansion. "But you also want to be careful not to create huge imbalances" that affect stability, he said.
In fact, what is happening in Europe right now -- and to some degree around the world -- is that military and economic alliances are being traded off, so that no one feels completely left out.
To make the Russians less grumpy about NATO expansion, the Clinton Administration granted them almost full membership in the Group of Seven industrialized nations, even though in economic terms they are hardly a superpower these days. Washington also promised to get Moscow into the World Trade Organization -- the club of trading nations -- by the end of 1998.
 
Bending Rules
 That is proving easier said than done. Mr. Clinton made the commitment despite warnings from some members of his economic team that Russia's legal system, trading regime and protectionist policies could not be revamped that fast -- warnings similar to the ones Western Europeans make about economic integration with the East. And if the rules are bent for Russia, what about China? It is also applying to the World Trade Organization, but is balking at the strict requirements -- especially allowing in imports that could undercut state-run industries. So whatever is done for Moscow must be done for Beijing.
"The cold war had one major thing going for it," one of Mr. Clinton's Cabinet members mused recently. "Simplicity."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Warplanes at a Paris show: Military promises are easier to make than economic ones. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: The Nation;
It's the Economy, Congress

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
They once stretched, as politicians often intoned, as far as the eye could see. But Federal budget deficits, which only a few years ago were symbols of national decline, government run amok and political gridlock, are now evaporating.
And for all the chest-thumping by leaders of both parties about their resolve in reaching an agreement to actually balance the budget over the next five years, the dissipation of the annual deficits has little to do with any tough choices or courageous leadership in Washington. 
 The stunningly rapid decline in the deficit is testament to the power of economic forces that governments have trouble anticipating or understanding, much less controlling. Because the economy over the last few years has been so much stronger than expected -- and because it is generating tax receipts far bigger than expected even for the robust economic growth rate -- the gap between what the Federal Government spends and what it takes in has already narrowed to its lowest level since 1979, and seems to be headed even lower.
 
Annual Shrinkage
 Under the most optimistic scenarios, the deficit could disappear entirely in the next few years, leaving the budget in balance for the first time since 1969, even without taking into account the effects of the balanced-budget agreement that is moving rapidly through Congress in tax and spending bills.
Indeed, the budget agreement could actually slow the progress toward eliminating the deficit because it cuts taxes immediately while delaying most of the cuts in spending..
Each month this year has brought better news on the deficit as the Treasury Department tallies its tax receipts and economists use the figures to project the size of the budget shortfall. The latest set of estimates, based on tax receipts through June, put the deficit for the current fiscal year, which ends Sept. 30, at as little as $45 billion.
That is down from the official projection incorporated in the budget agreement two months ago of $67 billion, and is less than half of last year's deficit of $107 billion. The deficit peaked in 1992 at $290 billion. Some economists believe the deficit could continue falling over the next several years, though Administration officials say it is more likely to rise slightly before the balanced-budget package sends it downward again.
The most meaningful way to measure deficits is as a percentage of the nation's economic output. By that standard, this year's deficit seems likely to be around 0.6 percent of the gross domestic product, the first time it will have been below 1.0 percent since 1974. Nearly all the other big industrial countries, by contrast, are struggling to bring their deficits below 3 percent of output.
The figures highlight a point that many economists have been making in recent years: that the deficit has become economically insignificant in a country the size of the United States. Eliminating the deficit, in their view, is primarily a political imperative at this point, intended to show voters that Washington can tackle a tough issue and overcome partisanship to get something done for the country.
 
The Rewards of Rectitude
 Still, the declining deficits do owe something to the tax increase supported by President Clinton in 1993. And there is a case for continuing the political push to drive the deficit down to zero, or to run a budget surplus. Fiscal rectitude in Washington helps ease fears of inflation. It also helps keep interest rates down by assuring investors that the Government will not be competing with the private sector to borrow money in the financial markets.
Running surpluses could allow the nation to establish a rainy-day fund to keep the budget balanced if it hits a bad economic downturn. Surpluses could also let the Government begin attacking its mountain of debt, which stands at $5.4 trillion.
If the optimists are wrong, the Federal Government may never have the luxury of deciding what to do with any excess money. But that does not mean that politicians are not already drawing up their wish lists.
Representative Bill Archer of Texas, the chief Republican tax writer, says he would want bigger tax cuts.
The Clinton Administration is developing a contingency plan for allocating any windfall among various spending programs, tax cuts and the reduction of remaining deficits faster than planned.
But it is starting to dawn on political leaders that they are dealing with economic forces that are impossible to tame or predict. Not only is it unclear whether the economy, now in its seventh uninterrupted year of expansion, can continue to grow at robust rates for long enough to eliminate the deficit, but no one knows for sure why tax revenues have been so high or whether that welcome phenomenon will continue.
"What we do want to do is keep the economy growing," said Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the Democratic leader in the House, "because we all now know that's the major way in which you bring down the deficit."

HEADLINE: DIARY

BYLINE: By FRED BROCK

 BODY:

TOBACCO SETTLEMENT
Joe Camel, R.I.P.
Under intense attack, R.J. Reynolds Tobacco decided to drop Joe Camel from its advertising and replace the cartoon figure -- which critics said enticed children to begin smoking -- with stylized versions of Camel cigarettes' original camel trademark. Anti-smoking advocates and the White House cheered the demise of Joe Camel. "We must put tobacco ads like Joe Camel out of our children's reach forever," President Clinton said. A brief statement from Reynolds did not mention a ban on cartoons as part of a landmark $368.5 billion settlement reached on June 20 by Reynolds and other tobacco marketers. Earlier in the week, Mr. Clinton rejected a central provision of that accord as "totally unreasonable." The provision would have required a cumbersome process to further regulate nicotine.
 
THE STOCK MARKET
Another Wild Week
Blue-chip investors must have felt as if they were on a seesaw. The Dow Jones industrial average began the week on a slightly sour note, falling 37.32 points. But on Tuesday, it surged 103.82 points, to its 32d record high for the year -- and its first close above 7,900 -- as investors remained optimistic about corporate profits and a stable economy. On Wednesday, the Dow inched to within 10 points of 8,000 before plunging almost 120 points. Analysts cited program trading and profit taking for the drop. The Dow gained 44 points on Thursday, and 35 on Friday, ending the week at 7,921.82, for a five-day advance of 26. A recovery in technology issues allowed the Nasdaq to set records all week. It closed on Friday at 1,502.62, up 11.69 -- and a gain of 35 for the week. 

COMPUTERS
Deal! Deal! Deal!
Hewlett-Packard, Compaq Computer and I.B.M. will cut prices for commercial desktop computers by as much as 24 percent to match lower prices offered by Dell Computer, which sells directly to consumers without a network of dealers and has been growing more rapidly. The reductions promise to be a bonanza for corporate computer buyers, but a price war could cut into the profits of all the computer makers. Japan's Hitachi Ltd., meanwhile, has become the No. 2 maker of powerful mainframe computers used by businesses, tripling its share of the market last year, to 20 percent. I.B.M. remains No. 1; the Amdahl Corporation, which was No. 2 in 1995 with a 12 percent share, slipped to third place, with 7 percent. Hitachi sells the machines through Hatachi Data Systems, a joint venture of Hatachi and Electronic Data Systems of Texas.
 
RETAILING
Ward's Woes; Bids for Barney's
Montgomery Ward, one of the oldest names in American retailing, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, which allows a company to operate while it develops a reorganization plan. GE Capital, half-owner of Montgomery Ward, will provide $1 billion as part of the reorganization; during the last nine years, GE Capital has invested $180 million in the retailer and lent it an estimated $300 million to $900 million. Montgomery Ward, based in Chicago, had been deadlocked for months in negotiations with its banking syndicate and insurance companies over $1.4 billion of debt. Four bidders, meanwhile, came forward to meet a deadline to bid for Barney's Inc., the luxury retailer in New York, which is also under bankruptcy protection. The four are Heico Acquisitions, an investment firm controlled by the Chicago financier Michael Heisley; Dickson Concepts (International), a Hong Kong retailer; Ong Beng Seng, a retail executive from Singapore, and Texas Pacific Group, an investment firm led by David Bonderman. Barney's has until July 25 to accept one of the bids. Saks Holdings declined to improve on the $290 million it offered in April, adding that it thought its bid was now too high anyway.
 
MEDIA
Hercules the Weak
Hercules, known for his great strength, has proved impotent at a very important task: lifting the Walt Disney Company's stock price. In its first two weeks of general release, Disney's latest animated feature, "Hercules," took in only $58 million at the box office. This was a poor showing compared with other recent Disney summer releases like "Pocahontas," which took in $80 million in its first two weeks in 1995, and "The Lion King," which grossed $119 million in two weeks in 1994. One Disney executive said "Hercules" was a disappointment, in part, because of heavy competition and the fact that it failed to appeal across various age groups within a family. The film's lackluster performance -- along with slowing growth at Disney theme parks and a management shake-up at its ABC broadcast network -- helped pare the company's share price to about $76 by Friday, compared with its 52-week high of $85.375 on May 12.
 
PUBLISHING
More Books Gather Dust
The Book Industry Study Group reported that sales of hard-cover and paperback adult trade books -- the chief moneymakers for publishers -- fell by 5.3 percent from 1995 to 1996, dipping to 459 million copies. It was the second consecutive year that the drop in sales exceeded 5 percent. Publishers have been acutely aware of the declines, which have been accompanied by large numbers of returns from bookstores. In contrast to companies in many other industries, book retailers share little of the risk that a product will be unsuccessful because publishers allow bookstores to return unsold items -- a custom that began in the Depression as an enticement to booksellers. By publishing fewer titles and limiting print runs, publishers may be able to improve their profits but not necessarily increase overall sales, according to the annual report by the publisher-supported group.
 
MANAGEMENT
Who Wants This Job?
Apple Computer's board, unhappy over continued losses, ousted the company's chairman and chief executive, Gilbert F. Amelio. In addition, Apple's executive vice president for technology, Ellen Hancock, resigned. The company said its co-founder, Steven P. Jobs -- who had been ousted in a 1985 boardroom coup but returned as an adviser in December when Apple bought his Next Software Inc. for more than $400 million -- would play a larger role in coming months but was not expected to take over as chief executive. Apple's woes have tested the loyalty of its customers and software makers; its share of the personal computer market in the United States is down to 3.3 percent, and many industry analysts wonder whether the company that pioneered the personal computer can be revived. Its troubles are a legacy of technological stagnation, product missteps and management turmoil; finding a new leader will probably be difficult. Apple's stock, which traded at a peak of $73 in 1991, ended the week at a little above $15 a share.
 
THE ECONOMY
Good News Keeps Flowing
Low unemployment is often followed by surging inflation, but the United States has been enjoying the best of both worlds: low joblessness and low inflation, thanks to millions of workers willing to enter the labor force without bidding up wages, economists say. The American labor force has been growing rapidly: By early this year, it was expanding at nearly twice the rate of other years in the 1990's and is continuing to grow faster than the working-age population. A result: Four million more workers have been fed into a growing economy since the start of 1996. Hispanic people are the biggest contingent, but younger women and men older than 55 also figure prominently among the new entrants. The Federal Reserve, meanwhile, reported that consumer borrowing increased at a slower-than-expected 2.9 percent annual rate during May, down from the 9.7 percent pace in April. The level of consumer credit increased by $3 billion in May, to $1.224 trillion.

HEADLINE: Roll Reversal;
Welfare Finds a Few New Friends

BYLINE: By RACHEL L. SWARNS 

 BODY:
FOR years, advocates fighting the unpopular fight to help people on public assistance have accepted that getting states to spend extra dollars on welfare is about as easy as wrestling hogs in a mud pit. Most expected the battle only to get tougher after President Clinton signed the welfare bill last summer that reversed six decades of social policy by eliminating the Federal guarantee of cash aid for the nation's poorest children.
But one year later, the outlook is sunnier than anyone might have imagined. Witnessing the shift in attitudes seems like watching the Earth spin in reverse. Who would have imagined that politicians, and the taxpayers who elected them, might support spending on what was considered the nation's most reviled social program? 
 While advocates for the poor still have long, unfulfilled wish lists, states are spending millions more than expected on innovative day-care and transportation programs, large and small, to help welfare recipients march successfully into the new world of work.
Minnesota will spend about $25 million to wipe out an 18-month waiting list for day care. Wisconsin will finance $4 million in emergency loans for welfare recipients and working parents who need to buy used cars or repair old ones to get to work.
And Rhode Island will spend more than $12 million to raise its payments to day-care providers by about 14 percent over the next three years while sparing parents any increases, in an effort to improve the quality of child care.
"I feel like the Red Sox just won the World Series," said Alexandra Moser, executive director of Catholic Charities' Office of Child Care in Rhode Island. "I'm still in a state of shock."
Spending is being approved, not nearly as often as advocates would like, but more than expected. Unlikely allies are even popping up in unexpected quarters.
In New York, for example, Republican legislators helped force Gov. George E. Pataki to abandon his plan to slash welfare benefits by 45 percent over five years, arguing that the cuts would drive families deeper into poverty. In Alabama, fiscally conservative Democrats argued more this year about how much more they should spend, than about how much they should cut.
"Legislators were asking themselves, 'Is there enough child care? Do we need to invest more money in early education?' " said Jack Tweedie, who follows welfare for the National Conference of State Legislatures. "The idea that states wouldn't care about welfare recipients was misplaced."
But it isn't benevolence that has spurred the spending. Very few states are actually using more of their own dollars. Instead, they are responding to an infusion of Federal cash. Under the new law, states will receive about $2 billion more this year, 16 percent more than they otherwise would have. The windfall, enough for an extra $650 for every welfare family in the country, is the result of a new Federal formula that pays states based on the welfare population of earlier years, even as rolls decline.
Officials have also been pushed to act by the threat of hefty Federal fines -- cuts in funding that range from 5 percent to 21 percent levied on states that fail to get welfare recipients working.
Under the law, 50 percent of the heads of welfare families must find jobs by the year 2002. And that won't happen if mothers can't find day care for their toddlers or easily accessible bus routes to their offices.
So Pennsylvania is considering offering free subway passes. And Delaware has expanded its criminal background checks to cover babysitters so that the new working women can kiss their babies goodbye with confidence as they leave each morning.
"These changes emerge from the recognition of the kind of barriers poor people face every day," said Mark Alan Hughes, a leading expert on transportation problems of the poor. "When you're driving a 1977 Buick LaSabre and it breaks down, being able to get a quick loan to have the brakes replaced is a serious policy intervention."
Not all the news is good. The end of welfare as it was known meant the death of a single Federal standard and the birth of 50 different plans in 50 states. No one has comprehensively assessed the evolving patchwork. But several state policies have been criticized for not doing enough.
New York, for example, plans to spend $54 million to create 23,000 new day care slots statewide, while advocates say New York City alone needs 35,000. In addition, Governor Pataki has been criticized for choosing to use nearly half of the state's $730 million windfall for purposes other than welfare. Pennsylvania, which has expanded day-care subsidies, gets a negative rating from advocates for raising the dollar amount that parents must contribute for that care.
And the need for funding is likely to increase, not decrease, as states struggle to move the most difficult cases from the rolls: the long-term recipients, the substance abusers, the illiterate. That money will be hard to come by if the economy sours and caseloads rise again as people turn to the dole for help.
"The hard work, the heavy lifting, has not started here," said Peter B. Edelman, who resigned as assistant secretary of the Department of Health and Human Services last year in protest over the welfare law.
"You're talking about four million people who have to be off the rolls four years from now," said Mr. Edelman, cautioning against premature celebration. "We're a long way away from being able to say we're doing everything that needs to be done."
But the good news is that while voters rejected spending on the old welfare system, they seem to support spending for one that puts people to work. In polls conducted in three states this spring, more than half of those surveyed said they were willing to spend more money to carry out welfare reform, said Celinda Lake, a Democratic pollster based in Washington.
"People want welfare recipients to work, but they don't want to see them starving on street corners," said Amy Tucci, a spokeswoman for the American Public Welfare Association, which represents state and local social-service commissioners. "And they're beginning to realize that it's much more difficult to put people to work than it is to write a check."

SECTION: Section 4; Page 1; Column 1; Week in Review Desk

HEADLINE: Hard of Hearing;
A Scandal Falls Victim to Its Own Irrelevance

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
THE telltale sign came only three hours after the much-touted hearings on campaign finance finally opened last week in the Senate: several spectators got up and left, leaving a noticeable swath of empty seats in the public gallery. These people did not go home to watch the proceedings on television, because even cable channels like C-Span and MSNBC devoted scant time to live coverage.
Even John Dean, whose compelling testimony in the Watergate hearings 25 years ago kept Americans glued to their seats for five days, said he did not have time to bother watching the hearings. And The Washington Post, which catapulted to international prominence for breaking the Watergate scandal, could not bring itself to give Page 1 play to the second day of testimony. 
 The proceedings don't seem to have penetrated deeply beyond the Beltway. A nationwide survey by the trade publication Talkers Magazine found that the most popular subject on talk radio last week was the Mars landing, followed by U.F.O.'s in Roswell, N.M., and the Nevada boxing commission's ruling on Mike Tyson. The Senate machinations came in fourth.
 
Interested in U.F.O.'s
 "People are talking about U.F.O.'s and a boxing match over the heart of the ethics of our political culture," said Michael Harrison, the editor of Talkers. Despite the potential gravitas of the hearings, he said, "you start yawning after a while. And when you think about what you're yawning over, it's incredible."
The lack of evident public outrage over the campaign finance practices described at the hearings is further evidence that there is not an angry, galvanizing constituency on the issue of money and politics. (True, it did not help that the hearings thus far have been devoid of vivid witnesses or gripping drama.)
Polls show that people are distressed that millions of dollars of unregulated money has seeped into campaigns. And they believe that moneyed interests wield an undue influence on their public servants.
Even so, people have become so discouraged that they seem to have given up. The latest ABC News/ Washington Post Poll, released last week, found that 63 percent of the public opposes the way Presidential and Congressional campaigns are financed. But 67 percent said they had little hope that Mr. Clinton or Congress would substantively change things. Further, there is no great incentive for Mr. Clinton to prod Congress to reform the system: according to the poll, his approval rating stands at 64 percent, as high as ever.
Senator Fred Thompson, the Tennessee Republican running the proceedings, sought to introduce some surprise and drama on opening day by announcing that there was as-yet-undisclosed evidence of a sinister plot by the Chinese Government to infiltrate elections in the United States. But even Mr. Thompson's dramatics did not seem to register.
So the public may be at peace with the notion that the campaign-finance system is flawed, even corrupt, and that it will never be fixed so long as that is left to the politicians who relied on the system to get elected in the first place.
Yet the lack of interest in cleaning up campaign finance is not fueled merely by cynicism after years of unfulfilled promises or the absence of a civic consciousness. To many people, the Government and the Presidency are not as important as they were in the days of Nixon and Watergate. In this era of relative prosperity and governmental devolution, when Republicans sound like Democrats and vice versa in the middle ground of moderate consensus, it does not seem to matter as much who is President or who is in Congress. As a result, even though they may pay dearly for their indifference, people simply may not care as they once would have that Candidate X spent millions of dollars of tainted money to get elected.
"Government and politics in this country has simply become less relevant to people -- they're less interested and paying less attention," said Robert M. Teeter, a Republican pollster. "We've had a long, sustained period without any major crises and no recession. So they view the economic system as more important than the political system."
Craig Fuller, who like Mr. Teeter was close to President George Bush, put it more bluntly: "I suspect more people are keeping their eye on the stock market these days. Dow 8000 may be more compelling than John Huang."
It's all a far cry from the days of Watergate, a true Constitutional crisis whose Senate hearings riveted the public and, for the most part, transcended partisanship. "Watergate was much more serious, and a lot easier for the public to understand," Mr. Dean said, adding that these hearings deal with "a problem both parties have and it's highly charged with partisanship -- I think the public sees that."
 
A Well-Worn Script
 Another difference is that during the Watergate hearings, the narrative was unfolding -- "What did the President know and when did he know it?" But the campaign finance hearings have dwelled on material that has already been made public. Desperate for a new script, Mr. Thompson has started to emphasize the national security threat rather than simply the corruption of politicians by money.
But it may be premature to write off his hearings, or the appetite in Congress for remaking the system. After all, the first witness in the Watergate hearings, Robert C. Odle Jr., a Nixon re-election committee official, was hardly memorable.
"All you need is one witness to say, 'The attache of the Chinese Embassy gave me a million dollars in a leather suitcase to pass around to American officials,' " said former Senator Warren B. Rudman, the New Hampshire Republican who was co-chairman of the Iran-contra hearings. Then, he said, "the American people would stay home from work to watch it on television."
 
Wish List
This 1994 memo to Ann Cahill, an assistant to Harold M. Ickes, who was deputy White House chief of staff, from Martha Phipps, a special assistant to the former general chairman of the Democratic National Committee, was released during the Senate hearings. Lanny J. Davis, a White House special counsel, explained: "This was a wish list drafted by someone who didn't understand what was or wasn't appropriate. It was just a proposal that never happened. . . . We're not saying that friends or supporters didn't do these things. But they were not in return for giving a campaign contribution."

HEADLINE: The World;
Handoff in Panama: Hong Kong Was Just a Rehearsal

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: BALBOA HEIGHTS, Panama

 BODY:
LIKE Hong Kong until this month, this American-run outpost is a place living on borrowed time. For the moment, pockets of the former Canal Zone still retain their quaint, Mayberry-in-the-tropics ambiance of Baptist churches, manicured lawns and Elks and Lions clubs. But a final, historic deadline is fast approaching: in less than 30 months, the Panama Canal will cease to be an agency of the United States Government and become a purely Panamanian possession.
Both sides are preparing for that signal event with a contradictory mixture of boosterism and trepidation. Just last month, Panama's national assembly approved the "organic law" that will govern the administration of the canal. But to oversee the transition process, President Ernesto Perez Balladares last week named Jorge Ritter, who served as Foreign Minister during the dictatorship of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, as Minister of Canal Affairs and head of the future Panama Canal Authority. 
 At the headquarters of the Panama Canal Commission here, overlooking the waterway's Pacific Ocean entrance, the emphasis is on what the canal administrator, Alberto Aleman Zubieta, an American-educated Panamanian engineer, likes to call "a seamless transition" on Dec. 31, 1999, when the final provisions of the Panama Canal Treaties, signed by President Jimmy Carter and Gen. Omar Torrijos in 1977, go into effect.
"That's a big date on the calendar for the politicians, but in terms of operating the Panama Canal, it is virtually meaningless and we are ignoring it," said Richard Wainio, director of planning for the canal commission. "We are already looking many, many years beyond that."
 
A Lock and a Hard Place
 The transition has been eased by two consecutive years of record traffic and revenue: more than 13,700 ships carrying 198 million tons of cargo paid $486 million in tolls in 1996. A billion-dollar modernization program that will increase the capacity of the canal by 20 percent is under way, and 92 percent of a work force of 9,800 people is already Panamanian, including two-thirds of the pilots who guide vessels through the 50-mile waterway. "We're going to be turning over a debt-free canal that is as modern as it has ever been, so that Panama will have a running start," Mr. Wainio said. "What more can you ask for?"
What shipping companies would ask is for the canal to remain in American hands. They worry that Panama will be tempted to divert canal revenue for its own use and that the Canal Authority will be politicized, concerns Mr. Aleman says are groundless.
But Panama is not the United States, "the American veneer notwithstanding," said a senior executive of a large shipping company. "That has always meant you have to deal with sudden swings in policy, nepotism, corruption and laws that look good on paper but are never enforced." Panama's recent handling of bids to privatize moribund ports at either end of the canal engendered protests from the losing American companies and public criticism of the bidding process.
On the Panamanian side, too, there are questions about the disposition of the real estate and military bases that surround it. Who will guarantee the security of the canal once American troops leave? Should the United States be encouraged to retain a military presence, despite the treaty's prohibition? How much are the 569 square miles and 7,000 buildings that are being handed over really worth on the open market?
"This sort of thing is always a trauma," said Nicolas Ardito Barletta, a former president of Panama who now heads the Government agency that supervises disposal of what are called in official parlance the "reverted areas." "We are going to be losing $200 million the American military presence contributes in added value to our economy each year. But we hope increased investments and exports will substitute for that."
Though the canal has been the central fact of Panama's existence since the country was carved out of Colombia in 1903 with the connivance of Teddy Roosevelt, the waterway remains an enigma to many Panamanians. Perhaps as a result, some people here are convinced the United States will not hand over the canal and is secretly plotting to remain; others, more than 75 percent according to recent polls, actually want the Americans to stay, but only so long as they are willing to pay to do so.
"The Canal Zone disappeared in 1979, but a lot of the myths and mystique that surrounded it linger on, which is what happens when you have run a closed shop like we did," one American military official here said. "The folks up in the hills still think the streets here are paved with gold, and it always surprises them when they come into the zone for the first time and find a lot of old buildings with roofs that leak."
 
America's Stake
 Nevertheless, the transition process here promises to be less wrenching than in Hong Kong. Unlike China, Panama has a government that is democratic and resolutely capitalist -- with its own home-grown robber barons, some critics would maintain. The preparation time is longer, more than 22 years, and the United States has gradually been ceding authority and territory, with the Southern Command set to move its headquarters to Miami and give up Albrook Air Force Station by the end of September. Already, the military has surrendered to Panama more than a third of the territory it once controlled.
Panama has many grandiose dreams for the zone, some of which seem fanciful, like a vast technology and research park to be called the "City of Knowledge," and some of which are already taking shape. The notorious School of the Americas, for instance, where Latin American military officers once were trained in dubious practices, has just been acquired by a Spanish-Mexican consortium, which plans to spend $20 million to turn the decaying building into a five-star hotel catering to eco-tourists.
With the end of the cold war and the emergence of new means and routes of transportation, the canal may be of less strategic importance than in the past. But it remains both a vital waterway and a symbol of empire, and the American stake in its smooth functioning will continue to be huge even after control is transferred. "We can't make Panama succeed," said an American military official here. "But we can't afford to let them fail."
