HEADLINE: The World;
Viva Mexican Democracy -- In Theory

BYLINE: By SAM DILLON 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY

 BODY:
DURING the Mexican Revolution, violence spilled across the United States' southern border so frequently that on the eve of World War I, the Army had half of its forces garrisoned there to contain Mexico's chaos. Ever since, Americans have wanted stability in Mexico and mostly they've had it: the Institutional Revolutionary Party, or PRI, has been in charge for seven decades.
PRI presidents made the important decisions, hand-picked governors, judges and legislators, and every six years anointed their own successors. Workers were kept submissive, and people -- and corporations -- with connections were able to get favors done. 
 And so the United States' initially positive reaction to the PRI's trouncing last week in a watershed national election may eventually develop into mixed feelings.
In rejecting the PRI, Mexico exchanged its longtime formula for stability -- one-party rule -- for a bold new democratic experiment. And while many of the changes that may follow will seem healthy and thrilling to Americans, others may cause discomfort. For Mexico, after so long seeming immutable and quiet, now is likely to be not only turbulent but newly assertive.
The emboldened opposition parties victorious in the elections may press President Ernesto Zedillo to seek better terms from the United States in trade and other disputes. American corporations here may confront new labor unions that will defend Mexican workers more vigorously than the PRI-controlled federations. And anti-Americanism, largely absent from public discourse in recent years, may be heard. The price of Mexican democracy, for the United States, may be a more contentious neighbor.
"Mexico may become more confusing," said Robert A. Pastor, a director at the Carter Center in Atlanta who led a delegation of election observers to Mexico. "There'll be more voices and it may seem discordant, but Mexico has become more stable. Some people think stability requires a strong hand, but they're mistaken. Stability requires a framework for peaceful change. That's what Mexico got with these elections."
At the end, the seeming stability of the PRI was deceptive as the party grew decadent and corrupt.
In recent years, for example, Patricia Hogan, who helps Americans relocate their families to Mexico, watched her business stall in the months around every major election. Business was awful in 1988, when presidential balloting was widely considered fraudulent. "People feared some sort of revolution," she said. Americans also stayed away in 1994, another election year when Mexico seemed headed toward chaos. This spring her business again hit the skids as Americans grew nervous about Mexico.
But on Monday, the day after elections in which the PRI suffered its worst defeat ever, Ms. Hogan's phone rang crazily. "The voting was clean, the stock market shot up, the peso stayed strong," she said. "It was a pretty good picture." The State Department applauded, several Wall Street firms recommended boosting investments here, and Ms. Hogan signed nine new clients.
Allowed for the first time to elect the mayor of Mexico City, voters chose Cuauhtemoc Cardenas Solorzano, the son of the Mexican president who nationalized the oil fields in 1938, who broke with the PRI a decade ago to form his own party. In the lower house of Congress, two opposition parties denied the PRI its perpetual majority and began preparing to transform what has been a rubber stamp chamber into an assertive new check on presidential prerogative.
 
Economic Ties That Bind
 America's craving for stability is understandable. Mexico has at least $50 billion in American investments, $156 billion a year in bilateral trade and a critical petroleum supply. Each year more than 10 million American tourists head south, and a million or more Mexicans head north, legally and illegally, to supply crucial labor for American fields and factories. The United States Embassy says some 350,000 Americans live in Mexico, many in retirement, many in professions or businesses.
John E. Smith, a Rhode Island native, has managed his own head-hunting business for 25 years, recruiting executives to work for American or Mexican companies here. "I think the elections were stupendous, a real mark of Mexico's maturity," he said. "But I see years of uncertainty and turmoil, and I'm not sure all Americans will welcome the roiling waves of Mexican democracy. It could be unsettling to comfortable working arrangements, for business people and others who have liked the secure surroundings of a well-established order."
One arrangement that may come under attack is the agreements struck among the Government, large employers and PRI-controlled unions, which for years have kept salaries low. Driving voters last week was not only a desire for fresh leadership, but also anger over 30 months of austerity and a daily minimum wage that has plunged to $3. Opposition lawmakers and independent unionists are likely to work together to improve conditions.
Along with labor unrest may come a dose of anti-American rhetoric, since many of the new lawmakers believe that PRI governments have been too solicitous of the United States. The newly independent Congress will also mount investigations into official corruption. To some Americans, it may even appear that Mexico is growing more corrupt as the country airs dirty laundry that has accumulated over years.
What Americans would like to see, but are unlikely to, are major new approaches to their main priorities in Mexico: slowing illegal immigration and narcotics trafficking. Both were non-issues in the Mexican election campaign.
"The major security issues in Mexico -- the increase in crime and especially kidnappings, the growing importance of Mexican gangs in the narcotics trade, the corruption of Mexican law enforcement -- are these things going to change as a result of an election?" asked Brian M. Jenkins, a deputy chairman of Kroll Associates, the security firm. "The answer is no. Those things are not going to change overnight."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Many Mexicans want their country to stand tougher against the United States on immigration and other issues. A May Day marcher burned the American flag. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Rights Abuses Stain Turkey's Democratic Image

BYLINE: By STEPHEN KINZER 

DATELINE: ISTANBUL, Turkey

 BODY:
Every Saturday at noon, as they have done for more than two years, about 100 Turks converge on a bustling plaza in downtown Istanbul and quietly sit down on the pavement.
There are usually no speeches and no placards. The protesters, mostly women, make their point by silently displaying photographs of their missing loved ones, although their emotion sometimes boils over into an occasional chant, like "Mothers' anger will strangle the murderers." After half an hour, they rise and go their separate ways. 
 "Three men in civilian clothes grabbed my husband as he left the house one night in 1995," one of the protesters, Hanim Tosun, 32, said on a recent Saturday. "They were carrying pistols and walkie-talkies. We checked the license number of their car and found it was registered to the police. That was almost two years ago. We have tried everything to find him, but the police tell us nothing."
Mrs. Tosun's husband was a street vendor who had served three years in prison on charges of collaborating with Kurdish guerrillas in southeastern Turkey and had come to Istanbul to start a new life. He is now a statistic, one of an unknown number of Turks believed to have disappeared while in police custody.
As Mrs. Tosun and the other "Saturday Mothers" carried out their weekly protest, people around them went about their business. At nearby kiosks, newspapers carried bold headlines accusing politicians of various abuses. Organizers of rightist and leftist parties huddled in downtown offices, making plans for the coming election campaign.
"This is in many ways a very free country, so free that people can go to the polls and change their government whenever they want," Orhan Pamuk, Turkey's most prominent young novelist, said in an interview. "But it is also a country with a horrible human rights record. Probably there is no country in the world where this contradiction is so sharp and clear."
Turkey's human rights record is the subject of endless debate, not only here but also in the Western world. Turkish officials say the problem is exaggerated, but it is one of the main reasons why the European Union insists on holding Turkey at arm's length and why some Westerners consider Turkey to be a difficult partner.
Many strategists in Washington and in European capitals agree that because of Turkey's membership in NATO, its geographical position, its history and its role as a defender of secularist democracy in the Muslim world, Turkey could become even more important than it has been.
But they also say that before Turkey can become a full partner of the West or a desirable model for the new nations of the Caucasus and Central Asia, it must resolve nagging questions about the way it treats prisoners and dissenters.
"Human rights and freedom of expression are very important issues for the image of Turkey, and they condition many people's reflex reaction to questions about Turkey's role in Europe," said Michael Lake, the European Union envoy in Ankara. "This reflex is so strong that it outweighs important perceptions of Turkey, such as its strategic importance, its place in the foreign and security architecture of Europe, and even its growing importance as an economic partner."
Hanging over the human rights debate is the war being waged by Kurdish nationalists in the southeast. Most charges of human rights abuses in Turkey stem from incidents in that region. As many as 80 percent of the charges arising in other parts of the country, according to several human rights advocates, are somehow related to the Kurdish conflict.
"Tens of thousands of people have been killed out there," said Sabri Ergul, a member of the human rights committee in Parliament. The remains of Turkish soldiers and civilians slain in the fighting "have come back to nearly every town and village in Turkey," he added. "Naturally people are very angry about this. They develop the feeling that whatever has to be done to stop terrorism is justified."
"Terrorism is the problem of our age, but our age is also the age of human rights," Mr. Ergul said. "The great mistake that is made here is the belief that when you combat terrorism, you don't have to respect democracy and law."
Mr. Ergul is involved in one of Turkey's most important torture-related cases. He is a lawyer for the families of 16 teen-agers who were arrested last year for scrawling leftist graffiti on walls and who are accused of belonging to subversive organizations in the western town of Manisa. Although the police have admitted that the teen-agers confessed to their crimes under torture, they were found guilty and sentenced to terms of up to 12 years in prison.
A public prosecutor in Manisa has filed suit against 10 police officers accused of having carried out the torture, but the Government is drawing out the case and seems to hope that it will somehow fade away. It is doing the same in another important case, the investigation of officers charged in the 1996 beating death of journalist Metin Goktepe.
"The Government, especially the Interior Ministry, protects the police who torture," Mr. Ergul said. "They encourage it. They are the ones telling the police forces to behave this way, so naturally they are not in a position to prosecute officers who follow their instructions."
Human rights advocates say that besides torture in detention centers and the "mystery killings" of perceived Kurdish nationalists, the other principal human rights problem in Turkey is the ban on statements deemed to threaten national unity. Laws that forbid these statements are applied most often against those who question Government policy in the Kurdish region. It is generally considered criminal to suggest that the army shares responsibility for the carnage there, to advocate peace talks or to assert that the Government should treat the Kurds as a distinct ethnic group that deserves autonomy.
These laws are often used in cases that devastate Turkey's image. Last year, for example, one of the country's most beloved cultural figures, the novelist Yasar Kemal, was sentenced to a 20-month prison term for making pro-Kurdish statements that were interpreted as separatist propaganda.
Mr. Kemal's sentence was suspended, as often happens in such cases. Nonetheless, human rights advocates say that more than 70 journalists and writers are in jail for statements they have made.
Turkish officials concede that torture is sometimes used in detention centers, but they insist that it is not systematic and not sanctioned by the authorities. They also assert that laws against separatist propaganda must be judged in the context of a civil conflict in which terrorism has been used as a principal weapon.
At a news conference in London last year, Foreign Minister Tansu Ciller said that Turkey "has decided to take a series of measures in order to totally eliminate in practice the crime of torture, which as a matter of fact is forbidden by our laws." After she spoke, Parliament passed a law cutting the maximum time defendants may be held incommunicado to 10 days from 30.
Perhaps the most illuminating human rights case in Turkey is the complex scandal that emerged after a spectacular car crash near the western town of Susurluk in November that killed a top police official and an escaped heroin smuggler. A pro-Government Kurdish clan leader who is also a member of Parliament survived. Questions about what the three men were doing in a car together led to accusations of Government involvement in smuggling, death squads, illegal repression in the southeast and other crimes.
But a parliamentary investigation of the scandal fizzled out after senior military and civilian leaders signaled that they would not cooperate. Many Turks believe responsibility for the crimes reaches so high that a full investigation is impossible.
"I'm glad we had Susurluk," said Taciser Belge, coordinator of the Istanbul-based human rights group Helsinki Citizens Assembly. "Now when we speak about these things, people realize that we're not making up stories. Since Susurluk, people understand that when things like mystery killings happen, the army and the state are involved. This is very new in Turkey."

GRAPHIC: Photo: In Turkey, human rights abuses contrast with a democratic tradition. Women and some men holding photographs of missing loved ones gather in downtown Istanbul every Saturday to protest disappearances. (Staton R. Winter for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Clinton's NATO: Keen on Growth, Murky on Mission

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

DATELINE: ST. PETERSBURG, Russia, July 12

 BODY:
For most of last week, President Clinton sang the praises of the NATO alliance, hailing the three nations invited on Tuesday to join the club and promising that others would be asked to join it in 1999.
Mr. Clinton spoke boldly of a new European order, and there is no doubt that the United States and its Western European allies have undertaken something of breathtaking scope -- a security network stretching, as an Administration official said, "from Vancouver to Vladivostok, the long way." At the first session of the Euro-Atlantic Partnership Council, 16 NATO members and 28 other countries were represented. 
 But what the President said added up to less than a comprehensive plan for the future, and he seemed to be addressing European security concerns more than making a case to his own electorate. Today, in a radio address broadcast in the United States, he said that expanding NATO was a "serious step." He added, "It requires a full discussion I intend to lead with the American people."
In Warsaw on Thursday, Mr. Clinton said that "the old dividing lines of Europe were wiped away forever" by the decisions NATO made in Madrid. He told a cheering throng in Castle Square: "Never again will your fate be decided by others. Never again will the birthright of freedom be denied you. Poland is coming home."
The next day, in Bucharest, Romania, the President was hardly less expansive. He assured a nation denied entry to NATO in the first round of expansion: "I welcome Romania's deep desire to contribute even more fully to Europe's security and strength. I want that, too, for Europe, America and you, and I say to you today: Stay the course and Romania will cross the milestone."
But what the new NATO and the new security network radiating from it will do, and how they will do it, remained murky despite the fervor of Mr. Clinton's oratory and the ambition of his commitments.
Although there is a lot of talk about making Polish weapons and Czech intelligence services and Hungarian communications systems compatible with those that NATO uses, Mr. Clinton made it reasonably clear that in the post-Soviet era military matters are no longer primary.
What the allies must guard against, the Administration believes, are terrorism, illegal drugs, nationalist extremism and regional conflicts fueled by ethnic, racial and religious hatreds. Yet Mr. Clinton has not spelled out what means would be used to do so. Warplanes are of little use against terrorism and drug smuggling, and naval power is of little help in fighting racism.
The idea seems to be that membership in NATO itself, and hope for such membership, will make nations behave. It has to some degree dampened the enmity between Turkey and Greece, supporters of the new order argue, and it has prompted the Romanians to paper over their conflict with Hungary over Transylvania.
"Bringing in new members," Mr. Clinton said, "will help to lock in the gains of democracy in those countries and the free market they are already achieving. The example of these new members will help to encourage others to aspire to membership and to continue their democratic reforms and their efforts to settle disputes with their neighbors."
Those are largely unexamined propositions. In the past, countries with democratic governments and market economies have found themselves seriously at odds with one another, even at war, in Europe and elsewhere. It is not self-evident that one NATO member, feeling its national interest threatened, would refrain from hostile action because the alliance would be upset if it did not. Things are less rational than that.
Nor, as recent history suggests, will it be as easy to bring NATO -- to say nothing of the wider alliance -- into focus against a perceived threat. With a small number of NATO members and a common enemy, the old Soviet bloc, it was relatively simple. That is one key reason why NATO is one of the great success stories of the century. But it proved much harder to make common cause against strife in Bosnia, even without an expanded membership with a more diverse ethnic, historical and geographic character.
Mr. Clinton will have to do a much more thorough job of selling and explaining in the months to come if he is to persuade the American people that the new system will work and that it is worth committing several billion dollars to its creation.
According to the opinion polls, few ordinary voters have devoted much thought to NATO expansion, which is not surprising. This week's were the first events when sustained publicity was given to the matter, especially on television. With no clearly definable military threat, and with the economy thriving, foreign policy has been remote from American voters' concerns.
Mr. Clinton is confident that he can win approval of the expansion plan in the Senate next year, even though it requires a two-thirds vote. So are most Senate leaders of both parties, although Jesse Helms of North Carolina, the sometimes bellicose chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, said that Mr. Clinton's "egregious mishandling of NATO expansion was raising serious concern" in the Senate and warned that "dramatic changes need to be made" if the plan is to win approval.
Perhaps a half-dozen other Senators have hoisted warning flags.
Ratification, if achieved, will not be enough; broad public support is clearly needed for an agreement that requires the United States to defend countries in Central Europe that are less familiar to most Americans, except those with ethnic ties, than are, say, France and Germany.
Mr. Clinton will have to take the offensive. One of his top diplomatic advisers said he had "already done a lot to sell NATO," including leading off the foreign-policy section of this year's State of the Union message with the subject, but the old political hands think he will need to press ahead in a much less abstract, more down-to-earth style.
That will be even more true if France continues to insist, as it did in Madrid, that it is unwilling to spend money to expand NATO and the other major European countries, including Britain and Germany, continue to show some fiscal reluctance as well. It would be political poison for the President if it looked as if the United States was doing things for the Europeans that they should do for themselves but were unwilling to.
Still, Mr. Clinton is in a strong position, should he wish to spend some of his political capital on NATO. Close to two-thirds of the voters approve of his performance, for all his personal troubles and all the investigations, and he need not worry about another election. If ever there was a moment to step up to the bully pulpit, this is one.

HEADLINE: Handy? Surely, But Debit Card Has Risks, Too

BYLINE: By DAVID J. MORROW 

 BODY:
When Meredith Platt ripped open the envelope from Chase Manhattan Bank in March, she expected a simple replacement for her automated teller machine card. But the shiny blue piece of plastic that fell out could be used at more than just the corner cash machine. It was also good for siphoning money from her checking account at more than four million retail outlets nationwide.
"My first thought was, 'Why are they sending me a debit card when I didn't ask for one?' " said Ms. Platt, a research psychologist in Orangeburg, N.Y. "That just didn't seem right." 
 Right or wrong, millions of Americans are getting debit cards -- also known as check cards -- that they did not ask for. And many are carrying them around without realizing they have them. In what some industry analysts are dubbing the Big Switch, 1.3 million debit cards are being issued each month -- largely as replacements for A.T.M.-only cards. And brokerage firms such as Merrill Lynch are offering them as part of their customers' Cash Management Accounts. Banking experts estimate that two-thirds of American households will have one by 2000, up from a little less than one-half today.
Ultimately, the experts predict, the penetration rate will rise to 80 percent, meaning that debit cards will rival the popularity of the ubiquitous credit card. Indeed, debit cards are already easier to get than credit cards and are becoming more so as banks tighten credit card restrictions and raise fees and interest rates to counter a rise in unpaid bills.
Many people are pleased with their debit cards. For one thing, users need not show identification, as they would have to when writing checks. Also, they can use the cards instead of cash, meaning they have to carry less money, and instead of a credit card, on which they would pay a double-digit interest rate.
"I love my debit card," said Toni Simonetti, who works for the General Motors Corporation in New York. "It's better than cash because I can keep track of where I'm spending my money. And when I travel, I no longer have to stock up on traveler's checks or cash."
But debit cards pose perils that consumers usually are unaware of and that banks do not like to discuss: liability for lost or stolen cards. Losses from credit card theft are capped at $50. But with debit cards, the loss limitation quickly climbs to $500 and is unlimited if the theft is not reported for 60 days. Also, people who write checks can always stop payment on them; they lack that option with some debit cards.
"Banks are not disclosing the pitfalls associated with debit cards," said Pam Pressley, a lawyer with the California Public Interest Research Group, a consumer organization based in Los Angeles. "If your card is stolen and money is taken from your account, you're out that money while the bank investigates." Consumer groups are pushing for the rules on debit cards to be changed to match those for credit cards.
Still, Americans are definitely warming to innovation, notching up 1.4 billion transactions totaling $54.5 billion with the new-style debit cards last year, up from 279 million transactions worth $14.2 billion in 1993. Consumers generally use the debit cards for small purchases at grocery, liquor and other stores where they used to spend cash or write checks. For big purchases, most shoppers still use their credit cards.
What is astounding about the proliferation of debit cards is that American consumers rejected them several years ago. Realizing that consumers balked at the word "debit" with its connotation of debt, the banks have quietly renamed them check cards and added the debit feature to automated teller cards.
The potential for profit is enormous. For one thing, when a shopper uses a debit card, the store pays the bank that issued the card a fee -- typically 2 percent of the purchase price, about the same as when a shopper uses a credit card. And banks and the major credit card companies, Visa U.S.A. and Mastercard International, which promote the debit cards, have concluded that the debit cards do not compete with credit cards, so they are not simply shifting revenue.
Better yet for the banks, debit cards save them money. The average debit card transaction costs 29 cents, compared with 65 cents to process a check and 91 cents to cash one with a teller, according to Gemini Consulting in Morristown, N.J.
But consumer groups worry that millions of people are unaware of the debit feature on their A.T.M. cards and the risks it carries. Only slightly more than half of American households that own debit cards regularly use them, according to Payment Systems Inc., a banking consulting firm in Tampa, Fla. That alarms industry consultants, who fear that many consumers pocket their new A.T.M. cards without reading the material that explains the debit card feature.
They miss plenty. Traditional A.T.M. cards could typically be used only at grocery stores and gas stations after consumers punched in their personal identification numbers. The newer versions, like the Visa Check and Mastercard's Master Money, are usually embossed with those companies' logos and are accepted like credit cards.
Most consumer groups think the old-fashioned cards are safer -- thieves have a more difficult time stealing an identification number than a receipt. But banks do not like them as much. Whereas the newer versions generate a 2 percent fee on each purchase -- or 80 cents on the average transaction of $40 -- the older cards generate a scant 14 cents for each transaction.
With debit cards expected to generate $250 million for banks this year, plus the savings on processing costs, it is no wonder banks are promoting the cards. In mid-June, 62.5 million new-style cards were in Americans' wallets, a 146 percent increase in three years.
"Consumers really liked Visa Check once they began to understand it," said Michael Beindorff, an executive vice president for Visa. "The card has developed a broad demographic."
It is lucky it has any demographic at all after its dubious beginning in the late 1980's. But the recent makeover worked so well that many bank customers now ask for a debit card.
But what millions of consumers often fail to grasp is their liability for fraudulent billings. Whereas credit card holders can be charged only $50 for charges by thieves, for debit card users that limit applies only if a card is reported lost or stolen within two business days. Wait more than that, and liability climbs to $500. Neglect to notify the bank of the theft within 60 days after a bank statement is sent, and you could lose everything in your account.
How is this possible? Debit and credit cards are covered under different Federal Reserve regulations, tricky laws that even bankers apparently have trouble following. Mr. Beindorff dismissed arguments that debit cards were not safe, saying that "people didn't have the real facts." He then misquoted the Federal Reserve regulation that applies to debit cards, stating wrongly that consumers do not face serious liability unless their cards' disappearance goes unreported for several weeks. (A Visa spokesman insists Mr. Beindorff knows the rules.)
Mr. Beindorff should talk to David Small, a 34-year-old grocery clerk in Stockton, Calif. Mr. Small's debit card was stolen from a gym in April, but he did not discover the theft until several days later. Rushing to his Bank of America branch, he canceled the card and closed his checking account.
He then opened a new account and ordered a new debit card. But whoever had stolen his old card continued running up bills. Even though Mr. Small was not liable for them, bills totaling $2,000 were charged against his new account until the bank finished its investigation.
He was flat broke. "I eventually got my money back," Mr. Small said. "But it wasn't easy. While Bank of America was investigating the theft, I was totally out of that money. That was about two weeks. They eventually had to give me $500 so I could live. They gave me another debit card, and I leave it in my house."
The banks dismiss contentions they have been recklessly mailing out debit cards. Banks send out material with each card, clearly explaining it is tied to a checking account, said John Hall, a spokesman for the American Bankers Association. On top of that, consumers who do not want the debit card can exchange it for a plain A.T.M. card.
"The theft protection, though, is different with a debit card," Mr. Hall said. "But the key really is when the customer notices that his card is missing. If someone has their apartment robbed, they're going to report it immediately, and then they would be covered. They wouldn't be if they decided to wait a few weeks while someone is running up charges. The customer has some responsibility."
To get more people to use their new A.T.M. cards as debit cards, banks are introducing incentive programs such as retailer discounts.
Turning a loyal check writer into a debit card user is not going to be easy, however. Not only are consumer groups questioning some of the banks' practices, but banks are also facing resistance from some retailers unhappy with the high fees. In a suit filed in Federal Court in Brooklyn last October, Wal-Mart and the Limited contend that Visa is forcing them to pay a debit card fee that is almost as high as the credit card fee.
And, concerned about consumer confusion and issues of antitrust, the Senate Banking Committee will begin hearings on banks' debit card practices in the fall.
Elizabeth Hitchcock, the communications director at the United States Public Interest Research Group in Washington, said her own brush with debit card fraud convinced her more controls were needed. Somehow, she says, a thief obtained one of her receipts and used it to make a $75 mail-order purchase and to book a hotel room.
"Losing my debit card receipt was an expensive lesson," she said. "The merchant is not on the hook when someone starts stealing money out of my checking account. The person who loses with that is me."

HEADLINE: Danger as a Way of Life

BYLINE: By Sebastian Junger; Sebastian Junger is the author of "The Perfect Storm."

 BODY:
For five years -- before I managed to make a living as a freelance journalist -- I made my money working as a high climber for tree-removal companies. The trees were leaning over people's houses and couldn't simply be felled; they had to be dismantled piece by piece. Two or three days a week I would climb 60- or 70-foot trees, cutting sections off with a chain saw and lowering them on ropes held by workers on the ground.
It was dangerous work, but for manual labor, it was extremely well paid and one of the few things that managed to prop up my self-esteem. Watching the top 20 feet of a pine tree peel off over my head while the chain saw screamed in my hands was a thrill that almost made up for my failure as a writer. For a few moments, at least, I would feel like the most powerful man on earth. 
 Society has a great use for young men who feel invincible. It throws them at projects that are so brutal or dangerous that no one in his right mind would go near them, much less relish them. In exchange for that feeling of strength, young men go to war, go to sea, build skyscrapers, parachute into forest fires.
One day I was up in an utterly forgettable elm tree when a hurried move with the chain saw opened up the back of my leg. I could see the Achilles tendon, white and rubbery, imbedded in a substance that was the inside of my leg. It didn't particularly hurt and it didn't bleed very much. But it took a month to heal, and, facing my 30th birthday and the revelation that I could actually get hurt or killed doing certain things, I started to reassess my life.
I decided to make it as a writer or to get out of the freelance trap entirely. No more of this in-between stuff, facilitated by the easy money I was making in the treetops.
So instead of doing the dangerous jobs myself, I researched smoke jumpers, loggers, war correspondents and commercial fishermen. The people who did these jobs seemed to divide neatly into two categories.
The first, in which I included myself, were mainly college-educated men and women who wanted to experience the world as broadly as possible. For them, fishing in Alaska or fighting forest fires in Montana was an interesting adventure. Eventually, they moved on to the kinds of careers that -- if I may say this -- their parents probably envisioned for them.
As the poet Michael Klein observed, "risk is extra life," and that wonderfully simple formula describes these people perfectly. Their decision to do dangerous work was evidence, in a way, of the vast array of choices they had available to them after college.
The other category of people -- almost exclusively men -- were in dangerous work for the opposite reason: They had almost no choices at all. The Oregon loggers I spoke with, and the fishermen in Gloucester, Mass., often hadn't even finished high school, much less college, and were hanging on for dear life to the only industry they knew. Few relished the beauty of the sea or forest. Most saw precious little romance in their work and wanted to get out of the business before they were killed or maimed.
The country has become fascinated with dangerous sports -- mountain climbing, big-wave surfing, extreme skiing -- and the people who do these things receive an incredible amount of attention, even glory. And some of them should. What is missing, however, is an appreciation for workers doing things that are just as dangerous -- and that actually contribute to society.
Let's face it, we don't, in any kind of basic way, need another solo ocean crossing or another free-diving record. But we do need people who are willing to work on oil rigs, build skyscrapers and run farm machinery -- jobs that kill people with relentless regularity. In Gloucester alone, for example, 10,000 men have been lost at sea since the town was founded. Has any other American town taken those kinds of losses?
 Not only are these jobs dangerous, many of them are dying out as well. Two of the country's most hazardous occupations -- logging and fishing -- are so fraught with problems that many families can't even support themselves anymore. One fisherman I know -- whose ancestors settled in Gloucester in the 1600's -- refused to let his children set foot on any fishing boat because he was afraid they'd fall in love with it. He wasn't worried that they might die at sea; he was worried that they might never get the chance to die at sea.
For many people, in other words, risk doesn't mean extra life -- it means hardship, unemployment and even the possibility of early death. And the rest of us, parachuting from airplanes, climbing up rock faces, skiing down mountain walls, would do well to keep our accomplishments in perspective.

HEADLINE: I Told You So

BYLINE: By David E. Bonior; David E. Bonior, a Michigan Democrat, is the House minority whip.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
On Friday, the Clinton Administration released a report on the first three years of the North American Free Trade Agreement. The most the Administration could bring itself to say is that Nafta has had a "modest positive effect" on the American economy. That's a far cry from the extravagant promises made by the accord's proponents during the 1993 debate: "Hundreds of thousands of new jobs! Higher wages! A cleaner environment! Just you wait and see!"
They were wrong. The facts are in. 
 Three hundred thousand new jobs? No. The report, required by Congress, suggests that Nafta-related exports have created 90,000 to 160,000 new jobs. But those figures don't account for the 132,000 Americans who have lost their jobs as a result of the agreement. That's the number of Nafta-related job losses certified under the Labor Department's Nafta Trade Adjustment Assistance Program, set up to help displaced American workers.
Higher wages? No. Mexican wages along the border have dropped from $1 to 70 cents an hour, according to International Monetary Fund figures. A 1996 Cornell University study commissioned by the Labor Department found that 62 percent of U.S. companies surveyed have used the threat of moving to Mexico to hold down wages here at home.
Environmental cleanup? No. Toxic sites along the border have continued to multiply. To date, only 1 percent of the $2 billion in cleanup funds promised under Nafta have been spent.
The Administration's report ignores these facts, trying to put the best face on an agreement that clearly hasn't delivered on its promises.
It is true that trade has risen between the United States and Mexico in the last three years, but it has been lopsided. Imports from Mexico have surged by 83 percent since 1993. What was a $2 billion trade surplus with Mexico before Nafta became a record $16 billion deficit last year.
Even the Nafta-generated exports are costing us jobs. More and more, multinationals are shipping components to Mexico, so they can be assembled by low-wage workers, then sent right back as finished products to the United States. According to an analysis by the University of California economist Harley Shaiken, these revolving-door exports have more than doubled, from $18 billion in 1993 to $42 billion last year.
So who does benefit from Nafta? Some of the big winners are the 28 core members of USA-Nafta, an industry group that lobbied for the agreement. Forty-two percent of these multinationals shipped jobs abroad once Nafta was adopted, an analysis of the Labor Department's trade adjustment assistance data shows. Their profits have increased by 296 percent, according to financial information published in Forbes.
Nafta's toll cannot be measured only in economic terms. The Administration's report also ignores real threats to our health and safety.
Imports of Mexican fruit have increased 45 percent since Nafta was enacted, and vegetable imports have gone up by 31 percent, the Florida Department of Agriculture and Consumer Services reported this year.
This produce rolls into the United States on 3.3 million trucks a year. Fewer than 1 percent of these trucks are inspected at the border, according to a May 1997 study by the General Accounting Office. That means parasites, pesticides and infectious diseases go undetected.
For example, the Environmental Working Group found that 18.4 percent of imported Mexican strawberries contain "very high rates of illegal pesticides."
Earlier this year in Michigan, 179 children became seriously ill after eating contaminated Mexican strawberries. Shouldn't such incidents argue for stiffer inspections of imported produce? Unbelievably, under Nafta, such inspections could be considered an unfair trade restriction.
This appalling lack of inspections is also encouraging the drug trade. The Drug Enforcement Agency says that 70 percent of the cocaine that enters the United States now comes across the U.S.-Mexican border.
Nafta has not delivered on its promises. Let's not repeat the errors of the past. Instead of rushing to expand it and putting other countries on the "fast track," let's concentrate on fixing Nafta first.

HEADLINE: Athletes Are the Victims In These Sneaker Wars

BYLINE: By ROBERT LIPSYTE 

 BODY:
Sixteen-year-old Rafael Berumen launched his basketball career in earnest last week, flying from California to New Jersey on booster-club money to audition with 239 other high school players for several hundred college coaches at a recruiting fair sponsored by a shoe company.
"I came to get rated," he said, shrugging at the suggestion that this seemed like a lot of pressure for a high school kid going into his junior year. He held one big hand, palm down, about four feet off the ground. "I'm used to it. People have been looking at me since I'm this high." 
 He is now 6 feet 8 1/2 inches high and a foot soldier in the Sneaker Wars. Berumen had chosen to attend the Adidas-sponsored ABCD camp although he had been invited as well to the rival Nike camp in Indianapolis, also held last week. The camps are kickoff events of the summer basketball season. On Tuesday, Berumen will compete with his Simi Valley High School team, which is outfitted by Adidas, in the Adidas-sponsored 182-team Big Time Amateur Athletic Union tournament in Las Vegas, Nev.
There are many front lines in the Sneaker Wars. Minds and soles are won by Spike Lee commercials for Air Jordans and by "street reps" who hand out shoes to gangsters and by the million-dollar deals of Coach Mike Krzyzewski of Duke and Georgetown's John Thompson. After the Asian sweatshop workers who actually make the shoes, the most exploited figures are the young players like Berumen.
"It's hypocrisy, lunacy," said Sonny Vaccaro, who runs the ABCD camp. While at Nike, he refined and institutionalized the hiring of college coaches to make their players wear a particular brand of shoes, and of using all-star games and summer camps as trade shows. "We get great advertising and the coaches get to see the kids. What do the kids get? A T-shirt. We give them all top-of-the-line tennis shoes to play in, but they have to turn them back afterwards. Amateur rules. We donate the shoes to charity."
Home in Simi Valley, Rafael's mother, Terry Berumen, laughed. "You think there are a lot of charity cases with size 15 feet? You know, I didn't even know it was Adidas, I just knew it was a chance for him. He's very talented, and we want him to get motivation. If we could have afforded it, we would have sent his older brother along. Rafael isn't so streetwise."
But he's courtwise. He averaged about 23 points and 11 rebounds per game as a sophomore last season on a team that won 23 and lost 4. His coach, Dean Bradshaw, says he has "soft hands" and is definitely Division I material. Syracuse, Georgetown and U.C.L.A. have expressed interest.
More schools may get interested if the coaches who crowded into the three-court circus of the Hackensack, N.J., gym of Fairleigh Dickinson University last week liked what they saw of Rafael. Follow-up is easy. For $75, each recruiter bought a book containing the vital playing statistics of each athlete -- most were going into their senior years -- as well as their home addresses and phone numbers, and the names and phone numbers of their schools and their coaches.
For the athletes, the meat-market atmosphere was only an extreme extension of their playing lives. Julian Dunkley, who was discovered at this camp by Temple coaches, was back last week as a counselor, playing in morning games that were covered by pro scouts and coaches.
"This jump-starts your summer," he said. "You get confidence in your game. The high school players get morning classes on how to take the S.A.T. exams, tips like that. Very helpful. The hotel rooms are really nice, and we're fed well. While I'm here, I'm also looking around. We could use a 7-foot center at Temple."
Last summer, Tracy McGrady, an unknown forward from Mount Zion Christian Academy, a basketball factory in North Carolina, took the camp by storm with play so brilliant that he didn't need the college scholarship that Dunkley got and Berumen wants. McGrady proceeded directly to the National Basketball Association. Not only was he picked in the first round by Toronto, but Vaccaro signed him to a $12 million Adidas deal.
There was no such overnight sensation at last week's camp, although the possibility was a common fantasy. Meanwhile, reality had its own built-in dreams. Berumen's parents -- his father is a security guard in Los Angeles and his mother, recently unemployed, is in school -- spent about $250 for his plane ticket. They were reimbursed by Simi Valley's active athletic booster club. In the convoluted world of "amateur" rules, Adidas "donates" basketball shoes to the club, which then distributes them to the team. Coach Bradshaw says he receives no money from Adidas.
According to the school principal, Dennis Rast, shoe company donations are welcome in this time of cutbacks, but need to be monitored. "You wouldn't want students picking a high school because it gets the most and best uniforms and equipment."
The Berumens picked Simi Valley because they wanted to give Rafael a chance to "improve his academics" in an atmosphere free of drugs and gangs. Through his freshman year they had lived in Pomona, more than an hour away, where blacks and Mexicans frequently fight. When they first visited Simi Valley High, senior citizens on duty at the entrances demanded to know where they were going and why; that immediately sold the school to Mrs. Berumen. Although Simi Valley is predominately white, she says she has felt no prejudice. Now and then, people ask her if Rafael is really Mexican, and what she fed him to make him so tall.
"I tell them rice and beans," she said, laughing. "It's what they think we always eat."
Rafael called home a half-dozen times to report on his progress. He thought he was doing well at camp. His mother was proud.
"But it's not a victory yet," she said, "There are bad influences out on the streets and he's at an age where he is easily impressed. I keep close tabs. I don't let him out at night. Except to play."

SECTION: Section 7; Page 8; Column 1; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1709 words

HEADLINE: Whatever It Is, I'm Against It

BYLINE: By David M. Kennedy; David M. Kennedy teaches history at Stanford University. He is finishing a study of the United States during the Depression and World War II for the "Oxford History of the United States."

 BODY:

 THE COLONEL
 The Life and Legend of Robert R.
 McCormick, Indomitable Editor
 of The Chicago Tribune.
 By Richard Norton Smith.
 Illustrated. 612 pp. Boston:
Houghton Mifflin Co. $35. 
 If men were ships, Robert R McCormick would have been a dreadnought, Six feet four inches tall, with a 52-inch chest, 36-inch arms, an armor-plated ego and a personality as pugnacious as a gun turret, he hugely displaced all ambient elements, physical, social, and political, as he steamed through his four-decade career as editor of The Chicago Tribune. And like the lumbering battle cruisers of the World War I era, it was his destiny to obsolesce badly as the Second World War eventually engulfed even "Chicagoland," McCormick's boosterish term for the Midwestern land island that stretched from Iowa to Ohio and was daily blanketed by a million copies of his ferociously conservative and stridently isolationist newspaper. McCormick, the British Ambassador to the United States reported in 1938, was "stubborn, slow thinking and bellicose." He was also implacably and-British, anti-New Deal and anti-Franklin Roosevelt -- and The Tribune, with the largest readership and the fattest advertising revenue of any standard-sized newspaper in the nation, was, Richard Norton Smith writes, "a megaphone to amplify the publisher's caprices."
 McCormick, in fact, was anti- just about everything, a man defined far more deeply by his loathings than by his loves. As Smith, the director of the Gerald R. Ford Museum and Library and a biographer of Thomas E. Dewey, Herbert Hoover and George Washington, says in one of the many penetrating appraisals of his subject in his candid and colorful biography: "McCormick needed enemies, it seemed, the way most men need friends."
 Irascibility flowed copiously in the McCormick family bloodstream. His paternal great-uncle Cyrus, inventor of the mechanical reaper, had pursued the Pennsylvania Railroad through the law courts for 21 years over a piece of damaged luggage. His legendary maternal grandfather Joseph Medill, the long-time editor and publisher of The Tribune and a confidante of Abraham Lincoln, in his waning days poured into young "Bertie's" ears the maunderings of his senescent mind, which Smith describes as "a magpie's nest of misinformation and prejudices." Medill's daughter Kate, McCormick's mother, a singularly unmaternal woman who bribed her grown children to visit her, was a gratuitously quirt-tongued harridan who once told an interviewer: "I hate the Jews. I hate the British. I hate the French. God damn them all." She thought Woodrow Wilson a "villain" and a "wretch." She dismissed McCormick's first wife as "that old strumpet." Joseph Medill, she lectured her son, had been a "man of stern morality and immovable convictions, and you . . . are neither."
 In that prickly family atmosphere, McCormick grew up to be a reflexive "aginner," a man of epic antagonisms, prodigious crotchets and -- here his mother was wrong -- fixed, taproot convictions impermeable to evidence or reason. He was "at home in his own mind," Smith writes, "and nowhere else."
 None of McCormick's hatreds burned more hotly than his odium for all things foreign; no conviction shone more brightly than his faith in Chicagoland's cultural and political superiority. McCormick's gentleman-diplomat father had served in London, Vienna and St. Petersburg, but all "Bertie" seemed to get out of those parental assignments was a tenacious contempt for all that was not American, or, more precisely, Midwestern. As a pupil in a British boarding school, he slept under a bedcover fashioned from an American flag. At Groton -- then the most Anglophilic of American schools -- he seethed with resentment as the only member of his class born west of the Hudson River (Franklin Roosevelt, his future nemesis, was one class behind him). Yale he found "feminized and Anglicized." By the time he left New Haven in 1903, McCormick had already crystallized the sentiments that eventually hardened into the Tribune's trademark editorial axioms: Britain was a "chalk-cliffed hell" inhabited by "pink-coated, horn-blowing, supercilious bankrupts." The northeastern United States swarmed with the "dodging, obligation-shifting idle rich . . . diluted in their Americanism by other hordes of immigrants." Should the United States need to be defended against an invasion, McCormick later advised, fortifications should be constructed along a line that ran from Albany through Pittsburgh and Atlanta to Houston, then up the spines of the western mountain ranges. Conspicuously outside this defense perimeter was the eastern seaboard
 When his uncle, The Tribune's editor Robert Patterson, committed suicide in 1910, McCormick and his cousin Joseph Patterson assumed control of The Tribune. They blazed their slogan, "The World's Greatest Newspaper," across the front page and set out to make good on the claim. Joseph Patterson eventually left Chicago to run The Daily News in New York, so it was mostly under McCormick's prodding that The Tribune grew into a fabulously profitable and enormously influential newspaper. Circulation quadrupled. The World's Greatest Newspaper bristled with comic strips, advice columns, sensational reportage and column-miles of advertising. It also trumpeted endlessly provocative opinions, handed down with regal arrogance from the editor's aerie on the 24th floor of the Tribune Tower, a flamboyantly Gothic shaft erected in 1925 that Smith calls "the presbytery of Midwestern conservatism." In the 1920's McCormick expanded into the newest medium of mass communication, radio, with a station whose call letters were -- what else? -- WGN.
 From these print and electronic pulpits, McCormick broadcast the conservative gospel according to McCormick. Even Herbert Hoover could not measure up to McCormick's demanding ideological standard. Hoover, he said, was "the greatest state socialist in history." It did not take the New Deal to make a conservative out of McCormick. "Long before the advent of Franklin Roosevelt,"Smith writes, "the man in the tower was warning of an erosion of personal liberties . . . . Here, then, are to be found the roots of a paranoia that sprouted strange blossoms as McCormick and Roosevelt, the patriot ant the pragmatist, fought a duel over the American way of life."
 After a brief flirtation between the two old Grotonians in early 1933, McCormick soon emerged as Roosevelt's most loud-mouthed critic. His detestation of the New Deal was bottomless. McCormick became the largest single contributor to Alfred Landon, Roosevelt's Republican opponent, in the 1936 Presidential election. As the campaign began, The Tribune headlined: "Only 97 days left to save your country!" -- a warning that McCormick ordered Tribune switchboard operators to repeat, with appropriate countdown as election day approached, to every incoming caller. "Mr. Roosevelt is a Communist," McCormick editorialized, an opinion he never saw any reason to qualify.
 The New Deal might have been an abomination, but Roosevelt's intensifying effort to pursue an internationalist foreign policy was anathema. As the world crisis deepened in the late 1930's, and Roosevelt sought ways to put American influence onto the scales on the side of the democracies, McCormick stepped forward as the most outspoken of isolationists. The United States had nothing at stake in the looming European conflict, McCormick thundered. All the proof necessary to that proposition was to be found in the history American involvement in World War I -- in which, not incidentally, McCormick had served, rising to the rank of colonel. The American intervention in Europe in 1917, McCormick believed, had claimed some 50,000 American lives yet had done nothing to redeem the hopelessly rivalrous Europeans. The miserable failure of that great departure from the ancient American principle of isolationism starkly warned against any further dalliance with internationalist policies. Along with cousin Joseph Patterson's Daily News and cousin Cissy Patterson's Washington Times-Herald, McCormick's Tribune formed a major platform for those isolationist preachments. Henry Luce called the cousins the Three Furies of Isolation. Roosevelt called them the McCormick-Patterson Axis.
 It was no accident that when Roosevelt in October 1937 gave his famous "Quarantine Address," the first of his major public speeches designed to wean his countrymen away from their isolationist illusions, he ventured into Chicagoland to beard the lion in his den (and was forced almost immediately to back off). Nor was it accidental that it was The Tribune that leaked the War Department's "Victory Program" plans in 1941, in an effort to undermine political support for military preparation; nor that it was The Tribune that published sensitive details about the Navy's victory at Midway in 1942 -- an episode that triggered an abortive attempt to convict McCormick on espionage charges. Against this background, The Tribune's most notorious journalistic gaffe -- the "Dewey Defeats Truman" headline in 1948 -- seems but one more episode in a long line of instances where McCormick's editorial wishes were father to The Tribune's reportorial position.
 Though for the most part Smith is content to describe rather than analyze, he explores these and many other chapters in McCormick's long career with sensitivity, flair and even a measure of sympathy. Yet even his measured empathy is put to the test in the book's concluding pages. McCormick, he writes, "lived too long," and in the years immediately preceding his death in l955, his "flair for the outrageous bordered on self-parody." Nor does Smith succeed in revealing much about McCormick's crabbed inner life, including his two marriages, both apparently as barren of emotional warmth as they were of children. Readers will be left wondering, too, what to make of the haunting paradox that McCormick, the scourge of all things alien, the most disillusioned of World War I veterans, the paladin of isolation, died at the estate he named for the World War I battle in which he had fought -- Cantigny -- and directed that he should be buried in his World War I uniform.

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS: VOWS;
Suki John and Horacio Cocchi

BYLINE: By LOIS SMITH BRADY

 BODY:
"I DESCRIBE myself as someone who does everything you can do to make a living through dance, except strip," said Suki John, 38, who teaches salsa and ballet at schools, senior-citizen centers and studios in New York City. She also writes about dance and has worked as a choreographer for companies in Spain, Cuba, England, Finland and France. "I am the definition of freelance," she said.
A petite woman who appears to have zero percent body fat, Ms. John is a blur of energy, enthusiasm and plans. She rarely stays in one place for long. "Suki has an incredible will to live fully," said Dr. Vera John Steiner, her mother. 
 Ms. John's best friend, Richard Laermer, added: "I gave Suki a postcard once, a picture of a woman packing, and the line was, 'The minute she puts her suitcases down, she's packing again.' That's Suki. She's not running away. She's just running."
In a rare quiet moment a year ago, Ms. John was sitting in a coffee shop near Lincoln Center when she saw Horacio Cocchi standing in line. Thinking he was seriously handsome, she watched as he paid for his lunch, then looked around for a place to sit.
"I gathered my courage and I went after him," Ms. John recalled. "I said, 'Would you like to sit with me?' It was the best move I ever made."
They talked about everything from Spanish poetry to modern dance. Mr. Cocchi, 39, is a Ph.D. candidate in agricultural economics at the University of Connecticut. He grew up in Uruguay, has lived in France and Italy, loves to cook and looks like a rumpled yet charming professor.
He called Ms. John a week later, but they couldn't get together since she was packing to leave for three months in Santa Fe, N.M., where her mother lives. Ms. John had set up yet another freelance job there -- teaching dance on an Indian reservation.
While in Santa Fe, she often thought about Mr. Cocchi, whom she called "the Coffee Shop Man." "One day, my mom said, 'Why don't you call the Coffee Shop Man?' " Ms. John said. "So I called him and asked for his E-mail address. I was aggressive in this relationship, and he loved it."
From then on, Ms. John and Mr. Cocchi corresponded almost every day via E-mail. "Then he started to call me," she said. "One time, my mother heard his voice on the answering machine and said, 'Wow, the Coffee Shop Man has a really nice voice.' "
Soon after Ms. John returned to New York, she went to visit Mr. Cocchi in Connecticut for a day and ended up staying a week. "She really fell for Horacio," said Mr. Laermer, who manages a Web site on America Online called Natives Guide to New York. "I told her, 'Hold back a little bit.' I've always believed the most important thing in a relationship is mystery. I used to tell Suki all the time, 'I know you love the guy, but it's none of his business.' "
Last Sunday, Ms. John and Mr. Cocchi were married in Accord, N.Y., in the backyard of an 1845 house owned by their friends Eric Stewart and Michael Sheran. The couple exchanged their vows under a weeping willow tree big enough to shade about 140 guests. The branches hung so low that one guest even took out a Swiss Army knife and cut off a few branches so he could see better.
Afterward, everyone ate a potluck meal under a white tent in a field of knee-high grass. Mr. Laermer delivered the first toast and reminisced about how he and the bride used to take long midnight walks through Manhattan, discussing their love lives and wondering if they would ever find the right mates.
"Now, eight years later, the answer is yes," Mr. Laermer concluded. "You will find the person of your dreams if you stick to your guns."

CORRECTION-DATE: July 16, 1997, Wednesday

The Vows column on Sunday about the wedding of Suki John and Horacio Cocchi referred incorrectly to the computer service that carries the Native's Guide to New York, an on-line forum managed by a friend of the bride. It is Compuserve, not America Online.

HEADLINE: Taipei Journal;
Crime Invades a Once-Peaceful Place

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN

DATELINE: TAIPEI, Taiwan

 BODY:
Wu Chihau often watches the good guys bash the bad guys on TV, but when he found himself tied up and blindfolded the other day, he abruptly realized that heroic escapes are not as easy as they seem.
Chihau, 13, was bound and gagged in a simulated kidnapping, one of a growing number of training programs that are flourishing after a surge of sensational crimes in Taiwan this year. 
 "If we faced the real thing, I'd be so scared I wouldn't be able to think of what to do," Chihau said with a wide-eyed look as he recalled the class. "But now, at least I'll have some idea."
Taiwan and the rest of East Asia have been proud of their mix of exploding wealth and low crime rates. Modernization has brought fancy cars, computers and marble floors to many million-dollar homes here, and at the same time crime rates have mostly been at the low levels of an agrarian society.
But lately, in Taiwan at least, rising rates of robbery, assault and murder have trickled into society along with the Italian fashions and Japanese department stores. Taiwan has become a cosmopolitan and mobile society, but also -- by its own standards -- a dangerous one.
Indeed, crime rates are creeping up and in some cases surpassing those in Western countries; the murder rate in Taiwan is 8.5 per 100,000 people, compared with 8.2 in the United States in 1995.
"The perception of the people is right," said Huang Fu-yuan, a criminologist at Central Police University. "Crime is terrible."
"We need to pay the price of modernization," he added. "If we are going to get more materialistic, then there will be more crime."
Over all, crime rates soared 80 percent over the last decade in Taiwan, but public discontent exploded in May after several particularly brutal cases, including the kidnapping and slaying of Pai Hsiao-yen, the 17-year-old daughter of a beloved movie actress.
The girl was on her way to high school when she was abducted. Later that evening, the kidnappers called the mother, Pai Ping-ping, and told her to go to a cemetery, where she found a demand for $5 million, scraps of her daughter's clothes and a section of the girl's pinky finger.
Miss Pai went immediately to the police, and when word of the kidnapping was leaked to the press, the drama unfolded on television and riveted the island. Miss Pai appealed to the public to cooperate with the police, but after a failed attempt to deliver the money, her daughter's body was found in a swamp. No one has been arrested.
"Now, society is very different from when we were small, when we'd play outside until our mother called us in for dinner. There was no fear at all," said Mao Kai-ling, 42, the mother of two teen-agers. "But now because society's changing so fast, we need to learn about these criminal affairs. We need to take responsibility for our own safety and get the tools to deal with it."
The killing of Miss Pai led to demonstrations in which thousands of protesters demanded that Prime Minister Lien Chan resign to take responsibility for what they viewed as a crime wave. And they called for President Lee Teng-hui to apologize for neglecting to safeguard the security of the island's 21 million citizens.
In the end, Taiwan's Interior Minister, Lin Fung-cheng, stepped down, along with the Government's spokesman. But the public concern has hardly abated.
Two other prominent cases remain unsolved, one of them the killing in November of a county head and his entourage of seven people at his official residence near Taipei. Also in November, a woman politician in the main opposition party, the Democratic Progressive Party, was killed, apparently by a taxi driver.
"Along with the development of our economy, people have been calling for democracy and freedom, but their moral thinking has not yet found solid ground," said Chou Wen-keh, a senior police official. "Violent crime is actually dropping, but these three cases give everyone the impression that there's a lot of crime."
In 1996, the number of criminal cases rose 12.5 percent. But in the first five months of this year, violent crime cases have actually dropped slightly, partly because the police began a crackdown on Taiwanese criminal gangs like the Bamboo Union.
In fact, in the years since 1991, only 30 children have been abducted. But the prominent cases have naturally drawn the public's attention.
That was why Shaw Mei-chen sent her daughters to a kidnapping-combat class run by the International Bodyguard and Security Service Association.
"If the kids don't have any inkling of how to handle such a situation and if something really happened, they'd be at a loss," Mrs. Shaw said. "They'd scream and shout."
"We protect her from everything," she said about one of her daughters. "We think of everything for her. She'd definitely get herself killed. So I wanted her to learn about what to do."

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 5; National Desk

LENGTH: 1806 words

HEADLINE: Cattle Barons of Texas Yore Accused of Epic Land Grab

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK

DATELINE: SARITA, Tex., July 9

 BODY:
As a courtroom drama, the legal battle shaping up between more than 800 descendants of Jose Manuel Balli Villarreal and the John G. and Marie Stella Kenedy Memorial Foundation has the makings of an epic, set against the backdrop of the vast and thorny brushland of South Texas. There are ancient family feuds, mysterious reports of yellowed documents found in an attic that could prove to be legal bombshells, claims and counterclaims of fraud and treachery.
In the early 1800's, Mr. Balli was given a land grant by the King of Spain to a large tract in South Texas when it was part of the Spanish empire. The clan descended from Mr. Balli and his wife, Maria Antonia Cavazos de Hinojosa, asserts that the land was ultimately stolen by Mifflin Kenedy, one of Texas's most powerful ranchers, who built a cattle empire across the area and whose own descendants later became fabulously wealthy from both the cattle and the oil and gas on the property. The Ballis are now asking for tens of millions of dollars, maybe much more, in compensation. 
 At its core, the issue turns on an interpretation of history: Were the great Texas ranchers like Mr. Kenedy and Richard King, of the fabled King Ranch, visionary figures who tamed a wasteland with honor and grit, or were they Anglo land grabbers who used trickery and violence to rob Mexicans of their property?
And, as scholars watch with fascination as the case unfolds, many say that the fact that the lawsuit has even advanced in the courts speaks volumes about the changing demographics of the region and the ways in which American history is revised from generation to generation.
"The kind of argument that the Ballis are making is going to get a much better hearing than it would have had 20 or 25 years ago," said Don Carleton, director of the Center for American History at the University of Texas in Austin, and a specialist in Texas history. "Hispanic-Americans in this country have a lot more political power, and this is what happens when you get political power in a democratic society."
In some ways the case can be compared to efforts in recent years by American Indians to gain land or compensation for past injustices, said Lynne Perez, a genealogist and historian in San Antonio who has been hired by the Balli clan to research old land claims.
"Years ago, no Mexican-American family could have gone into court and demanded justice from the white establishment," said Ms. Perez, whose husband is a great-great-great grandson of Mr. Balli and thus a claimant to the fortune. "Times have changed."
In setting the stage for a lawsuit, the more than 800 Balli descendants asked to be legally acknowledged as his heirs. Last month, the case took an important step forward when Judge Manuel Flores of the 49th State District Court in Zapata County, along the Mexican border, declared 586 of them in that role. They joined about 250 other petitioners who had already been declared Balli heirs.
In an unusual response, the Kenedy Foundation, a charitable trust whose assets derived from Mr. Kenedy's fortune, filed a court petition in tiny Sarita -- the county seat of Kenedy County, named for the rancher -- that seeks to have the roughly 370,000 acres at issue legally declared to be owned by the foundation.
The petition, which listed many of the Ballis by name in an effort to have their claim ruled invalid, said that the Kenedys had been "in possession of all of said lands for over 100 years," and noted that the land had been "fenced and enclosed" for all that time. It also argues that even if the land had at one time been taken from the Ballis, it had long since come into the Kenedys' possession under a legal principle known as "adverse possession," a rough equivalent of squatter's rights.
Moreover, suggested Richard Leshin, a Corpus Christi lawyer who represents the foundation, the very principle being invoked by the Ballis could open up a Pandora's box of legal problems across the state.
"The opportunity to attack the legal title system based on assertions about events that occurred centuries ago could cause strong disruption to the ownership of properties throughout the state of Texas," Mr. Leshin said in a recent interview.
Not so, say the Ballis, who contend that they never abandoned the land and who note that various efforts have been made by clan descendants over the years to get land back, including an effort in the 1950's to reclaim much of Padre Island, on the Gulf Coast. The bid was thrown out by a state court.
"Those lands belong to us," said Jose A. Perez, a retired air traffic controller in the Fort Worth area who is president of Los Ballis Restoration L.L.C., a partnership of Balli descendants formed to advance the clan's claims on the land. "They were taken, stolen, whatever, from our forefathers, and it's time we go into court once and for all and get this resolved."
Land claims in South Texas have sparked lawsuits for decades, mainly among Anglo families, and many of them have resulted in financial settlements.
"This region has had so many overlapping legal jurisdictions, from Spain to Mexico to the Republic of Texas, to the period after the United States annexed it, and so on and so on and so on," said Professor Carleton at the University of Texas. "The whole area is really a quagmire as far as land titles are concerned."
With so many hundreds of Ballis involved in the lawsuit, no one in the clan seems to expect to get rich if it is successful. Instead, said Irene Balli-Dumas, a 42-year-old corporate communications manager who lives in California, "I think what's important to us now is that a wrong, so to speak, gets corrected."
About half of the Ballis are in Texas, with the rest spread from Mexico to Michigan and California to Florida. Many of them gather regularly at family reunions.
Of the family's contention that a great historical injustice was done by Mr. Kenedy and other ranchers, she said, "I've been hearing about this my entire life." There is no question that the land owned by Mr. Balli, a Spanish military officer and rancher, and other Hispanic families was swallowed up over the years, primarily by Anglo ranchers, after Texas defeated Mexico and became an independent nation in 1836.
In 1842, Texas military commanders "advised all Mexican nationals to evacuate south of the Rio Grande," writes T. R. Fehrenbach in his book, "Lone Star: A History of Texas and the Texans" (American Legacy Press, 1983). "Many did, abjuring Texas citizenship and abandoning their land, from Juan Seguin of San Antonio to the Balli heirs on Padre Island."
But many did not, and even many of those who had fled in fear came back, arguing that they had never truly renounced their claims.
By 1848, with the United States having annexed Texas and defeated Mexico in yet another war, the Treaty of Guadalupe Hidalgo "confirmed all Mexican land titles in principle but could not guarantee them in practice," Mr. Fehrenbach notes. "A horde of American businessmen, squatters and ex-soldiers arrived," he added, many with various types of claims to the land.
In subsequent years, many of the large ranching families consolidated their holdings, including Mr. Kenedy and Mr. King, for a period. And for decades, the dominant version of Texas history had the two and other ranchers fighting a valiant effort to claim the land and ward off the advances of cattle rustlers, many of whom were Mexican.
But a newer generation of scholars has offered a radically different interpretation of the era. These scholars have suggested that the ranchers essentially used their leverage over law-enforcement agencies, including the Texas Rangers and the court system, to steal land from Mexicans.
"These were very large landholders, the economic elite, and they were so powerful that they often resorted to what I would call illegal means of obtaining land from Tejanos," or Texans of Mexican origin, said Armando C. Alonzo, a history professor at Texas A & M University.
"They could basically get whatever they wanted through using the courts and the sheriffs and extra-legal means, " said Professor Alonzo, who is the author of a book scheduled for publication next year, "Tejano Rancheros and Settlers in the Lower Rio Grande Valley 1734-1900" (University of New Mexico Press).
Whether all this will help the Ballis in court in 1997 is, of course, another question, but several legal experts said that if they could demonstrate continuing efforts to get back the land, they might just have a case -- or a shot at a settlement with the Kenedy Foundation, whose assets in land and other holdings are widely believed to be worth hundreds of millions of dollars. The foundation, created in 1960 after all of Mifflin Kenedy's heirs had died, supports a variety of causes, most associated with the Roman Catholic Church.
Moreover, Eileen McKenzie Fowler, a Houston lawyer who is representing the 586 Balli family members recently certified as heirs, said that one family member had unearthed a stunning set of papers while cleaning out the attic: a 50-year lease that had been signed in 1949 by Sarita Kenedy East, Mifflin Kenedy's granddaughter and then the leading member of the Kenedy family, and by Gustavo Munoz, Mr. Balli's great-great grandson.
In it, Mrs. East purportedly agreed to a cash payment and cattle in return for the grazing rights to Balli land.
"This lease is absolutely a killer for them," Ms. Fowler said of the Kenedy Foundation. "They know they don't have a clear chain of title to this land, because adverse possession can never apply to a lease. You can't have abandoned land that you took the time and trouble to exercise a lease on."
Because the case has not yet reached the trial stage, the reported lease has not even been shared with the Kenedy Foundation, and its lawyer, Mr. Leshin, said he was highly skeptical of its authenticity.
Soon, however, the question will likely be aired in court, as the foundation tries to establish its rightful ownership of the land.
Specifically at issue is a tract known as La Barreta when it was granted to Mr. Balli by the Spanish King. The overall grant to Mr. Balli and some of his relatives involved about two million acres in nine present-day counties; Ms. Fowler and other Balli lawyers have suggested it is only a matter of time before claims may be made on other land.
Just how jurors here might respond to the issue of claims dating back to the early part of the last century remains to be seen, of course, but the filing here insures that the Ballis' claims are at least going to be heard.
Without predicting the outcome of the Balli suit, Professor Alonzo at Texas A & M said, "We've had so much change, social and economic change, their chances are better today than they ever were."
