HEADLINE: The Souffle Of His Success, And Its Fall;
Exiled From His Restaurants, A Culinary Star Ladles Soup

BYLINE: By ERIC ASIMOV

 BODY:
At 23, Johannes Sanzin was a sous-chef at Bouley, the youngest ever at the TriBeCa temple of gastronomy. After leaving Bouley, he had a six-month stint at the equally renowned Le Bernardin, then helped to open Pitchoune, a small French restaurant. Last year, Mr. Sanzin, at 25, opened his own restaurant, Sanzin, in SoHo, where he was praised for such dishes as pan-roasted skate dusted with walnuts in Roquefort sauce. In March, he opened his second restaurant, named 131 Duane Street, in TriBeCa, again to raves for his exhilarating combinations of flavors.
So why does Mr. Sanzin now ladle out soup and work the cash register behind the tiny counter at Souperman, his takeout operation tucked into an alley in the financial district? 
 In the ever-changing New York City restaurant business, where money, ambition and ego may rise in the heat of a kitchen to form a delicate souffle of success, Mr. Sanzin's fall shows how perishable such a recipe can be. Nobody denies that Mr. Sanzin (pronounced sahn-ZEEN), now 26, was given the boot by his partners. Beyond that, the reasons for the breakup seem as irreconcilable as oil and vinegar.
His former partners say that while Mr. Sanzin is an inspired cook, he has an artist's contempt for restaurant economics, an attitude they say was heightened by drinking. But Mr. Sanzin dismisses that characterization, saying his problem was not alcohol but having partners motivated only by profit. Either way, to those in the restaurant business, the story of a young chef achieving acclaim one minute and in exile the next is all too familiar.
Since Mr. Sanzin's first apprenticeship in Munich, where he grew up, he has pointed toward the chef's holy grail, owning his own restaurant. Further training in Paris, then experience in two of New York's best restaurants, won him a reputation as a skilled, strong-willed cook.
In late 1995, he was introduced to two young Frenchmen who were opening Pitchoune at Third Avenue and 19th Street. Mr. Sanzin took charge of the kitchen and quickly earned praise for his beautifully executed, moderately priced dishes. Among those taking note of the young chef was Jim Mamary, who owned three restaurants in Brooklyn but was itching to break into Manhattan.
By chance, Mr. Mamary had dinner at Pitchoune after it had been open a few months and liked what he ate. He liked it so much that he went back four nights in a row. "I thought, this would be a great guy to go into business with," Mr. Mamary said.
As it happened, Mr. Sanzin would soon be looking for a new opportunity. While the owners loved his cooking at Pitchoune, other tasks, like controlling food costs, were causing friction.
"I asked him to leave," said Thierry Cabiego, an owner. "When you start a restaurant, it's your baby. If a guy starts to think he's the main person in the restaurant, he has to go." And, he added, Mr. Sanzin had no regard for the bottom line. "Money was flowing down the drain."
Mr. Sanzin sees it differently. The entree prices were set too low, he said. "They wanted to serve a rack of lamb for $16, and then complained that the food cost was too high," he said.
For Mr. Mamary, the timing was perfect. He and Mr. Sanzin agreed to become partners. They found a site in SoHo and named the restaurant Sanzin.
More seasoned restaurateurs might have sensed danger. Drew Nieporent, who counts Montrachet, Nobu and TriBeCa Grill among his holdings, discussed naming Montrachet with David Bouley, the first chef there. "If we name it Bouley or we name it Drew, you can never use those names again," Mr. Nieporent said.
While Mr. Mamary and Mr. Sanzin were to be the operating partners in the new venture, they would not, at first, be owners. In the restaurant business, upfront costs for real estate and construction can be immense. They needed financial backers.
Mr. Mamary lined up investors, who offered a typical arrangement. They would make the initial investment, and the two operating partners would get a percentage of the ownership, but not until the initial investment was paid back.
Mr. Sanzin was responsible for the food, wine and kitchen staff, and Mr. Mamary was responsible for everything else. "I didn't see a menu until the day we opened," Mr. Mamary said.
That day was June 12, 1996, just six weeks after signing the lease. At first, Mr. Sanzin's inventive cooking attracted little attention. "I thought I might have to go back to the investors and ask for an infusion to get us through," Mr. Mamary said, "because Johannes only uses the best."
Instead, the infusion came from another source, a glowing two-star review in The New York Times. Ruth Reichl likened Mr. Sanzin to Primo, the brilliant, uncompromising chef in the movie "Big Night."
"Business literally tripled," Mr. Mamary said.
The stories diverge here, though both Mr. Mamary and Mr. Sanzin agree on one thing: It was a nightmare.
According to Mr. Mamary, Mr. Sanzin took some time off shortly after the review was published. He had been working six nights a week and deserved a vacation, Mr. Mamary conceded. Meanwhile, Alex Oefeli, the sous-chef, also from Pitchoune, held the fort.
The problem, Mr. Mamary said, was that Mr. Sanzin never returned. October melted into November. Thanksgiving passed, he said, and Mr. Sanzin still was not cooking. "He'd come in, have a couple glasses of wine and we'd talk," Mr. Mamary said. "I figured he'd know when to come back. It was chronic absenteeism."
To Mr. Nieporent, this was a critical mistake, "When you're given such an accolade, now's the time to put your heads down and earn it."
The Times review said that Sanzin's dining room was uncomfortable, and Mr. Mamary thought a different setting might reinspire Mr. Sanzin. "I started looking again," he said. "I thought, maybe he's bored, maybe he needs a new thing."
But Mr. Sanzin says a second restaurant was his idea. "Sanzin was a very small kitchen," he said. "To be really creative, there was just no way."
Mr. Mamary found a bigger place, at 131 Duane Street near West Broadway in TriBeCa. He said he gave Mr. Sanzin everything he wanted: "Fancy stuff from France, copper pots, a $5,000 convection oven; this was going to be his signature place."
They timed the opening of the new place, called 131 Duane Street, for March, hoping to gain momentum from a review of Sanzin that was to appear in the March issue of Gourmet magazine.
Dan Iserra, who had become a friend of Mr. Sanzin when both worked at Bouley, signed on to assist in the kitchen. But Mr. Iserra, 33, sensed that something was wrong.
"He was talking to so many people, trying to do so many things," he said. "He was going to consult, he wanted to open a nightclub lounge. He had a wife and kid, and he had OD'ed on the American dream."
Mr. Iserra left after one night.
The Gourmet review of Sanzin called Mr. Sanzin "a new German-born star." The irony, Mr. Mamary said, was that Mr. Sanzin was not in the kitchen when the critic visited. Mr. Oefeli, the sous-chef, was.
"A lot of respect I used to have for Johannes dissolved," said Mr. Oefeli, 24, of his mentor. "Johannes was here, but he wasn't cooking. In his mind, he was working, but he wasn't doing anything except being at the bar."
Mr. Sanzin disagrees vehemently. "I was active cooking in both restaurants," he said. "They have to say negative stuff about me, otherwise why would they get rid of me? I like a good glass of wine, but I'm not a drunk."
Meanwhile, at 131 Duane, things were not going smoothly. Mr. Mamary asserted that Mr. Sanzin was hardly in the kitchen and often drank, which Mr. Sanzin denied. In any case, a Times review of 131 Duane awarded the restaurant two stars and again praised Mr. Sanzin as an uncommonly interesting, "supremely confident" cook.
"He got two stars, and he wasn't even trying!" Mr. Mamary wailed. From there, things degenerated. Orders in the dining room were not being filled, Mr. Mamary said. People were left waiting, the staff left directionless. Mr. Mamary said he believed Mr. Sanzin was sabotaging the restaurant. "He spent and did whatever he wanted to do in pursuit of his culinary career," he said.
In June, he told the investors that Mr. Sanzin had to go.
Mr. Iserra said what galls him is that, at 25, Mr. Sanzin had an opportunity with his restaurants that other people wait years to get. "It was his own thickheadedness that did him in," he said.
Mr. Sanzin said he believed his former associates were just waiting to get rid of him. He said they feared he would succeed with his soup business, which had been in the works for months, and leave them in the lurch, so they wanted to jettison him first.
"It was four against one," he said. "Each time something came up, it was me. For me, it is more important to please the customer than it is to make a huge amount of money."
To Mr. Sanzin, the reviews speak louder than the criticism.
"I created the restaurants," he said. "It's me who made the food. I worked 18 hours a day, six days a week. I worked for it: It wasn't an opportunity just presented to me on a silver tray."
Mr. Sanzin resents the fact that his ex-partners retain the name Sanzin. "Just give it another name," he said.
Mr. Mamary says the name is tied to the success of the restaurant, where Mr. Oefeli is now the chef. "In reality, nothing has changed," he said. "He's still not here."
Many in the restaurant business see Mr. Sanzin's fall as a cautionary tale about too much acclaim, too many restaurants, too soon.
Jonathan Waxman, who owned Jam's, Bud's and Hulot's in the go-go 1980's, sympathizes with any chef celebrated at a tender age.
"You have no personal life," he said. "I think most chefs are pretty shy. Once they're put in the limelight, it's very tough. Your partners expect more from you, your public expects more from you. Your every move is scrutinized."
For his part, Mr. Sanzin said he is proud of Souperman, at 77 Pearl Street and Coenties Alley, where the lunch line for his soups extends out of the building. "Now I get up at 3 in the morning to make my soups, to make sure they're ready at noon, and they're good," he said.
He says he enjoys his relationship with his Souperman partners, two French restaurateurs, and would definitely like to open a new restaurant.
What has he learned?
"It's a tough business," Mr. Sanzin said. "But if things go apart, it's an ugly business."

HEADLINE: Orders Increase 8% For Machine Tools

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Orders for machine tools by American companies rose 8 percent in May, compared with a year earlier, further evidence of steady expansion in manufacturing, according to two trade groups.
The rise came despite an unexpected falloff in orders in the Midwest, home to the Big Three auto makers and other large manufacturers. Because of that drop, orders in May were lower than in April, even though they were higher than the level of May 1996. 
 "The Midwest experienced a needed breather in May machine tool orders, but compared to a year ago the national picture is still strong," said Ralph J. Nappi, president of the American Machine Tool Distributors' Association, which compiles the report along with the Association for Manufacturing Technology.
Total domestic orders were estimated at $678 million, up from $627 million in May 1996. For the first five months of this year, orders rose 10 percent, to $3.47 billion.
Machine tool orders are used to gauge manufacturers' long-term confidence in the economy. A rise in orders suggests that companies expect enough future business to justify expanding or upgrading their factories.
The two trade groups obtain data from about 70 percent of the nation's machine tool makers to derive their estimates. They do not disclose which companies are increasing orders.
In the Midwest, orders fell 10 percent, to $184 million among companies surveyed. The strongest region was the Far West, which increased spending 69 percent, to $69 million.
Orders rose 24.5 percent in the South, to $67 million; 19 percent in the Northeast, to $80 million, and 5 percent in the region between the Mississippi and the Rockies, to $94 million.
Export data in the report showed that foreign demand for United States machine tools rose 15 percent from a year earlier, to $103 million. For the first five months of 1997, export orders totaled $371 million, up 69 percent.

HEADLINE: PIONEERING STATE FOR MANAGED CARE CONSIDERS CHANGE

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
Leading a national surge of second thoughts about managed health care, California, long a pacesetter in the field, has plunged into a wholesale review of its managed-care system, which now covers more than half the state's 32 million people.
An avalanche of proposals for tighter government regulation is advancing in the California Legislature. The Governor and legislators have appointed a joint commission to recommend improvements in managed care. And patients are expressing their qualms: State officials registered more than 2,000 consumer complaints about health maintenance organizations last year, an 18 percent increase over 1995. 
 The growing skepticism about managed care, which reduces health care costs by rejecting treatment that is deemed not medically necessary, is fueled by cases like those of Joyce Ramey, a 69-year-old retired nurse in Riverside, who was awarded $1.1 million last week in a binding arbitration with her Medicare H.M.O.
Mrs. Ramey, who has required kidney dialysis treatments twice a week since April 1995, said her health plan had for two years ignored or rejected her primary doctor's requests to send her to an H.M.O.-approved kidney specialist. The arbitrator, John K. Trotter, a retired California appeals judge, said in his ruling that the H.M.O.'s conduct was "unconscionable."
The health maintenance organization, Inter Valley Health Plan Inc. of Pomona, is considering an appeal on the ground that "the medical facts of the case don't support the decision," said Mark Covington, the company's president.
Defenders of managed care say that California -- and the nation, as well -- is legislating by anecdote, exaggerating the importance of cases like Mrs. Ramey's. They say that the benefits to the public of managed care -- lower health care costs foremost among them -- are being obscured in a haze of story telling. And insurers can point to surveys showing high levels of patient satisfaction with their health plans.
But consumer groups, doctors and spokesmen for the elderly say they are countering the excesses of the managed-care avalanche, which in the last decade has brought at least 150 million Americans under some sort of plan that reviews or restricts health care choices. Most of the legislation these groups are backing would make it more difficult for health maintenance organizations to deny care. Several bills would also weaken their sway over doctors.
Across the country, state legislators have introduced about 1,000 managed-care bills so far this year. At least 182 bills have become law, following the adoption of 100 such laws in 1996, according to the National Conference of State Legislatures.
Recently adopted laws require H.M.O.'s in a number of states to authorize hospital stays after mastectomies and to pay for emergency room visits that turn out to have been avoidable. Health plans are being ordered to allow direct access to obstetricians and certain other specialists without permission in advance from a primary doctor.
So far this year, 16 states -- including Connecticut, Florida, Minnesota, Ohio and Texas -- have adopted comprehensive consumer-rights bills covering a number of managed-care issues; New York and five more states enacted similar bills last year. In June, the New Jersey Legislature approved and sent to Gov. Christine Todd Whitman a bill that would establish an independent appeals process for H.M.O. members, forbid financial rewards to doctors for denying care and require managed-care companies to subsidize care by doctors outside their networks.
In May, Texas attracted national attention by enacting the first law allowing medical malpractice lawsuits against H.M.O.'s. Similar bills have been introduced in Congress.
Managed-care companies have always insisted that they do not make medical decisions, and insurers lobbied hard against the Texas measure. In June, Aetna Inc. filed a lawsuit in United States District Court in Houston seeking to invalidate it under the Employee Retirement Income Security Act, or Erisa. Erisa has often been invoked to thwart state regulation of health insurance, but recently there have been conflicting court decisions about its reach.
California, though, is the cockpit for some of the most hotly contested battles. The State Senate has scheduled hearings this week on 50 health care bills already passed by the Assembly. The Assembly health committee, meanwhile, will take up 30 measures approved by the Senate.
A coalition that includes labor unions, the American Association of Retired Persons, Consumers Union and Health Access California, an umbrella advocacy group, is promoting an 11-point legislative package it calls a "patient bill of rights." Recently, dozens of supporters of the package came to the Capitol in Sacramento to lobby and demonstrate.
One of the measures would make H.M.O.'s and the physicians who are their medical directors liable in malpractice lawsuits involving denials of care judged by the H.M.O.'s not to have been a "medical necessity."
Other bills backed by the California coalition would give protection against reprisals to patients, doctors and health care workers who complained about managed-care misconduct. Health maintenance organizations would also have to state reasons and give advance notice before dismissing doctors, nurses, therapists or medical technicians.
The H.M.O. industry and the California Chamber of Commerce are lobbying vigorously against five bills in the Health Access package, as well as a number of other proposals. Allan Zaremberg, executive vice president of the chamber, said the measures were "job-killer legislation" that would raise medical costs, especially for small employers, and add to California's 6.5 million uninsured.
Myra Snyder, president of the California Association of Health Plans, a trade group, agreed. "Everything they add to a benefit package, no matter how worthy, will increase the cost," she said. "No one is looking at the big picture, at what happens to the monthly premiums and to the numbers of uninsured."
However, the business representatives said that they would not oppose popular bills that would make it difficult for managed-care companies to send women home without a hospital stay after a mastectomy, or within 48 hours of giving birth.
Self-interest is evident on all sides of the debate. The California Medical Association is backing a measure to make it harder for H.M.O.'s to drop physicians from their networks. It also supports a bill that would require the companies to disclose the "actuarial criteria" on which they base capitation payments to doctors -- the set monthly amounts paid for each enrolled member.
Some doctors complain that H.M.O.'s cut these rates arbitrarily, forcing them to skimp on care or absorb financial losses.
Dr. Melvin Kirschner, a family practitioner in Van Nuys, a suburban area of Los Angeles, said that one managed-care group with which he is affiliated had reduced its monthly payment per patient by 30 percent in May. "I can't make a living," he said.
Ms. Snyder of the health plans association said capitation rates remained "appropriate," and remarked that H.M.O.'s perform actuarial studies "to negotiate with physicians, not to help them to negotiate with us."
Alain Enthoven, a Stanford University management professor who is a longstanding advocate of managed care, said the backlash in California against H.M.O.'s had been encouraged by a sharp rise in enrollment, to 14 million last year, with 3 million more Californians in related types of managed care.
"It has been worsened by the fact that a lot of the media are dealing with it quite irresponsibly," asserted Mr. Enthoven, chairman of the state's Managed Health Care Improvement Task Force, which is scheduled to report to Gov. Pete Wilson on Jan. 1. "They take one episode and blow that up into a huge story."
He mentioned widespread coverage of the refusal by Healthnet, a big California H.M.O., to pay for a cancer patient's bone-marrow transplant. The company said that the procedure was experimental.
"It was unfair to attack Healthnet," Mr. Enthoven said. "All health insurance has exclusions for experimental treatment."
In the wake of the publicity, a law was passed giving patients the right to an independent medical review when a health plan rejects a treatment as experimental.
He acknowledged that managed- care consumers need protection from corporate excesses. "This has to be the most complicated product or service in our economy," he said. "A health insurance contract is extremely complex. Anybody who says they understand their health insurance doesn't understand the problem."
Steven Thompson, vice president of the California Medical Association, said that changing managed care had lately become a bipartisan issue, because more and more people in "the middle and upper middle class" were experiencing H.M.O.'s firsthand.
Jeanne Finberg, a lawyer with Consumers Union in San Francisco, said she was worried that Governor Wilson, a Republican who is generally opposed to regulation, might reject most of the managed-care legislation.
"I worry that the task force will be used as an excuse for delay," she said. But Mr. Enthoven said that would not happen. The Governor's office, he said, had pledged that each bill would be considered "on its merits."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Joyce Ramey, 69, a retired nurse in Riverside, Calif., was awarded $1.1 million in arbitration. She said her health plan ignored or rejected her doctor's requests to send her to an H.M.O.-approved kidney specialist. (Ed Carreon for The New York Times)(pg. D8)
 
Protecting Patients
A few years ago, the main focus of state legislation to rein in health maintenance organizations was on protection for doctors and other providers. This year, many states have passed or are considering bills to protect patients.
 
Map shows states where comprehensive consumer rights bills have been enacted or are pending. Specific provisions vary from state to state, but most of the bills require grievance procedures for patient complaints; ban "gag clauses that limit what doctors tell patients; require payment for emergency-room visits even if, in hindsight, they might have been avoided; limit financial incentives for doctors to deny treatment; and require direct access to certain specialists, like obstetricians, without going through a primary care doctor.
 
Similar legislation was passed in New Mexico this year but was vetoed by the Governor. Some states primarily use regulations rather than laws to govern health care; some of these have written aspects of comprehensive consumer protection bills into their regulations.
 
(Source: National Conference of State Legislatures Health Policy Tracking Service)(pg. D8)

HEADLINE: Sale of Institutional Investor By Disney Is Expected Soon

BYLINE: By PETER TRUELL

 BODY:
The Walt Disney Company, continuing with its sale of assets outside its core entertainment business, is expected soon to reach an agreement to sell Institutional Investor publications to Euromoney Publications P.L.C. for $120 million to $130 million, according to executives familiar with the negotiations.
Other potential suitors, including the Thomson financial publishing group and Pearson P.L.C. of Britain, have shown strong interest in buying Institutional Investor, according to these people, who spoke on condition of anonymity, but those companies have recently dropped out of the discussions. The Economist and McGraw-Hill also looked at the company's books, they said. 
 In the world of glossy trade magazines and specialist newsletters that chronicle high finance, the acquisition of Institutional Investor by Euromoney would be rather like Newsweek buying Time. Institutional Investor, based in New York, and Euromoney, which has its head office in London, have competed for years for the reading time and desk space of financiers and investors. Euromoney is 63-percent-owned by Daily Mail and General Trust P.L.C., publishers of The Daily Mail of Britain.
Institutional Investor has a circulation of about 150,000, some of which is free, with two-thirds in the United States. It has outpaced Euromoney in the American market and has for years been on Wall Street's preferred reading list. Its annual survey of analysts, with rankings, can help make or break a securities analyst, and a top ranking generally adds many hundreds of thousands of dollars to an analyst's annual bonus.
There is concern at Institutional Investor that Euromoney might seek to influence its editorial content. Discussing whether a takeover by Euromoney could work, someone inside the company said that "the company's franchise is based on the editorial integrity and independence."
"If any effort were to be made to compromise that independence and integrity, that would put the whole franchise at risk," this person said.
During the last few months, Disney's advisers have been sounding out potential bidders about Institutional Investor. "Most of the bids were around $130 million," said an executive at Institutional Investor, who spoke on condition of anonymity. He added that the eventual price would probably be less than that, most likely around $120 million.
"There have definitely been negotiations" between Euromoney and Institutional Investor, another person familiar with the matter said, adding that the price was expected to be lower than the original asking price of $170 million to $200 million.
Euromoney, if it acquires Institutional Investor, is expected to use it to build its American magazine business, an area where it has been relatively weak. But Euromoney is also expected to try to prune costs and perhaps close Institutional Investor's international edition.
Officials of Euromoney and Institutional Investor were unwilling to provide much detail on their talks on Friday. "We had some discussions and there is nothing new to report," P. Richard Ensor, a managing director of Euromoney Publications, said in a telephone interview from London. The discussions, he added, "are sporadic and continuing." Ken Green, a spokesman for Disney in Burbank, Calif., dismissed questions about the talks, saying, "We never discuss discussions in progress."
After its $19 billion acquisition of Capital Cities/ABC last year, Disney said it would sell companies from the deal that were not related to its core entertainment business, and it appointed the investment bank CS First Boston to advise it on those sales, which could realize as much as $2 billion to $3 billion, according to Wall Street estimates.
In April, Disney sold the Chilton group of magazines to Reed Elsevier P.L.C., the British-Dutch business publishing company, for $447 million in cash. That month, Disney also sold four newspapers -- The Kansas City Star, The Fort Worth Star-Telegram, The Belleville News-Democrat in Illinois and The Wilkes-Barre Times Leader in Pennsylvania -- to Knight-Ridder for $1.65 billion.
A deal for Institutional Investor would include its newsletters and its conference business.
Other potential bidders for Institutional Investor dropped out of the negotations because of price, the executives familiar with the talks said. Ron Schlosser, president of the Thomson financial publishing group, did not return telephone messages left with his office on Friday. An assistant at the London office of Marjorie M. Scardino, chief executive of Pearson, said late Friday that Ms. Scardino had left for the day and could not be reached.
Institutional Investor, which was founded by Gilbert E. Kaplan in 1967, was sold to Capital Cities in 1984 for an amount that was widely rumored to be around $72 million. Mr. Kaplan left the company some years ago to pursue his interest in music.

HEADLINE: THE FALL OF NEWARK -- A special report.;
In Riots' Shadow, a City Stumbles On

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS; Ronald Smothers covered the Newark riots 30 years ago as a reporter for The Washington Post. He lives in Newark.

DATELINE: NEWARK, July 12

 BODY:
Amiri Baraka, the poet and writer whose advocacy of "black power" is inextricably linked to the riots that tore through this city 30 years ago, was sitting on the porch of his Victorian style house in west-central Newark the other day, pointing to his neighbors' well-kept homes.
The neighbors -- a mailman, a schoolteacher, a college professor -- were determined, he said, "to stay here and scratch it out." But, he went on, "If you go two blocks in either direction from here you are in some of the worst slums imaginable." 
 Mr. Baraka's porch is as good a vantage point as any from which to view Newark's situation now. Much as his neighborhood of neat blocks of single-family homes represents a gleam of hope amid wider devastation and poverty, there are other pockets of progress in the city, from a huge new $200 million performing arts center to hundreds of middle-class town houses to construction at the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey and the New Jersey Institute of Technology.
Yet all the millions of dollars in national and state aid that have flowed into the city since the riots in 1967, all the corporate assistance, both in dollars and sense, all the jobs and education and housing programs, have failed to change this fundamental fact about Newark: It is a city in the clutches of poverty, a city sliding ever downward, one that many say is in worse shape now than it was on July 12, 1967, the night the riots began.
The riots were less a turning point than a "historical inevitability," said Mr. Baraka, who was then known as LeRoi Jones and who was charged but later acquitted of weapons possession and inciting to riot.
Even before 1967, Newark -- like many other troubled cities, particularly in the industrial Northeast -- was gripped by economic forces that were squeezing its tax base, shuttering its factories and drawing its middle class to the suburbs.
The city remains a transportation hub. Train and bus lines still run through Newark. Its airport has become a major force in the region, as has its port. Newark also has the advantage of being near New York City. But many of the warehouses and trucking companies that once thrived in the city's 24 square miles have shifted out of its narrow, crowded streets to spacious suburban tracts made more accessible by new highways.
From 1960 to 1967, more than 60,000 white residents moved out of the city's aging and heavily taxed one- , two- and three-family frame homes for newer dwellings in the suburbs, much as the white middle class was abandoning other big cities in the country.
At the same time, black people from the South and Hispanic people were moving in, on the familiar currents of hope that had carried generations of immigrants years before. Only now there were far fewer jobs to greet them.
But even as the population was changing in 1967, political power in the city -- in the mayor's office, the City Council, the Police Department and school system -- remained in the hands of white people, many of them corrupt and racist.
The conditions in Newark were a warning of the "clear and present danger to the very existence of our cities," according to a 1968 study of the riots and the city's plight commissioned by Gov. Richard J. Hughes of New Jersey.
In a statement that prefigured the findings by President Lyndon B. Johnson's National Advisory Commission on Civil Disorders, popularly known as the Kerner Commission, the state study said: "If the events of last July had one effect, it was to show that we can no longer escape the central issue. The central issue with which this nation has temporized for the past 100 years -- to make equality real for the black man -- was bound sooner or later to land on the doorstep of each of us."
The riots did lead to some significant changes. In 1970, the city elected its first black Mayor, Kenneth J. Gibson. And national and state assistance began to pour in.
But these changes failed to reverse Newark's decline. The city remains New Jersey's largest, but it has shrunk substantially in the last 45 years. From 1950 to 1967, its population fell to about 406,000 from 438,776, and in 1994, the latest year for which figures are available, it was about 259,000.
Mr. Gibson, who now runs a business consulting company, noted in a recent interview that his early successes in getting national and state grants, as well as in building "a kinship" within the city, worked to arrest the city's problems only for a time. In the end, abandonment of housing continued, along with the departure of businesses to the suburbs. Eventually, black middle-class families joined this exodus.
And many people in the city now say that the black political establishment, in place by the mid-1970's, grew to be as ineffectual, and perhaps as corrupt, as the white administrations it supplanted.
Mageline Little, a retired school librarian who at the time of the riots was among the few middle-class black residents in the mostly white Weequahic Park area, recalled noticing within two years of the riots that many of her white neighbors had moved away. She and other black homeowners hung on, clinging to the hope that the election of black mayors would bring more services, lower taxes and more police protection.
"I think it was the third burglary in a month and no one from the Police Department showing up that did it for me," she said, explaining why she decided in 1990 to move to the nearby suburb of Maplewood. "I was tired, and it was like the black elected officials had forgotten us. Somehow they got selfish and failed to encourage us."
Sharpe James, the current Mayor, who won a City Council seat in 1970 when Mr. Gibson was elected Mayor, conceded that he and others had thought "we could wave a magic wand and overnight things would change." But, he went on, "the tragedy was that we didn't have the skills, knowledge and vision to move the city. We had many failed projects."
Mr. James, who has been Mayor since 1986, insisted that he had brought "a new realism" to city government, bringing in professional managers and aggressively pursuing the construction of the performing arts center and a proposed stadium for soccer and minor-league baseball.
Still, he conceded, "The disinvestment continues; the Federal Government is still trying to balance its budget on the backs of the cities; the population continues to decline, and the manufacturing jobs that used to be here are still disappearing."
Mr. James was careful in his comments about today's Newark and its prospects, recalling the heady days after Mr. Gibson took office predicting, "Wherever American cities are going, Newark will get there first."
The reality proved to be the opposite, Mr. James said. "Baltimore with their harbor crossed the line. Seattle was bringing people back from the suburbs, and even Cleveland, which someone once called 'the mistake by the lake,' is now jumping with arts centers and professional sports. And the question was, 'Where's Newark?' "
 
Marginalized Majority
Black Residents Sense Hostility
 In the summer of 1967, Newark had many reasons to be tense. Even though the population was nearly 52 percent black, the city's police force was 90 percent white. There was only one black elected official. And the Mayor, Hugh J. Addonizio, a white Democrat, had an uneasy relationship with black residents, many of whom felt he was interested in them only at election time.
There were many problems, but perhaps the one that best illustrates that relationship involved the proposed expansion of what was then the College of Medicine and Dentistry. While publicly professing their desire to remain in Newark, trustees of the college decided in early 1967 to move to Madison, which lies to the west in Morris County.
Their price for staying, according to the Hughes commission's report after the riots, was an offer they thought the city had to refuse -- condemning 150 acres in the middle of Newark.
The Addonizio administration, desperate to keep such a major institution, came up with a gambit of its own. It offered the college 185 acres, just 30 of them in blighted areas the city had already slated for urban renewal. But the deal also included more than 100 acres of relatively stable, racially mixed, working-class neighborhoods.
Richard Cammieri, who was a child at the time and lived in one of the mixed Italian and black areas, recalled the reactions to the plan and the subsequent fight.
"A black family on the block -- he was a postal worker and she was a schoolteacher -- led the neighborhood effort to fight the condemnation, and we were successful for a while," said Mr. Cammieri, who still lives in Newark and drives by his old block, now just vacant land.
This contributed to the tense mood in the city on the night of Wednesday, July 12, when two white police officers, John DeSimone and Vito Pontrelli, arrested John W. Smith, a black cabdriver, for resisting arrest after a minor traffic violation.
Mr. Smith later told investigators that one of the officers had beaten him in the patrol car. He had been doubled over in pain as they arrived at the Fourth Precinct house and was dragged inside, where he was thrown into a cell and beaten some more.
Residents of Hayes Homes, a public housing project across from the station house, saw the police dragging Mr. Smith inside. Word quickly spread, drawing 250 people to the station house, many of whom by that time believed he had been killed.
The first barrage of bottles and Molotov cocktails came from this crowd, although the anger seemed contained that night to the area around the Hayes Homes. But the next night it spread rapidly, as rampaging black residents ripped security gates from businesses along major commercial boulevards in black areas of the Central Ward, looted them and set fires.
City officials met with civil rights leaders, but were unable to stop the violence.
By Friday, the first wave of more than 6,000 National Guard soldiers and state police officers streamed into the city. The patrols often found themselves besieged by youths throwing rocks.
According to the state study of the riots, the presence of the soldiers and state police, while quelling the rioting, hardly proved a total blessing. Investigators attributed some of the 26 deaths in the riots to panicky shooting at apartment buildings by frightened guardsmen. Businesses that displayed signs showing they were black-owned were spared the rioters' wrath, but were later damaged by gunfire from angry white police officers and guardsmen.
About 1,500 Newark residents were arrested over the five days of rioting. And what sticks in the minds of many who lived through that time, including Mayor James, was how all of the black people in the city were treated as if they had broken the law.
 
Hardy Optimism
Good Intentions Survive for a Time
 Even with the political and racial tensions in the city, 1967 was also a time of great optimism. Rebecca Doggett, who was 26 at the time and working with the new Head Start program and a nonprofit housing group, recalled that white groups like the Students for a Democratic Society were working in the city alongside local civil rights groups and the Committee for a Unified Newark, founded by Mr. Baraka.
"Young people were coming out of the woodwork to save the world," she said. "There were black and white churches, nonprofit groups and school activists, and we all saw ourselves as the Northern branch of the Southern civil rights movement."
What was surprising, she said, was that the riots failed to dim that optimism. "In spite of the violence and the real loss suffered by Newark, there were positive and productive things going on."
That mood persisted for a while, as a wave of good intentions seemed to engulf the city. State and Federal agencies began pumping millions into the city to improve the schools, housing and health care. Nonprofit housing programs with hopeful names like Amity Village, New Hope Homes and the New Community Corporation sprung up to build housing and promote home ownership.
But by the early 1980's the hope had faded. Msgr. James Linder, a Roman Catholic priest who founded the New Community Corporation, said that much of what was built was underfinanced, poorly designed or poorly managed. Many of the new high rises fell into disrepair and the homeowner-assistance programs ran out of grant money.
Mrs. Doggett recalled the loss of state support in the 1980's for a homeowner-assistance program she helped develop, Amity Village. Today, the 30 houses in the Central Ward have fallen into disrepair.
"I am concerned because I don't think the city has the same sense of optimism that it had 30 years ago, even in the aftermath of the rioting," she said. "Then, there was much more interaction between the poor in the city and middle class, white and black, the service providers and those served. Now, the poor are just more isolated."
Newark's school system is perhaps in a more dismal state than its housing. A year after the riots, the commission appointed by Governor Hughes found the Newark school system "in an advanced state of decay," either "poorly educating or miseducating children in the schools in our ghetto neighborhoods."
Two years ago, state educators wrote this in a study of Newark's schools that formed the basis for the state takeover of the district: "The Newark School District has been at best flagrantly delinquent and at worst deceptive in discharging its obligations to the children enrolled in public schools."
 
Troubled Future
Fear of Violence Pervades Thinking
 The fate of public education in Newark, economists and other analysts say, is one of the crucial elements determining the city's future as it tries to attract service sector jobs, which are growing in the region.
Monsignor Linder said he was troubled by the gulf between the skills of the people that his New Community Corporation seeks to serve and those needed by the businesses that may help revive Newark's downtown. And he said he saw the shiny new buildings as underscoring that gulf.
"Prime office space is that with garage parking, and they are all built like fortresses, with their lobbies up on the second floor and retail space in atriums and courts," he said. "They were all built with the riots in mind, and it's not very pedestrian-friendly and inviting. The result is you have two cities downtown: the one in and around the offices and the one on the streets where the people are."
It is in these concrete ways that the 1967 riots remain an abrupt line of demarcation, and not merely a step in the city's decline, for those who lived through it. The riots persist for them as the yardstick against which so many things today are measured.
A case in point is the routine drug arrest on June 7 that ended in an officer shooting to death a 31-year-old pregnant woman, a half-mile from where the riots started.
Just as had happened 30 years before, angry crowds gathered at the scene. But this time, the officer involved was black, as were many of the officers who arrived. By the time demonstrators descended on City Hall to protest the shooting two days later, Mayor James had already suspended the officer without pay. By the end of June, the Mayor announced a group of measures to improve police-community relations.
"Some conditions are worse today in Newark than 30 years ago, but you didn't have rioting this time like you did then," Mr. Gibson, the former Mayor, said. "Today the city administration doesn't make the mistake of not allowing the questioning of police actions, and there is a penalty for unwarranted police violence."
Mr. Baraka himself circulated among the people and the police on the night of the shooting last month, less a lightning rod than a calming voice.
"I made it clear to the police that we weren't interested in any madness," he said.

PUB-DATE: July 14, 1997

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 1796 words

HEADLINE: Political Memo;
Gore's Bandwagon Gets Big Push As Clinton Shows His Enthusiasm

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 13

 BODY:
Not Ronald Reagan, not Dwight Eisenhower, not even Thomas Jefferson worked as early and as aggressively as President Clinton to help his Vice President succeed him.
Even before he took the oath for a second term, Mr. Clinton shattered White House tradition by signaling his support for Vice President Gore in several interviews. No President in at least 150 years has made such early public declarations about his Vice President. The last two-term President, Ronald Reagan, waited until shortly before the general election to announce his support for Vice President Bush -- and his initial remarks were hardly enthusiastic. 
 More important than words, Mr. Clinton has taken steps to make sure that the staff and resources of the White House are at Mr. Gore's disposal -- not only the traditional perquisites like Air Force Two. As a result, while Mr. Gore quickly established himself as an unusually influential Vice President after the 1992 election, his public and political profile has intensified in recent months.
And behind the scenes, Mr. Clinton has stocked the White House with many of Mr. Gore's allies who are committed to seeing the Vice President elected President in 2000.
The President's efforts may have significant consequences not only for Mr. Gore but for Democratic politics. Some of the President's allies may feel that they have little choice but to rally behind the Vice President.
For example, George Stephanopoulos, Mr. Clinton's former senior adviser, has long been close to Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House minority leader, for whom he once served as a top aide. But if Mr. Stephanopoulos does not support Mr. Gore, the President could interpret that as a personal slap. (Mr. Stephanopoulos, who has maintained close ties with the Administration despite his position as a television news analyst, has said that he expects to back Mr. Gore.)
The downside is that by taking sides this early, Mr. Clinton could further damage his relationships with important Democrats in Congress who are preparing to run for President themselves, notably Mr. Gephardt. And Mr. Gore could still be hurt if the President's popularity slides, or if voters rebel against being told whom to vote for -- or against the notion of a Clinton dynasty. (Only four Vice Presidents have been elected directly to the Oval Office from the Vice Presidency: Martin Van Buren, John Adams, Thomas Jefferson and George Bush.)
"I don't think any President three years before the election has tried to designate his successor," said Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr., the historian who was an adviser to President John F. Kennedy. "It carries certain risks of alienating possible contenders, particularly Dick Gephardt."
The President is willing to take those risks, his aides said, because his support is a logical outgrowth of their unusually close relationship. While the two were not close when Mr. Clinton picked Mr. Gore as his running mate in 1992, they have had one of the closest personal and work relationships of any President and Vice President in history. This weekend, the President cut short his European trip by a day and on Saturday flew back to Washington, where he attended the wedding reception of Mr. Gore's daughter, Karenna.
"This President has always felt that Al Gore would be an excellent President," said Douglas Sosnik, a senior Clinton adviser, "and that furthermore, the Vice President has been an integral part of the successes of this Administration."
Mr. Clinton may also have some self-interest in helping Mr. Gore. Mr. Gore's ascension to the White House would affirm Mr. Clinton's tenure, White House aides said, and help him win credit for reshaping a more moderate Democratic Party.
Joel Silbey, a historian at Cornell University, said he thought that Mr. Clinton was "really trying to establish an inheritance here."
Mr. Silbey said President Andrew Jackson, who was elected with Vice President Martin Van Buren in 1832, was the last President who went out of his way to signal his belief that his Vice President should succeed him. Yet even then, Mr. Jackson's comments about Mr. Van Buren were far less direct than what Mr. Clinton has said about Mr. Gore.
The most public demonstration of Mr. Clinton's backing of Mr. Gore is the extent to which Mr. Clinton has dispatched him to deliver major announcements that past Presidents would have reserved for themselves.
For example, when Mr. Gore recently announced White House support for tax breaks to help start-up companies, his advisers remarked privately that his involvement could help the Vice President clinch political and financial support from the high-technology industry.
In the last several days, when Mr. Clinton was in Europe, it often seemed as if Mr. Gore were President. Over the Fourth of July weekend, Mr. Gore appeared on the network news broadcasts when he congratulated space officials for the Mars landing. Rather than save the appearances for Mr. Clinton's return, the White House had Mr. Gore announce the new television ratings system, and held several events assuring pivotal Democratic groups that they would benefit from tax cuts supported by the Administration.
On Thursday, at a White House news conference where a $500-per-child tax cut was proposed, Mr. Gore shared the stage with Mr. Gephardt. But after he spoke, Mr. Gephardt was placed in a spot far to the side, while Mr. Gore dominated the event.
When Mr. Clinton injured his knee in March, Mr. Gore benefited, at first, because the President was forced to constrain his schedule, leaving the high-profile assignments such as touring flood disaster areas to Mr. Gore. But White House advisers also said that since his re-election, Mr. Clinton has been less interested in attending heavily political events like labor conventions.
In one exchange that demonstrated the President's cheerleading, Katie Couric of NBC News asked Mr. Clinton in early January how important it was for Mr. Gore to be the Democratic nominee in 2000. Mr. Clinton responded that "the Democrats of America will have to decide that question." But, Mr. Clinton continued, Mr. Gore "has been, unquestionably, the most effective Vice President in history. And if the people decide to make him President, they won't be disappointed."
"That's quite an endorsement," Ms. Couric said.
"That's my feeling," Mr. Clinton responded.
The President's comments were particularly notable in contrast with what Mr. Reagan said about Vice President Bush in the last paragraph of a speech in 1988. At the time, Mr. Reagan acknowledged that his comments were perceived as so "lukewarm" that he had to issue a stronger statement of support. On top of that, he called him "George Bosh."
The episode created a furor of speculation; some people theorized that Nancy Reagan did not want her husband to cede the limelight, while others said Mr. Reagan was never convinced that Mr. Bush had true conservative credentials.
Mr. Gore's ample opportunities to appear at public events have deflected attention from his controversial role in Democratic fund-raising, in contrast to Mr. Bush's inability to break free from the negative publicity over the Iran-contra affair.
Richard N. Bond, who was Vice President Bush's political director, argued that an early public endorsement from Mr. Reagan would have backfired because critics such as columnist George F. Will were already calling Mr. Bush a "lap dog." "Having had Reagan hover too protectively over Bush isn't what Bush wanted," Mr. Bond said.
But when asked whether an earlier endorsement from Mr. Reagan would have been welcome, Mr. Bond said: "Reagan was the strongest thing in the Republican Party for 12 years. At any given time that was certainly a welcome thing to have."
Well before Mr. Reagan, Presidents had been less than helpful and sometimes openly scornful of their Vice Presidents. At times, Presidents were threatened by the ambitions of their Vice Presidents; in other instances, Presidents were not fond of their Vice Presidents but picked them out of expediency.
In the 1960 campaign, President Eisenhower did not do his Vice President, Richard M. Nixon, much good when he was asked what decisions Mr. Nixon had participated in. Mr. Eisenhower replied, "If you give me a week, I might think of one."
And in 1968, President Lyndon B. Johnson and Vice President Hubert H. Humphrey clashed so much over Vietnam that neither man seemed to want to be associated with the other.
Several White House aides said Mr. Clinton has been quite blunt about how he wants to make certain that Mr. Gore succeeds him. As Dick Morris, Mr. Clinton's former political adviser, put it in his book, "Behind the Oval Office," the President told him: "I just want you to know I will work ceaselessly, ceaselessly, to be sure that Al Gore is the Presidential nominee -- without a primary if at all possible. Ceaselessly."
From all indications, Mr. Clinton is working hard, if not ceaselessly, to help Mr. Gore. At the Democratic convention in Chicago last summer, Mr. Gore was given an especially long speaking slot in prime time.
More recently, White House aides said the President suggested that Mr. Gore address a political dinner in Arkansas, a move that could help Mr. Gore win political support early from the President's home state. In June, Mr. Clinton used a setting in the Vice President's home state of Tennessee to announce tougher new air quality standards -- and to give Mr. Gore some of the credit.
A more obvious sign of how Mr. Clinton has broadened the Vice President's network can be counted in the number of Gore loyalists on his own staff. Karen Skelton, who was Mr. Gore's political director, has moved to Mr. Clinton's staff as deputy political director. Thurgood Marshall Jr., who was Mr. Gore's head of legislative affairs, is now secretary of the President's Cabinet. Lynn Cutler, a longtime party worker close to Mr. Gore, is now Mr. Clinton's deputy for intergovernmental affairs. Frederick P. DuVal, Mr. Gore's campaign manager last year, is also a deputy for intergovernmental affairs. The national chairman of the Democratic Party, Steven Grossman, is a Gore ally. And two others hold top posts in the second term: Andrew M. Cuomo as Housing Secretary and Franklin D. Raines as the director of the Office of Management and Budget.
Despite all the positioning so early on, some analysts argued that Mr. Clinton's popularity in 2000 -- which will ride heavily on the health of the economy -- is what really matters.
"Al Gore is locked in the trunk of Bill Clinton's car," Ted Van Dyk, a longtime Democratic analyst, said. "If the car goes over the cliff, that's the end of Al. If it speeds first over the finish line, it helps Al."

PERSON: RONALD REAGAN (93%); BILL CLINTON (92%); AL GORE (79%); JOHN F KENNEDY (79%); GEORGE W BUSH (78%);

PUB-DATE: July 15, 1997

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 4; Science Desk 

LENGTH: 1677 words

HEADLINE: Shark Is Efficient Killer, but Picky Eater

BYLINE: By WILLIAM J. BROAD 

 BODY:
FEW animals have the power to frighten people into the cold terror of being eaten alive. But the great white shark does so effortlessly. Its reputation for blood lust is rooted in images of jaws gleaming with rows of razor-sharp teeth, their edges nicely serrated to ease the job of tearing through bone and flesh.
Nature's great killing machine grows to lengths of 20 feet or more and is often viewed as crude and mindlessly malevolent, feeding just as heartily on humans as on fish, seals, whales and sea lions. 
 But new research is challenging that notion and shedding light on the hidden life of the great white, revealing a finicky eater that may find people unpalatable.
Though it is pitiless with prey, lunging and slashing in red-stained water, the species can be quite civil among its own. Scientists have found what appears to be a ritualized competition over kills in which two great whites will forgo attacking one another for a genteel bout of slapping tails on the sea's surface. The biggest splash decides the winner.
Such finesse stands in stark contrast to the raw violence among predators like wolves, which can engage one another in bloody fights to the death.
Over all, scientists say, great whites have been badly misunderstood, wrongly making them the demons of movies and nightmares.Some research has even found evidence that the killers, when thwarted in feeding, get visibly frustrated and agitated, perhaps even sad and dejected.
"We're dispelling myths and learning a lot about how they really live," said Dr. A. Peter Klimley, a biologist at the University of California Bodega Marine Laboratory in Bodega Bay, Calif., who is a prominent expert on the infamous shark.
"They're not stupid feeding machines," he said. "They're exquisitely adapted."
Dr. Douglas J. Long, a fish scientist at the California Academy of Sciences who studies great whites, said the new insights, while substantial, still left a greater number of riddles.
"For instance," Dr. Long said, "we know virtually nothing about how and where they mate."
Even as scientists seek to unravel the great white's biology, behavior and ecology, a political push is accelerating to protect the beast. The top predator of the sea, it appears to be declining in numbers because of assaults by sport fishermen as well as commercial interests serving a growing international market for white-shark jaws and teeth.
California, South Africa and Australia have taken steps to try to save the great white, and other states and countries are considering such conservation efforts.
Its numbers "will inevitably dwindle unless prudent controls are enacted," Dr. Richard C. Murphy, a marine ecologist at the Cousteau Society in Chesapeake, Va., wrote in "Great White Sharks," a collection of scientific reports published late last year by Academic Press.
"In addition to being increasingly rare," Dr. Murphy said, "they are majestic preeminent participants in a complicated food web which we, as yet, only partially understand." The willingness and ability of humans to protect the killer, Dr. Murphy said, "are indicators of the economic, political and sociological health of our own species."
The mythology of terror surrounding the great white is even wider and more ominous than the shark's jaws are in real life. In "Twenty Thousand Leagues Under the Sea," Jules Verne tells how Professor Aronnax was taken by Captain Nemo for a global submarine tour, the two men finding themselves face to face with some of the razor-toothed giants during an underwater walk.
"The blood froze in my veins," the professor said, as "silver bellies and huge mouths bristling with teeth" rushed out of the darkness.
After a narrow escape, the professor later told his companions of reports that fishermen had cut open the stomachs of great white sharks and found a buffalo head, a whole calf and "a sailor still in uniform."
More recently, the beast achieved fame as the villain of "Jaws," the best-selling book by Peter Benchley and the blockbuster movie by Steven Spielberg. Both featured a marauding great white that terrorized swimmers near crowded beaches.
The great white is "firmly ensconced in the pantheon of sea monsters," Richard Ellis wrote in "Monsters of the Sea," (Knopf, 1994). "It is the largest predatory fish in the world," he said, with some specimens weighing "as much as a full-grown rhinoceros."
Sharks are ancient animals, long predating the dinosaurs and myriad types of modern creatures. Carcharodon carcharias, or "ragged tooth" in scholarly Latin, is found in temperate waters throughout the world's seas. To find prey, it has acute sensors known as lateral-line organs that apparently can detect disturbances in seawater at ranges of a mile or more.
Closer to a victim (exactly how close is uncertain), its keen ears can hear thrashing, its sensitive nose can sniff blood, and its eerie black eyes can spy flesh. Powerful muscles send it lunging.
The triangular teeth grow to lengths of two or more inches and are extraordinarily strong. Three layers of enamel crisscross in different directions so the teeth can better withstand impact as well as twisting and bending. If a tooth is lost, a replacement directly behind it will rotate forward in a day or so. New teeth are constantly being formed in this replacement process.
Judging from stomach contents, the beast can indeed devour prey whole, including other sharks and sea lions. Though one of its nicknames is "man-eater" (another is "white death"), no one knows for certain if people are in fact a preferred food.
To explore such questions, scientists in the last decade have increasingly studied the beast's predatory habits. Dr. Klimley of the Bodega Marine Laboratory, working with Peter Pyle and Scot D. Anderson, did a pioneering study near the Farallon Islands, which lie some 30 miles west of San Francisco in one of the most productive fisheries on the West Coast.
Video recordings were made of 129 great-white attacks on seals and sea lions, the assaults rich in explosive splashes in bloodstained water.
An analysis suggested that a shark near the surface would bite its victim, drag it down bleeding, carry it underwater and perhaps take another bite, then let the carcass float upward. If the victim was still alive, the act might be repeated.
The shark's aim, the scientists deduced, was to have the prey bleed to death as soon as possible, minimizing a violent struggle.
In an interview, Dr. Klimley noted that attacks on people often followed a similar pattern -- but the sharks, after dragging humans down, bleeding, often let them go.
Dr. Klimley said white sharks might spit out humans, birds and sea otters because their bodies lacked the energy-rich layers of fat possessed by animals like seals and whales. "If they ingest something that's not energetically profitable, then they're stuck with that for a few days" of slow digestion, he said. "Fat has twice the energy value of muscle."
Dr. Klimley noted three recent attacks along the northern California coast near Bodega Bay in which people had been quickly let go.
"Can you imagine?" he said. "These sharks are seizing people and holding them very gingerly to make this decision. They strike and hold and release -- and that's for big sharks, three or four meters long." A meter is equal to 3.3 feet.
Worldwide, great white sharks attack people four or five times a year, perhaps killing one of them.
An even more subtle side of predation involves the tail-slapping ritual, which Dr. Klimley discovered and has described. One white competing with another over a kill will often twist its body to the side, lift its tail and slap the sea surface, often splashing water in the direction of the rival.
"A shark was permitted to feed further on a seal only if the vigor and frequency of its tail slaps were greater than those of its opponent," Dr. Klimley wrote in a paper on the ritual in the Academic Press book "Great White Sharks."
To study the shark's feeding habits, scientists are about to inaugurate a system of acoustic tags and buoys that will reveal the position of seals and great whites as they battle under the sea.
The first-of-its-kind experiment is to begin this fall along the California coast near Santa Cruz and Ano Nuevo, a rocky isle that is the year-round home of 1,500 to 5,000 elephant seals. It and is a stop-and-shop for great whites.
Twenty acoustic transmitters will be attached to as many sharks and elephant seals, and the underwater signals will be picked up by three electronic buoys and radioed to scientists on shore. The work is financed by the University of California at Davis, which runs the Bodega Marine Laboratory, and the National Science Foundation, a Federal agency that supports basic research.
Heading the investigation are Dr. Klimley, the shark specialist, and Dr. Burney J. Le Boeuf, a seal expert at the University of California at Santa Cruz.
"It's difficult to know what the predator is doing and the evasive tactics of the prey," Dr. Le Boeuf said in an interview. "Now we have a chance to understand that very well.
"I think we can find out some fundamental things about this animal that have eluded us -- basic things like how many there are around a seal rookery. It's like a supermarket. The seals are coming and going at all times. So why don't the sharks live there all year round?"
The speculation, Dr. Le Boeuf said, is that the great whites breed in the south and move north for easy feeding.
"But even so, once in central California," he said, "how do they divide the food among themselves? We don't have a clue. Whether it is the most dominant individuals and families, or more random, no one knows."
Scientists say a better understanding of the life history of the white terror will ultimately help it survive the increasingly crowded seas of the next century.
"If we want to conserve them, we have to figure out where they go," said Dr. Long, of the California Academy of Sciences. "There's still a lot of mysteries."

GRAPHIC: Diagram: "Bloody Clues to a Killer's M.O."
By studying red stains and surface attacks, scientists have found that the shark apparently tries to get victims to bleed to death quickly in an effort to minimize violent struggle. Sharks near the surface bite prey, drag it down bleeding, carry it underwater and perhaps take another bite, then let the carcass float upward. If the victim is still fighting, the act may be repeated. (The New York Times; Illustration by Michael Rothman)(pg. C1)
 
"On the Scent"
Great white sharks' noses can sniff blood at great distances. A large part of a shark's brain is devoted to the sense of smell.
 
"Destroying Bone and Flesh"
Extraordinarily strong teeth are made of three layers of enamel that crisscross to withstand impact, twisting and bending.
 
"Tracking Distant Turmoil
Acute sensors called lateral-line organs, which run the length of the shark's body, can detect disturbances in seawater, likely to signal the presence of prey, at ranges of a mile or more.
 
"New Insights Into a Perfect Killing Machine
Scientists are exploring the hidden life of the great white shark, discovering how it tracks and kills its prey and how it vies with others of its own kind for the spoils.
 
"Ritual Combat Over Dinner"
After a kill by two male sharks, scientists observed them in a splashing display to determine who got the carcass, first swimming past each other without toouching, then rolling over slightly to splash water in the other's direction. The shark that managed to stir up the most water in several passes ended up with the meal.
(Source: "Great White Sharks," A. P. Klimley and D. G. Ainley (Academic Press)(pg. C2)

HEADLINE: Hispanic Workers Get Left Behind

 BODY:

To the Editor:
While it is encouraging that the national economy is absorbing the rapidly growing labor force (front page, July 10), political leaders and the Hispanic community must not overlook the problem of Hispanic workers being hired as low-wage manual laborers. They are the largest group filling the void left by others who "shift from one sector to another in pursuit of better jobs." When the economy slows down, Hispanic laborers will be out of a job and will not have the skills for the service-oriented job market. 
 As I read that Hispanic workers are "clearly among the nation's most mobile workers," I worry that their children will move from school to school, slip through the cracks of our educational system and join the nearly 1.1 million Hispanics between ages 16 and 24 who are high school drop-outs.
 
ADRIAN GONZALES
West New York, N.J., July 11, 1997

HEADLINE: A Break for Students

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL 

 BODY:
Hewing to the five-year budget deal struck between the White House and Congressional Republicans, both the House and Senate tax bills include $30 billion-plus in tax breaks for college students. And while both have been criticized by President Clinton for doing "an inadequate job of opening the door to college," the White House's alternative is close enough to assure that a variation will be part of the eventual tax package.
But many economists, including some who favor increased investment in education, see little cause for applause. Some of the money, they note, is almost certain to be drained away in higher tuition. And a good chunk will end up in the bank accounts of parents who would have sent their children to college anyway. "The subsidy will pay for a lot of vacations and new furniture that families would have otherwise forgone," Thomas Kane, an economist at the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard, predicted. 
 More generally, they view new tax incentives with skepticism, doubting that the benefit is worth the price in added complexity and government involvement in private decision-making. "This whole tax bill is antithetical to the spirit of tax reform," argued Joel Slemrod, an economist at the University of Michigan Business School.
Both the House and Senate bills offer credits to offset half of the first $3,000 in tuition for the first two years of college, phasing out the benefit for families with incomes exceeding $80,000. Both would restore the tax-free status of employer-paid tuition at least temporarily, and create a variety of opportunities for setting aside tuition nest eggs in tax-exempt accounts. The Senate bill would also make interest on student loans deductible up to $2,500 a year for five years. President Clinton's college plan goes further, phasing in a 20 percent tax credit on up to $10,000 in tuition for the third and fourth years of college.
The White House portrays the plan as fitting into its often-repeated goal of increasing wages and narrowing income inequality by spurring investments in "human capital." But there is an obvious catch: it will also tempt colleges to raise prices.
This should not be a problem for students attending the majority of four-year private colleges, Mr. Kane noted, "where competition drives tuition." But it could easily change the priorities of state legislatures that largely underwrite public college systems. And the most selective private colleges, which could enroll far greater numbers than they have room for, will have incentives to reduce need-based financial aid, dollar for dollar.
The tax credits will also be powerful incentives for low-tuition community colleges to raise charges. President Clinton's plan would offer a 100 percent tax credit on the first $1,000 in tuition and, after 2002, a 50 percent credit against the next $1,000. In 1994-95 fully one-third of community college students paid less than $1,000 annually to attend.
Moreover, the money that does reach students is unlikely to reach those in greatest need. Lawrence E. Gladieux, director of policy research at the College Board, estimates that 30 percent of families with children are too poor to owe Federal income taxes, and would thus not be eligible for the credit. Nor would most older, self-supporting students, who typically scrape by on part-time work and their own savings.
The White House understands the problem: President Clinton is also proposing to increase the maximum tuition subsidy under the Pell grant program for low-income students. But the $300 increase in the maximum annual grant in the President's budget, Mr. Gladieux noted, is far less than the tax credit.
By the same token, the credit would put cash into the hands of the great bulk of the middle class whose children already go to college. That would be no problem, were the idea to relieve their financial strain. But Len Burman, an economist at the Urban Institute, said it was inconsistent with the end of inducing families to save more on their own. And it hardly meshes with the primary goal of raising the productivity of the work force through education.
College attendance has risen by one-third since the early 1980's in response to the widening wage gap between the skilled and unskilled. Indeed, nine out of ten college-age Americans in the top quarter of the income distribution already get some form of post-secondary education, Mr. Gladieux said. "So if we're going to lift our net investment in education," he concluded, "the action has to center on those with incomes below $50,000."
The three proposals could be sliced and diced to deliver more of the benefit to this group. No amount of tinkering, though, would be likely to satisfy reformers who view tinkering itself as the enemy of sound tax policy. A central idea behind the 1986 Tax Reform Act -- and more recent reform proposals including the flat tax -- is to separate the task of collecting revenue from how it is spent.
But after a decade without new Federal programs or tax cuts, the temptation to use the tax code as a prescription for what ails -- or, more simply, as a means of pleasing important constituencies -- is apparently irresistible. "It's been a long time since Washington has been able to hand out money," Mr. Slemrod said.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Securities Drop in Price

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities fell yesterday, as investors remained cautious ahead of this week's retail and price data and stood unfazed by the June Atlanta Fed survey of manufacturing activity, which inched up.
The price of the 30-year bond dropped 10/32 , to 101 to yield 6.55 percent, up from 6.52 percent at the close of the New York market on Friday. 
 Over all, the Atlanta Fed's index for June showed a reading of 17.5, up from 17.3 in May, while its prices- paid component declined to 8.7 in June from 11.0 in May. Investors remained focused on today's release of the June retail sales and tomorrow's Consumer Price Index for any hint of whether the economy could accelerate and push inflation higher, leading the central bank to tighten credit.
Greg Jones, an economist with Briefing.com, a market analysis firm in Menlo Park, Calif., said a busy week lay ahead for the Treasury market, with important reports every day beginning today. "While the bullish tone remains intact as we enter the week, there are two significant threats to the market in this week's releases, retail sales and the Consumer Price Index," he said.
"Neither release is expected to pose a problem for the market," he said, "but an unexpected upside surprise on either could undermine the optimistic economic slowdown-low inflation scenario. The bottom line is that while further gains appear likely this week, the downside potential is greater than the upside potential, particularly early in the week."
Retail sales fell in March, April and May, and the June report today is not expected to extend the negative streak to four, he said, but not much a rebound is expected either. Like the market consensus, Briefing estimates a two-tenths of 1 percent gain over all with the ex-auto numbers a bit stronger. Briefing.com sees a gain of three-tenths of 1 percent, and the market estimate is for a gain of five-tenths of 1 percent.
"While auto sales are not likely to surprise on the strong side given the weakness in unit auto sales," Mr. Jones said, "ex-auto sales remain something of a wild card."
Kenneth J. McCarthy, founder of the Economic Intelligence Company, an economic consulting and forecasting firm, is not concerned. "The economy of the 1990's is a low inflation economy, able to grow strongly and maintain a low unemployment rate without experiencing any increase inflationary pressures," he said.
This important change, he said, means that the outlook for the coming years is about as good as it gets. "The Fed is committed to keeping the economy from overheating, so the likelihood of a significant increase in inflationary pressures is low," he said. "Instead, the economy should be able to continue expanding at a healthy rate for the foreseeable future."
Rates at yesterday's bill auction were lower than the previous week, but the bills auction was generally in line with recent offerings. The rate for a three-month issue increased to 5.05 percent, from 4.97 percent, while the six-month bill increased to 5.09 percent, from 5.07 percent.
The following are the results of yesterday's Treasury auction of new three-month and six-month bills:

HEADLINE: U.S. to Give North Koreans Surplus Grain

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 14

 BODY:
Two weeks after North Korea agreed to join peace talks, the United States announced today that it would donate $27 million worth of surplus grain to help that Government cope with severe shortages of food.
The announcement came in response to the latest appeal by the World Food Program for emergency aid to avert a catastrophe in North Korea, where there are reports of severe food shortages caused by floods and years of economic decay. 
 The United States has repeatedly insisted that it does not link aid to North Korea's willingness to take part in "four party" talks with the United States, South Korea and China to devise a formal end to the Korean War.
After months of delay as it raised demands for food, North Korea finally agreed on June 30 to take part in those talks. The four countries scheduled a meeting in New York in August to hammer out further details on the timing, site and agenda.
However, Administration officials remain wary of North Korea's willingness to see the process all the way through to a formal treaty to replace the 1953 armistice.
