HEADLINE: Laws Are Urged to Protect Religion

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 14

 BODY:
The effort to counter the Supreme Court's recent decision that struck down the Religious Freedom Restoration Act is likely to take the form of legislation and steer clear of a contentious effort to amend the Constitution, testimony at a Congressional hearing indicated today.
Representative Charles T. Canady, the Florida Republican who heads the Constitution subcommittee of the House Judiciary Committee, said at a subcommittee hearing that a constitutional amendment would be "ill-advised," premature and "most likely would not pass in any event." 
 Mr. Canady called the hearing to explore other approaches to shielding religious observances from Government regulation, the goal of the doomed Federal law that had passed both houses of Congress in 1993 with only three dissenting votes.
Lawyers for several of the major religious groups that made up an unusually broad coalition that supported the law all urged legislative action rather than an amendment.
"My overriding message is one of caution," said the Rev. Oliver Thomas, special counsel to the National Council of the Churches of Christ, and the chairman of the coalition four years ago.
Mr. Thomas, while calling the Supreme Court's decision "a profound national wrong," said a constitutional amendment would "create a bigger problem than the one we seek to solve."
Mr. Thomas and other witnesses, including a law professor who played a leading role in drafting the 1993 law, predicted today that more narrowly written laws tied to Congress's authority to regulate interstate commerce and to control Federal spending would accomplish the goal of protecting religious practices and surviving a Supreme Court challenge.
The Religious Freedom Restoration Act said no level of government could enforce a law that "substantially burdened" the free exercise of religion unless the law served a "compelling governmental interest" and was the "least restrictive means" of serving that interest. On June 25, in a 6-to-3 decision in City of Boerne v. Flores, the Supreme Court ruled that the law was unconstitutional because it exceeded Congress's authority.
In passing the measure, Congress had invoked its authority under Section 5 of the 14th Amendment, which gives it the power to enforce constitutional rights and to prevent violations of those rights by the states. Justice Anthony M. Kennedy's opinion for the Court said the law amounted to a substantive change in the meaning of the Constitution, an unauthorized expansion of constitutional rights, rather than a permissible enforcement or remedy within the proper meaning of Section 5.
While the hearing today was in one sense the first step of a congressional response, in another sense it was only the latest chapter in an unusual dialogue that Congress and the Court have been conducting since 1990. That year, in the decision in Employment Division v. Smith, the Court ruled that the "compelling interest" test was not part of the First Amendment's guarantee of the free exercise of religion. A generally applicable law that happened to place a burden on religious practices did not violate the Constitution, the Court said. The Religious Freedom Restoration Act, making the compelling-interest test a matter of Federal law, was the response to the 1990 decision.
Mark E. Chopko, general counsel of the United States Catholic Conference, which supported the law, said at the hearing today that the use of the word "restoration" in its title was a red flag to the Justices that Congress was encroaching on the Court's domain. Mr. Chopko urged Congress to "avoid the linguistics of 'restoration' " and focus instead on the goal of protecting religious liberty through legislation. Trying to pass a constitutional amendment would be divisive, he said.
Marc D. Stern, legal director of the American Jewish Congress, urged Congress to compile a "careful record" of the negative impact that regulations burdening religion can have on the economy. For example, Mr. Stern said, many Roman Catholics might not want to live in a state where liquor laws would not permit minors to drink communion wine.
With an adequate record, he said, Congress should be able to defend a new version of the law as an exercise of its power to regulate interstate commerce.
Mr. Stern and Douglas Laycock, a law professor at the University of Texas who was instrumental in drafting the Religious Freedom Restoration Act, also urged Congress to consider requiring a high level of protection for religious observances as a condition of receiving Federal money, much as Title VI of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 has been effective in barring racial discrimination in programs that receive Federal aid.
One issue mentioned at the hearing was the effect of the Supreme Court decision on Congress's ability to apply the Religious Freedom Restoration Act to Federal laws, as opposed to state or local laws, a question the Court did not directly address. Professor Laycock and others said that since Section 5 of the 14th Amendment dealt only with Congressional authority over the states, the Court's interpretation of Section 5 left undisturbed Congress's authority to make law for the Federal Government.
But to be sure, he said, Congress should pass a joint resolution or a new measure to assert that the 1993 law is still binding on the Federal Government.
Amid the general enthusiasm for moving ahead with a Federal reply to the Court's decision, one witness, Jeffrey S. Sutton, the Solicitor General of Ohio, said the law had created a problem for Ohio and other states. Its failure to exempt prisons from its coverage led to burdensome and often frivolous lawsuits from prisoners who claimed violations of their religious rights, Mr. Sutton said.
Mr. Sutton, who argued in the Supreme Court on behalf of 16 states that the law violated state sovereignty, said the Ohio Attorney General, Betty D. Montgomery, had drafted a proposed state "religious liberty act" that did not cover prisons. While other witnesses said a state-by-state approach would lead to an unwieldy patchwork of religious protection, Mr. Sutton said states should be permitted to experiment.
The concept of federalism that the Court honored in its decision last month "was also designed to protect individual liberty," he said.

HEADLINE: Governors Island Is No Lure For Developers, Panel Hears

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
With developers saying that its isolation and high maintenance costs may make Governors Island a money-loser at any price, the island's fate seemed caught in a web of conflicting city, state and Federal Government interests yesterday at a Congressional hearing in Manhattan.
The hearing, intended to provide New York officials, business people and civic groups with a forum to suggest ways to reuse Governors Island -- and prevent it from being auctioned off as surplus Federal real estate -- became as much an exchange of opinions about what cannot be done and should not be considered for the scenic tract in New York Harbor. 
 "It is just not logical to consider this as an attractive development site," said Douglas Durst, a Manhattan developer, who said that the cost of a large-scale development on the 174-acre island, half of it protected as a city historic district, could be close to $1 billion.
President Clinton has offered to help transfer Governors Island to New York for $1 if city and state officials can agree on a plan for its development. The island was vacated by the United States Coast Guard in May after 200 years as a military installation.
If the city and state cannot agree on a development plan, the island would be offered to other Federal agencies and then put up for auction in 2002.
One point of agreement at yesterday's hearing, conducted at the Custom House in lower Manhattan, was that Congress has grossly overestimated the appeal of the island to real estate investors. Congress has approved a provision in the Federal budget that calls for the sale of the island in 2002, and it estimates the selling price at $500 million.
"Every once in a while it's like the Congress discovers a bunch of Confederate money lying around and thinks it's worth something," said Stephen Horn, a California Republican and chairman of the House Subcommittee on Government, Management, Information and Technology, who presided at the hearing with Carolyn B. Maloney, a Manhattan Democrat and fellow member of the committee. "Somebody in Washington pulled that $500 million figure out of a phone book," Ms. Maloney said.
But while holding the Congressional estimate in collective ridicule, those testifying yesterday differed sharply on what a redeveloped Governors Island would cost and who should pay for it.
"It is time for Washington to show us some money and maybe everybody will get serious about this project," said Randy Levine, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's Deputy Mayor for finance, planning and economic development. He maintained that Congress must drop any hope of raising money from the island's sale, and must provide Federal support to help the city and state maintain it.
The President's offer to transfer the island to city and state control for $1 had been made to Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, who described it in an interview in March. He said that the advisers to Mayor Giuliani and Gov. George E. Pataki risked losing out on the President's offer of help because they appeared unable to agree on a plan for the island.
"I have the President's promise, but two years from now the island will be irrecoverable unless we come to Washington with a plan," Senator Moynihan said in an interview yesterday.
One proposal that has circulated widely among civic groups -- and was offered at the hearing yesterday by officials of the Sierra Club -- would turn Governors Island over to the National Park Service, to be combined with Ellis Island and the Statue of Liberty as a national park and tourist attraction.
"The parks service perhaps ought to take it over, but we know it won't," Senator Moynihan said, adding that the National Park Service is under too much financial strain managing its existing parks to add to its property in the New York Harbor.
Another proposal, offered at the hearing by Ms. Maloney, is that a development agency controlled by a consortium of Federal, state and city officials be formed to acquire the island.
The proposal drew a cool response from Mr. Levine, reflecting a repeated refusal by the Giuliani administration to share power with other levels of government in development projects. "The city is fully capable of handling this on its own," Mr. Levine said.
Mr. Levine's response was criticized by Ms. Maloney, who said: "The city seems to be saying it has the resources to get this done, but they certainly didn't put any cash on the table today."

HEADLINE: Is This the End of Lilco? Silver Has the Crucial Vote

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

DATELINE: ALBANY, July 14

 BODY:
Gov. George E. Pataki's proposed state takeover of the Long Island Lighting Company, a deal that would help determine the Island's electric rates for the next three decades and require the largest municipal bond sale in American history, faces a crucial test this week, with its fate resting in the hands of the Governor's nemesis, Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver.
For the $7.3 billion plan to go into effect, it needs the unanimous approval of the state's Public Authorities Control Board, which will take up the matter on Wednesday. Mr. Silver is a member, as are representatives of Governor Pataki and the Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, two certain votes in favor. That leaves it up to the Speaker, who has said he will not postpone the vote, but has not said which way he will go. 
 "The deal will rise or fall on its merits," he said recently.
When it was announced in March, the proposal to take over Lilco's debts and many of its assets was one of the Republican Governor's proudest achievements. It appeared to resolve some seemingly intractable problems for the Governor in a region that is one of his political bases, just in time for his 1998 re-election campaign. State officials argued that it would lower the Island's electric rates, the highest in the continental United States, by 19 percent, while settling a tax dispute with Lilco that threatened the financial health of Suffolk County and some local governments there.
For Mr. Silver, a Democrat from Manhattan, the calculations on the politics and the merits are different. Some of his allies are concerned that if he votes against it, Republicans will accuse him of blocking the Island's only hope for significantly lower electric bills. And he is surely loath to give the Governor something he so dearly wants.
Mr. Silver's aides and other Assembly Democrats say that he has given them few clues as to his intentions, but they predict that he will at least try to alter the deal in ways that will allow him to say that he improved it.
The deal was warmly received at first by a wide range of business groups and politicians. But since then, it has come in for heavy criticism, forcing Mr. Pataki to stump for it aggressively in recent days. Consumer groups oppose it, the Republican-dominated Suffolk County Legislature commissioned a study that came out critical of the takeover, the Island's Democratic Assembly members have urged Mr. Silver to oppose it, and Lieut. Gov. Betsy McCaughey Ross, continuing her feud with the Governor, sent him a letter today saying that she, too, had reservations.
An examination of the deal, and interviews with people on both sides of the issue, yield several crucial questions and conclusions. And, allies of Mr. Silver said, he is considering these issues as Wednesday's vote approaches.
The first is whether the state can back out of a 1989 agreement that allows Lilco to recover nearly all of its costs from the Shoreham nuclear plant. The administration says no. If the answer is yes, the savings to consumers would be far greater.
The second issue is that the deal is fairly sweet for Lilco and its shareholders, though how sweet is a matter of dispute. While this is galling to the utility's legion of critics, it appears that Lilco will accept no less, leaving the state with little choice if it wants to execute the takeover.
The third issue is that the agreement pumps up consumer savings in the early years by increasing the amount borrowed by more than $500 million and postponing some debt repayment for years. That increases the long-term cost of the deal -- and the amount people will pay for electricity over the next three decades -- by more than $1 billion. State officials make arguments for this arrangement, but critics say it is meant to bolster Mr. Pataki's short-term political fortunes.
Another major issue is the promised rate savings. Even some advocates of the deal concede that the savings are exaggerated, though it is impossible to say just how much. Still, it appears that there are savings, which state officials argue is, finally, what matters.
After the state control board, the proposal must jump two more administrative hurdles. One is approval by the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, the other a waiver by the Internal Revenue Service of $2 billion in capital gains tax that Lilco could owe on the deal.
As with all Lilco matters, it seems, the entire dispute centers on Shoreham. The utility, which serves Nassau and Suffolk Counties, and the Rockaway peninsula in Queens, began work on the nuclear plant in the early 1970's, with the state's support. But in the 1980's, local opposition prevented it from going into service.
In 1989, that dispute ended when Gov. Mario M. Cuomo signed an agreement that insured that Shoreham would never go into service. A state agency, the Long Island Power Authority, took possession of the generator and decommissioned it. Lilco was promised that higher rates, over many years, would allow it to recover all its outstanding costs for the plant, a figure that now stands at $4.5 billion.
The fight over Shoreham left a legacy of bitterness toward the utility that infiltrates every discussion of the proposed deal. It also left the region with rates more than double the national average, which hinders its economy.
Consumer advocates have long argued that state should simply order Lilco to swallow some of Shoreham's costs and lower its rates. "Shareholders, investors, should have to take a write-off, rather than socking it all to the ratepayer," said Gordian Raacke, executive director of the Lilco Citizens Advisory Panel, appointed by a Federal judge as part of a lawsuit settlement against Lilco.
But officials at Lilco, the Long Island Power Authority and the Pataki administration insist that the state is still bound by the 1989 agreement.
"The State of New York made a contractual agreement to let them recover the cost of Shoreham," said Louis R. Tomson, first deputy secretary to the Governor and one of the architects of the buyout. He said an attempt to break the pact would be tied up in court for a decade.
Electric industry analysts on Wall Street say there is no clear answer to the legal question. Other states have ordered utilities to write off costs, but those states had nothing like the 1989 agreement to contend with.
The state buyout would settle the matter once and for all, guaranteeing that Long Island ratepayers would pay for Shoreham.
Under the takeover, the power authority would buy almost all of Lilco's outstanding stock for more than $2.8 billion, and would take over $3.2 billion in Lilco debt. To pay for these and related expenses, the authority would sell $7.3 billion in bonds, to be repaid by electric ratepayers over the next 33 years.
The authority would acquire Lilco's transmission and distribution system, and the company's 18 percent ownership of an upstate nuclear plant, Nine Mile Point 2. By the state's calculations, Lilco would be paid book value for those assets, or $2.5 billion.
But critics charge that the company is being vastly overpaid for the assets. For instance, Nine Mile Point 2, one of the most trouble-plagued nuclear plants in the country, has been a money loser. Yet the power authority proposes to pay Lilco $301 million for its share of the plant.
But Mr. Tomson argued that the deal negotiated -- the total dollar figure and the inclusion of Nine Mile Point 2 -- were the minimum that Dr. William Catacosinos, the company's chairman, would accept.
Joseph W. McDonnell, senior vice president of Lilco, insisted that the deal was a take-it-or-leave-it proposition. "The deal has been negotiated," he said. "The transaction will not be negotiated before each body that needs to provide approval."
The merger agreement with Brooklyn Union provides that if the state takes over the debt, Lilco stockholders would get a 9.6 percent bonus -- more than $2 a share -- in the form of a larger share of the merged company.
Yet Wall Street does not view the takeover as a windfall for Lilco. Even with the promise of that bonus, the proposed merger and proposed state takeover, the company's stock has under-performed the market as a whole since late last year.
One of the more appealing aspects of the deal is that it allows Suffolk County, the town of Brookhaven and the Shoreham-Wading River School District to escape a $1.1 billion judgment Lilco recently won against them for years of excessive property taxes on the Shoreham plant. The company had several similar suits pending against other local governments, over taxes on other properties, that are potentially worth another $400 million.
Under the takeover, the authority, inheriting Lilco's role, would settle the Shoreham case for $625 million, and drop the other cases.
"All the people who complain that we're paying too much don't take into account that we're getting out of a $1.5 billion obligation for $625 million," Mr. Tomson said.
But the authority proposes to finance the settlement of the property tax case like a family using credit cards to live beyond its means, though it means higher costs in the long run.
The settlement could be paid off by adjusting electric rates over many years, at no overall increase in costs, but that idea was rejected by Suffolk officials. So instead, the authority proposes to send customers rebate checks and give them large rate reductions in the first five years. To pay for that, it would borrow $462 million, to be repaid by Suffolk residents through higher rates until 2028.
"The whole thing is just nutty," said Larry Shapiro, staff attorney for the New York Public Interest Research Group, a consumer advocacy group that opposes the takeover. "You borrow half a billion just to hand people some cash?"
Similarly, much of the borrowing behind the entire deal would be arranged to postpone payments for several years. Such moves allow deeper rate reductions right away, but raise the cost of repayment for the next 33 years.
Mr. Tomson said the structure was needed to provide the authority with a cushion of cash as it goes into business. Yet the state had already earmarked $640 million in borrowing specifically for the creation of a reserve fund.
In the long run, critics say, the agreement is flawed in that it hinders competition, which is replacing electric monopolies around the country, and which could lower rates. This is in part based on a provision that has the Power Authority pay the merged Lilco-Brooklyn Union for 15 years for the right to buy its power.
Critics have also attacked the authority's promise that it would lower electric rates an average of 19 percent over the first 10 years. In fact, the authority's predicted prices average 15 percent below current levels, not 19 percent. The higher figure is based on a comparison with Lilco's projections that assume steadily climbing rates without the takeover.
The state's predictions assume modest increases in power demand, which consumer groups say may not materialize.
Still, it appears that the deal would, at least over the first decade, save ratepayers money. The authority can issue tax-exempt bonds, so it would pay lower interest rates on the debts that Lilco has been paying. And unlike Lilco, the authority would not have to pay Federal income tax on shareholder dividends.
In the second and third decades, by the state's own projections, the savings would be much smaller.

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
Agency to Sell Bonds To Expand College

BYLINE: By DAVID W. CHEN 

 BODY:
The New York City Industrial Development Agency has authorized the issuance of bonds worth $9.16 million on behalf of the College of New Rochelle that will allow the private, nonprofit institution to expand its services to adult-education students at its School of New Resources.
The bonds are to be used by the college to purchase and renovate a building it now leases at its South Bronx campus and to create a new Adult Learning Center at its Co-op City campus. The improvements will enable the college to double its Co-op City enrollment to 1,000 students. 
 The tax-exempt bonds are more advantageous to nonprofit institutions because they usually come with a lower interest rate than bonds issued by the institution itself.
In fiscal 1997, the Industrial Development Agency, a public benefit corporation created by the State Legislature and administered by the New York City Economic Development Corporation, expects to issue $102 million worth of private activity bonds for 12 institutions, including some Y.M.C.A.'s in Manhattan and Staten Island.
 DAVID W. CHEN

HEADLINE: THE DOLLAR SOARS AS EUROPE DOUBTS ITS CURRENCY PLAN

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, July 14

 BODY:
Defying the efforts of policy makers on both sides of the Atlantic to restrain the strength of the American currency, the dollar surged in value today against most major European currencies, reaching its highest level in six years against the German mark and the French franc.
The rise reflects the dollar's expanding role as a haven for currency traders skeptical over the future of the euro, the new single European currency that is supposed to start replacing several national denominations here in 1999. 
 With the dollar buying nearly 1.8 German marks and more than 6 French francs, it is now worth about 10 percent more than it was in early February, when American and European finance ministers declared that the United States currency had already climbed enough and was due for a pause.
By contrast, however, the dollar has moved in the other direction against the Japanese yen, helping to alleviate fears in Washington that a weaker yen will only aggravate the gaping American trade deficit with Japan by making Japanese exports cheaper in world markets.
After soaring against the yen for more than a year, the dollar has slipped back in recent months from its high point of 127 yen in April to about 114 today. For the Clinton Administration, led by Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin, a slumping mark is much less worrisome than a slumping yen would have been, several economists said today.
"If the dollar strengthens too much against the Japanese yen, it will contribute to a further deterioration in the trade balance," said Robert D. Hormats, vice chairman of Goldman Sachs International. "That argument will not be made about Europe."
Treasury officials declined to comment on the dollar today.
There is little question, though, that Tokyo has always been seen in Washington as more of an economic rival to the United States than Germany or Western Europe. When the dollar spurts against the yen, it brings politically powerful protests from American auto makers and others industries that compete against Japanese imports or are trying to crack Japan's sheltered market.
For American tourists in continental Europe, the stronger dollar means that they can buy far more for their money than during last summer's vacation season.
But the resurgence of the dollar in Europe after a few months of relative stability could mean headaches for at least some American exporters because it makes American products more expensive and European products more competitive.
The divergence between European and Japanese currencies highlights the extent to which exchange markets dance to their own tune rather than the dictates of policy makers.
On Feb. 7, Mr. Rubin signaled a significant change in American policy. Mr. Rubin had previously held fast to the position that a strong dollar was good for the United States but suddenly and explicitly he began saying that the dollar had been strong "for some time now."
Though subtle, that shift was formalized and welcomed in Berlin the next day by the finance ministers and central bankers from the Group of Seven industrial countries -- the United States, Japan, Germany, France, Britain, Italy and Canada. Hans Tietmeyer, president of Germany's formidable central bank, followed up by frequently stating that the "correction" had gone far enough and that the mark was ready to stabilize.
Since then, however, policy makers have been rocked with new shocks related to the introduction of the proposed euro. Germany, bogged down with the highest level of unemployment it has seen since World War II, is running budget deficits that violate its own tough fiscal standards for countries that are allowed to join in the new European Monetary Union. France, meanwhile, has elected a Socialist Government that has been far more hostile to the strict fiscal requirements of the euro, and its budget deficit is running much higher than economists had expected just a few months ago.
All of this has raised serious new doubts about the strength of the future euro. Analysts predict that Germany, with red ink of its own, will no longer be able to block weaker countries like Italy from taking part in the new monetary union.
"It looks like the European Monetary Union will occur and that it will be relatively wide, and this will keep alive doubts about the euro until the new European central bank establishes its credibility," said Kermit L. Schoenholtz, chief global economist for Salomon Brothers in London.
Other analysts argued today that the dollar was now one of the few good escape routes for investors skeptical of the euro who want to bail out of marks.
The other escape route is the British pound, which has also soared against the mark in recent months, in part because Britain is not expected to join the new monetary union. The pound has also been helped by Britain's comparatively strong economy and by the fact that the Bank of England, Britain's central bank, is widely expected to further raise interest rates to help cool off the overheated economy. The British currency, which closed today at 1.6821 to the dollar, down from 1.6946 on Friday, has even strengthened against the dollar in recent weeks.
But there is only so much money that can go into the pound. And the Italian lira and Spanish peseta, which had served as attractive targets for skeptics of the euro, are now considered overpriced. "The avenues for investors to bet on a soft euro have been closed off," Avinash Persaud, an economist at J. P. Morgan in London, said. "So those who want to sell Deutsche marks are now putting more money into dollars."
In late currency trading in New York today, the dollar traded at 1.7907 marks, up sharply from Friday's close of 1.7744. The dollar settled at 6.0680 French francs, up from 5.9885 on Friday.
Analysts say there are reasons to believe that the dollar could go even higher against European currencies in the weeks and months ahead. For one thing, European leaders have yet to demonstrate serious alarm about the depreciation of their currencies.
"Deep in their hearts, the Europeans are happy about the falling mark," Mr. Hormats of Goldman Sachs International said. "They are saying that they have to create more jobs and one of the few areas of hope is on the export side. If the dollar goes up, so much the better."

HEADLINE: I.M.F. Seeks Argentine Deal Linking Credit to Governing

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS 

 BODY:
In negotiations that could have a ripple effect throughout developing nations, the International Monetary Fund is offering for the first time to give its seal of approval to a country that agrees to improve its governing process instead of simply meeting strict economic targets.
The offer, now being discussed with Argentina, would make an I.M.F. line of credit dependent on such evidence of "good governance" as emphasizing spending on health and education, overhauling the tax system, improving court practices, strengthening private property rights and opening Government ledgers. 
 Until now, the fund's credit was pegged to holding the line on inflation, limiting budget deficits and the like.
If both parties agree on the arrangement, Argentina would have improved standing in private credit markets, allowing it to borrow at lower rates. Presumably, it would also attract more foreign investment since the changes sought by the I.M.F. would provide more protection for business.
The arrangement, if it works, could well serve as a model for developing countries in Latin America and possibly other areas, giving private business and investment a bigger share of the role that the monetary fund has played.
The offer grows out of Argentina's success in overcoming inflation and promoting the fastest growth in Latin America this year -- currently around 8 percent. It also reflects the decision in 1991 to peg the Argentine peso's value to to the United States dollar as well as the Government's willingness to embark on what the I.M.F.'s managing director, Michel Camdessus, has termed "the second generation of structural reform in Latin America."
The Argentine economy is forecast to grow 7 percent for the year with virtually no inflation, leaving the monetary fund with no grounds for seeking new pledges of conventional economic rectitude in exchange for credit promises.
Instead, Argentina would be given the right to borrow an as yet-undecided amount in exchange for a package of governing reforms.
The goal, I.M.F. officials predict, is to prolong Argentina's strong growth and further reduce poverty.
"These commitments will consolidate and extend the reforms we have already taken," Argentina's Economy Minister, Roque Fernandez, said in an interview in New York yesterday. "They give us more credibility. They are an international seal of approval."
Pablo Guidotti, the country's Treasury Minister, added, "We do not plan to draw the new loan because we have adequate access to private capital markets. But we need technical assistance from the I.M.F. for many of the changes we plan."
Under the emerging agreement, he said, the Government would give priority in public spending to improving the health and education of the work force. It would make public-spending accounts more open and create special courts to clear a backlog of tax disputes.
It would also reform the selection process for judges to give the impression of greater judicial independence. And it would make it easier for banks and other lenders to recover assets from borrowers in default.
The proposed agreement reflects the increased importance economists now attach to the quality of government as a means of encouraging development.
The I.M.F.'s sister finance agency, the World Bank -- in its latest World Development Report, published last month -- said that countries with sound governing practices and effective economic policies saw real income rise 3 percent a year in the three decades from 1963 to 1993.
For those with poor governing practices but good economic policies, the rise was 1.4 percent. And for those with poor ratings in both areas, the gain was a mere four-tenths of 1 percent.
In a speech to Argentine bankers in Buenos Aires in May, Mr. Camdessus said that the kinds of changes Argentina planned to make would allow nations to achieve "high-quality growth of the kind that will be genuinely sustainable over the long term."
While the widespread adoption of market-oriented economic policies in Latin America and the Caribbean has lifted average growth rates to around 5 percent from 1.5 percent in 1988, most countries have been unable to narrow the income gap with more economically advanced nations or make a significant dent in poverty rates, Mr. Camdessus said.
The answer, he contended, involved "reducing state intervention in the economy," as well as carrying out the sorts of changes that are now the subject of the talks with Argentina.

HEADLINE: Chicago Journal;
Once Stolid and Big-Shouldered, Now a Cinderella on the Lake

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, July 14

 BODY:
Property values are zooming. Crime is plunging. Unemployment is falling. The Bulls are reigning.
Test scores in the public schools are rising. And the 110-story Sears Tower has regained its status as the tallest building in the world, at least by some measures. 
 In this city that always has one eye on the mirror, the self-image of Chicago, as in "Sweet Home, Chicago," has lately been something to dance about.
Describing the mood of Chicagoans, Greg Longhini, the city's spokesman for the Department of Planning and Development, sounded a bit like James Brown:
"We feel good."
If not for the hapless Cubs (still in last place) and the shady politicians (five current or former Aldermen are among 13 people charged in a recent Federal investigation of corruption), it would seem that this capital of Middle America had lost its salt-of-the-earth demeanor.
It helps, of course, that it is summertime. With the music in Grant Park, the revelers at outdoor cafes on Rush Street and the sailboats on Lake Michigan, this city looks distinctly more charming than it does, say, in January, when hypothermal pedestrians cling desperately to light poles to avoid being swept away by the freezing wind.
But not even the infamous winter wind, known here as The Hawk, appears likely to chill the property market here.
It does not take a rocket scientist to figure out why Chicago is booming. In a national economy that seems almost too good to be true, the industrial Midwest is a regional leader. And this city is the financial and cultural center of the vast sweep across the heart of the nation.
Developers seem to be salivating at virtually every scrap of land in Chicago. Abandoned railroad property is being transformed into upscale housing. Even near public housing projects, new town houses are commanding prices of $350,000.
While many malls outside Chicago are struggling, suburbanites now flock to Michigan Avenue to shop on weekends. And many of them, weary of long commuting times to work, have been returning to live in the city.
Parts of the city do not seem so different from the suburbs anymore. Neighborhoods like Bucktown and Wicker Park, downright dangerous a decade ago, have become yuppie havens. Lincoln Park, once a hot spot for the young and hip, is now rich and staid. The 43d Ward, a nerve center for the antiwar movement in the 60's, now has Republican leanings.
This city still gets plenty of mileage out of the Big Shoulder image, the dominant Chicago cliche since Carl Sandburg coined the phrase in 1914.
In truth, it can be tough to find the old Chicago, the lunch-bucket, working-class town that jumped to the sound of factory whistles.
One of the greatest symbols of that plain-spoken ethos was Montgomery Ward, which started its mail order catalogue in 1872, a year after the Great Fire. Now in desperate straits, the company recently filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, and dismissed 400 people, or 20 percent of its staff at the corporate headquarters here.
Chicago these days, especially on the North Side and along the lakefront, is no longer a town filled with typical Montgomery Ward customers: sensible, no-frills shoppers who think twice before spending a hard-earned dollar.
Rather, it is the razzle-dazzle of North Michigan Avenue, the high-end stores along the Magnificent Mile, that has been setting the Chicago retail market on fire.
Unemployment has dropped below 6 percent, the lowest in more than 20 years. The fastest job growth is in the financial sector, including people who have grown suddenly rich in the high-flying stock market.
Chicago is gaining on the dirty rats, and not just the kind targeted by the prosecutor's office.
Rodents are dying off in this city. Not so long ago, rats outnumbered Chicagoans more than 2 to 1.
People strolling along Rush Street in the Gold Coast, a neighborhood of expensive brownstones and boutiques along the lakefront just north of downtown, sometimes crossed paths with the furry creatures -- which did not create the best kind of advertisement for tourists.
But an aggressive campaign to clean up neighborhoods and require tighter lids of garbage containers has cut the rat population to about 500,000, down from about 6 million in 1979, according to the city.
Chicago politics have become so peaceful they are almost boring, except, of course, for the corruption. During the 1980's, Chicago was called Beirut on the Lake for its political warring, often along racial lines.
For the last few years, this city has largely been getting the kind of ink that is better than advertisements, like the glowing reviews that surrounded last year's Democratic National Convention here.
Mayor Richard M. Daley, the son of the legendary boss of the Chicago machine, much prefers the role of efficient manager to ward politician. In his easy re-election in 1991, Mr. Daley won 25 percent of the black vote, up from the single-digit percentage in his first successful campaign for the office.
But one politician who thinks Mr. Daley is vulnerable is Representative Bobby Rush, a former Black Panther and later an influential alderman. A Democrat, he is considering a run against Mr. Daley next time around.
In the view of Mr. Rush, Chicago, under Mayor Daley, has evolved into two unequal societies. He sees the division not so much along racial lines as class ones. He says the Daley administration has used tax incentives to rebuild neighborhoods for the rich, while lining the pockets of developers, a pin-stripe patronage.
"He's trying to suburbanize Chicago," Mr. Rush said.
The City Council, however has presented Mayor Daley the younger, as he is sometimes called, with virtually no opposition. And he is reaping the rewards of the improvements in the city's fortunes.
 "He will be Mayor as long as he wants," said Paul Green, an author on Chicago politics and professor at Governors State University. "He has far more control over this city than his father ever had."

HEADLINE: Entrenched Hispanic Democrats Feel New Mexico's Sands Shifting

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: SANTA FE, N.M., July 10

 BODY:
For years, the hills and arroyos of northern New Mexico seemed to be an unchanging tableau of Hispanic farmers wedded to ancient irrigation ditches and to ancient political loyalties -- Democratic.
But in an electoral upset two months ago that still reverberates around the plazas here, northern New Mexico voters have sent to Washington a Congressman who is non-Hispanic, Protestant, Republican and born in Chicago. 
 In a three-way race to succeed Representative Bill Richardson, Bill Redmond, a nondenominational Christian minister, won the May 12 election in the state's Third District with 43 percent of the vote. Mr. Richardson, a Democrat of Mexican and New England ancestry, gave up the House seat in February to be the United States Ambassador to the United Nations. Holding his Congressional seat since it was created in 1982, Mr. Richardson had easily beaten Mr. Redmond in last November's election.
"Hispanics have controlled the politics of northern New Mexico for so many years -- what the heck happened?" asked Mayor Debbie Jaramillo of Santa Fe, a Hispanic Democrat who plans to challenge Mr. Redmond in next year's election. "I just can't close my eyes and pretend that he represents me."
Mr. Redmond's victory, a surprise to Republicans, is more than a triumph over high political odds. It is also part of a larger story of political, social and economic change being played out across the Southwest, particularly in New Mexico, as wealthy whites, known here as Anglos, have moved in, markedly changing the character of the area. For Hispanic leaders, angry at seeing their political power diluted here even as it grows in other parts of the nation, these changes, brought home by the election of Mr. Redmond, are cause for soul-searching.
In 1970, 65 percent of the surnames in Santa Fe were Spanish, but that number was down to 49 percent in 1990, according to the United States Census. Rising real estate prices and taxes have forced old Hispanic families to trade their adobe houses in the center of the city for trailers on its edge. With 60,000 residents, Santa Fe has about 200 art galleries, 300 restaurants and 800 real estate agents.
"The white people moved in, painted the town brown and moved the brown people out," Mayor Jaramillo once said.
But the well-known changes in Santa Fe are not the only reasons for the political shift here. High-tech industries have arrived in a big way, with the Intel Corporation opening a major manufacturing plant in Rio Rancho, just north of Albuquerque. Fast-growing Rio Rancho is a model of Sun Belt development and could soon displace Santa Fe as the district's largest city. Its demographics show an increasing number of voters who are evenly split between Republicans and Democrats, as well as expanding suburban neighborhoods of retirees drawn by the warm, dry weather.
In the northwest corner of the state, Farmington is the center of both a growing gas and oil industry and conservative politics. Republicans have long been strong in Los Alamos, the home of Mr. Redmond and of Energy Department laboratories. In the district's dry eastern flatlands, a region known as Little Texas, conservative politics flourishes among the cowboy twangs and military personnel.
Still, Mr. Redmond's victory comes in a district where registered Democrats outnumber registered Republicans two to one, and where the gradual swing of much of the West toward the Republican Party, with the notable exception of Denver and Boulder, Colo., had not taken hold.
But Democrats in New Mexico have found a new competitor, the Green Party, which has used its environmental agenda to siphon votes from Democrats in recent elections. Indeed, many here credit Mr. Redmond's victory to the strong showing by the Green Party candidate, Carol Miller. She won 17 percent of the vote, leaving the Democrat, Eric Serna, a longtime state official who spent more than twice as much as Mr. Richmond, with 40 percent.
In Santa Fe, Hispanic leaders are fighting the cultural changes, especially the transformation of the city into what some old-time residents grumble is "Santa Fake," with adobe architecture mandated for new construction. As Spanish fades from sidewalk conversations, and prices in high-end chain stores like Talbot and Ann Taylor keep locals away from the streets around the 17th-century central square, city officials have responded with an official community celebration each May called Take Back the Plaza Day.
"Children today do not speak Spanish -- in my grandmother's house, we were not allowed to speak English," said Frank Ortiz, a retired United States Ambassador to Peru who traces his family's presence in Santa Fe to 1607.
Like Mr. Ortiz, about a third of the voters in Mr. Redmond's district are Hispanic, many tracing their family's presence here back nearly four centuries. Some of the district's 21 Indian tribes date back 1,000 years. And for some with historic ties here, the Republican victory in the district is particularly bitter, especially when they consider the influence of the Green Party.
In this week's Santa Fe Reporter, a local weekly newspaper, Chris Roybal, a lifelong Democrat who traces his family's presence here to the days of Spanish kings, wrote: "We do not have the benefit of trust funds or the luxury of taking on causes that benefit the salvation of the whales far away at the expense of our own economic development and well-being here at home. We are here forever, as were our ancestors before us, loving and protecting our lands -- not just having a summer condo to live in during the good weather periods."
Hispanic, and Democratic, concern about the growing influence of the Green Party may well be justified. In the 1994 race for governor, a Green Party candidate won 10 percent, helping to insure victory for a Republican, Gary E. Johnson. In a setback to Mayor Jaramillo's hopes to run for the Congressional seat next year, Ms. Miller narrowly won Santa Fe in May and plans to run again in 1998.
Ms. Miller, a health care planner, spoke of a sour mood among many Hispanics here. " 'Spoiler' is what people say when they lose," she said. "We are stimulating democracy, helping the United States reach a more diverse political situation."
The Greens not only won Santa Fe, but also did well in Navajo areas and won the Indian pueblo of Taos, just north of the resort town.
"The Native American vote," Ms. Miller said, "is a cornerstone for building the Green Party.".
Noting that her party's platform had been translated into Navajo, she added, "My Indian friends told me they were tired of hearing that this was a Hispanic seat."
But the defeat of Mr. Serna, who regulates a variety of industries as a member of the New Mexico State Corporation Commission, has created ill feeling toward the Green Party among many Hispanic voters.
"A lot of people are mad at the Greens," said Sam Baca, a historic preservation worker whose family presence in Santa Fe goes back 13 generations. "They don't have a chance of winning, and they just serve to elect Republicans."
Hoping to make peace -- and win elections -- some Democrats want New Mexico to pass the kind of election law in effect in New York State, where a candidate can run on the ticket of more than one party. But Governor Johnson is expected to veto such a law if it reaches his desk.
"The Republicans are dancing in the streets," Attorney General Tom Udall, a Democrat, said of the Green Party's electoral strength. "It's elected a Republican Governor and a Republican Congressman in a heavily Democratic state. Why would they want to change that?"
Mr. Udall, who says he "is leaning" toward running against Mr. Redmond next year, knows that his family name could help him gain Indian support. His father, Stewart, and an uncle, Morris, promoted Indian affairs in the 1960's and 1970's. But as for the latest political force on the horizon, he vowed, "I intend to make peace with the Greens."
To win, Mr. Udall may well need to do so. "The district may be registered Democratic, but it is . . . very independent," Mr. Richardson said in a telephone interview from New York. "It is an eclectic Western constituency that can turn on you if you don't have the right message."
Indeed, some have called the district the nation's most diverse, pointing to the balkanization among the Indian tribes, conservative and liberal whites, and the Hispanic base.
In a rare point of agreement, Representative Redmond concurred with his predecessor.
"The people are more independent-minded in their politics than outsiders give them credit for," he said.

HEADLINE: Diet Pills: Allure and Risk

BYLINE: By GINA KOLATA 

 BODY:
DR. PIETR HITZIG of Timonium, Md., is so impressed with the diet pill combination fenfluramine and phentermine that he has given it to 8,000 people. In fact, he advertises on his web page that if you cannot make it to his office, he will prescribe the drugs anyway over the phone. There are no contraindications, his web page says.
Dr. Ben Z. Krentzman, a family practitioner, said he had come out of retirement last year to prescribe the pills. He began by advertising on the Internet and seeing patients in his living room. Now he has an office in Culver City, Calif., and is about to open two more, one in San Luis Obispo, Calif., and the other in Hawaii. So far, he said in an interview, he has given the drugs to 800 people. 
 Not since the amphetamine craze of the 1970's have diet pills swept the country like fen-phen, as the drug combination is known. Patients got 18 million new prescriptions and refills last year, said IMS America, which tracks drug sales.
But now, in the wake of new hints that the drug combination might be dangerous, some medical experts are asking what the nation has wrought. What does it say about the American medical system when millions of healthy people rush to take an untested combination of drugs for long periods of time? What are people willing to risk to be slim?
The evidence that the drug combination may be dangerous is preliminary, but leading cardiologists and obesity experts say they are alarmed. Last week, doctors at the Mayo Clinic and elsewhere reported that 35 women who had taken fenfluramine and phentermine had developed an unusual and serious heart-valve defect. Previous studies have linked fenfluramine and dexfenfluramine, a chemically purer version of the drug, to primary pulmonary hypertension, an often fatal condition in which the artery that feeds blood to the lungs becomes choked off.
Wyeth-Ayerst, one of two companies that make fenfluramine and the sole maker of dexfenfluramine, sold as Redux, sent out a news release saying it was working with the Mayo Clinic to further investigate the question of whether the fen-phen combination causes the heart valve defects but added that at this time the data were "limited and therefore not conclusive." In addition, said the company, a unit of the American Home Products Corporation, obesity itself "is associated with serious health disorders."
The Food and Drug Administration sent out a letter to thousands of doctors advising them of the valve defects but not telling doctors to take patients off the drugs.
Fenfluramine and phentermine are old drugs, approved two decades ago as short-term diet aids for the obese. Doctors started combining them only recently, after a four-year study of 121 obese people indicated that the combination could succeed where diets alone failed. Dr. Bernard Weintraub of the University of Rochester, who conducted the study, noted that the patients had not actually reached their ideal weights but that most had lost enough weight to lower their blood pressure and blood sugar levels. He suggested that obesity be treated as a chronic illness, with patients taking drugs for life.
But except for Dr. Weintraub's small study, no one has tested fenfluramine and phentermine together, and no one has looked for adverse effects when people take the drugs for long periods of time. In effect, said Dr. Alan L. Hillman, an internist and economist who is associate dean of the University of Pennsylvania School of Medicine, when doctors began prescribing the drugs en masse, they were conducting an uncontrolled experiment on millions of Americans. That was legal because doctors are free to prescribe approved drugs for any uses they please, but Dr. Hillman and others question whether it was wise.
When a nearly untested drug combination enters the obesity market in a country where people are willing to try almost anything that promises to help them shed pounds, Dr. Hillman said, "you have a potential disaster on your hands."
Of course, not every weight loss center freely prescribes the drugs. For example, Dr. Xavier Pi-Sunyer, director of the Van Itallie Center for Weight Loss and Maintenance at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital in New York City, said his center's doctors had prescribed the drugs for fewer than 5 percent of their patients.
And Dr. Adam Drewnowski, director of the Center for Human Nutrition at the University of Michigan, said that an overweight but not obese friend of his had gone to a weight loss clinic near Atlanta looking for the drugs but that the doctor at the weight loss center had refused to prescribe fen-phen for him.
But there is no doubt that some clinics have prescribed the drugs to huge numbers of people.
About 10,000 people visiting the 16 Los Angeles area offices of California Medical Weight Loss Associates have taken the drugs, said Aaron Baumann, the group's administrator. "This is L.A.," Mr. Baumann said. "People tend to want to be thinner than in the rest of the country." He said the drugs "work like magic." He himself takes them.
Some commercial diet centers have used the drugs to attract customers. Nutri-System, for example, advertised two months of free medication with either fen-phen or dexfenfluramine to dieters who switched to them from Jenny Craig, a competing chain of diet centers. Jenny Craig Inc. said on Thursday that it was recommending that doctors at its centers stop prescribing fen-phen. Nutri-System's vice president for scientific affairs, Dr. Joseph Di Bartolomeo, said yesterday that his company's medical advisers were studying the new data and that, in the meantime, the company was still prescribing the drugs.
The Internet is bristling with fen-phen advertisements, including one that rather mysteriously quotes "L.D., San Diego" as saying, "I lost 40 pounds in six weeks on fen-phen and had to force myself to eat." The web page adds, "It was so easy," and promises to tell more for $5.
Dr. Hitzig, Dr. Krentzman and others say they have prescribed the drugs to people with just a few pounds to lose. Dr. Hitzig's web page quotes a patient saying that until taking fen-phen, "no matter what I did, I could never shed that last 15 pounds." Dr. Hitzig also said he prescribed the drugs for people with eating disorders, who may not be overweight, as well as for alcoholics, cocaine addicts and people complaining of gulf war syndrome. But he noted that the vast majority of his patients wanted to lose weight.
Mr. Baumann, of California Medical Weight Loss Associates, said that doctors there prescribed the pills for people who are at least 20 percent above their ideal weights. "A lady who weighs 120 and should weigh 100 pounds is obese," he said. But he added, "You might not look at her and say she is obese."
Mr. Baumann and others whose medical centers have prescribed the drugs widely said they had not seen any patients with heart damage. But cardiologists say the damage is not easy to spot.
"The first step is that you have to be aware of the connection," said Dr. Jeffrey Isner, a cardiologist at Tufts University School of Medicine. If a young woman comes in complaining of shortness of breath and fatigue -- signs of a heart valve defect -- most primary care doctors would look at other possible causes first. The woman would most likely be overweight, which could account for her symptoms, Dr. Isner said. "You may not think to inspect the cardiac system that carefully," he added. Now, of course, examining a fen-phen patient's heart "jumps to the top of the list," and doctors would be likely to order echocardiograms to examine patients' heart valves.
The same goes for primary pulmonary hypertension, Dr. Isner added. The initial symptom is shortness of breath. Since the condition is so rare that doctors may have never seen it, few would think to do an angiogram -- injecting dye into the arteries -- which is the only definitive test for pulmonary hypertension. In a recent study in France documenting the association between fenfluramine alone or dexfenfluramine and primary pulmonary hypertension, the researchers noted that it took a year, on average, from the onset of symptoms until a correct diagnosis.
Doctors at some medical centers say they are starting to examine fen-phen patients for heart valve problems. "We've called all our patients who were on it," said Dr. Albert Stunkard, an obesity researcher at the University of Pennsylvania who said that the university's obesity center had prescribed the drugs for 20 patients.
But some doctors who enthusiastically prescribe the drugs say they are not worried. "It's stupid to bring patients in for an echocardiogram," Dr. Krentzman said. "That's a very expensive procedure." The risk is not established, he said, adding that none of his patients had experienced problems with the drugs.
Dr. Christian Renna, a doctor with offices in Dallas and in Los Angeles, who says he has prescribed fen-phen for hundreds of patients, said, "I am not worried about the use of these medications." Rather, he said, "I am worried about the public's reaction."
Dr. Hitzig said he simply modified the dose of the medications if people start to have problems, thereby preventing serious ill effects. "Every side effect I've seen, to my current state of knowledge, is an indicator to modify the dose," he said. When it comes to serious problems, he said, "we abort them before they happen."

SECTION: Section C; Page 11; Column 4; Cultural Desk

HEADLINE: Finding Government Profit in Aid to the Arts

BYLINE: By RICK LYMAN 

 BODY:
Government support for the arts in New York State is a low-risk, high-yield investment that in taxes recovers several times its cost and generates billions of dollars in related economic benefits, says a government-commissioned study to be released today.
The study, conducted over the last year by McKinsey & Company at the request of the New York State Council on the Arts and the City of New York's Department of Cultural Affairs, is an admitted attempt to make a case for giving the arts financial help and to counter arguments that such help is elitist and a drain on public funds. 
 It is being released just as support for the arts is under attack in Washington. This month, the House of Representatives voted to abolish the National Endowment for the Arts, then stripped it of $10 million in shutdown costs and rejected a compromise to replace it with block grants to the states. The agency's fate will be decided in negotiations with the Senate and the White House, which are somewhat more sympathetic to Federal money for the arts.
"The idea behind the report is to offer a businessman's approach to this, something that you just could not quarrel with," said Reba White Williams, a member of the state arts council. "If it's returning a great benefit to the state, then you can't argue with it."
The study, titled "You Gotta Have Art," found that $197 million was spent on the arts in 1995 by Federal, state, county and city agencies in New York State, while the arts generated $761 million in taxes, although obviously much of the taxes would have been collected even if government had spent nothing on the arts.
New York City spending on the arts that year was $91 million, while city tax revenues from the arts were $221 million. The report said that $65 million in state support helped generate $480 million in state taxes.
The study was based in part on a report by the Alliance for the Arts, to be released shortly, that concludes that the total economic impact of the arts on New York State in 1995 was $13.4 billion. That figure includes direct spending on the arts, as well as secondary spending on restaurants, parking and other services and the effect of the money circulating through the economy.
A study by the alliance in 1993, covering New York City and its suburbs in New York State and New Jersey, found that the arts had a regional economic impact of $9.8 billion.
"I hope these reports will help both the public and private sector to realize that financial support for the arts is an investment, not a charitable contribution," said Schuyler G. Chapin, the city's Cultural Affairs Commissioner. "Hopefully, this is the kind of thing that will put real teeth into our often stated position that the arts are a huge economic engine."
The study being released today was not designed as a guidebook for public investment in the arts. Though it acknowledges that not all spending on the arts has economic benefits, it concentrates on the successes.
Instead, the study is intended to make the case for more money for the arts and to change the terms of the political debate over government spending.
"Frequently, public spending on the arts is viewed as 'support' or 'charity,' for some vague benefits related to the cultural importance of the arts," the study says. "We disagree with this narrow point of view."
Instead, the study concludes, government spending on the arts should be viewed as an investment. More money should be spent on the arts because it is a sound way to spend the public's money, generating taxes, jobs and economic growth far in excess of the amounts invested.
The study, which McKinsey undertook without charge, was based on an analysis of state and local records and field work around the state on the effects of government spending in specific instances.
It concludes that not only has government spending generated economic and social benefits, but that there remains considerable room for growth in the arts.
"We believe that New York State, including New York City and even Manhattan, is substantially unsaturated in terms of both supply of and demand for the arts," the report said. "We believe that there is a large untapped audience for the arts in New York State."
Just over 183,000 people in New York say their primary occupation is artist, about 2 percent of the state labor force. The report estimated that 180,000 to 270,000 people are "nonartistic employees" of arts organizations.
The presence of all of these artists has other benefits, the report said, providing a pool of creative people who can move into commercial sectors, generating business opportunities, increasing real estate values, improving the quality of life and revitalizing cities and neighborhoods.
"I was most excited by some of the case studies, showing how a very small amount of seed money from the government, a little venture capital, revitalized whole communities and neighborhoods," Ms. Williams said.
While state and local support for the arts has risen slightly in New York State in the last two years, the report found that such spending had declined 25 percent since 1990. At the same time, Federal money for the arts in the state fell precipitately, to $10 million in 1996 from $33 million in 1993. Whatever the outcome of the debate in Washington, further cuts are expected.
"We also found a decrease in support from private donors, perhaps out of this concern that the arts are elitist," Ms. Williams said. "We hope this will help convince them to give more."

HEADLINE: Francois Furet, Historian, 70; Studied the French Revolution

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING 

DATELINE: PARIS, July 15

 BODY:
Francois Furet, a prominent historian who challenged the popular Marxist interpretation of the French Revolution and reshaped French thinking about subsequent events, died on Saturday in a hospital in Toulouse. He was 70.
He had received a head injury while playing tennis a few days earlier, his family said. 
 Mr. Furet, who for 12 years had spent each autumn at the University of Chicago as a member of the Committee on Social Thought, was considered one of the most influential French thinkers of the postwar era, a reputation consolidated by the enormous European success of his most recent book, published in 1995, "The History of an Illusion: An Essay on the Idea of Communism in the 20th Century."
But it was his lifelong fascination with the French Revolution and his many books on it that earned him a special place among historians. He won both admirers and critics with his conceptual approach to history, in which he preferred to overlook minute detail in favor of political and philosophical analysis.
This led him first to question and then to undermine the Marxist interpretation of the revolution, which in the 1960's and 70's was still widely taught in French schools and universities. According to this view, which glorified the revolution, an attempt by a rising urban bourgeoisie to overthrow the monarchy led within four years to the Terror and the possibility of a proletarian takeover, although it was later blocked by the bourgeoisie.
Mr. Furet's rejection of this approach in a sense reflected his own experience of the left. Like many intellectuals of his generation, he belonged to the French Communist Party in his 20's but resigned in protest after the Soviet invasion of Hungary in 1956. "It was the most intelligent thing I did in my life," he later said.
He challenged what he called the "revolutionary catechism," arguing that democratic ideals existed as early as 1781 and were based less on class struggle than on breaking up the highly centralized power of the state. In this way, he chopped away at revolutionary myths about France that had lasted into this century. "The French Revolution is over," he liked to proclaim.
"Thanks to his talent, his strong opinions and his moral courage, he was the man who changed the revolution in the spirit of intellectuals and eventually in the spirit of all French," Laurent Joffrin wrote today in the left-of-center daily Liberation in an article with the headline, "He Remade the Revolution."
Although frequently denounced as reactionary by the left, Mr. Furet did not embrace the ultraconservative position of French Catholics and monarchists, who came to view the revolution as a precursor of Stalinist totalitarianism. Rather, he took a firmly centrist position on both the Revolution and contemporary politics.
"He was responsible, more than anyone else, for the revival of liberal thinking in France," said Nathan Tarcov, professor of political science at the University of Chicago. "He championed the European concept of liberalism, one that honors democracy, individual rights and a mixed economy. His own work and teaching spanned political theory, history and literature."
Born in Paris on March 27, 1927, into a wealthy family, Mr. Furet was a brilliant student who graduated from the Sorbonne with the highest honors and soon decided on a life of research, teaching and writing. In 1961 he entered the School of Higher Studies of Social Science and was president from 1977 to 1985. Then he joined the faculty at the University of Chicago and became the founding director of the Raymond Aron Institute in Paris.
He was a prolific writer, publishing at least 13 major studies, notably "The French Revolution" (1964), "Interpreting the French Revolution" (1978), "Marx and the French Revolution" (1986), "The Revolution 1770-1880" (1988) and A Critical Dictionary of the French Revolution (1988), of which he was co-editor with Mona Ozouf. Many of his books were published in English and were influential in British and American universities.
In March this year, he was elected a member of the Academie Francaise, although he died before he could take his seat. His first marriage ended in divorce. He is survived by his second wife, Deborah, and two children, Antoine and Charlotte. He was buried on Monday in a private ceremony near his country home in the village of St.-Pierre-Toirac in southern France.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Francois Furet. (Agence France-Presse, 1995)

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
German Remarks Halt Dollar, But It Climbs Strongly vs. Yen

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
After briefly touching a six-year high, the dollar retreated yesterday against the mark as Germany's Finance Minister called the United States currency's strength excessive. But the dollar rose strongly against the yen on comments from Japan's foreign-exchange policy maker.
The remarks by Germany's Finance Minister, Theo Waigel, were surprisingly blunt and suggested the possibility of coordinated intervention by central banks to cap the dollar, which has accelerated on growing doubts about the credibility of the single European currency. 
 Mr. Waigel said the rise in the dollar and the British pound against the mark in recent weeks reflected an "overreaction of markets."
He also reiterated his belief that Germany would meet the euro's strict fiscal standards and said the German Government would have more to say about the mark's exchange rate today.
"I think Waigel pretty effectively put a lid on things," said Jan Alvarez, senior currency dealer at Corestates Bank in Philadelphia.
Still, despite Mr. Waigel's veiled hint of central bank intervention, analysts and traders remained skeptical that such action would occur, limiting the dollar's slide.
The dollar reached an intraday high of 1.8035 marks, the strongest since August 1991 and second consecutive six-year high, before pulling back on Mr. Waigel's remarks to settle at 1.7920 marks in New York, up from 1.7907 on Monday.
The dollar also reached an intraday high of 115.98 yen, the strongest since June 6, before settling in New York at 115.53 yen, up from 114.05 yen on Monday. The pound settled at $1.6779, down from $1.6821.
The dollar strengthened against the yen early in the trading day after Eisuke Sakakibara, the new Vice Finance Minister and Japan's foreign-exchange policy maker, said he did not think that Japan's trade surplus would rise significantly this year and that Japanese surpluses would not aggravate trade frictions.
Mr. Sakakibara's remarks came three days before the United States reports its trade balance for May. Currency traders have been reluctant to push the dollar higher against the yen on fear that Japan's surpluses will continue to grow.

HEADLINE: Nafta Is About Foreign Relations, Not Jobs

 BODY:

To the Editor:
The "modest positive effect" of the North American Free Trade Agreement -- reported by the Clinton Administration last week and derided by Representative David E. Bonior (Op-Ed, July 13) -- disappoints only those who believed the Administration's pro-Nafta hyperbole. A modest positive effect, while remarkable given the 1994 peso crisis, is exactly what most economists predicted. 
 Unfortunately, both sides continue to assess Nafta in terms of jobs. As the economist Paul Krugman and others have observed, phasing out our already low tariffs (about 3.5 percent on average) has had little to do with United States employment, which is fundamentally determined by the discount rate. The economy is now at full employment neither because of nor in spite of freer trade with Mexico.
The pact's importance lies in foreign relations, not economics. In this sense, Nafta has already paid dividends: Mexico's recent successful elections show the country is living up to expectations that as a trade partner it play by "first world" rules.
 
PAUL KANTZ
Washington, July 14, 1997
 
The writer has taught international business at the Monterrey Institute of Technology in Mexico.

HEADLINE: Resisting Reform in Kenya

 BODY:
Across Africa, people are demanding greater democracy and condemning corrupt governments that cheat them out of economic growth. The latest protests have erupted in Kenya, where the autocratic regime established by Jomo Kenyatta in the 1960's has continued, with deepening corruption, under President Daniel arap Moi since 1978.
Oblivious to Africa's new climate, Mr. Moi has responded, as ever, with brute force. In this he ignores a new sensitivity to democracy among the Western countries he counts on to provide aid and encourage investment and trade. The Clinton Administration and its European partners need to remind Mr. Moi that Kenya risks losing this crucial support if it continues to meet reasonable demands with violent repression. 
 For years Kenya's opposition leaders and human rights activists have braved police beatings, long prison sentences and even death threats to press for broader political rights. Five years ago, after their efforts were backed by a brief suspension of Western aid, Mr. Moi agreed to multiparty elections. He survived that challenge, even though he failed to win a majority of the votes. Opposition divisions and electoral regulations favoring the ruling party preserved his grip on power.
With new elections due this year, opposition groups are campaigning for constitutional changes that would give them a realistic chance of winning. Their efforts have attracted broad public support, and a harsh police response. In the past two weeks, Kenyan police have attacked unarmed demonstrators with guns, clubs, whips and ax handles and invaded the sanctuaries of churches and universities. At least nine protesters have been killed.
Kenya's crisis is an early test for the Clinton Administration's newly declared approach to Africa, unveiled just before last month's economic summit meeting in Denver. The new policy links the extension of investment incentives and other forms of assistance to efforts by recipient countries to increase democracy, combat corruption and extend economic reform.
Other nations represented at Denver are moving in parallel directions. Britain, closely linked to Kenya since colonial times, has a new Labor Government that is emphasizing democracy and human rights issues in its diplomacy. Germany, another large donor, said this week that continued assistance to Kenya would depend on Mr. Moi's respect for "democratic, pluralist and constitutional rules in political debate." One clear lesson from past policy failures in Africa is that far more attention must be given to the internal practices of governments receiving significant Western support. Kenya is a good place to start.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Commercial Real Estate;
A New Hotel Is Out of the Way but Fits Right In

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA 

DATELINE: MOUNT OLIVE, N.J., July 10

 BODY:
When builders of the Wyndham Garden Hotel here dedicated the structure, they happily reported that occupancy rates in the first few weeks of operation had been unexpectedly high. "In the second week after opening, we had sellouts," said Dave Johnson, senior vice president for operations at the Wyndham Hotel Corporation. "That has not happened before."
This would seem an unlikely location for a hotel, a rural stretch of wooded hill country adjacent to Interstate 80, about 50 miles west of New York City. But it is part of the International Trade Center, a 670-acre business park that is home to companies employing nearly 6,000 people -- about the population of the entire township when I-80 was built here 30 years ago. 
 "The hotel was part of the original master plan," said Leslie E. Smith Jr., executive director of the center. He said businesses located in the center need a place for visitors to stay and the nearest comparable lodgings are in Parsippany, which is about 25 miles away.
Indeed, he said the BASF Group, the German chemical giant, insisted that the center commit to building a hotel before the company would agree to move its North American headquarters here, with about 2,000 employees.
Business travelers have shown up as expected, but what has surprised the developers is the local demand for rooms for out-of-town visitors attending social events, like parties and athletic events. "The local community has taken this place to heart," said Jonathan D. Green, president of the Rockefeller Center Development Corporation, a division of the Rockefeller Group, which owns 90 percent of the trade center and the affilated office park.
When the hotel opened for business on June 9, its executives expected to rent no more than 30 rooms, said Carlos Molinet, the hotel's general manager. Instead, more than 60 were occupied. "We had told the companies in the park what our opening date was, and they believed us," he said.
With a weekday room rate of $105 a night, including breakfast, the Wyndham Garden is positioned slightly above a midscale business hotel in the suburban market, Mr. Green said. The developers own the building, which is operated by Wyndham Hotels & Resorts.
The hotel, which was built in 12 months, has 141 rooms, including eight suites, in a five-story building. An attached one-story building holds a restaurant, an indoor swimming pool and a meeting room that can hold up to 300 people.
The hotel is the latest amenity added to the trade center, about half of which is reserved for the New Jersey Foreign Trade Zone. The zone is, in effect, a duty-free port connected to the ocean by I-80. Companies operating in the zone are mostly warehouse and light manufacturing operations, while the rest of the center is occupied by office tenants.
Among the companies in the trade center are BMW of North America, Calvin Klein Cosmetics, Lucent Technologies and the Shell Oil Company.
In operation since 1982, the center is about half developed, with 3.5 million square feet of the permitted 7 million square feet of space completed. Most of the buildings are owned by the center and occupied by tenants on long-term leases.
Mr. Smith bought the land where the center is located from a visionary developer named Andrew Clark, who assembled the site in the 1950's when the Interstate System of highways was still in the planning stages. Mr. Clark believed that the highways would promote commerce the way railroads had in the 1800's and that because of them, free ports could easily be located inland. "He knew that Route 80 was going somewhere near here, but he never expected that it would go right through the property as it did," Mr. Smith said.
When Mr. Clark retired, Mr. Smith bought the property and recruited the Rockefeller company as an investor, retaining a 10 percent interest in the project for himself. "I was a local real estate developer who was looking for an international equity partner," he said.
The first tenant, the Seiko Corporation, was signed up in 1982, Mr. Smith said, adding that "15 years and 2 recessions later, we are still together."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The operators of the Wyndham Garden Hotel have been surprised by its high occupancy rates. (Lenore Victoria Davis for The New York Times)
 
Map of Morris County showing location of the International Trade Center: The Wyndham Garden Hotel is part of a 670-acre business park.
