HEADLINE: U.N. Renews Censure of New Israeli Housing in East Jerusalem

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, July 15

 BODY:
For the third time in four months, the General Assembly adopted a resolution today condemning Israel for continuing to build housing in disputed territories.
The resolution asked Israel to identify products produced in those areas, with the intention of calling for a boycott. It also made a vaguely worded but clear threat to Israeli rights within the United Nations. 
 The resolution was approved by a vote of 131 to 3, with 14 abstentions. Only Micronesia voted with Israel and the United States against the resolution.
The action brought immediate criticism from Israeli and American envoys, who accused the General Assembly of reverting to the anti-Israeli crusades of the cold-war era.
"This session represents an approach which threatens to turn the clock back decades, undermining the painstaking efforts of the international community in three vital areas: the work of the United Nations, the work of humanitarian organizations and the work of all those involved in the peace process," said Dore Gold, the new Israeli representative at the United Nations, who arrived in New York this morning and had not yet presented his credentials.
He spoke as a special envoy of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu.
Bill Richardson, the American representative, repeated Clinton Administration criticisms of Israeli building of a housing complex called Har Homa on a site in East Jerusalem that Arabs call Jabal Abu Ghneim. But Mr. Richardson said hints of a boycott ran counter to a pledge by Middle Eastern countries to improve economic relations. He called the threat to Israeli membership in the United Nations "a throwback to the ugly credentials challenges of past decades."
In an interview after speaking to the Assembly, Mr. Gold, a scholar of the Middle East and of American strategic interests there, said the Palestinian leadership had always "looked over its shoulder" at the United Nations as a fallback.
"When the issues in the peace process are relatively easier -- Israel withdrawing from the Gaza Strip and Jericho -- and things run relatively smoothly, that's one thing," Mr. Gold said. "As the process becomes more difficult, it can be expected that there will be an attempt by the Palestinians to bring every impasse to the United Nations and to the international community. We believe very strongly that the attempt to build bypass roads away from direct negotiations is doomed to fail."
The issue of Israeli housing construction and the United Nations response has already drawn Secretary General Kofi Annan into a diplomatic impasse and cost him an Israeli rebuff.
Mr. Annan recently proposed sending the head of the United Nations Department of Political Affairs, Kieran Prendergast of Britain, to Israel on a fact-finding mission before submitting a report requested by the Assembly in April.
Israel objected to the plan, which had to be called off. Unable to send a mission, Mr. Annan depended on unnamed sources in the field for information in compiling his report.
In his speech today, Mr. Gold accused United Nations relief agencies of gathering information for the Secretary General in the region in contravention of their assigned tasks.
"U.N. member states support such agencies so they can help refugees and coordinate aid projects," Mr. Gold said. "The use of such assistance and funding for political ends raises serious concerns. It also threatens to harm the cooperation between host states and U.N. agencies, which is essential to their effective functioning."
Mr. Gold also called the Secretary General's report "hostile and one-sided."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Sales Figures Fail to Move Treasuries

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury securities were flat to slightly higher after yesterday's release of retail sales data for June. The report appeared strong at first, leading investors to sell securities, but after deducting auto sales, the number was less imposing.
June sales rose five-tenths of 1 percent, which was more than expected. But excluding autos, sales were weaker than anticipated. The May sales data were revised downward to a decline of three-tenths of 1 percent, from a drop of a tenth of 1 percent as first reported. A gain of two-tenths of 1 percent was expected. 
 The 30-year bond gained 4/32 , to a price of 101 4/32 , in what many traders said was a dull summer session. The yield was 6.54 percent, down from 6.55 percent on Monday.
"Though retail sales rebounded off weakness in March, April and May, the rise does not suggest the consumer has come back with a vengeance," said Kim Rupert, an economist with Standard & Poor's MMS.
She said the data were not strong enough to cause the Federal Reserve to act on rates. In fact, she said, almost no one whom her company had surveyed expected a tightening in August, and yesterday's data should not change those opinions.
"With inflation staying tame, the Fed seems to have the luxury of waiting," Ms. Rupert said. "However, the Fed is not completely out of the picture. We and a slight majority of our survey participants expect a September rate hike."
There is some concern that prices of government securities may be topping and that the dollar will run out of steam, causing foreign investors to stem the flow of cash here, which has kept rates lower.
But Maury N. Harris, chief economist at Paine Webber Inc., said, "The Federal Reserve System should not view the preliminary June retail sales recovery as being part of anything strong like the strong January-February demand conditions that ultimately triggered a round of Fed tightening of short-term interest rates at the end of March."
Regarding the trading environment, Jack Regan, chief derivatives strategist at Josephthal, Lyon & Ross, said: "Bonds are at a point where they need something significant -- a statement or economic data that would be so bullish it would take the yield on the long bond through the 6.50 percent level. Meanwhile, we'll be trading in a narrow band of between 6.50 percent and 6.75 percent until inflation is proved to be nonexistent or the fear of its resumption occurs."
This afternoon, the Treasury is to announce the size of next week's two- and five-year note auctions.
"At this juncture, supply does not pose a problem for the market, which up until now has absorbed everything," Mr. Regan said. "One factor that could impact the bond market is if earnings data from equity markets come in on the strong side. This could be another element that could be somewhat disquieting for the fixed-income market."
Also, some investors are skittish about buying securities with so many economic statistics still to come this month. The market consensus for today's report on the Consumer Price Index for June is a rise of two-tenths of 1 percent over all, with the core rate advancing three-tenths of 1 percent. If those numbers are in line with expectations, some investors may turn to the industrial production and capacity utilization report, also scheduled today, for direction.
Another factor is a heavy supply of new corporate issues, as companies take advantage of the environment for low interest rates.
The Chrysler Corporation priced $500 million of 100-year bonds through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers yesterday.
The issue, which is rated A-3 by Moody's Investors Service and A by Standard & Poor's, is callable in 90 years. It was given a 7.40 percent coupon and priced at 99.914 to yield 7.406 percent, about 82 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, more than the 6.50 percent Treasury bond due in November 2026.

HEADLINE: June Rise Ends 3-Month Retail Sales Slump

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 15

 BODY:
Retailers rang up their first increase in sales in four months during June, the Commerce Department said today, as consumers spent more freely after a spring lull.
Total retail sales increased five-tenths of a percent, to a seasonally adjusted $210.3 billion, helped by a surprising pickup in new-car sales. The June rise comes after a revised drop in May of three-tenths of 1 percent. 
 Analysts said that last month's increase reflected a modest revival in consumer demand, enough to fuel continued economic growth but not enough to fan fears of inflationary price rises that might cause the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates in an effort to slow the economy.
"It's not explosive by any means," said Robert Dederick, economic consultant to the Northern Trust Company in Chicago. "But as the weather warmed, consumers' spending propensities seemed to warm as well."
May sales were originally reported to have been down one-tenth of a percent, while April sales, previously reported to have fallen nine-tenths of a percent, instead dropped a revised 1.1 percent. March sales fell three-tenths of a percent.
The Commerce Department said that June sales by new-car dealers climbed 1.1 percent after a 1.2 percent decline in May. That was a surprise because auto makers had earlier reported feeble June sales and that weakness had been expected to be a drag on overall retail business.
Analysts said dealers might have been selling cars from their inventories in June; some of the car makers themselves were hurt by strikes that held down production earlier this year.
Even without automobiles, the overall trend in retail sales was firm in June. Excluding new cars, retail sales rose a relatively modest three-tenths of a percent, after being flat in May and declining six-tenths of a percent in April.
Sales of all types of durable goods, from cars to refrigerators and furniture, rose five-tenths of a percent, to $85.1 billion, after a drop of nine-tenths of a percent in May. Sales of nondurables, like food and clothing, were up four-tenths of a percent last month, to $125.2 billion, after rising one-tenth of a percent in May.
"The modest rise in June retail sales suggests that the slump in household spending may have ended and consumption expenditures are rising at a moderate pace as the economy heads into the third quarter," said Joel Naroff, an economist in Philadelphia for the First Union Corporation of Charlotte, N.C.
Sales by general merchandise stores rose eight-tenths of a percent, to $27.5 billion, after a gain of five-tenths of a percent in May. At apparel stores, clothing sales were flat in June, at $9.6 billion, but that was after a sturdy 1.2 percent jump in May.
Strong job growth and rising incomes are widely expected to lead to a further recovery in consumer spending, which accounts for two-thirds of national economic activity.
"The extent of the rebound will be the key in determining Federal Reserve policy," Mr. Naroff said. The Fed last raised short-term interest rates, by a quarter of a percentage point, on March 25.
The central bank's policy-making committee is next scheduled to meet Aug. 19. The Fed held rates steady at its last two policy-setting sessions, in May and this month, amid signs that inflation remained muted.

HEADLINE: Centrist Democrats Give Warm Welcome to Mayor

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE 

 BODY:
The 25 prominent centrist Democrats who gathered at a midtown conference room for lunch yesterday had no interest in meeting any of the bona fide Democrats running for mayor. Instead, they lavished a warm reception on the one Republican in the race -- Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani -- even calling him a "first cousin" to a Bill Clinton Democrat.
With admiration in their eyes, the trustees of the Progressive Policy Institute, the think tank of the moderate Democratic Leadership Council that President Clinton helped found, nodded appreciatively as Mr. Giuliani told them how many people he had removed from welfare rolls and how far crime had fallen. They asked how long it would be before he gained full control of the schools, and why the city did not understand his ideas about promoting sports franchises. 
 And if there was an actual partisan mayoral race going on somewhere in the distance, they did their best to ignore it.
"This was not about the Mayor's re-election; this was about talking to one of the real innovators in public office," said Al From, the president of the Democratic Leadership Council, which, in the view of many New York Democrats, is not centrist, but right of center. "The principles that he enunciated today were very reflective of the New Democratic philosophy. The concept of mutual responsibility he talked about is at the core of what we think the new social compact should be, almost in exactly the terms that he described it."
What the Mayor had talked about was one of his favorite topics: the need for citizens who receive government benefits to give something back to society in exchange, as in his workfare program, the country's largest. It is similar to the philosophy that helped get President Clinton elected and re-elected, but it is not a major plank of any of the Democrats running against the Mayor, who have mostly focused on what they say are the inequities in the workfare program, and Mr. Giuliani's difficulty connecting with those at the lower end of the economic spectrum.
As a result, none of those candidates, including Ruth W. Messinger, who is considered the front-runner, have generated any interest within this wing of their own party, which has always been far more influential at a national level than it has been at the state or city level.
"Ruth's failure to move to the center has cost her the support of national Democrats who see Giuliani as a Clintonlike leader," said Fred Siegel, a fellow at the institute and a professor at Cooper Union, who attended yesterday's luncheon.
Ms. Messinger has actually tried to move a bit away from her base in the party's left wing, accepting the idea of workfare even as she argues against Mr. Giuliani's version of it, making overtures to business groups, favoring certain tax cuts. But the Mayor's successful romance with the Clinton wing of the party -- in which his halfhearted endorsement of Bob Dole last year was forgiven -- dramatized the difficulty that she and the other Democrats will have in redefining Mr. Giuliani away from the ideological middle.
Mr. From's group, for example, has been active in making the Democratic Party take a tougher stand on law enforcement issues, backing Mr. Clinton in signing a major crime bill in his first term, and reduced crime rates have been Mr. Giuliani's most highly touted achievement. It has strongly supported a work requirement for welfare recipients, demonstrated in Mr. Clinton's signing of the welfare law last year, and workfare is the program that the Mayor says is actually his most important change to the city's culture.
In his remarks yesterday, in fact, he even found a way to tie the two issues together. "The reason I believe that crime has continued to decline beyond levels that I thought were possible is that massive movement of 265,000 people who used to be dependent on the government who are now finding ways to take care of themselves," he said, without fully explaining how one issue affects the other. "That really transformed the community. That, I think, is the most exciting change we've made."
The Democratic candidates did not seem terribly surprised that they were not invited to attend.
"Obviously, we disagree with Mr. From's analysis," said Leland T. Jones, the spokesman for Ms. Messinger. "We would just hope that as we move through this election, he and his colleagues at the D.L.C. keep an open mind as we make our argument and present our critique."
The Rev. Al Sharpton, who is also vying to be the Democrat to challenge Mr. Giuliani, said that the moderate Democrats he described as "Demo-publicans" had long ago migrated to Mr. Giuliani's camp and that his base was the only hope of unseating Mayor Giuliani.

HEADLINE: KPMG Abused Its Relationship With Audit Client, Judge Rules

BYLINE: By REED ABELSON 

 BODY:
A New York judge ruled yesterday that KPMG Peat Marwick, one of the nation's largest accounting firms, had abused its relationship with one of its audit clients. The suit, brought by Stern Stewart & Company, a New York consulting firm, accused KPMG of using its position as the firm's long-term auditor and tax accountant to create a rival business.
The case illustrates the kind of conflicts that arise when accounting firms venture outside their traditional lines of business. KPMG had served as Stern Stewart's accountant for more than a decade before setting up a unit that offered the same kind of economic analysis conducted by Stern Stewart. That firm learned of KPMG's actions after KPMG had created the unit and hired a number of Stern Stewart's employees. 
 "At bottom, the claim is that a fiduciary, learning of a profitable area of economic practice, acted in violation of its fiduciary obligations," Justice Diane A. Ledebeff of the State Supreme Court in Manhattan said in her ruling. "A fiduciary is not entitled to engage in an actual secretive competitive venture when still in the embrace of an active relationship with a principal. The court finds that Peat Marwick's conduct violated these principles."
Noting that KPMG "had access to a large number of Stern Stewart's confidential documents including financial statements and employee information," the judge found that the accounting firm demonstrated "an absolute assurance" that this area of economic consulting had a potential for "explosive' growth." That assurance of the unit's profitability, Justice Ledebeff said, "ominously bespeaks of inside knowledge."
The court awarded no actual damages in the lawsuit, although a separate trial may look into the possibility of punitive damages.
G. Bennett Stewart 3d, senior partner for Stern Stewart, applauded the court's ruling. "There are ethical boundaries within which accounting firms should be operating," he said.
The lawsuit aside, the situation with KPMG suggests the profession needs to take a closer look at how firms handle possible conflicts with their clients, said Arthur W. Bowman, the editor of Bowman's Accounting Report, an industry newsletter in Atlanta. KPMG "should have resigned from the engagement," he said.
KPMG maintains that it had no fiduciary relationship with Stern Stewart but merely a professional one. "We are always sensitive to business-client issues," said George Ledwith, a KPMG spokesman, and KPMG regrets "any misunderstanding" between it and its former client.
Stern Stewart had also accused KPMG of misappropriating trade secrets, unfair competition, stealing key employees and inducing those employees to breach confidentiality agreements and other contractual obligations. The court rejected those claims.
"We are generally pleased with the outcome," Mr. Ledwith said. "The court has rejected all the claims against individuals and all but one against KPMG."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Earnings Rise at Citicorp And at Chase Manhattan
The nation's biggest banks, Chase Manhattan and Citicorp, reported big gains in earnings for the second quarter despite disappointments in their credit card businesses. 
 But Wells Fargo and Banc One said their profits fell, hurt by costs from the acquisitions of First Interstate and First USA. [Page D2.]
 
Trouble Deepens for Kia Motors
Kia Motors, which makes the Sportage utility vehicle, was effectively placed under bankruptcy protection, becoming the fourth big South Korean conglomerate, and the biggest yet, to collapse or nearly collapse this year. [D6.]
 
Stocks Again Set Records
Stocks continued their march into the record books, bolstered by rising optimism over corporate earnings. A strong report by Texas Instruments accelerated the move into technology shares, and the Nasdaq composite index soared 18.23 points, to 1,542.11. The Dow industrials rose 52.73 points, to 7,975.71. [D6.]
 
Strong Profits on Wall Street
Earnings at Merrill Lynch, Paine Webber and Travelers, which owns Smith Barney, exceeded expectations. [D2.]
 
Southern Giants In Sugar to Merge
Savannah Foods, the maker of Dixie Crystal sugar, plans to merge with the domestic sugar operations of Flo-Sun, the private holding company of the Fanjul family of Florida, forming a new public company. [D2.]
 
Retail Sales Up 0.5%
After a spring lull, consumers spent more freely in June, particularly on cars, driving up retail sales by half a percent. [D4.]
 
After deducting auto sales, the increase looked less impressive, comforting the inflation-wary bond market. The 30-year Treasury's yield fell to 6.54 percent from 6.55. [D16.]
 
Pfizer Posts Disappointing Gain
Pfizer's earnings rose 16 percent but fell short of expectations, while Johnson & Johnson met forecasts with a 15 percent rise. [D2.]
 
Book Tracking System Is Planned
Soundscan, a computerized sales tracking system that brought order to the nation's pop music charts, is preparing a version for books that some publishers hope could bring efficiency to an industry struggling with declining sales and bloated print runs. [D5.]
 
KPMG Loses Suit by Client Company
A judge ruled that KPMG Peat Marwick abused its relationship with an audit client, Stern Stewart, a consulting firm that accused KPMG of using its position to create a rival business, even hiring away Stern Stewart employees. [D6.]
 
Swiss Bank in Japanese Link
Swiss Bank and Long-Term Credit Bank of Japan have formed an alliance in which they will take 3 percent stakes in each other and set up joint ventures in asset management and investment banking. [D4.]
 
Discussions on Tobacco Settlement
Lawyers for the cigarette companies said they were willing to pay a high price to win a reprieve from the legal and political threats they face, as they met with Clinton Administration officials for the first time to review the proposed settlement of tobacco litigation. [A12.]
 
Ruling on Surveillance Is Sought
Telephone industry executives said they would petition the F.C.C. to resolve a dispute over digital surveillance, contending that the F.B.I. wanted to force them to develop wiretapping equipment that goes beyond the law. [A13.]

HEADLINE: CAPITOL SKETCHBOOK;
Campaign Finance Labyrinth Is Obvious, If Not Clear

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 15

 BODY:
The moment was more graphic than revealing: On a day when the Republican Senate majority was determined to portray interlocking intrigues between the Riady family's holdings in the Lippo conglomerate and the business interests of China, a chart was brought forth, seven feet square, to dwarf all previous offerings in what has become a sub-battle of graphics at the campaign finance hearing.
The chart, reputedly depicting the growing involvement of the Lippo Group's global interests with Chinese joint ventures, was a massive web-like display of scores of intersecting lines radiating out from a tiny red Chinese flag. The lines connected to dozens of tiny green squares identified in minuscule printing as businesses like the Beijing Tati Turbo Dragon Real Estate Company. 
Senators walked up to the chart squinting in puzzlement.
"Is this supposed to be an orbital track?" asked Senator John Glenn, the former astronaut and ranking Democrat in the Senate inquiry into campaign financing abuses. Mr. Glenn, of Ohio, seemed delighted at the sheer incomprehensibility of the exhibit. "I'm a Cancer. Where do I fit in?" he asked, shifting to astrology as a possible explanation.
"It's Nancy Reagan's star chart," a photographer agreed, frustrated in trying to make anything graphically usable of a Lippo-Beijing universe to rival the Milky Way.
Within minutes, the Democrats had their own far simpler graphic on the easel, displaying the day's two key vectors -- the overlapping Lippo and China business ambitions. But in this graphic there was a smiling third partner, Pat Robertson, the Christian fundamentalist broadcaster who is dear to many Republicans and who had a broadcasting interest in China that he sold this year.
A whiff of laughter ensued, the same as for an earlier mention that the Riady family, whose ubiquitous Lippo holdings extend back to Little Rock and President Clinton's days as Arkansas Governor, owned a house in the Brentwood section of Los Angeles. This laughter was offered in recognition of the fact that even on a day devoted to tracking the arcana of the Lippo Group, there seemed no way in modern American culture not to encounter coincidental notions of O. J. Simpson and his troubles in Brentwood.
The Democrats did show an unequivocal moment of retreat today when they conceded that a 1992 contribution of $50,000 to the Democratic National Committee arranged by John Huang, the devoted Clinton fund-raiser and former Lippo executive, appeared to have been covered illegally by a bank wire from overseas Lippo interests. "It certainly looks like the movement of foreign money to an American campaign," said Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, Democrat of Connecticut.
Even so, for much of the day the Democrats were in the odd position of defending the interests of the absent Riadys and other Lippo principals in the face of Republican curiosity about $800,000 in Democratic contributions from small-scale, barely profitable Lippo interests.
Democratic senators countered that Lippo business ventures seemed legitimate and that most of their contributions seemed legal. A former Lippo Bank executive, Harold Arthur, insisted that the sizable donations had nothing to do with seeking Government favors but rather were the result of a long friendship between James Riady, a Lippo principal, and Mr. Clinton.
If nothing else, the Lippo-China graphic bore out the caution heard in earlier testimony that the hardest thing to track in big-money politics is the ultimate source of campaign donations from the American subsidiaries of global corporations.
For his part, Senator Fred Thompson, the Tennessee Republican who is chairman of the hearings, patiently kept to tracking Mr. Huang's role in this sprawling sphere. He gratefully hailed a former Lippo employee who testified as one of the "few people who worked at Lippo who remained in the United States."
Back on the graphics front, a Republican floor plan of the executive offices at Lippo Bank of California showed Mr. Huang's space occupied by a literally shadowy figure -- a silhouette of a man vaguely reminiscent of a Pink Panther cartoon character. To the Republicans' charge that Mr. Huang may have been a political and economic spy for China and the Lippo interests, Mr. Arthur, chairman of the bank's board of directors, politely replied, "Hogwash."
During a break in the hearing, Senators Glenn and Lieberman released a printed statement to try to deal with the overarching Republican charge in pursuing Mr. Huang: that the Chinese Government had an ongoing plan to infiltrate American elections and influence Administration policy. They said intelligence information "strongly suggests" that the Chinese Government did have a plan "containing components that are both legal and illegal" to influence Congressional elections, but not the Presidency.
"It is not clear from the evidence that the illegal aspects of such a plan were ever put into motion," they carefully added.
As the second week of hearings maintained what Republicans term their mosaic approach of bit-by-bit progress, one Democrat conceded privately that this was his party's week for "the fetal position" of having to concede some points.
Still, the proceeding is nowhere near what politicians in both parties fear as the "mutual assured destruction" stage -- a cross assault by senator on senator, disclosing each other's questionable campaign initiatives in the era of big-money fund-raising personified by Mr. Huang.

HEADLINE: Koreans Place Kia Motors Under Bankruptcy Shield

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: TOKYO, July 15

 BODY:
The Kia Motors Corporation, one of South Korea's leading car manufacturers, was effectively placed under bankruptcy protection today, as Korean banks announced emergency financial assistance to the debt-ridden company and many of its subsidiaries.
The Kia group of companies, centered on Kia Motors, is the fourth of the nation's top 30 conglomerates -- and the biggest so far -- to collapse or nearly collapse since the beginning of the year. The failures have weakened South Korea's financial system and raised alarm about the mountains of debt that many Korean industrial giants have accumulated in their race to expand. 
 Kia's difficulties are also a signal of problems, and perhaps of a consolidation, in the South Korean automobile industry. The big three Korean auto makers -- Hyundai, Kia and the Daewoo Motor Company, part of the Daewoo Corporation -- have created more capacity than is needed for the once-rapidly growing domestic market, intensifying pressure on the auto makers to increase exports. Adding to the pressure are plans by the giant Samsung Group to begin selling cars next year.
South Korea manufactured 2.81 million cars last year, and its auto makers are planning to increase annual production to 6 million cars in four years. Only 1.65 million cars were sold domestically in 1996.
Kia's export effort in the United States has been gradual, beginning three years ago with its Sephia sedan and the Sportage sport utility vehicle. Kia models are sold in Western, Southern and mid-Atlantic states, and the company plans to open dealerships in the New York area late this summer. Kia Motors America said today that "the steps being taken in Korea have no immediate impact on the operation of Kia in the United States."
[On Wednesday morning, the Kia group said in Seoul that it would sell 1.9 trillion won, or about $2.1 billion, in land and other assets to raise cash and would reduce its work force of 56,000 by 4,300. In addition, half of the group's 28 companies will be sold or merged, reducing the number of concerns to 14.
[In stock trading early Wednesday, the Korean composite index was down nearly 2 percent; since the first of the year, it is up 14 percent.]
Until last month, Kia was manufacturing and shipping to the United States a small car sold as the Ford Aspire.
The Korean producer's troubles are a setback for the Ford Motor Company, which owns 9.4 percent of Kia Motors. Ford is already trying to revive Mazda, the Japanese producer of which Ford owns 33 percent; Mazda, in turn, owns 7.5 percent of Kia.
Today, Ford officials played down the effects from Kia's problems. "To the extent it appears Kia will continue production, the vehicles we receive from them should continue," a Ford spokesman, John Spelich, said. Ford continues to sell a Kia-manufactured Festiva model, a car that resembles the Aspire, in Taiwan, Thailand and Australia.
The troubles at Kia could increase pressure in South Korea -- which imported only 10,315 cars last year -- to keep its home market virtually closed to foreign cars. Trade groups of American and European makers are in Seoul pushing to open markets.
Kia did not declare bankruptcy. Rather, it was designated for rescue today under a plan announced in April by South Korean banks that was created to prevent more big companies from failing. Kia will be allowed to continue operations, to temporarily forgo debt repayments and even to receive new loans while it works on a restructuring plan over the next two months.
In South Korea, though, being designated for protection from bankruptcy carries the same stigma as bankruptcy itself. Kia said today that it had not asked for such protection.
Jeun Sang Jin, a spokesman for Kia Motors in Seoul, said that the company thought that its debts were not unusually large by Korean standards and that the company "can get back on track again in two months."
The Kia group, the nation's eighth-largest conglomerate, has debts of 9.54 trillion won, or $10.7 billion. That approaches twice the nearly $6 billion in debt of Hanbo Steel when it collapsed in January.
Hanbo's collapse, which precipitated a political corruption scandal, was followed by that of the Sammi Steel, a smaller producer. Jinro, the 19th-largest conglomerate, was given help under the banks' plan, as was the Dainong Group.
Korean banks have long served as unofficial arms of the Government, extending credit to the conglomerates, to fuel the nation's export-driven economic development. But the companies often expanded recklessly and the banks loans' turned sour. Particularly hard hit has been the Korea First Bank, which is owed about $900 million by Kia and was also the leading creditor of Hanbo.
Kia had been looked upon as different from most of the conglomerates because it focuses mainly on one business, and has professional, not family management. But its smaller size has perhaps hurt it in competing against the larger and far more diversified Hyundai and Daewoo.
Still, the subsidiaries it does have are what hurt Kia. While Kia Motors had a small net profit of $8.3 million on sales of $7.8 billion last year, the entire group lost more than $140 million. A big problem is Asia Motors, a truck manufacturer that nearly defaulted on debt payments last month.
Kia has been rumored to be a takeover target for the Samsung Group, which already owns 6 percent. An acquisition of Kia would give Samsung instant market presence as it prepares to begin selling cars. Perhaps to keep Kia out of Samsung's hands, the Hyundai and Daewoo groups have been buying Kia's convertible bonds.

HEADLINE: Lilco Deal Seems Set as Silver Backs Plan

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

DATELINE: ALBANY, July 15

 BODY:
The $7.3 billion partial state takeover of the Long Island Lighting Company appears likely to win final state approval on Wednesday, after Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver said today that he would vote for it if certain conditions were met.
Mr. Silver said that before he could agree to the plan at Wednesday's meeting of the state Public Authorities Control Board, there must be a guarantee that the buyout would actually produce the double-digit reductions in electric rates that Gov. George E. Pataki had promised. Some of the Speaker's other demands concern increasing competition among power retailers, which could lower rates further. 
 "We're looking at the conditions and we're hopeful that they can all be met to his satisfaction by tomorrow morning so that the vote can go forward," said Mr. Pataki, the sponsor of the plan. Officials at Lilco, which is planning to merge with Brooklyn Union Gas Company, also expressed optimism that Mr. Silver's concerns could be addressed.
The takeover contract requires unanimous approval by the three-member control board. It must also be approved by several Federal agencies, and hinges in part on whether the Internal Revenue Service will waive a $2 billion capital gains tax bill that Lilco would otherwise owe on the deal.
In another area of state energy policy, the Legislature approved a bill today to triple the size of a program that provides low-cost power to businesses as an incentive to keep them from leaving the state. The measure would make 400 megawatts of power, the output of a medium-size power plant, available at less than half the market price, in addition to 200 megawatts the program already provides. The bill imposed no pollution standards on the power production, so some of it could come from the state's dirtiest plants, a feature that angered environmentalists.
Mr. Pataki's Lilco plan has met with opposition from consumer advocates, some business groups and politicians of both parties. They contend that it would pay Lilco too much for its assets, saddling consumers with high costs for the next three decades. Mr. Silver's decision to back the plan, first reported today in Newsday, is a boost for the Governor, who had invested considerable effort in it.
"It's a difficult decision, in that a lot of the criticisms of the plan are accurate," said the Speaker, a Manhattan Democrat. Still, he said, the Governor's plan appears to be the only way to cut deeply into electric bills that are the highest in the continental United States.
Lilco customers are still paying heavily for the never-used, $6.5 billion Shoreham nuclear plant. The administration contends that the state cannot force Lilco to absorb more costs, and that any attempt to do so would be tied up in court for years.
Mr. Silver said that he thought the state could legally make Lilco bear some of the costs, but that that was not one of his demands. When asked why, he said the state needed to act quickly to gain the Federal tax waiver, whose savings would be passed on to consumers. The Federal agency is expected to make such waivers impossible in the future.
Gordian Raacke, executive director of the court-appointed Citizens Advisory Panel to Lilco, said he liked Mr. Silver's conditions but was disappointed that he had not insisted that Lilco continue to pay for Shoreham.
Some consumer advocates said they thought the takeover would be challenged in court, on environmental and other grounds.
The deal would leave Lilco with $1.9 billion in cash, and Mr. Silver said he wanted a commitment that about half of it would be invested on Long Island in ways that would improve the local economy and foster competition, perhaps through the development of the island's limited gas distribution system. He also called for steps to allow power companies from outside the region to compete directly for consumers' business.

HEADLINE: Costs of Tobacco Accord Take Center Stage

BYLINE: By JOHN M. BRODER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 15

 BODY:
Clinton Administration officials and cigarette industry representatives met to review the proposed tobacco settlement together for the first time today, and the topic on the table was money.
Lawyers representing the major cigarette makers said that they were willing to pay a high price to win reprieve from the legal and political threats they now face but that further financial demands could drive them into bankruptcy. 
 Government officials responded by saying they would not recommend approval of a deal unless it included sufficiently harsh penalties to insure that the tobacco companies would drive down smoking by teen-agers through drastic changes in marketing and advertising practices.
Administration officials also began publicly raising questions about the tax deductibility of the industry's payments, which would result in a drain of roughly $100 billion on the Federal Treasury over 25 years. Most of the money in the $368.5 billion settlement proposal would go to the 39 states that have sued the industry to recover smoking-related Medicaid costs, and to plaintiffs seeking individual damage payments.
The meetings' participants, using terms usually reserved for high-level diplomatic encounters, later described the session, in the Roosevelt Room of the White House, as "businesslike" and "candid."
Both sides indicated that they hoped it would be the first of a number of meetings, as the Administration seeks to convert the settlement proposal into a document that the President can present to Congress and the American people as a solution to the decades-long tobacco wars.
Emerging from the 90-minute meeting, Donna E. Shalala, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, said one crucial question arising from the tobacco accord was "who pays, and how it affects the budget of the United States."
Dr. Shalala noted that while it was "standard business practice" to deduct the cost of legal settlements from earnings for tax purposes, the size and scope of the tobacco accord, and its implications for the Federal budget, were unprecedented.
The tobacco representatives, led by J. Phil Carlton, a North Carolina lawyer representing the RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation, were uncommunicative after leaving the meeting.
Mr. Carlton said only that his team had explained the settlement "in its present form" and had answered questions from Ms. Shalala and the White House domestic policy chief, Bruce Reed, who are coordinating the Administration's review of the accord.
Mr. Carlton declined further comment as a throng of reporters pursued him down the White House driveway.
The industry was also represented by Meyer G. Koplow of the New York law firm of Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz; Jane Hickie of the Washington firm of Verner, Liipfert, Bernhard, McPherson & Hand, and D. Scott Wise of the New York firm of Davis Polk & Wardwell.
The Treasury Department and the White House Office of Management and Budget are studying the proposal to gauge its fiscal impact as well as its effects on the financial health of cigarette makers and tobacco growers and the economies of tobacco states.
An Administration official involved in the settlement review, who spoke on the condition that he not be identified, said that because the settlement as currently written allowed for the tobacco industry's costs to be deductible, it essentially provided for a huge subsidy for the states' Medicaid accounts, paid for by Federal taxpayers.
This official added that while the companies had signaled some flexibility on the taxation issue, they were likely to balk at any significant increase in the overall cost of the settlement.
Dr. Shalala said the tobacco representatives had given no sign of how willing they were to accept changes in the agreement, which was negotiated over 12 weeks by state attorneys general, plaintiffs' lawyers and industry representatives.
"They established no line," the Secretary said. "They didn't turn us up or turn us down."

HEADLINE: Essay;
Good News Is Big News

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Those of us whose job it is to view the world through alarm-colored glasses are having a very tough summer. The good news keeps piling up.
The dollar is strengthening against the franc and mark because the Europeans can't get their act together and we did our downsizing years ago. That means a bottle of wine, as well as imported still water, is tantalizingly cheaper for Americans. 
 Epidemics are coming under control and welfare rolls are shrinking. The Food and Drug Administration bureaucracy snapped out of its lethargy long enough to approve an anti-plaque dentifrice that enables modern mothers to wash their kids' mouths out with soap. Meanwhile, a potency potion on the horizon for both sexes is getting the geezer generation all excited.
Peace is breaking out all over the world. War criminals are belatedly being given a hard time -- resist arrest and make my day -- while political reformers from Mexico City to Moscow are riding high. Astronomers with roving eyes are thinking of renaming planets (Mars is too warlike, Venus sexist).
Economics, which Thomas Carlyle dubbed "the dismal science," is now the delirious science. Inflation is a spent balloon and unemployment a relative joke. The Euphoria Index (new-job creation plus productivity gains multiplied by the percentage rise in consumer confidence) is making new highs every day.
Which brings us to the stock market. A few years ago executives had to rent the Glomar Explorer to observe their companies' stock options, but now they're up here drying in the warm sunshine of runaway prosperity. Who would have thought that lowering the capital gains tax would become a populist issue -- with the populists in favor?
Such a happy combination of peace, progress and prosperity is not without its downside. It has driven professional pessimists -- "prophets of gloom and doom" and "troubadours of trouble" who see the tank half-empty -- into disarray.
Wall Street bears are stuffed and hung on the wall. The Union of Concerned Scientists' clock has been wound back to two minutes past noon. As catastrophists in every field suffer their worst disaster, Gloomy Gus has become a laughingstock.
In journalism, too, naysayers are in a rout. Upbeat reporters focus on the ho-hum reaction rather than the underlying action and cover the coverage rather than advance the story. Headline writers of ordinarily objective newspapers airily declare investigations into wrongdoing to be "irrelevant." Sight-bite newsmaggies declare Senate hearings not geared to a one-week attention span or seven-second sound nibble to be "not ready for prime time."
All this goes right to the top and is reflected in opinion polls. As we laissez les bons temps rouler, the President of the U.S., Reno-loose and fancy-Freeh, rides this wave of national positivism and worldwide well-being to new crests of popularity.
What's missing? What element does the nation need to give sharp definition to the picture of unrelieved optimism -- to remind good pilgrims that the Man with the Muckrake, his gaze eternally cast downward, fails to see the glorious celestial crown offered to him?
Needed at this moment is a contrarian. No garden party is complete without its skunk. Who will volunteer to click on the icon of the iconoclast, to provide the partying populace with the low mutter of a jeremiad, to be the happy society's scapegoat for the sin of negativism, to present a target to be hooted at with universal glee?
I volunteer. Here I stand scruffily in sandwich boards, proclaiming my deviant doctrine.
You see this article in Foreign Affairs titled "The End of the Business Cycle?" and assuring babyboomers no babybust is ahead? I say hogwash. You're going to see a correction one of these days that will curl your hair, followed by a year in the doldrums before the next recovery. Those of us now conservatively 5 percent in cash will laugh.
Count on the Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse as an entry in the Belmont Stakes, computer crashing on Millennium Morning, and the unexpected social consequences of the geezer-sex pill. Brace yourself for the dreary data in indictments handed up on Hubbell and Hillary followed by the Great Popularity Plunge.
All this loathed melancholy do I provide as a summertime public service. Repent! The end is near.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: White House Begins Push for New Global Warming Pact

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 15

 BODY:
After tinkering with computer models for more than a year, the Clinton Administration predicted today that measures to combat the growth of global warming by limiting the emissions of carbon dioxide and other gases that trap heat from the sun would have a far less dramatic effect on the economy than had been projected by industries opposed to restraints on energy use.
The Administration's analysis opens what is expected to be a long campaign between now and the end of the year, when international negotiations are scheduled to conclude in Kyoto, Japan, to build support for a proposed binding treaty to limit the emissions of those kinds of gases. 
 Any measures to reverse the steady growth in such emissions, mostly given off by burning fossil fuels to operate cars and generate electricity and heat, would probably involve the biggest Federal intervention in energy markets since oil-exporting countries raised oil prices substantially in the 1970's.
But the Administration's computer models suggested that the economic side effects would be only half as severe as those projected in a recent study by economists at Charles River Associates for the American Petroleum Institute, a lobbying group for fuel producers.
Critics who say the Administration is moving too fast on global warming have warned that mines and factories would close, inflation would rise and productivity would fall. But another school of thought holds that energy conservation can pay for itself and that new technologies can be found, offering major economic gains, not to mention the benefits of limiting global warming and its potentially serious effects.
As the Administration tries to decide how fast and how far to cut those gas emissions, the question of the treaty's economic effect is being asked with increasing urgency in Congress, which has ultimate authority over the country's energy policy. In addition, any treaty would have to be submitted to the Senate for ratification.
In a staff paper released today, the White House said tough action on such gas emissions might, over the next few decades, shave a fraction of a percent from the nation's economic growth, followed by a recovery -- or might, if implemented cleverly, have a barely discernible effect or even a net economic benefit.
"It just boils down to this," Janet Yellen, chairwoman of the Council of Economic Advisers, said at a hearing of the House Commerce committee. "If we do it dumb, it could cost a lot, but if we do it smart, it will cost much less, and indeed could produce net benefits in the long run."
Ms. Yellen's comments were met with skepticism from both the ranking Republican and Democrat on the committee, and by many junior members of the panel as well.
"Unfortunately, in the area of global climate change, the Administration has not yet presented a persuasive case," said Representative Thomas J. Bliley Jr., the Virginia Republican who heads the chairman.
Representative John D. Dingell, Democrat of Michigan, treated Ms. Yellen and Timothy Wirth, the Undersecretary of State for Global Affairs, to a sometimes blistering questioning.
Mr. Dingell, whose district is a prime manufacturer of automobiles, said the analysis suggested "huge economic constraints" on American businesses.
According to the Administration's projections, Mr. Dingell said, stabilizing emissions at their 1990 levels by 2010 would require steps equivalent to charging about $100 for every ton of carbon emitted when a fossil fuel is burned. That would be like raising the tax on gasoline of about 26 cents a gallon, a tax on electricity of 2 cents per kilowatt hour, a tax on coal of $52.52 per ton, and a tax on natural gas of $1.49 per thousand cubic feet.
But, Administration officials said, the projections are put in terms of taxes merely because that is the easiest way for economists to model things that are even more complex than the tax code.
Nobody seriously expects the White House to propose a big increase in the gasoline tax.
The White House supports a treaty that would bind the United States and other developed countries to significant reductions in emissions of carbon dioxide and other heat-trapping gases, leaving each country to decide how it wanted to do so.

HEADLINE: Senate Panel Is Told Huang Kept Ties to Company Linked to China

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 15

 BODY:
John Huang, the offstage protagonist of the Senate hearings on campaign finance practices, was depicted today as the highly paid agent of an international conglomerate that has close ties to the Chinese Government and a record of generous contributions to the Democratic Party.
During the time Mr. Huang worked at the Commerce Department and the Democratic National Committee, the Senators were told, he retained his ties to his former employer, the Lippo Group, an international financial holding company based in Indonesia. 
 On its fourth day of hearings, the Senate Government and Oversight Committee produced what appeared to be its first direct evidence of a foreign political contribution -- a memo in which Mr. Huang asked the Indonesian conglomerate that he worked for in 1992 to "please kindly wire" money to cover several expenses, including a $50,000 donation to the Democratic Party. Mr. Huang ultimately raised $1.6 million in donations for the 1996 campaign that later had to be returned because it came from suspect sources.
Lippo, according to a witness, Thomas R. Hampson, who specializes in international business operations, has evolved in the last few years from being a family-owned enterprise to what he said was essentially a joint venture with the Chinese Government. Mr. Hampson was hired by the committee to provide information on the Lippo Group. He was one of three witnesses who appeared before the committee today to testify about Lippo.
"The significance," said Senator Fred Thompson, the Tennessee Republican who is the chairman of the committee, "is that apparently both Mr. Huang and Lippo were perfectly willing and adept at putting illegal money into the United States."
On the question of Chinese involvement in American political affairs, two Democratic Senators, John Glenn of Ohio and Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut, said today that material they had seen in a Federal Bureau of Investigation briefing on Monday left little doubt that the Chinese had a plan to influence Congressional elections. But they added that they saw no indication that the plan had been put into effect or that it had involved the Presidential race.
The significance of the evidence being heard by the committee has been hotly debated ever since Mr. Thompson opened the hearings last week by saying that the Chinese had plotted to give money to influence last year's elections, including the Presidential campaign.
Democrats have said Mr. Thompson vastly overstated the case.
The evidence presented at today's session included these points:
*After President Clinton took office and while Mr. Huang was still at Lippo, he visited the White House 52 times.
*During the period he was working in the Commerce Department, Mr. Huang made hundreds of calls to various Lippo entities.
*In April 1996, when he was on the Democratic payroll, Mr. Huang was registered at a World Bank seminar as a representative of Lippo.
While none of these pieces of evidence are by themselves eye-popping, the Republicans who are conducting the investigation see them as building blocks in the case they are trying to make that the Chinese Government tried to influence the 1996 election campaign in the United States by funneling money to Democrats and that Mr. Huang was instrumental in this enterprise.
Mr. Huang has asserted his Fifth Amendment right against forced self-incrimination and has refused to appear before the committee. Members of the Riady family, the principal owners of Lippo and longtime patrons of Mr. Clinton, and many other people who worked with Mr. Huang at Lippo are in Indonesia and have refused to cooperate with Congressional investigators.
To tie the Lippo enterprises to China, the committee heard testimony from Mr. Hampson, president of Search International, which conducts research into the operations of international businesses.
Mr. Hampson said that in the last few years the Lippo Group had "shifted its strategic center" from Indonesia to China, and that much of the conglomerate's business now involved joint ventures with China Resources, a company wholly owned by the Chinese Government.
"China Resources also has a more geopolitical purpose," he said. "It is well established in the public record that the Government of the People's Republic of China uses China Resources as an agent of espionage -- economic, military and political."
The company, Mr. Hampson continued, "is kind of like a smiling tiger; it might look friendly, but it's very dangerous."
Under questioning from Democrats, however, he conceded that he did not know whether Chinese money was part of Lippo's enterprises in the United States or whether China Resources had any activities in this country.
Documents the committee released showed that Mr. Huang was handsomely paid by Lippo, with a salary of about $90,000 a year and annual bonuses of about $230,000. When he left Lippo in 1994 to join the Clinton Administration, he was given severance pay of more than $450,000, a figure that included the book value of the company car he was allowed to keep, a 1988 Mercedes Benz.
Among the material disclosed today were a $50,000 check sent to the Democratic National Committee in 1992 by Hip Hing Holdings, a Lippo affiliate in California where Mr. Huang worked, and a memorandum from Mr. Huang to the company's headquarters in Indonesia asking for reimbursement for the donation.
Senator Lieberman said this "certainly looks like the movement of foreign money into an American campaign in 1992."
While donations to political parties by American subsidiaries of foreign companies are legal, the contributions must come from money made in the United States.
Because James T. Riady, one of Lippo's principals, lived in the United States in the early 1990's, the family could legally donate to American political campaigns, and documents produced today showed that as much as $800,000 was given from 1992 through 1994 to the Democratic National Committee and the Democratic Party in several states.
Senator Lieberman asked one witness, Harold Arthur, a former chief executive officer and now chairman of Lippo Bank in California, a bank owned by James Riady, why the Riady family was so generous.
"Friendship," Mr. Arthur replied. "I know that James Riady became closely acquainted with the then-Governor Clinton, and they developed a personal friendship."
Senator Lieberman asked for Mr. Arthur's reaction to assertions that Mr. Huang was a spy for either the Lippo Group or China.
"Hogwash," Mr. Arthur answered.
Although they were associates for years, Mr. Arthur said he did not know exactly what work Mr. Huang performed for the Lippo enterprises.
Whatever Mr. Huang did, the evidence indicated that he had a close relationship with the Clinton White House. He went there 52 times from January 1993 to June 1994, and five of the visits were to Mr. Clinton's private quarters.
After Mr. Huang went to the Commerce Department in 1994 as Deputy Assistant Secretary for international economic policy, Mr. Huang kept in touch with his former employer.
Senator Susan Collins, Republican of Maine, said records showed that Mr. Huang telephoned Lippo entities as many as 400 times after he went to the Commerce Department.
Democrats maintained that he made many of those calls simply to get messages that had been left by people who did not know that he no longer worked at Lippo.
One of the most intriguing documents was a registration form to the World Bank's International Finance Corporation Conference in April 1996, several months after Mr. Huang had left the Commerce Department to become the Democratic Party's chief fund-raiser among Asian-Americans.
The typed form showed that Mr. Huang had registered at the conference, listing his employment as "Lippo Group," his address as that of the Lippo Bank in Los Angeles and his position as "adviser."
There was no evidence of who filled out the form.

HEADLINE: Metro News Briefs: NEW YORK CITY;
Man Convicted of Killing His Wife, a Police Officer

 BODY:
An unemployed city bus driver charged with fatally shooting his estranged wife, a police officer, in January was convicted yesterday by a Brooklyn jury.
The defendant, John Rivera, 37, was convicted of second-degree murder with depraved indifference for human life in the shooting of Officer Kimberly Rivera, 28, during an argument outside his apartment in Bath Beach, Brooklyn. Four of the victim's former patrol partners, who had come every day to the four-and-a-half-week trial, sat in court with her family as the sentence was read. 
 Mr. Rivera will be sentenced on Sept. 10, and faces a prison term of up to 15 years to life. During the trial, prosecutors contended that the murder stemmed from a combination of Mr. Rivera's frustration at losing his job as a bus driver and his anger at Ms. Rivera for seeking divorce and custody of the couple's child.
Mr. Rivera maintained during the trial that his wife, a six-year veteran of the 68th Precinct in Bay Ridge, had committed suicide after a late-night argument. In convicting him, the jury of nine women and three men concluded that while he might not have done so intentionally, it was Mr. Rivera who pulled the trigger.

HEADLINE: U.S. May Cut Back on Aid Until Cambodian Election

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 15

 BODY:
In a stiffer response to the coup in Cambodia by Co-Prime Minister Hun Sen, the United States is planning to suspend all aid except basic humanitarian assistance until after elections can be held, senior American officials said today.
While final decisions are still to be made by Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright and President Clinton, the officials said, there was a growing consensus that a fuller suspension of aid, tied to fresh elections held under international monitoring, is the only way to prevent Mr. Hun Sen from an outright power grab. 
 About 50 percent of the Cambodian national budget comes from foreign aid of one kind or another, either bilateral or through multilateral institutions like United Nations agencies and the World Bank.
But American officials said that if reports were confirmed that Mr. Hun Sen's forces have killed up to 40 members of the political opposition in custody, "that changes things," though they said it was too early to say how.
The United States earlier condemned reports that two supporters of the ousted First Prime Minister, Prince Norodom Ranariddh, had been killed in captivity. "But if two becomes 40, we have a very different situation," the official said.
If confirmed, such reports would also increase pressure in Congress, especially in the House, to cut off all aid, even humanitarian aid.
There is also a debate, both within the Administration and outside it, about the timing of a new election. Before Prince Ranariddh fled Cambodia on July 4, the day before Mr. Hun Sen's coup, the two Prime Ministers had agreed on elections in May 1998.
Some officials believe that May is too soon for elections in the current conditions, which would likely favor Mr. Hun Sen. But other officials, and some human-rights workers, have said that elections should be much sooner, to prevent Mr. Hun Sen from consolidating power.
This fiscal year, the United States has appropriated $35 million in direct aid to Cambodia with another $7 million or so in Defense Department money, mostly for the removal of land mines. About half the $35 million would be cut off, with the rest going to programs for AIDS prevention, care for mothers and babies and other basic humanitarian aid. All the Defense money would be cut off, except to remove mines, the officials said.
But they cautioned that these figures could change in the Government debate, and Congress could also have the final say. The House Foreign Aid Appropriations Bill is due to be drawn up this week, and Representative Dana Rohrabacher, a Republican of California, has called for the withholding of all American assistance to Cambodia under legislation that requires such action if an elected Government is overthrown in a coup.
American officials have publicly refrained from calling the events in Cambodia a coup for that very reason, in an effort not to punish innocent Cambodian civilians who have suffered much in the last 30 years.
Earlier, the State Department announced a 30-day suspension of American aid while it tries to coordinate policy with allies from the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, which holds its annual meeting later this month in Malaysia.
Japan, which has also suspended aid, gives about $150 million a year. The World Bank had approved funds of some $54.3 million through June 30, but large amounts of that money has not yet been spent. The International Monetary Fund had already suspended its loans due to bad economic performance.

HEADLINE: Ex-47th St. Photo Owner Is Indicted in Fraud

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON 

 BODY:
The former president and owner of 47th Street Photo, Irving Goldstein, was indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury in Manhattan on charges that he and a group of co-defendants falsified accounts to bolster the fortunes of a struggling company that was closely tied to 47th Street Photo, which filed for bankruptcy in 1992.
The indictment illuminates a period in the early 1990's when the fortunes of 47th Street Photo, once a major force in electronics retailing in New York City with its discount prices and high-volume style, had crumbled in an environment of heightened competition and the recession. The criminal charges announced yesterday by the United States Attorney in Manhattan, Mary Jo White, do not relate directly to the electronics chain's collapse, but she said that the investigation into Mr. Goldstein's business dealings is continuing. 
 The charges relate to a now defunct company called Micro Innovation Computer Center that, court documents say, was controlled by Mr. Goldstein.
Prosecutors said that Mr. Goldstein and five other defendants, including his son Josef, and two brothers-in-law, Herbert Greenfield and Michael Mendlovic, created a scheme that allowed Micro Innovation to borrow money by creating the impression that Micro Innovation was doing more business than it really was. That resulted in losses of $5 million to one of the company's lenders, the indictment said.
From January 1995 through July 1995, the lender, Fidelity Funding of California, was presented with what prosecutors say was a false-fronted business, which included fake orders and bogus documents intended to create an impression of health that would keep credit flowing.
Also named in the charges were Isaac Reinhold, the president of Micro Innovation, and the United Talmudical Academy, a yeshiva in Brooklyn on whose board Mr. Goldstein sat. Prosecutors said the school participated in a conspiracy to commit wire fraud. Mr. Goldstein faces up to five years in prison and fines of $250,000 or more if convicted. The school could be fined $500,000 or more.
None of the defendants have entered a plea, pending on arraignment July 24. Mr. Goldstein's lawyer, Gerald L. Shargel, said his client would plead not guilty. Mr. Mendlovic's lawyer, Gustave Newman, declined to comment.

CORRECTION-DATE: July 18, 1997, Friday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Wednesday about the indictment of the former president and owner of 47th Street Photo, on charges of falsifying accounts, referred incompletely to a yeshiva in Brooklyn also named in the indictment. According to the office of United States Attorney in Manhattan, the institution involved, the United Talmudical Academy, is based at 5301 14th Avenue in Borough Park, and has four other Brooklyn locations -- at 1010 45th Street, at 1346 45th Street, at 5411 Fort Hamilton Parkway, and on 49th Street (for which a specific address was not available). The indictment did not involve other institutions in Brooklyn with similar names.

HEADLINE: AROUND DALLAS WITH: Doug J. Swanson;
In the Sunbelt, A Shadow Master

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK 

DATELINE: DALLAS

 BODY:
"YOU want the Flippo tour?" asks Doug J. Swanson, author and creator of Jack Flippo, a down-and-out Texas private eye. He points the car west into the Dallas night, away from the gaudy, neon skyline of downtown, over the mud-ditch Trinity River and into a neighborhood of factories, fleabag motels and dingy doughnut shops.
At one time, Jack Flippo, the chief character in Mr. Swanson's three crime novels, was a young assistant district attorney in Dallas, a man with a future. One serious "libido-driven mistake" and a few lesser wrong turns later, Flippo is prowling the seedier side of Dallas, with forays into the city's better-known, big-rich side. He peeps in keyholes and digs up dirt, while engaging himself in a philosophical struggle to preserve his integrity, or some shred of it. "He looked on his conscience as something that crashed in the jungle," Mr. Swanson writes, "but was still sending out weak Maydays." 
 Flippo intersects with many of Mr. Swanson's other distinctive Dallas characters, including Buddy George Jr., a motivational speaker (and adulterer and blackmail target) with a pompadour "the size of a canned ham" and hand-tooled baby-blue cowboy boots. A constant font of corny dictums -- "You triumph when you combine 'try' with 'umph'!" -- Buddy makes his money on people who come to his Wayupper seminars, where he sells his book, "Birth of a Salesman!"
"Jesus was a salesman," Buddy tells his crowds. "Sure he was. People say he has millions of followers. I like to think of 'em as customers."
With the Flippo series -- "Big Town" (1994), "Dreamboat" (1995) and "96 Tears" (1996, all HarperCollins) -- Mr. Swanson, 44, has drawn acclaim for his zany writing style ("crime fiction slathered in broad comedy," Publishers Weekly says). "Big Town" won the British Crime Writers Association prize for best first novel. Some reviewers have compared him to off-the-wall crime novelists like Carl Hiaasen and Elmore Leonard.
As much as any human being in the Flippo series, Dallas is a central character in the books, but with a twisted and clever reflection of its vaunted self-image as the ultimate city of money and deals. Everybody has a hustle here. Even low-life criminals are upwardly striving in Mr. Swanson's Dallas; those who blackmail Buddy George listen to his motivational cassette tapes and ask him for more and more money.
"Dallas is not an artistic place -- it's a business place," Mr. Swanson explains, and the pervading sense of money's importance may give his desperate, scrambling characters a greater edge. "You're expected to come here and work and make your money and be a productive citizen and be conservative, and all that," he says as the car zooms across a Dallas freeway. "So I think maybe the contrast here is stronger. And that seems to fit with what I'm trying to do."
At the same time, none of the action takes place in corporate board rooms or the conference areas of luxury hotels, which would explain why his little tour of the Dallas inspirations for his novels is like no sightseeing tour offered by Gray Line.
This tour includes two storefront tarot parlors, an inexpensive Salvadoran restaurant and a very budget motel on Fort Worth Avenue, which helpfully advises its clientele that drug dealing and prostitution are not allowed. (The place, or one a lot like it, gets torched in "96 Tears.") Also on the itinerary is Brownie's Coffee Shop, an east Dallas hangout with eight colors of vinyl seats. In real life, a collection agency and a beeper-repair shop are just above the place; in the books, the coffee shop is called Greenie's, and Flippo's office is upstairs.
"You could imagine a somewhat legitimate detective winding up up there," Mr. Swanson says. "Somewhat legitimate."
His writing is a sort of Sunbelt noir and cocks an amused eye at some of the urban Southwest's small absurdities, like the Timberpark Hill apartment complex along a Dallas freeway -- "nowhere near timber, park or a hill," the author observes in "Big Town." The plots are heavy on double- and triple-crosses and other twists.
"Sure I gave you my word," a swindling lawyer explains to his clients in "Dreamboat." "But all guarantees are subject to change." Even friendly conversation has an edge. "I won't lie to you except it's to sell commercial real estate," says a man Flippo meets in a bar in "Big Town."
The books raise an intriguing question: Is Dallas a natural place to set a crime novel?
Maybe, though while Hollywood is interested in Mr. Swanson's plots, it may just change his setting. Steven-Charles Jaffe, the producer who has optioned "Big Town" and who plans to begin shooting the film late this year, said he would probably set the whole thing in San Diego. More picturesque.
Mr. Swanson, who lives 45 miles north of Dallas with his wife, Susan Rogers, and their two children, says he takes no offense. "I can't imagine the books not being in Dallas, but a movie is a different creature. I don't think it would work so well in Cleveland or Toledo, because the Sunbelt, the sense of quick money, is such a big ingredient. San Diego's O.K. It's really beautiful, but it does have its own sleazy side."
There are other cities where crime stories naturally work. Miami, for instance, with all its flamboyance, somehow seems bred for its part in Mr. Hiaasen's best-selling books. Los Angeles has exuded intrigue and mystery and portents of doom amid the sun and palm trees from the days of Raymond Chandler to the present, when it is seen through the eyes, say, of Harry (short for Hieronymous) Bosch, the tormented police detective in Michael Connelly's best-selling series.
But Dallas?
It is a question to which Mr. Swanson, who has a day job as a roving national reporter for The Dallas Morning News, has clearly given a lot of thought. Dallas, he says, has no stunning natural backdrop.
"It doesn't have mountains. It doesn't have the ocean. It doesn't have a forest. It doesn't have a desert," he says. "I guess I sound like I'm not out to increase tourism to Dallas or anything." ("Rain often fell on Dallas," he writes in "96 Tears," "the way money might drop on some hard-luck bastard who every now and then picked a winner at the track. Not often enough, or regularly enough, and when it did come there was too much too fast to handle.")
"It's not New Orleans," Mr. Swanson says. "It doesn't create the natural mood for plots of intrigue. But it does have this outsized quality. Everyone, I think, has some idea about Dallas. It might be the city that killed Kennedy, it might be the TV show, it might be the Dallas Cowboys. But they've heard about it."
In the main, however, Mr. Swanson's Dallas characters are not moneyed like J. R. Ewing in "Dallas." "People keep telling me I should write about the real Dallas rich," he says. "I've thought about that. But I would have to make it somebody who had money and who is losing money. I just couldn't imagine having a lot of fun with someone who has had it all in life and continues to have it, and is not desperate. I need desperate people to write about."
Most of Mr. Swanson's characters are Texas types. In "Dreamboat" Flippo is called on to investigate a drowning in Lake Dolph Brisco, and the East Texas Sheriff is no help at all (for a reason). Rex Echols, a friendly guy who owned a topless bar called the Melon Patch Ranch with the deceased, seems intent only on making up country music lyrics:
 It hurts to admit it, but one thing I do know
If cheatin' was a fel'ny, I'd live on Death Row.
Other characters seem more universal. Like the coroner who talks only to his poodle, or the divorce lawyer who gives Flippo much of his business. "You think I'm sorry people say their wedding vows like they're ordering fries?" he says. "Ask my wallet."
And then, the author explains, there are a few out-of-state characters, including an overlarge tough guy and recurring nemesis of Flippo, Theodore N. Tunstra 2d, known as Teddy Deuce, the "unemployable son of a dentist" from Queens.
Mr. Swanson says his inspiration for Teddy Deuce was a real-life New Yorker he encountered in Brooklyn when he was from 1986 to 1991 the head of the New York bureau -- actually, he was the New York bureau -- of The Dallas Morning News.
"He worked at this toy store in Park Slope," Mr. Swanson recalls. "We used to call it Toys or Else. He was this big muscle-bound guy with tattoos. Anyway, one day I was in there with my son, who's maybe 4 years old, and this big guy is on the phone behind the counter, and he says, 'Yeah, the judge told me, I just keep seeing the shrink, I stay out of prison.' Then he hangs up, and he's staring there at my boy, and I just remember thinking, 'What a guy to be selling toys to kids.' "
In the books, Teddy regularly tries to kill Flippo, but he has a softer side: an intense phobia about germs and a clearly quixotic daydream of making enough money to settle down and buy himself a nice house.
"Showcase home, I'm talking about," Teddy says. "Tree, four bedrooms. Maybe even one wit a Jacuzzi love tub inna bat room."
Flippo is a pastiche of a lot of characters Mr. Swanson has seen over the years, many when he was covering crime for The Dallas Times-Herald, now defunct. The less glitzy side of Dallas, he says, has been an inspiration since he worked as a teen-age delivery boy for his father's machine shop there. Mr. Swanson has neither the income nor the inclination -- not yet, anyway -- to quit his job as a reporter.
And Dallas will remain the setting for his Flippo novels, including one built around Flippo's relationship with an "assassinologist," who gives tours of Dealey Plaza in his 1963 Lincoln convertible, playing a radio broadcast of the shooting of President Kennedy. Mr. Swanson has plans to branch out and would like to write a novel about a World War I submarine, on which his grandfather served. "Of course," he deadpans, "that would not be set in Dallas."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Doug J. Swanson lurking by a seamy Dallas motel like one that gets torched in his "96 Tears," a Jack Flippo mystery. (Mark Graham for The New York Times)(pg. C4)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Off vs. Yen on Concern About Trade Gap With Japan

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar touched a two-month high against the Japanese yen but fell to end lower yesterday, weakened by worries about the United States trade imbalance with Japan.
The pullback at least temporarily halted a rally that had pushed the dollar to six-year highs against the German mark and left it sharply higher against most other currencies. The dollar has been supported by the health of the United States economy, the ebullient stock market and doubts about Europe's plan for a single currency. 
 "We saw a significant selloff in the dollar," said Joseph Pedone, a currency trader at the New York branch of the Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank. "There's some concern out there that a further expansion of Japan's trade imbalance might lead to pressure on the dollar."
Japan's trade report for June is being released today in Tokyo. United States trade data for May, to be released tomorrow, are expected to show a growing Japanese surplus with the United States, in part because of the weakening of the yen this year, which has made Japanese goods more affordable abroad and hurt the ability of American companies to compete in Japan.
The dollar reached an intraday high of 116.40 yen yesterday, the strongest level since mid-May, before falling to settle in New York at 115.52 yen, down from 115.53 yen Tuesday. Against the mark, the dollar reached an intraday high of 1.7982 marks before settling at 1.7906 marks in New York, down from 1.7920 Tuesday. The British pound cost $1.6784, up from $1.6779.
The dollar-selling erased advances made earlier in the day after the German Government said it was not overly concerned about the United States currency's strength.
Traders had been expecting a blunt warning about the dollar's gains after Finance Minister Theo Waigel of Germany said on Tuesday that the dollar was excessively strong. Mr. Waigel also said the Cabinet would have more to say about foreign-exchange rates.
But yesterday a spokesman said only that the Cabinet considered the dollar's strength a reflection of the improving United States economy. He also said the euro currency to be introduced in 18 months would be "punctual and strong."
