HEADLINE: Tax Credits Will Not Lead to Higher Tuitions

 BODY:

To the Editor:
In "A Break for Students" (Business Day, July 15), your analysis of the proposed tax breaks for college tuition, you report that Lawrence E. Gladieux of the College Board noted that President Clinton's proposed increase in the maximum Pell grants is far less than the proposed tax credit for the first two years of college. This is misleading. 
 For the neediest students, the President's 1998 budget includes a larger college work-study program and a $3,000 maximum Pell grant award, which is double the tax credit proposed for the first two years of college.
The President's tax proposals help lower- and middle-income students in two ways: the tax credit for the first two years of college, and another tuition tax credit for all other students.
These tax credits begin diminishing for families that earn $80,000 a year and phase out completely for families that earn $100,000 or more.
You say that state legislatures could use tax breaks to raise tuition. Three decades of experience shows that the rate of tuition inflation slows as Federal student aid increases. Responding to public pressure and competition, state legislatures and private colleges today are limiting tuition growth, often tying it to the inflation rate.
 
MARSHALL S. SMITH
Acting Deputy Secretary
Department of Education
Washington, July 15, 1997

HEADLINE: Just a Small Tick Up for Consumer Prices

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 16

 BODY:
Consumer prices ticked up just slightly in June, the Government said today, leaving inflation virtually dormant and generating further optimism that the economy can continue to enjoy steady growth and low unemployment.
The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported that the Consumer Price Index rose just one-tenth of 1 percent in June, bringing inflation for the last year to 2.3 percent and for the last six months to a 1.4 percent annual rate, the lowest rate for the first half of a year since 1986. The report appeared to eliminate any need for the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates at its next meeting, in August. 
 It also reassured investors that there were no inflationary surprises lurking over the horizon that could derail Wall Street's remarkable run. Stock prices jumped, with the Dow Jones industrial average climbing above 8,000 for the first time, and bond prices also rallied.
"It's pretty much the same story, but a very good one -- moderate growth and low inflation," said Oscar Gonzalez, an economist at the John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company.
The economy's sound footing was underscored by several other sets of data released today. Industrial production rose three-tenths of a percent in June, a moderate increase suggesting that a downturn in consumer spending during the spring was largely offset by an increase in manufacturing.
Capacity utilization held steady at 83.5 percent, remaining well below the level at which production bottlenecks tend to force prices higher. Business inventories rose two-tenths of a percent in May, indicating that companies have supplies on hand to cope with any surge in orders.
The increase of one-tenth of a percent in the Consumer Price Index matched the increase in each of the previous three months. The so-called core index, which excludes volatile food and energy prices, also rose one-tenth of a percent, after a rise of two-tenths of a percent in May. The 2.4 percent annual rate of increase in the core index for the first six months was the lowest rate for the first half of a year since 1965.
The report said the moderation in prices was evident in nearly all categories of consumer goods and services. The index for dairy products fell by nine-tenths of a percent, while most other types of food increased in price by less than they had the previous month. New-car prices were flat and air fares were down 1.2 percent.
The category that the Bureau of Labor Statistics calls "apparel and upkeep" fell two-tenths of a percent in June after rising one-tenth of a percent in May, while medical care was up two-tenths of a percent in June, compared with three-tenths of a percent in each of the two previous months. Among the major categories, only housing and entertainment costs rose faster in June than they had in May.
After last week's report that prices on the producer level had fallen one-tenth of a percent in June, economists said that inflation had ceased, for now, to be much of a concern for either policy makers or for business executives and investors planning for the future.
Cliff Waldman, an economist at the National Federation of Independent Business, the small-business lobby, said surveys showed that companies were still trying to push through price increases, but were almost invariably unable to do so.
"The gap between plans and actual pricing activity is almost at a 20-year high, which indicates that the atmosphere is making it almost impossible even for those who want to raise prices," Mr. Waldman said.
Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, is scheduled to testify before Congress next week on the central bank's monetary policy outlook. Fed officials remain uncertain whether the current combination of moderate to strong growth, low unemployment and dormant inflation reflects a fundamental change in the way the economy operates or whether it is a temporary phenomenon generated by a confluence of inflation-dampening forces.
A relatively strong dollar has helped keep import prices down. The shift toward managed care has allowed companies to keep their health care costs down. Computer prices have fallen at a rate that analysts said would eventually flatten out. Slow growth in parts of Asia and in Europe has held back demand for many goods and services that are sold on a worldwide basis.
Economists said some or all of those trends were likely to be reversed at some point. And they said that if consumer spending in the United States rebounded in the second half of the year, it could quickly translate into higher prices.
Still, today's figures gave new ammunition to economists who believe that cost-cutting and productivity improvements among businesses have permanently altered the old rules of thumb about how much growth the economy can accommodate without igniting inflation.

HEADLINE: Embers Of Anger In the South

BYLINE: By Mary Frances Berry; Mary Frances Berry is professor of American Social Thought at the University of Pennsylvania and chairwoman of the United States Commission on Civil Rights.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
After a task force announced last month that there was no national conspiracy behind the fires that have destroyed more than 100 black churches, the message was clear: It is time to rebuild and move on. But it would be wrong to ignore the racial polarization left in the wake of the attacks, in town after town across the Deep South.
Two-thirds of all the fires remain unsolved, and new ones have been set in the past year. The people whose churches were burned down are still fearful. Unless we get to the bottom of what happened in those many individual cases, how can we prevent a recurrence? 
 Last summer the United States Civil Rights Commission held forums in the states where most of the burnings of African-American churches occurred. We announced that only a few of the arson attacks for which arrests had been made seemed to be racially motivated. But we also found that though there was a wave of outside support for rebuilding, the already poor race relations in many communities failed to improve.
I recently went back to Mississippi, Alabama and Louisiana to meet with people in towns where churches were burned. I brought the National Church Arson Task Force report showing that there have been 81 arrests and 27 convictions for arson at black churches. Though arrests have been made in only 35 percent of all church arson cases, the report notes that the arrest rate for arson in general is just 16 percent.
The picture it gives of the response by Government, law enforcement authorities and religious groups is a reassuring one. But in rural Alabama and Louisiana and the Mississippi Delta, people were not reassured. There the 1963 church bombing in Birmingham, Ala., that killed four black girls seems to have happened only yesterday. Old-time racism and poverty still hold sway.
In Alabama, only five of 12 church fires have been solved; there were two new ones in the state last week. In Boligee, at the town's black public high school in the valley below the private white academy, the audience buzzed about the still unsolved burnings of three black churches. The Rev. Levi Pickens of Mount Zion Baptist Church, 73, stood up on his one leg and spoke proudly of the people from outside Boligee who contributed toward rebuilding his church. Remarking on the lack of interest among local whites in helping, he said that in this town, blacks and whites "were taught to be against each other" from childhood.
In Louisiana, only one of the 14 arson attacks on black churches has been solved. In Baker, La., African-Americans were angry not only about this but also about what they saw as an effort by local whites to carve out a segregated school district.
In Mississippi, there have been arrests in just five of the 14 arsons of black churches. In Ruleville, Miss., the Rev. Dexter Brown of New Mount Zion Church told us that his twice-burned church is regularly shot at from a bridge nearby. The bridge has been repeatedly defaced with graffiti, including Ku Klux Klan symbols.
In town after town, we listened to people describe their fears and dashed hopes. Everywhere we went, African-Americans saw the lack of arrests and the public silence about the investigations as another example of contempt for them. The only whites who came to the public forums were one or two politicians whose votes depend on blacks, a reporter or two, and the transcriber.
It is difficult to be dispassionate where the ghosts of civil rights martyrs stalk the land and the flames of black churches burning are etched in memory. Even if all the arsonists are never arrested, and even if race is not the motivation in the still-unsolved cases, we cannot afford to be smug. We must not close our eyes to what these fires have exposed: the rot of southern rural poverty and persistent racism. An old Alabama woman said, referring to Federal civil rights officials: "You were here 30 years ago and you've come again and again and you promise to come back but little changes." I hope she is wrong.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Large Vehicles Lift Profits at G.M. and Ford

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, July 16

 BODY:
The General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company announced better-than-expected second-quarter earnings today, profiting from lower costs and America's seemingly boundless appetite for huge sport utility vehicles and big pickups.
Financial analysts said that the mammoth Ford Expedition sport utility vehicle had emerged as the industry's most profitable model. Jack V. Kirnan at Salomon Brothers estimated that Ford earned $14,000 in pretax profits on each $30,000 Expedition, excluding vehicle design and engineering costs, amounting to $1.05 billion in the second quarter. 
 With inflation and unemployment staying low, G.M. and Ford predicted the good times would keep rolling. "All the indications are that 1998 will be a good year as well," J. Michael Losh, G.M.'s chief financial officer, said. G.M.'s second-quarter profits climbed 11.1 percent, to $2.10 billion, or $2.68 a share, 11 cents better, after adjustment for one-time gains, than the consensus prediction of Wall Street analysts. G.M. had earned $1.89 billion, or $2.63 a share, in the second quarter of last year.
Ford's earnings jumped 33.2 percent, to $2.53 billion, or $2.06 a share, from $1.90 billion, or $1.56 a share, a year earlier. That was 12 cents a share better than analysts anticipated, according to First Call.
Wall Street had a mixed reaction to the earnings. G.M. shares inched up 12.5 cents, to $54.375, but Ford shares dropped $1.50, to $40.625, as many investors took profits on a stock that had risen 31 percent for the year until today. Also, some financial analysts began worrying publicly about the company's falling lease profits and rising costs for rebates and other discounts.
Because of moves to cut costs, notably their insistence that suppliers accept lower prices and become more efficient, G.M. and Ford managed to raise profits despite modest sales increases. G.M.'s sales edged up to $45.15 billion from $44.78 billion, while Ford's sales rose to $40.27 billion from $38.97 billion.
In its annual ranking of the world's biggest companies in terms of sales, Fortune magazine announced on Tuesday that G.M. and Ford were once again the world's largest. For two years, the giant auto makers trailed several Japanese trading companies, but the dollar's rise against the yen over the last year put the American manufacturers back on top.
Nicholas Lobaccaro, an analyst at Merrill Lynch, attributed Ford's strong second quarter to the spectacular success of the Ford Expedition. The enormous sport utility vehicle has been selling so briskly since its introduction last autumn that Ford has had to double production.
"If you have a hot-enough product, you can buck an otherwise not-that- great environment," he said.
Mr. Losh said that because G.M.'s factories were already operating at maximum speed to make the similar Chevrolet Suburban and Tahoe, "the Expedition has not cost us a single unit sale." He said, "Full-size trucks and large sport utility vehicles continue to go gangbusters."
Both companies have also introduced new car models. John M. Devine, Ford's chief financial officer, said that the Expedition "is a good contributor, but not the only one."
Ford's share of the overall United States market for cars and light trucks rose to 25.6 percent in the second quarter from 24.8 percent a year earlier, while its share of the car market alone climbed to 20.3 percent from 19.8 percent. G.M.'s share of the overall market fell to 30.5 percent from 32.0 percent, entirely because of lost car sales; its share of the market for sport utility vehicles, mini-vans and pickup trucks held steady at 28.5 percent.
G.M.'s efforts to rebuild its car business by introducing a dozen new models this year have been hurt by strikes at assembly plants. Work stoppages cost the company $490 million after taxes during the second quarter, mainly because of an unresolved strike at a pickup truck factory in Pontiac, Mich.
The United Automobile Workers has notified G.M. that workers could walk out as soon as Tuesday at a transmission factory in Warren, Mich., and a taillight factory in Anderson, Ind. A strike at either factory could hobble G.M. assembly plants across the country within a week. But the U.A.W. has sometimes threatened strikes at crucial auto parts factories to put pressure on G.M. to settle assembly plant strikes like the one now in Pontiac.
G.M.'s strike-related losses in the quarter were largely balanced by two one-time gains -- $318 million from merging the satellite service operations of its Hughes Electronics subsidiary with those of the Panamsat Corporation, and $103 million after taxes from the sale of its stake in Avis Europe.
Two potential blemishes appeared on both companies' earnings reports. Profits slipped in their lending divisions, because of more bad debts and, at Ford, narrower profit margins on leases. With overall incentives at their highest levels ever, G.M. and Ford also reported that their costs for rebates and other discounts climbed in the quarter.
Mr. Losh said that G.M.'s average incentive on vehicles sold in North America, which hit $1,060 in the second quarter, up from $695 a year earlier, had probably peaked. But Mr. Devine said the high level of incentives was likely to remain a concern in the second half.
G.M.'s and Ford's foreign operations, particularly in Latin America, brought more cheer to auto executives. Ford recorded a $25 million profit in South America during the second quarter, its first profit in the region in two years.
South America produced higher profits per vehicle for G.M. than any other region in the world, Mr. Losh said, but it did not release figures.
Mr. Devine and Mr. Losh said in separate interviews today that a devaluation of the Brazilian currency, the subject of recent market speculation in Brazil, would have little direct effect on profits.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices Surge As Yield Hits 7-Month Low

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices surged yesterday after the latest statistics on manufacturing production and consumer prices provided additional confirmation that the economy is not picking up steam and inflation is benign. The rally drove the yield on the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond down to its lowest level in more than seven months.
"The inflation news just gets better and better," said Sherry Cooper, chief economist at Nesbitt Burns Securities Inc. 
 The price of the 30-year bond rose 27/32 , to 101 31/32 . The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction of the price, fell to 6.47 percent, from 6.54 percent on Tuesday, and is the lowest since 6.46 percent on Dec. 8, 1996.
Bonds rallied after the Labor Department reported that consumer prices rose one-tenth of 1 percent in June, slightly less than expectations. The Consumer Price Index has now risen one-tenth of 1 percent in each of the last four months and five of the last six, which has not happened since 1965. Excluding energy and food costs, the so-called core index also edged up just one-tenth of 1 percent.
"The economic statistics released today were very much in line with the concept of a moderate growth environment with quiescent and nonthreatening inflation, and certainly do not point to any change in monetary policy in the near term," said Donald Fine, chief market analyst as Chase Asset Management.
"Indeed, no change in Fed policy is expected when the Federal Open Market Committee next meets on Aug. 19, and despite some early signs of a pickup in economic growth in the third quarter, the magnitude of such may not be nearly enough to prompt the Fed to change its policy at the Sept. 30 meeting either."
In a separate report, the Federal Reserve said industrial production rose three-tenths of 1 percent in June. The moderate gain was expected, as was the unchanged level of capacity utilization at 82.5 percent. While both numbers suggested continued moderate forward momentum in the industrial sector during the third quarter, the market reaction was neutral to positive after their release.
Mr. Fine noted the spread between the Federal funds rate, now 5.50 percent, and the yield on the two-year note was about 36 basis points -- or hundredths of a percentage point -- which indicates a "neutral Fed stance," and that the bond market was not expecting a Fed move soon.
Ms. Cooper of Nesbitt Burns said, "Even if the U.S. economy stages a third-quarter growth rebound, the stellar inflation data will give the Fed plenty of leeway to stay on the sidelines for some time yet."
Elsewhere, the Treasury announced yesterday that it planned to sell $15.5 billion in two-year notes and $11.5 billion in five-year notes next week. In when-issued trading ahead of those auctions, the two-year note was being offered at a price to yield 5.91 percent and the five-year note was being offered at a price to yield 6.10 percent.
And with interest rates as low as they are, corporate borrowers have lined up to borrow from the public sector. Last week companies sold around $11 billion of debt securities.
Yesterday, Vencor Inc., which operates acute-care hospitals, nursing centers, pharmacies and assisted-living communities, priced $750 million, up from $500 million, of 10-year senior subordinated notes through underwriters led by J. P. Morgan Securities. These securities are noncallable for five years. Rated B-1 by Moody's and B by the Standard & Poor's, the notes were priced to yield 8.69 percent, or about 250 basis points more than a Treasury security with a similar maturity.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
3d-Quarter Loss at Apple Computer Is Smaller Than Expected

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, July 16

 BODY:
A battered Apple Computer Inc. surprised analysts today, reporting a smaller-than-expected loss and allaying fears that the company was on the verge of collapse.
The company's loss grew to $56 million, or 44 cents a share, in the most recent quarter, which ended on June 27, from $32 million, or 26 cents a share, a year earlier. Still, that was significantly better than the 61 cents a share that analysts surveyed by First Call had expected. 
 In an effort to reduce its sales woes -- revenue for the quarter fell to $1.74 billion, from $2.18 billion a year earlier -- Apple has apparently embarked on the crash development of a new hardware project.
People familiar with it said yesterday that Steven P. Jobs, one of the company's founders and a former chairman who has taken on a renewed leadership role, had ordered the project. They said it might involve a network computer -- an inexpensive machine for browsing the Internet, of the type propounded by the chairman of Oracle, Larry J. Ellison.
Since the abrupt dismissal last week of Apple's chairman and chief executive, Gilbert F. Amelio, concerns had mounted that the board had acted in the face of a potential financial meltdown. The company's stock plunged briefly to a low of $12.75 before rebounding to close today at $16.4375 in Nasdaq trading, up 50 cents for the day.
"I had feared a disaster," said Daniel Kunstler, a computer industry analyst at J. P. Morgan Securities in San Francisco.
This afternoon, after a telephone conference call led by Apple's chief financial officer, Fred D. Anderson, Mr. Kunstler said that the company's future remained cloudy, but that it had shown that there was a silver lining as well.
Apple executives said that the company's cash position was still strong at slightly more than $1 billion. And Apple said that it had made progress in cutting costs and bringing its break-even point in terms of revenue down toward $7 billion a year -- an amount at which it believes it can be profitable in the long run.
However, Mr. Anderson reiterated that the troubled computer maker, which is based in Cupertino, Calif., can no longer predict when it will return to profitability.
"We do not expect a profit in the fourth quarter," he said. "But as we look to the fourth quarter, operating expenses will go down and the break-even point will be reduced."
The company must still struggle with the fact that its sales have declined substantially in the last year. Apple shipped 698,000 computers during the last three months, compared with 838,000 in the quarter a year earlier. Mr. Anderson said that makers of Apple clones shipped about 75,000 computers during the quarter, suggesting that the market share for the Macintosh product line is still declining compared with machines based on Intel microprocessors and Microsoft software.
The company has chosen an executive search firm to find a person to replace Mr. Amelio, and Mr. Jobs is now spending about half his time at Apple. Mr. Anderson said that Mr. Jobs intended to remain chief executive of Pixar, the digital animation company.
Mr. Anderson did not respond directly to questions about Mr. Amelio's departure, but several statements from people close to the company have indicated that the board took action last week after it became clear that a financial turnaround was still not in sight.
"He had promised the board that he would surprise Wall Street and he didn't do it," said Charles Wolf, a financial analyst at First Boston.
Though sales fell from a year earlier, Apple's revenue increased about 12 percent in the United States compared with the previous quarter. And its sales were up by 60 percent in Japan, compared with the fiscal second quarter.

HEADLINE: Clinton Again Waives a Penalty on Foreign Companies in Cuba

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 16

 BODY:
President Clinton today waived for the third time provisions of a law he signed last year that would allow American citizens to sue foreign companies for using American property confiscated by Cuba nearly 40 years ago.
The decision drew praise from some American trading partners, who have strongly opposed the provision, but it brought protests from prominent members of the Republican-controlled Congress. 
 The law, named for its sponsors, Representative Dan Burton, Republican of Indiana, and Senator Jesse Helms, the North Carolina Republican, was passed last year in an effort to tighten the United States' 34-year economic embargo against Cuba's Communist Government.
American allies, however, have complained that it also sought to force their cooperation in the embargo, which they have refused to join.
European trading partners stopped short of a legal confrontation with the United States over the law before the World Trade Organization in April. That challenge was put off until October to allow both sides to work out a policy.
In announcing the move today, Mr. Clinton said there had been "sustained progress" in rallying allies to isolate Cuba. He pointed to such actions as the European Union's renewed commitment to make any improvement of relations with Cuba dependent on advances in human rights and political freedom.
Mr. Clinton said that European and Latin American countries were taking steps to press Cuba for democratic changes and that he was suspending parts of the law "to continue strengthening cooperation." Stuart E. Eizenstat, the Under Secretary of State for Economic Affairs, also noted statements by Argentina, Nicaragua and El Salvador calling on Cuba to begin the process of democratization.
But the chairman of the House International Relations Committee, Representative Benjamin Gilman, contested Mr. Clinton's assertion that other countries were promoting change in Cuba. He pointed to a French investment deal with Cuba signed in April and to a medal of friendship given to a Canadian Ambassador by the Castro Government.
Mr. Gilman, Republican of New York, said a bill now in Congress that would take away the President's right to waive parts of the law "will send a strong sobering signal to the President."
He and Senator Helms, the chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, also questioned whether the Administration was deliberately failing to enforce another provision of the law, which mandates the denial of United States visas to executives of companies that are using property that had been confiscated by the Cuban Government.
That provision was also sharply protested by American allies and is at the center of negotiations taking place between the United States and the Europeans.
In a letter to Mr. Clinton, Mr. Helms noted that the President does not have the authority to waive this section. He asked why only officials of two companies had so far been denied visas. They were from Grupo Domos, a Mexican telephone company, and Sherritt International Corporation of Canada, which owns nickel mines and other interests in Cuba.
Mr. Helms charged that there was a growing suspicion in Congress that the Administration was not enforcing this section "as a quid pro quo" for Europe's suspension of its World Trade Organization suit.
Mr. Eizenstat said the Administration was enforcing the provision.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
A new move to cut the costs of Federal regulations.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
SENATOR FRED THOMPSON, chairman of the Senate Governmental Affairs Committee, is making headlines with reports that China tried to influence the 1996 election. But when he's not searching for the Manchurian Candidate, the Tennessee Republican's first priority these days is adding a little common sense to the way regulations are analyzed. To this end, Senator Thompson and Senator Carl Levin, a Michigan Democrat, have introduced the Regulatory Improvement Act of 1997, which would require Federal regulators to calculate price tags for all major rules.
That is a lot more than some environmental groups -- who see bean counters as more worrisome adversaries than their traditional enemies -- are prepared to tolerate. The bill "would undermine crucially important environmental, public health and safety protections," proclaimed the Natural Resources Defense Council.
And it is a lot less than business lobbies want. "The bill is so weak, it's probably not worth passing," said Charles di Bona, president of the American Petroleum Institute.
But the support of a number of centrist Senators, including two Democrats, John D. Rockefeller 4th of West Virginia and John Glenn of Ohio, has heartened pragmatic economists who fear that Federal regulation is becoming a serious drag on economic growth. "At least cost is no longer a four-letter word," argued Robert Hahn of the American Enterprise Institute.
Washington has never quite made up its collective mind about what is needed to justify regulation. Every President since Gerald R. Ford has demanded that executive agencies compare costs and benefits with an eye toward efficiency. But Congress has formally prohibited cost considerations on the biggest-ticket health and safety laws -- notably the Clean Air Act.
In the brief, heady days of the Gingrich revolution, there was much talk of creating a "supermandate" under which regulations could be challenged if costs exceeded benefits. But Congress lost its enthusiasm for regulatory reform after the Government shutdown fiasco. And while the Administration has paid lip service to curbing regulation, the White House approved the new standard for ozone exposure last month, despite estimates showing that its multibillion-dollar annual cost was grossly disproportionate. More striking, the Republicans don't seem inclined to stick their necks out in opposition.
The Levin-Thompson bill lays claim to a rational middle ground that emphasizes accountability and public disclosure. Regulators would be required to hire independent experts to compare costs and benefits in consistent ways, and to provide justifications for any rules that flunked the test. Where regulation addressed health and safety, the regulators would have to explain who was at risk and to what degree. If there are several possible means to the same end -- for example, a choice of mandated technological fixes or market-based financial incentives -- agencies would have to explain the alternatives and the reason for favoring one over another.
Nothing in the bill would invite the courts to toss out rules because costs exceeded benefits. Indeed, little in the bill would break new ground: except in cases of independent agencies like the Federal Communications Commission, the President already has the authority to set standards by executive order. But Robert Litan, director of economic studies at the Brookings Institution, noted that "no one's been forced to pull it all together" -- that formal guidelines would help reduce uncertainty and increase consistency.
Mr. Litan and Mr. Hahn would go a step further. They note with approval that Senator Ted Stevens, Republican of Alaska, inserted an amendment into a big appropriations act last year requiring the White House to produce a detailed accounting of the costs and benefits of all Federal regulation by Sept. 30 this year. Why not make this an annual accounting, they ask, giving the public a chance to second-guess regulatory mandates?
There are very few innocents left on the long-contested battleground of regulatory reform. While Senator Thompson insists that he has no desire to "slash and burn" regulation, most environmental groups will brook no changes in the way rules are made because they have the inside track on influencing the senior bureaucracy at the Environmental Protection Agency. By the same token, business lobbyists are at best lukewarm about the Levin-Thompson approach because they are convinced that green-friendly regulators will be inclined to cook the books to justify intervention.
That explains why this seemingly innocuous bill is a long shot, particularly in the House, where compromise on regulation is far from almost everyone's mind. But it also explains why regulatory policy may lurch from "anti-business" to "pro-business," reducing productivity without having a significant impact on health or safety.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
A Market Oblivious To Gravity

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
What goes up must come down.
Says who? 
 The Dow Jones industrial average climbed above 8,000 yesterday, just seven months after it first topped 6,000. It has doubled in less than 30 months.
Over the last 12 months, the index has risen 50 percent, a kind of performance seen only during the most explosive market moves.
Why is this happening? "Things are perfect," said Edward Kerschner, Paine Webber's top strategist. "They truly are. How else can you describe 2 percent inflation and 10 percent profit growth?"
That is not all. Interest rates have been falling, and some of the overseas markets that had seen explosive growth have begun to seem risky. Individual investors have continued to pour money into stock mutual funds, with many accepting the thesis that stocks are the best long-term investment, and companies are buying each other at a fast pace. When they pay cash for shares, as many do, that shrinks the available supply of stock.
Many Wall Street veterans find the market's surge hard to believe, and valuation measures show stocks to be quite expensive. But that was also true 1,000 Dow points ago, and anyone who got out then has missed a great few months.
Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, scared investors in December with talk of "irrational exuberance," and then frightened them more by raising short-term interest rates a bit in March. But since then the Fed has backed off, and now there is confidence that it will do nothing to spoil the party.
"The question," Mr. Kerschner added, "is what price you pay for perfection." He thinks the price being paid now is dangerously high, and expects the Dow to suffer a 10 percent drop soon, something that has not happened to that index since 1990. It has never gone longer than that without such a pullback, but similar forecasts in recent years have always been wrong.
People do not care about value, Steve Leuthold, a Minneapolis-based analyst whose Leuthold Group closely monitors valuation, said yesterday. "Individual investors don't know price-to-book value, or any of those things," he said. "They know prices are going up." Given the market's momentum and the demand for stocks, Mr. Leuthold's market model is bullish, however, even with valuations looking to be very high.
Perhaps the most impressive aspect of the Dow's ascent is the 50 percent climb since this time a year ago. Over the last half-century, there have been only three times when the market managed to show gains of as much as 47 percent over a 12-month period. Two of them, in 1982-83 and 1975-76, came as the market exploded out of severe bear markets that had been accompanied by recessions. The only similar move in a market environment like this one -- after a prolonged rise in stock prices -- came in 1986-87. It was followed by the 1987 crash, but prices rallied, and within a couple of years the Dow was again setting new highs.
By some measurements, the current bull market can be traced to the 1982 low. By that definition, it will celebrate its 15th anniversary next month. Those 15 years have been better than any comparable period in American stock market history. The Dow is now more than 10 times as high as it was in 1982.
In a true bull market, bad news about a company can have only a transient effect. For example, Intel stock plunged in May, when the company warned that its second-quarter earnings would be disappointing. This week it reported earnings that were a bit better than the profits it had forecast in May, but still well below what analysts had expected before the May announcement. The stock zoomed up, and hit a record high yesterday. It has risen 25 percent since the end of June.
In that kind of environment, the risk of not being in stocks seems to many investors to be much greater than the risk of being in them, regardless of whether valuations seem high. There is nothing apparent on the horizon that is likely to change that risk-reward calculation.

HEADLINE: Political Memo;
'Uncle Rudy' Uses Power To the Fullest

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE 

 BODY:
Hardened observers of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani were astonished earlier this week when the Mayor removed his jet-black double-breasted Hugo Boss suit jacket and casually tossed it on the grass in the sweltering shade of City Hall Park. As the city's masculine standard bearer, Mr. Giuliani almost never publicly acknowledges that he is capable of perspiration.
It immediately became obvious, however, why it was necessary to parade the mayoral sweat stains before the public: Mr. Giuliani was about to teach summer school. The lesson plan: Drink plenty of fluids, but nothing with alcohol or caffeine. Avoid strenuous activity. And don't wear dark clothing. (He seemed to sense this was not an appropriate lecture for a starchy business suit.) 
 Though wilting city residents may have heard those helpful suggestions once or twice before in their lives, the lesson was somewhat more illuminating of the Mayor's turn of mind regarding his role and that of municipal government in general. This was Mr. Giuliani in what one City Hall staffer called "Uncle Rudy mode," using his prominence and the tools of power to help direct the lives of citizens.
In fact, for all his talk about leaving behind the "tired, old-fashioned ways" of doing things in New York, the Mayor is as much a believer in an activist, in-your-face government as any of his predecessors. Though he has consciously worked to make welfare less user friendly, and though his spending cuts have reduced a variety of city services, he has demonstrated that he is eager to employ the full apparatus of city government when it suits his interest, particularly as election time gets closer.
In his view, much disputed by his opponents, it is government that reduced crime, government that is restarting the city's economy, government that is protecting battered children and putting computers in the schools. Having championed immigrants' rights as one of his campaign themes, he announced earlier this year that he was setting up entirely new offices of government to help immigrants become citizens.
Just yesterday, in fact, Mr. Giuliani made three announcements large and small that clearly illustrate his predilection for using the power of the state: He said his staff had spent the last several days persuading private companies to hire many of the 475 workers soon to be laid off when Swingline Staplers moves to Mexico. (His electoral opponents had criticized him for seeming not to care about the layoffs.) He announced plans to spend $260 million to build the long-delayed replacement for Kings County Hospital, having moved away from his earlier position that the city should move out of the hospital business. He even chimed in on the story about the murder of the designer Gianni Versace in Miami Beach, setting up the city's own reward for the capture of the killer.
At a luncheon with a group of moderate and right-of-center Democrats on Tuesday, the Mayor acknowledged that he was not one of those Republicans who believes government should stay out of people's lives.
"On one side you have people who philosophically believe government has no role, and on the other side you have people who believe government should run people's lives," he said. "I try to fall somewhere right in the middle. I try to figure out where government can be helpful. Sometimes government has to run people's lives because nobody else will help them, but you should try to keep that to a minimum."
Councilman Sal F. Albanese, one of the Democrats vying for his party's nomination to challenge the Mayor, said Mr. Giuliani often goes too far in manipulating the levers of government. "He's got this autocratic style, and he wants to micromanage the entire city," Mr. Albanese said. "In the Police Department, he wants to decide who the precinct commanders will be. He overreaches to the point of causing his managers to second-guess themselves, and it's not an effective style."
Mr. Giuliani is clearly aware that no New York mayor can succeed at the helm of a laissez-faire city government. Residents have become accustomed to the idea of an all-embracing city government, and that's why the city shouldn't expect to hear much talk about austerity as November nears. It's summertime: Put on a hat!

HEADLINE: Japan Trade Surplus Fell 21.6% in June

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Thursday, July 17

 BODY:
Japan's merchandise trade surplus fell in June from the previous month, with export growth slowing from its blistering pace earlier this spring.
The surplus decreased a seasonally adjusted 21.6 percent in June from May, to 865.46 billion yen, or $7.45 billion, the Finance Ministry said. That was the first decline since March. And while the surplus in June was up about 28 percent from a year earlier, it was still smaller than economists had expected. 
 That lends credence to claims by Japanese officials that the surplus is stabilizing as manufacturers rely less on exports to reap profits.
An end to the growth in the surplus could help defuse tensions with Japan's largest trading partners, including the United States.

HEADLINE: Dow Breaks Through 8,000; Nasdaq Surges 38.52 Points

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA 

 BODY:
The stock market, already in the midst of one of the greatest bull runs in history, reached yet another milestone yesterday.
The Dow Jones industrial average -- the most widely followed market gauge -- closed above the 8,000-point level for the first time, gaining 63.17 points to close at 8,038.88. 
 And the broader market, while not crashing through any particular barriers, easily outperformed the Dow. Soaring shares of technology issues sent the Nasdaq composite index up 38.52 points, or 2.5 percent, to 1,580.63 in one of its best sessions of the year and its 10th consecutive record close. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 10.83 points, to a record 936.59.
The impressive gains this year have come about, analysts say, largely because America is in the midst of a stunning, seven-year-long economic expansion. Corporate profits are soaring, unemployment is at a 24-year low, and yet inflation remains benign.
"You've got a favorable earnings trend, a favorable interest rate trend, and investors are feeling pretty good about it," said Byron R. Wien, the United States investment strategist at Morgan Stanley & Company. "This is a market where it looks like everything is going right."
Yesterday's gains, for instance, came on a day when the Government said that the Consumer Price Index rose just one-tenth of 1 percent in June. That means that inflation for the first six months of the year rose at its slowest pace in 11 years. That sent bond prices higher yesterday, with the yield on the benchmark 30-year Treasury tumbling to 6.47 percent -- its lowest level since December.
Although many on Wall Street had believed at the end of last year that the best days of this bull market were behind it, investors this year have continued to pour billions of dollars into a booming stock market, sending all of the major indexes to record highs.
Of course, many of Wall Street's seasoned analysts believe that shares are too pricey, and that the fundamentals, although excellent, do not justify the escalating prices. Even more believe the market will end the year below this level.
"I thought we'd have a down year, but I think the chances of that are pretty low now," said Mr. Wien of Morgan Stanley. "But I still have a sense of the ominous. I think something negative is brewing; it's just taking longer to come to a boil."
But investors who heeded such advice over the last two or three years have missed out on a spectacular run.
Yesterday, the market was bolstered by another batch of strong earnings reports, from companies like General Motors and Lucent Technologies, both of which jumped sharply in the stock market. And as the second-quarter earnings season picks up, investors are becoming even more ebullient.
While yesterday's session occurred in the middle of summer, when volume is traditionally light, activity was historic -- the fifth- heaviest trading day ever for the Big Board, where advancing issues beat decliners by a better than 2-to-1 margin.
"This is what is called a melt-up," said Charles Pradilla, a market strategist at Cowen & Company. "I've never seen a rally like this. Every time things seem excessive, more good news chimes in."
After flirting with the 8,000 level for a week, the Dow finally broke through at 9:40 A.M. yesterday, 10 minutes after the opening bell, to the cheers of many traders on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange.
Although the Dow was the center attraction yesterday, technology stocks crowded the market once again. Shares of the software giant Microsoft, a bellwether computer issue, rose 9 31/32 , to 148 7/16 . For the year, Microsoft is up nearly 80 percent, allowing the stock to pass shares of Coca-Cola yesterday as the second-largest issue in terms of market value at $178 billion. General Electric, a Dow component stock, is first at $242 billion. G.E. rose 1 13/16 yesterday, and is up almost 50 percent this year. Coca-Cola, also a Dow stock, rose 3/4, to 70 7/8, with a total market value is $176 billion.
Part of the technology surge was also due to Intel, which reported better-than-expected earnings after the market closed on Tuesday. Shares of Intel rose 7 16/32 yesterday, to 88 3/8. Dell Computer, on a tear in recent weeks, surged 6 1/2, to 147 15/16 , and Compaq Computer, up 35 percent in three weeks, rose 6 1/4, to 133 1/2.
J. P. Morgan was the Dow's best performer, up 3, to 111, followed by the Travelers Group, up 2 1/4, to 68 1/2. Eastman Kodak was the worst performer, losing 8 1/2, to 68 3/8, after it reported disappointing second-quarter earnings.
With yesterday's gains, the Dow has now doubled in two and a half years, passing through five 1,000-point barriers. Seven months ago, few on Wall Street thought 7,000 was possible. Now, there is a growing chorus of unapologetic bulls chanting, "Dow 10,000 by 2,000."

HEADLINE: U.N. Chief Promises to Overhaul Organization From the Top Down

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, July 16

 BODY:
Secretary General Kofi Annan announced today that he intends to sweep away a United Nations management system accrued over more than half a century and restructure the organization's administration from the top down.
There will be no large cuts in staff or programs in the plan, which some critics of the United Nations had demanded. 
 But the Secretary General, who said in a news conference today that he was offended by those demands, argued that his plan was intended to make the organization more efficient rather than smaller.
Gone will be the cumbersome arrangement under which more than two dozen fiefs within the Secretariat and the organization's more or less autonomous agencies all had direct access to the Secretary General. In its place will be a cabinet of fewer than a dozen top officials with enhanced powers in major areas.
Under his proposal, for the first time in the organization's history, there would be a Deputy Secretary General. A Department of Disarmament would be reinstated and a strengthened human rights office would get a role in the top tier of management, Mr. Annan said. Some changes require General Assembly approval while others do not.
The Secretary General, who presented his plan to a special General Assembly session this morning, is gambling that his proposals contain enough streamlining and cumulative cost-cutting to pacify the United States Congress and yet pay adequate attention to the demands of poor nations, which could use their majority to block key changes that many believe have been forced on the organization by industrialized countries.
In a two-phase process that began just after Mr. Annan took office in January, he promised to complete cuts of 1,000 staff positions.
A fund for development is to be set up from money saved in administrative reforms. The hope is to have $200 million by 2002; about $55 million may be available this year.
In Washington today, initial reactions to Mr. Annan's proposals were predictably mixed, given the divisive nature of the debate over the relationship between the United States and the United Nations.
A spokesman for Jesse Helms, the North Carolina Republican who is chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations committee, said that Mr. Annan's proposal fell short of what he had promised Mr. Helms in meetings earlier this year.
"They're going to have to go a lot further than this," said the spokesman, Marc A. Thiessen. He said the plan "really doesn't do anything."
Critics of the United Nations in Washington had demanded further large cuts in staff and the abolition of programs or agencies as well as more control over United Nations activities.
Saying that "the United Nations is not working as it should," Mr. Annan pledged today to begin "a quiet revolution" that would make the organization more efficient without reducing its ability to have an impact in a wide range of areas.
"In return, I ask of you, and of the world, that you judge us not only by the cuts we propose or by the structures we change," the Secretary General said, addressing both rich and poor nations. "Judge us instead -- and judge us rightly -- by the relief and refuge that we provide to the poor, to the hungry, the sick and threatened: The peoples of the world whom the United Nations exists to serve."
Most diplomatic missions here and interested groups around the United States are seeing the completed plan for the first time today, since it has been written and rewritten many times over in the last week or two amid gathering gloom in many quarters that a lot of watering down was taking place within the United Nations bureaucracy.
These criticisms have come not from budget-cutters, but mostly from volunteer organizations who have seen the United Nations appear ineffectual in an increasing number of civil wars and refugee crises and want the organization to take a more active role in these areas.
In a news conference after his address, the Secretary General made clear that his plan was aimed at the General Assembly, not the United States.
"My report is directed at the member states, and there are 185 of them," he said. "I know that you keep pulling me back to the Congress, to the Hill and to Washington. I know there are people in Washington who would want to see a much stricter, a much deeper cut. I'm not sure that some of the people on the Hill who are so strong against the U.N. and come with these conditions and really make these demands on the 184 other states realize the impact of their actions. In my contacts and observations, I can tell you my assessment is that these unilateral demands do not impress. They do not intimidate. In fact, they offend."
Senator Rod Grams, the Minnesota Republican who is chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations subcommittee on international organizations, said that "this meager package represents nothing more than the status quo, and that is unacceptable."
"Today's plan merely reshuffles the deck at a time when the number of cards need to be reduced," he said in a statement.
Senator Joseph Biden, the Delaware Democrat who negotiated a compromise set of demands on the United Nations that would allow money to be released to pay some of the more than $1 billion the United States owes the organization in dues, welcomed the plan for its efforts to consolidate programs, but also alluded to Congressional "benchmarks" for measuring reform -- restrictions on United Nations activities and more American oversight of the United Nations -- demands that many diplomats say are both unacceptable and in violation of international treaties.
Richard L. Thornburgh, a former United States Attorney General who wrote a critical report about the functioning of the United Nations when he was Under Secretary General for Administration and Management in 1992-1993, said today that he applauds the recommendation that a Deputy Secretary General be appointed. He said that the organization was "replete with diplomats" and needed a manager to bring coherence to its many programs.
Mr. Thornburgh, a Republican, echoed the cautious hopes of many when he described Mr. Annan as "a good man who really intends to accomplish reform."
The Secretary General, the first insider elected to the position, is widely believed to have a reservoir of good will to draw on. But he will be judged by his firmness in making appointments, cutting into bureaucratic empires and fending off pressures from governments demanding jobs.
Bill Richardson, the United States representative to the United Nations, said in an interview after Mr. Annan's speech that the report "heads in the right direction."
"The general thrust, which improves efficiency, lowers cost and focuses on the core missions of the U.N. are steps in the right direction," Mr. Richardson said.
"But the Secretary General can't accomplish all his proposed reforms by himself," he said. Mr. Richardson, in his speech to the General Assembly today, urged it to set up a committee to begin work on the proposals immediately. The formal annual work session of the assembly does not begin until September.
Among several proposals that require action by the General Assembly, and are expected to generate controversy there, is the appointment of a Deputy Secretary General. Another is the plan to create for the first time a revolving fund to tide the organization over during financial crises like the one caused by Washington's refusal to pay its dues. Such a fund would rob Congress of some of its power to hold the organization at ransom.
The General Assembly would also have to approve the disbanding or redirecting of bodies like the Trusteeship Council, the insertion of "sunset" clauses into new programs and the creation of a high-level ministerial commission to study the workings of United Nations agencies not under the Secretary General's direct control -- among them the World Health Organization, Unesco and bodies dealing with international trade and communications.
The assembly was also asked today to consider a new system of "results-based" budgeting that would allow the Secretary General and other officials to decide how to spend the money the assembly has allocated and would hold them accountable for their decisions.
David E. Birenbaum, the former United States representative for reform and administration at the United Nations, said in an interview today that this budget reform plan was "terribly important" because it pushes officials to deliver. He characterized the proposals in total as "a good solid package."
Mr. Annan will not need assembly approval to create his government-style cabinet, however, or to group the organization's activities under four major headings led by managers of cabinet rank: Peace and security, humanitarian affairs, economic and social affairs, and development. This process has already begun, but not without frictions. Human rights will also have a cabinet-level position.
Unicef's executive director, Carol Bellamy, had publicly criticized plans to put her agency (and the United Nations Population Fund) under the oversight of the United Nations Development Program, whose administrator is another American, James Gustave Speth.
A similar group of relief organizations -- the High Commissioner for Refugees, the World Food Program and the Relief and Works Agency in the Middle East -- will come under the chairmanship of a new Emergency Relief Coordinator, yet to be named. That office will replace the larger Department of Humanitarian Affairs, which will be abolished.
Mr. Annan said at a news conference today that he welcomed a little conflict in the decision-making process. "In this organization we are often worried about conflict," he said. "We go around believing that conflict must be avoided at all cost. I don't share that view. I'm not a confrontational person, but I'm not one who avoids conflicts.
"I want us to be a team, but I'm not talking about a rowing team, for example," he said. "I'm talking of a team like soccer, where you play as a team but there is room for individual brilliance, individual expression and for entities to do what they do best."
Other proposals made by Mr. Annan today include the following:
In the field, United Nations agencies will work from one office -- called a United Nations House -- in each capital instead of having separate offices and uncoordinated programs.
The proposal also calls for the creation of a strategic planning staff to advise the Secretary General and his cabinet on policy matters. It also calls for international Internet access to United Nations information and documents.
Taken together, the two phases of streamlining proposals will have the effect of trimming administrative costs by 33 percent and reducing the use of paper by the end of this year by 30 percent.

HEADLINE: Swingline Workers, Facing Layoff, Get a Promise of Help, Sort Of

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON 

 BODY:
The 487 workers at the Swingline stapler factory in Long Island City, Queens, who will lose their jobs as a result of the company's move to Mexico, received a promise yesterday from Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani that the city would help in their search for new jobs.
For a while it looked like more than just help. Mr. Giuliani was quoted in a press release from his office as saying that the city had "reached agreements with private sector companies," many of them in Long Island City, "to hire a large number of Swingline employees." 
 Aides to the Mayor, and spokesmen for the companies themselves, quickly back-pedalled, saying that employers had agreed only to consider the Swingline workers in their future plans.
"They're willing to look at hiring the Swingline people," said Rudy Washington, the Deputy Mayor for community development and business services. No company, Mr. Washington said, had agreed to hire, "sight unseen -- that's not good business."
"But they are willing to hire out of the Swingline pool," Mr. Washington said.
Mr. Giuliani's announcement came 10 days after he was harshly criticized -- by his likely Democratic opponent for re-election in November, Ruth W. Messinger, among others -- for a series of remarks in which he played down the significance of the Swingline closing. The Mayor said then that in a time of economic growth in New York, a company that was leaving simply to increase profits by getting cheap labor somewhere else would not be overly missed.
Yesterday, the Mayor's tone was just as upbeat, this time about how terrific New York business and educational institutions were for their "willingness to lend a helping hand to others in a time of great need." He said that St. John's University in Queens had volunteered, for example, to help in the retraining of 100 of the displaced Swingline workers.
Swingline, which is owned by Acco U.S.A., an indirect wholly owned subsidiary of Fortune Brands Corporation in Old Greenwich, Conn., said in May that it could reduce labor costs more than $12 million by moving operations to Mexico. At the request of the city and the state, the company held off a final decision. But the package of tax abatements, energy cost reductions and other inducements assembled by economic development officials were not enough. Last month, the company said it would close in about 18 to 24 months.
Mr. Washington said that more than 70 companies in New York had been contacted on the Swingline closing. The companies, from manufacturers to bakeries, have combined plans to hire 600 to 700 people by the end of this year.
Several companies said they were not sure what kinds of skills the Swingline employees had, so it was impossible to guess how good the fit might be. Steve Kaplan, a spokesman for Blue Ridge Farms, a company in East New York, Brooklyn, that makes prepared foods like salads and entrees for institutions and supermarkets and which hopes to add 100 jobs this year, said he needed mechanics. As blue-collar work in New York has declined, he said, those people have become harder to find.
"There's not the great cadre there used to be of mechanics who know what they're doing, so we're hoping we'll be able to utilize these people," he said. "We'll take a look."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Inflation Remains Benign, And Wall Street Applauds
Consumer prices rose only one-tenth of 1 percent in June, generating further optimism that the economy can continue to enjoy steady growth and low unemployment, without the need for interest-rate increases. 
 The report reassured investors, buoying the stock market as the Dow Jones industrial average climbed above 8,000. [Page D4.]
 
The bond market reacted favorably, too, with the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond falling to its lowest level in more than seven months, 6.47 percent, down from 6.54. [D15.]
 
G.M. and Ford Above Expectations
General Motors and Ford announced better-than-expected earnings, benefiting from reduced costs and the seemingly boundless appetite for big sport-utility vehicles and pickups. An analyst estimates that Ford earns $14,000 every time it sells one model, the Ford Expedition. [D4.]
 
Columbia/HCA Papers Are Seized
Law enforcement agents seized documents at dozens of hospitals and offices operated by Columbia/HCA Healthcare. The investigation is multifaceted, but was said to center on whether Columbia misrepresented expenses to increase compensation from Federal programs like Medicare. [A1.]
 
Federal investigators conducting an audit of Medicare said that the Government had overpaid hospitals, doctors and other health care providers last year by $23 billion. [A1.]
 
Apple's Loss Is Below Forecasts
Apple Computer surprised analysts with a smaller-than-expected loss, allaying fears that it was on the verge of collapse. Apple has embarked on a crash hardware development project -- possibly a network computer -- people familiar with the project said. [D3.]
 
Time Warner Entertainment to Stay
Time Warner and U S West ended their talks to disband their cable TV and entertainment venture, Time Warner Entertainment. Also, Time Warner reported earnings that exceeded Wall Street's expectations. [D6.]
 
Weak Kodak Report Hurts Stock
Kodak's earnings fell sharply, hurt by a strong dollar, a price war on film, and mounting losses on its digital and Advantix cameras, and the company's stock plunged. [D2.]
 
Strong Quarter for Lucent and GTE
The popularity of the Internet and of wireless telephones fueled strong earnings at Lucent Technologies, the nation's biggest maker of telecommunications equipment, and GTE, one of the largest telecommunications services companies. Lucent's stock soared on the news. [D5.]
 
Northrop and General Dynamics Up
Two military contractors, Northrop Grumman and General Dynamics, reported earnings gains that were bigger than expected. [D4.]
 
Helms-Burton Provisions Waived
President Clinton for the third time waived provisions of the Helms-Burton Act, which has angered trading partners, who say that it would force their compliance with the American trade embargo against Cuba. [A8.]
 
Partial Lilco Takeover Is Cleared
New York State officials approved a partial state takeover of Long Island Lighting, after the inclusion of a guarantee that electric rates for Long Island residents would drop by at least 14 percent over 10 years. [B6.]
 
Anti-Seizure Device Approved
The F.D.A. approved the first medical device intended to reduce epileptic seizures, made by a Texas company, Cyberonics. [A20.]
 
New Rule Planned on Derivatives
The Financial Accounting Standards Board, despite pressure for delay from banks and brokerage firms, said that it would issue a new rule on accounting for derivatives this fall. It wants derivatives to be reflected on companies' balance sheets, not hidden. [D19.]
 
Racial Bias Charges Against Firm
The Government added charges of racial discrimination to those of sexual harassment facing Lew Lieberbaum & Company, a securities brokerage. [B6.]

HEADLINE: Sister Charged With Murder, and Identity Switch

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: OAKLAND, Calif., July 16

 BODY:
A woman who had been hailed as an anti-drug crusader after she claimed her home had been firebombed by drug dealers was arrested late Tuesday night, suspected of killing her sister and assuming her identity.
The woman, Sarah Allman, 47, was charged with murder, forgery and giving false information to the police in a scheme the authorities said was meant to withdraw money belonging to her sister, Stevie Allman, 52. 
 The police say the older Ms. Allman's body was inside a charred freezer they discovered on Tuesday in the burned-out house that the two women shared.
"I don't know if bizarre quite describes it," said Capt. Peter Dunbar of the Oakland Police Department. "This is the stuff of a Hollywood movie."
At some point, the authorities said, Sarah Allman assumed the identity of her sister, apparently to gain access to the deed to their house and payments that the elder sister was to receive from a previous job.
Stevie Allman was an unemployed secretary known by the police for her efforts to rid her East Oakland neighborhood of drug dealers.
For more than a year, Ms. Allman had been videotaping drug sales on her street and sending the tapes to the police. The police say she may have last been seen in early April.
The night of the July 1 blaze firefighters rescued a middle-age woman who had been badly burned on her face, arms and legs. The woman, who identified herself Stevie Allman, told the authorities that she suspected that the fire had been set by drug dealers she had angered.
Her story seemed to check out after officials confirmed that they had been called there twice before to extinguish fires set outside the house.
For residents of this blue-collar city, Ms. Allman's tale instantly struck a chord. Within days, dozens of Oakland residents had cleaned Ms. Allman's street, and $3,000 was donated to a fund set up to cover her hospital costs.
The sudden civic beneficence was capped last week when the Gov. Pete Wilson announced a $50,000 reward for the arrest and conviction of Ms. Allman's attackers.
All the while, the police say, Sarah Allman had been posing as her sister, gilding the fraud by releasing a pair of defiant statements directed at her purported assailants.
"I have no doubt they intended to murder me," she said in statement released on Tuesday. "Their warped minds thought the act would clear the way to do their dirty dealing."
It was only when one of Ms. Allman's 10 siblings alerted the police that two women were living in the house that the authorities became suspicious.
On Tuesday afternoon, officers searching the house with a dog found a charred freezer near the spot where the blaze had begun.
A few hours later, the police said, they persuaded Ms. Allman to provide them with fingerprints, which matched a set taken in 1971 when she was arrested for prostitution. The police say Sarah Allman then confessed to impersonating her sister.
The Governor's office said the reward would stand until officials could determine whether the blaze was actually Sarah Allman's work or someone else's.
Adding more uncertainty to the twisted case, the police said it was not certain whether Sarah or Stevie Allman had sent the videotapes to the department. "We can't tell, we just can't tell," Captain Dunbar said. "Nothing about this so far has been clear."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Officials say Sarah Allman killed her sister, stuffed the body into a freezer and then took her identity. (Associated Press)

INTERNATIONAL A3-15
 
Leader at United Nations Unveils Reform Proposals
Secretary General Kofi Annan proposed his plan to streamline the United Nations organizational structure to the General Assembly. A1
 
U.S. Moves on Security Council
The Clinton Administration is poised to recommend that three permanent seats on the United Nations Security Council be given to developing nations, a senior American official said. Under the American proposal, developing countries would decide how to fill the new permanent seats. A14 

New Cambodian Leader Chosen
A rump session of Cambodia's Parliament selected Foreign Minister Ung Huot, who was educated in Australia, to be the country's titular head of government. Mr. Ung Huot become First Prime Minister, replacing Prince Norodom Ranariddh, who was ousted in a coup led by Second Prime Minister Hun Sen. The selection signaled acquiescence to Mr. Hun Sen's seizure of power by those royalist members of Parliament who have not fled the country. A7
 
Bosnian Serbs Threaten NATO
Bosnian Serb authorities have threatened widespread retaliation against NATO soldiers if NATO attempts further arrests of war crimes suspects, according to United Nations officials. State-controlled Bosnian Serb television and radio commentary have been inflammatory. An American soldier was gouged by a man wielding a sickle. A6
 
European Union Looks East
Invitations to begin negotiations for membership in the European Union were extended by the European Commission to five former Communist countries and Cyprus. Hungary, Poland, the Czech Republic, Estonia and Slovenia were all pleased, although the timetable was vague. A6
 
NASA Approves Mir Repair Plan
NASA has endorsed a Russian plan to deploy an American astronaut in a key supporting role in a difficult operation to repair the damaged Mir space station. They said the plan is technically sound and would not pose excessive risk for Michael Foale, who they said was willing to replace the Russian commander, who is ill. A3
 
Rwandan Troops Accused
Rwandan troops were responsible for most of the atrocities committed against refugees and local civilians in the eastern half of neighboring Congo over the last several months, investigators from a human rights group told a Congressional committee. A10
 
Concessions Made in Kenya
President Daniel arap Moi of Kenya said his Government would grant permits for opposition rallies. Mr. Moi met with Christian and Islamic leaders and agreed to meet with opposition leaders next week. Protests in favor of constitutional reform before coming elections had led to violent conflicts between civilians and riot policemen. A9 
 
NATIONAL A16-21, B7-9
 
Big Medicare Audit Shows Widespread Overpayments
Federal investigators who completed the most comprehensive audit of Medicare to date said the Government overpaid hospitals, doctors and other health-care providers last year by $23 billion, or 14 percent of all the money spent in the traditional Medicare program. An official said there was no way to determine how much of the overpayment resulted from fraud. A1
 
Huang Didn't Seek Briefings
A C.I.A. official told the Senate committee examining campaign finance abuses that John Huang's briefings on classified information about Asia were part of routine procedures at the Commerce Department and were not initiated by Mr. Huang, a political appointee who later became a controversial fund-raiser for President Clinton. A1
 
Suspect Leaves Odd Trail
Andrew Phillip Cunanan was a gregarious and charming figure in San Diego's gay community, but none of those who knew him said they saw any trace of the violence that has made Mr. Cunanan the sole suspect in a cross-country killing spree, leaving five men dead including the fashion designer Gianni Versace. Law-enforcement authorities in South Florida have orchestrated one of the largest manhunts in recent times, stationing agents at airports, seaports and along major highways to find Mr. Cunanan. B8

A study by researchers at New York University Medical Center extends the growing list of ways in which the AIDS virus can invade human cells and suggests that future treatments aimed at blocking a single pathway might not be enough to fight the infection. A18
 
Traffic Deaths Increase

Delinquent parents shirk court orders to pay child support in four of every five cases, and Federal efforts to help states boost compliance rates have failed, the General Accounting Office reported. A16

President Clinton is planning to announce today that he will ask Congress for $350 million over the next five years to help recruit and train teachers for students in impoverished urban and rural districts, Administration officials said. B7
 
NEW YORK/REGION B1-6
 
Renovation Scaled Back For Kings County Hospital
The Giuliani administration announced a drastically scaled-back proposal to rebuild Kings County Hospital in Brooklyn, the city's largest and most dilapidated public medical center. The plan would abandon all vestiges of an earlier billion-dollar reconstruction project that fell apart in 1994 amid charges of mismanagement and incompetence. Instead, $260 million would be spent over the next six years to construct two new buildings for emergency services and beds for medical and surgical patients on the hospital's 40-acre campus. B1
 
Lilco Deal Wins Approval
In a $7.3 billion deal that involves the largest municipal bond sale in history, state officials approved a partial state takeover of the Long Island Lighting Company, including a guarantee that the buyout would lower electric rates for Long Islanders by at least 14 percent over 10 years. B6
 
CUNY Official Has Interview
W. Ann Reynolds, the chancellor of the City University of New York who has been harshly attacked in recent months by leaders of the university's governing board, appeared before the trustees of the University of Alabama and made an eager pitch to become president of their Birmingham campus. She is one of two finalists for the post. B1
 
Queens Suffers Blackout
About 5,000 Queens residents lost electrical power as the demand for energy soared amid the summer's first extended heat wave. Temperatures were expected to rise back into the 90's today and an ozone advisory was likely to remain in effect. B3
 
SPORTS B11-17
 
Kwan on Path to Olympics
Seventeen-year-old figure skater Michelle Kwan jokingly refers to the previous competitive season as "my coma." Her story could have become a cautionary tale of another young skater pushed too far, too fast. Instead, she picked herself up when she fell, finished second at the world championships, and is now seven months away from the 1998 Winter Olympics in Nagano, Japan. B15
 
HOME C1-9
 
Coping With the Sun
Sun worshipers hoping to avoid long-lasting damage have been buying new products that contain antioxidants. But some dermatologists are concerned that patients are getting the wrong message from antioxidants, whose benefits have not been proven conclusively. C2

O'Keeffe Museum Opens
A museum devoted to Georgia O'Keeffe opens today in Santa Fe, N.M., to the predictable hoopla. But for many people, the news will be that no O'Keeffe museum has existed until now. C11
 
BUSINESS DAY D1-19
 
Health Investigation Widens
Teams of law enforcement agents armed with search warrants descended on dozens of hospitals and offices operated by the Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation as part of a wide-ranging inquiry that involves multiple grand jury investigations in several states. The investigation centers on complex accounting issues related to forms known as cost reports that are filed by the company and its hospitals with the Federal Medicare agency. A1 
 
Dow Jones Hits 8,000
The Dow Jones industrial average -- the most widely followed market gauge -- closed above the 8,000-point level for the first time, gaining 63.17 points to close at 8,038.88. But even that gain was overshadowed by the broader market, where soaring shares of technology issues sent the Nasdaq composite index up 38.52 points, or 2.5 percent, to 1,580.63 in one of its best sessions of the year and its 10th consecutive record close.
