HEADLINE: FILM REVIEW;
Golden Girl of Vice K.O.'s Oleo Heir

BYLINE: By STEPHEN HOLDEN 

 BODY:
So many cigarettes are theatrically flourished in Raymond De Felitta's nifty sleeper of a film "Cafe Society" that when it's over you may be tempted to inspect your clothing for the stale, clinging odor of secondhand smoke. Many of those cigarettes jut from the enameled tips of tapering holders fingered by bejeweled, white-gloved "socialites" posing for the flashbulbs in El Casbah, a swank early-50's Manhattan saloon reminiscent of El Morocco.
"Cafe Society," which remembers a real-life sex scandal that rocked New York City 45 years ago, is the rare 50's period piece that gets it right, from the little red-shaded lamps on the cramped tables of El Casbah to the slithery come-hither sexual signals of a more repressed era. The hard-boiled banter over endless martinis also has an authentically pseudo-sophisticated ring. Or as one jaded habitue of El Casbah observes when an unfamiliar face appears in the club: "She's new to cafe society. Nescafe, we call that." 
 The movie, which opens today at the Screening Room (it was originally seen on Showtime), re-enacts the downfall of Mickey Jelke (Frank Whaley), the pint-size, girl-crazy, porno-collecting heir to an oleomargarine fortune. In 1952, after a police investigation of prostitution in upscale Manhattan nightclubs, Jelke was arrested and convicted of pimping. The star witness against him was his girlfriend, Patricia Ward (Lara Flynn Boyle), whom he pressed into prostitution after his family cut him off from his trust fund. He had also promised to marry her. When the scandal hit the front pages of the tabloids, Patricia realized her lifelong dream of fame by being dubbed "the golden girl of vice," and for two seconds Hollywood seemed to beckon.
The police officer who dreams up the investigation (a pre-election publicity stunt to help re-elect Frank Hogan, the Manhattan District Attorney) is Jack Kale, (Peter Gallagher), who infiltrates cafe society by posing as an unemployed Hollywood actor. He befriends Jelke by punching out the escort of a former Jelke girlfriend one night at El Casbah. Jelke rewards Kale by dragging him into a world of wild, booze-filled parties attended by a network of prostitutes.
By today's standards, the depravity seems pretty tame. But "Cafe Society," filmed in a style that evokes 50's tabloid news photos, captures the era's zest for naughtiness. As cramped, squalid and soulless as this smoke-filled dolce vita appears, it also exudes the tawdry glamour that can be found among people whose dream of fulfillment is to see their pictures in the paper.
Among several strong performances, Mr. Whaley's Jelke is the most memorable. The young actor, who suggests a homelier, runtier Matthew Broderick, makes this spoiled playboy-manque a pathetically empty creature who is given to hysterical tantrums and whose only claim to fame is the size of his bankbook. Ms. Boyle's Patricia is almost as impressive and equally pathetic, as she brazenly and transparently lies about her background. (She's not from Newport, R.I., as she claims, but from Avenue D in Manhattan.)
Mr. Gallagher is a little too soft as the New York vice officer who becomes disenchanted with his cause. But John Spencer's icy, side-of-the-mouth portrayal of Ray Davioni, a poisonously cynical press agent and pimp, deserves special mention. This ominous bottom feeder is so coldblooded he could have stepped from the shadows of that ultimate 50's nightmare of Manhattan press agentry and corruption, "The Sweet Smell of Success."
"Cafe Society" is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). It has nudity, strong language and sexual situations.

At the Screening Room, 54 Varick Street, at Canal Street, TriBeCa. Running time: 110 minutes. This film is rated R.

HEADLINE: ARCHITECTURE REVIEW;
The Designs of a Genius Redesigning Himself

BYLINE: By HERBERT MUSCHAMP 

 BODY:
WHEN America's westward expansion finally reached the Pacific coast, the artist's imagination became the country's new frontier. Or so one might conclude from a show of uncommon beauty on view at the Whitney Museum of American Art, "Frank Lloyd Wright: Designs for an American Landscape, 1922-32." The show, first presented at the Canadian Center for Architecture, offers five projects, all unbuilt, in which Wright developed a range of innovative forms for buildings far removed from the urban center. Not coincidentally, the show also depicts an artist in the painful process of recreating himself.
This exhibition is a result of a recently forged alliance between the Canadian Center and the Whitney Museum. Since its founding in 1989, the center has presented some of the most intelligent architecture shows to be seen anywhere today. Now, thanks to the Whitney, New Yorkers won't have to journey to Montreal to view them. 
 Good news for us. But the work on view at the Whitney occupies such a peak of genius, and it has been assembled with such sensitivity, scholarship and skill, that those who care about architecture may feel more than a little ashamed for not having leaped onto a plane and rushed to see it earlier. There are drawings here as ravishing as any that Wright produced: as beautiful, that is to say, as any architectural drawings that exist on earth. There are times when understatement is useful. This is not one of those times.
The show, organized by David G. De Long of the University of Pennsylvania and beautifully designed by the New York architect George Ranalli, includes roughly 100 drawings, architectural models and computer renderings. One might call it "A Man and His Pencils." Wright used to talk about the joy it gave him to spread a selection of colored pencils in his hand and see the colors sparkling in the sun. The architect could be grandiose when talking about himself, and the image of him contemplating the tools of his trade may seem off-puttingly divine. That's the way Wright was. And when you see what he accomplished with these tools, Wright's high opinion of himself begins to look like objective fact.
Wright designed these five projects in the decade following his completion of the Imperial Hotel in Tokyo. These were not Wright's happiest years. He had little work. His personal life was a shambles. Eventually, with the completion of the Fallingwater residence outside Pittsburgh and the Johnson's Wax Headquarters in Racine, Wis., in 1936, his career burst into a second flowering. But meanwhile, Wright was widely perceived as a burned-out case.
We should all burn out so vibrantly. Even though these five projects were not built, this is a show of rebirth, of new beginnings. Here, the American landscape becomes a metaphor for the eternal American belief in fresh starts. The car becomes a symbol for moving on.
Go west, middle-aged man. In his earlier years in Chicago, Wright developed a predominantly horizontal vocabulary of forms for the Midwestern prairie. In these projects, he devised a formal vocabulary for three different terrains: mountain, desert and lake. All but one of the projects were designed for the American West. All five utilized the concrete-block construction he employed in the Mayan-inspired houses he built in Los Angeles in the 1920's. All typify the anti-urban strain that would dominate Wright's thought in later years. Now, the car enjoys the pride of place Wright had once granted the hearth.
The Doheny Ranch Development, planned in 1923, is the only true suburban project among the five. Conceived for a stretch of the Santa Monica Mountains subsequently known as Beverly Hills, the scheme boasts genuine Hollywood glamour; it could be a set for a vanished sequence from the film "Lost Horizon." A community of homes spread over 411 acres would have been linked by roads and viaducts. To a degree, this is an early version of what architects in the 1960's called the megastructure, but one that draws hill and valley into its lush, sprawling mass.
In 1923, Wright prepared an even more Arcadian dreamscape, a vacation colony for Lake Tahoe. Like Wright's residential designs for Los Angeles, the Tahoe project also drew on Pre-Columbian forms. Here, the Mayan influence is evident in the battered concrete bases of the cabins, while their tall wooden roofs evoke wigwams.
Wright's integration of these structures with nature is as impressive as the forms themselves. Rocks and boulders cluster around the cabins' bases. The wooden roofs echo the surrounding forest, Adirondack style. Wright also designed a series of floating barges that would have dissolved the borders between building, land and water. An offshore lodge to be erected on piles in the lake features "water courts," aquatic atriums enclosed within the building's long, low-slung wings.
The drawings convey an image of baptismal purity. And yet, looking at them in the light of Wright's turbulent life at the time, one is inclined to see this as a place of infidelities and indiscretions, unsolved murders, mysterious drownings, untold Prohibition-era delights.
The American desert provided Wright with almost too poetically apt a setting for the hardships of his middle years. In 1934, with the construction of Taliesin West, the architect made Arizona his winter home. Ten years earlier, however, he prepared a desert oasis for the insurance tycoon A. M. Johnson.
Johnson had already built a small compound of Spanish-style houses on the edge of Death Valley. He invited Wright to join him there on one trip and asked the architect for recommendations on improving the property. Wright responded in typical fashion by drawing up an ambitious proposal that would have enclosed the existing structures within a long, linear building sited to take advantage of the views, the terrain and the approach by car. The plan included terraced farming, fountains and a chapel.
In 1928, Wright was commissioned to design a new hotel outside Phoenix, San Marcos in the Desert. Not long before, he had helped a former apprentice with the design for the fabulous Arizona Biltmore. (That hotel's magnificent lobby, never officially credited to Wright, produces an impact on the body that is felt nowhere except in Wright's buildings.)
For San Marcos, he produced a long, three-story block with setbacks and balconies, a form adopted by many other architects almost 40 years later. The folded planes of the ceiling in the hotel's dining room anticipated the geometric experiments of avant-garde architects today. Again, as in Death Valley, the flat desert plane enables Wright to orient the building around the roadway approaching it.
The most delirious design in the show is the Gordon Strong Automobile Objective, which Wright designed in 1925 for the top of Sugarloaf Mountain in Maryland. Here, the spiral makes its first appearance in Wright's work. Later, he would use this form for projects as various as a jewelry store, a car showroom, a parking garage and the great Guggenheim Museum in Manhattan.
The Automobile Objective, as its name implies, was a tourist destination, designed to lure people out for a drive. And the design makes clear the cosmic terms in which Wright regarded cars. Its ziggurat shape recalls the sacred "world mountain" temples of ancient Sumeria. Inside the temple, Wright proposed to build a planetarium.
What's striking about all these projects is that Wright proceeded as if he, personally, had discovered America. He is starting over from scratch, as if the nation had not already been invaded by neo-classical, Gothic Revival and other European styles of building. Sybil Maholy-Nagy was not exaggerating when she observed that Wright was the first architect in history who felt obliged to design an entire continent.
And Wright was hardly the only American for whom the car and the highway symbolized the freedom to seek the future, to speed away from past mistakes: failed marriages, botched careers, the wretched confines of tradition. In hindsight, of course, this optimism seems painfully naive. No force has done more to despoil the American environment than the car culture and its insatiable gobbling of the American land.
Wright cannot be wholly absolved from responsibility for the megalopolitan sprawl of the postwar years. "When people ask me where they should build," the architect wrote in the early 1950's, "I tell them to go far from the city, at least as twice as far as think they should go. And when others follow, as they will, move on!"
Yet in those same years, Wright found himself railing against the electric power lines stretching across his beloved Arizona desert, their metal stanchions disfiguring his glorious mountain views. Soon, tract houses, cars and asphalt would be dumped upon the landscape in overpowering abundance. The nation's economy would become critically dependent on this mass production, never mind that the pileup of industrial production would be hazardous to mental and physical health.
In short, this show will leave the alert visitor hungering for a sequel, in which today's most informed thinkers would be asked to work through the history and prospects of the desert we have built in the wake of Wright's ideas.
"Frank Lloyd Wright: Designs for an American Landscape, 1922-32" remains at the Whitney Museum of American Art, 945 Madison Avenue, at 75th Street, through Aug. 31.

HEADLINE: In America;
A Pitiful Giant

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT 

DATELINE: PITTSBURGH

 BODY:
This year's convention of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People was supposed to have been all about children, which was not a bad idea because huge numbers of black children are hurting in ways that would break a normal person's heart. But the interests of children were betrayed right at the start when the thuggish boxing promoter Don King was honored, embraced and gushed over by Kweisi Mfume, the man who was hired to clean up the act of the once-illustrious civil rights organization.
Don King. How's that for a role model? Maybe it'll be Mike Tyson next year. 
 In presenting Mr. King with the association's President's Award, Mr. Mfume compared him to Jackie Robinson and complained about Federal prosecutors who have targeted the promoter in an insurance fraud case. Mr. Mfume did not go into Mr. King's long history of unscrupulous business practices, or the time he spent in prison for pistol-whipping and kicking a man to death.
Mr. King, in accepting the award, smilingly and enthusiastically asserted that the United States is a great country. And he offered what he felt were some helpful comments about the Constitution.
The N.A.A.C.P. has lost its grip. There is a disoriented and at times paranoid quality about the organization that more than any other did the difficult, dangerous and noble work of desegregating America. The N.A.A.C.P. was once the home of giants like W. E. B. DuBois and Charles Houston and Thurgood Marshall, brilliant and fearless individuals who spent their lives beating back the raging flames of racism and fighting for the civil rights and personal dignity of everyone. Their heroic lives embodied the true greatness of America.
Now the N.A.A.C.P. is something different, something so much less. It is not just diminished, it has decayed. Instead of the soaring rhetoric and strategic brilliance of past decades we now get a chairwoman, Myrlie Evers-Williams, who vows to fight the "rats" who are gnawing at her organization, and a president, Mr. Mfume, who promises "to get rid of the snakes" who would undermine him. Neither identified the objects of their wrath. Puzzled delegates could be overheard in elevators asking whom they were talking about.
Rats and snakes and kudos to Don King. If there is a method to the madness, I've been unable to decipher it.
As for the children, there is one thing they need more than any other. Fathers. Real fathers, that is. Fathers in the home. Not just boys or men who have dropped their seed and split. But you could have wandered from one workshop to another, from this plenary session to that, from the cocktail parties to the most solemn prayer service without hearing a word about the greatest threat to black children since slavery -- their abandonment by their own fathers.
Children who grow up in fatherless homes are far more likely to live in poverty, to do poorly in school, to have children out of wedlock themselves, to be unemployed and to commit crimes. In short, they are far more likely than the offspring of two-parent families to spread misery and tragedy among themselves and others. You want to do something for the kids? Fight with the intelligence and passion of the civil rights movement for their right to have a committed and loving father in the home.
Mr. Mfume, unfortunately, is not well positioned to lead this fight. In his autobiography, "No Free Ride," he writes:
"I gave new meaning to the phrase 'sowing wild oats.' Consider: In May 1968, Pauline gave birth to Donald. Later that year in August, Yvonne gave birth to Kevin. A year later, in October 1969, Brenda had my son Keith. In January 1970, Carlitta gave birth to Michael. And three weeks later, in January 1970, Pauline gave birth to our second child, a boy we named Ronald."
Five children by four women in 21 months. Mr. Mfume says in his book that his consciousness has since been raised and he has tried to be a good father. Perhaps he has been. But the simple truth is that high-profile black leaders tend not to talk much, in public or in private, about the desertion rate of black fathers and the incredibly destructive effect it is having on black children.
It's like not talking about slavery.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Income Is No Measure Of a Life's Value

 BODY:

To the Editor:
In cases of airplane crashes at sea, like Trans World Airlines Flight 800, the United States Supreme Court decision to use a victim's wages, rather than loss of companionship, as a barometer of damages is indeed unjust (news article, July 11). I applaud the House bill that would eliminate the legal distinction between crashes on land and at sea.
Unfortunately, because of New York State's 150-year-old wrongful-death law, the House bill would bring no relief to victims of planes that crash over the state. New York is one of the few states that award damages only for economic losses. 
 I have sponsored a bill that would amend our archaic law to permit family members to recover economic damages as well as those for emotional grief when a wrongdoer is found liable for the death. We must not continue to discount mothers, wives, children and grandparents by judging their worth in terms of earnings alone.
 
HELENE E. WEINSTEIN
Brooklyn, July 16, 1997
 
Assembly Member, 41st Dist.

HEADLINE: Solarz to Tackle Cambodia Issues

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 17

 BODY:
In an effort to explore a resolution to the political crisis in Cambodia, Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright today asked the former New York Congressman Stephen J. Solarz to travel to the region as a special envoy, the State Department announced.
Mr. Solarz will report to her July 26 in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, where she will attend meetings of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, which is making its own diplomatic efforts on Cambodia. His mission "is intended to be consistent with and fully supportive of those efforts," the department spokesman, Nicholas Burns, said. 
 Mr. Solarz served on the House International Relations Committee and has a strong interest in Southeast Asia. He was elected to Congress in 1974 but defeated in 1992.

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
Tax-Break Deal Tied To Creation of Jobs

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON 

 BODY:
As part of an agreement to keep Furman Selz, an investment banking and financial services firm, in Manhattan, the city and state have agreed to give the firm up to $2.4 million in tax breaks over the next 16 years, city officials said yesterday. But the deal has some important fine print: The firm has to grow and create jobs in order to collect.
The incentive package with Furman, which has 580 employees in the city, is only the second that New York has done in tying financial abatements or benefits to growth. It suggests a greatly improved bargaining position for the city as its economy and business environment have improved. 
 The first such deal tied directly to job growth, with ING Barings, a British-Dutch financial services firm, was announced in April. In the past, most companies only had to promise to stay in the city to collect concessions.
City officials said that Furman had considered a move to Weehawken, N.J., but will instead stay at its 230 Park Avenue location. The city said the company plans to expand at another Park Avenue location nearby. The company projects that it will add 400 new jobs over the next 16 years. It will be eligible for benefits only as it achieves specific employment thresholds along the way.
 KIRK JOHNSON

HEADLINE: High Marks for Giuliani From Budget Watchdogs

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE 

 BODY:
With only a few whispers of gloom, the state board that oversees New York City's finances gave an unusually positive grade to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's most recent budget yesterday, saying the fiscal outlook is the brightest in years.
At the annual meeting of the New York State Financial Control Board in Gov. George E. Pataki's midtown Manhattan office, board members said the budget picture had improved significantly because of the prosperity on Wall Street. The board -- which includes the Governor, State Comptroller H. Carl McCall and City Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi, among others -- also credited the Mayor with reducing the size of the long-term deficit by dedicating some of this year's $1.3 billion surplus to paying future expenses. 
 Mr. McCall, a Democrat who has often been at odds with the Republican Mayor, said that despite the progress, he was disappointed that the Giuliani administration is increasing spending by 7.4 percent in this year's budget. He said the city was still relying too heavily on "one-shot" methods of balancing the budget that do not help the long-term picture. And, he maintained, the projected deficits over the next four years remain too high, peaking at $2.8 billion in 2000.
"I support what the Mayor has done, and I urge the city to continue to take efforts to achieve more than a one-year balance by the use of stopgap or one-shot initiatives," Mr. McCall said, with the Mayor sitting nearby. "We have to provide long-term fiscal security for city taxpayers, and the city must continue to work to curtail expenses, as they've done, boosting revenues, especially if it plans additional tax cuts, and continue the practice of establishing significant reserve funds."
But Mr. Hevesi, also a Democrat, was far more upbeat, saying the city was in the best shape since at least 1989, when the current City Charter first required his office to comment on the Mayor's financial plan. He said that the surplus continued to grow and that the long-term deficits could actually be lower than Mr. Giuliani had projected, and he warned only that the city's debt burden was growing too large.
"Even in the worst case, the city will balance the budget without the kind of pain it has known historically," he said, referring to next year's budget. He also praised Mr. Giuliani for devoting almost half the surplus to deficit reduction, saying he had resisted "the temptation in an election year to spend lots of money."
Though such compliments are not particularly good news for the Mayor's Democratic opponents, they seem to reflect a growing consensus within the financial community that the city's books are entering a period of relative stability.
Yesterday, for example, Moody's Investors Service, a credit-rating agency, announced it was giving the city a "positive" credit outlook, an upgrade from the previous "stable" rating. Though the Moody's rating of the city's bonds remains below average at Baa1, where it has been since February of 1991, the improved credit outlook is considered an indication of trends and budgetary practices that increase the likelihood of a change in the bond rating in the next three years.
The Moody's report said the low bond rating reflects the city's underperforming economy, its high debt burden, and its poor financial history. But in improving the outlook, it credited the Mayor with reducing the city's social service costs and welfare rolls, and for strengthening the city's reserve funds.
"Although long-term structural budget imbalance continues to pose challenges," the report says, "fiscal flexibility has improved and outyear gaps have narrowed, positioning the city to better weather future economic and revenue cycles endemic to its economy."
At the control board meeting, the Mayor thanked the members for their generally kind words, which were a departure from the stern warnings that often marked such meetings earlier in his term. He acknowledged that the city will continue to struggle to balance its budget, but said the enormous spending cuts in his first years in office had made the task easier.
"Now the deficits are down to numbers that still should concern us, numbers that still present a challenge to us, deficits that say to us that the era of fiscal discipline is not ended, merely because we are doing better," he said. "But it gives us a great deal of confidence that we're moving very, very much and aggressively in the right direction."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bond Prices Slip After More Data Show a Strong Economy

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices fell slightly yesterday following a recent run-up, after several reports showed signs of economic strength.
Still, those reports -- on housing starts, a Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelpia survey and weekly jobless claims -- were not enough yesterday to change the market's view that inflation remains benign. Nor did they greatly dampen the enthusiasm generated on Wednesday, when the Government reported that consumer prices barely moved in June and that inflation was running at the slowest annual pace in more than a decade. 
 Alan Levenson, a senior vice president and director of research at Aubrey G. Langston & Company, said that this week's soft data did not give a hint of inflationary pressure.
"All the talk of a rebound in the economy in the second half has been just that, talk," he said.
Prices moved higher for a time yesterday, bolstered in part by rumors of a large purchaser of 10-year securities tied to the mortgage-backed market. But profit taking in the afternoon cut short what would have been the market's third consecutive gain.
Instead, by the end of trading, the price of the 30-year bond fell 5/32 , to 101 27/32 . The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, edged up to 6.48 percent, from 6.47 percent on Wednesday.
Bond prices fell briefly after the Philadelphia Fed reported an unexpected pickup in business activity. The regional Fed's general economic index -- compiled from a survey of about 150 manufacturers in eastern Pennsylvania, southern New Jersey and Delaware -- rose to 28.1 this month from 25.2 in June, higher than the 23.3 analysts had expected.
Also yesterday, the Commerce Department reported that housing starts grew 4.8 percent in June, to 1.45 million units, at the high end of expectations.
Sherry Cooper, chief economist at Nesbitt Burns Securities, said that housing fundamentals remain very strong and should get another lift from the latest slide in long-term interest rates.
"While conditions are solid, they are by no means overheated, and starts are still below last year's average of 1.47 million units," she said.
In another report, the initial claims for unemployment insurance fell 28,000, to 349,000, in the week ending Saturday, reversing much of the previous week's run-up that had been a consequence of early seasonal shutdowns of automobile factories.
The focus of market participants now appears to be turning to next week's testimony of Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman. Mr. Greenspan is scheduled to give Congress his semiannual testimony on the state of the economy.
At yesterday's Treasury auction of new 52-week bills, good investor interest lowered the average discount rate to 5.26 percent, from 5.35 percent last month and the lowest since 5.16 percent on Dec. 5, 1996.
The bid-to-cover ratio, or the number of bids compared with the total amount of the issue was 4.52 to 1, compared with 4.71 to 1 last month.
Ahead of next week's sale of two-year and five-year notes, yields edged up. In when-issued trading yesterday, the two-year note was offered at a price to yield 5.89 percent, while the five-year was offered at a price to yield 6.11 percent.

HEADLINE: Despite Assurances, U.N. Workers Fear Downsizing

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, July 17

 BODY:
This morning it was the United Nations staff's turn to hear about reform from Secretary General Kofi Annan.
The people who keep the organization running from day to day came with some trepidation, overflowing one conference hall and then another and another here at headquarters or tuning in to live broadcasts beamed to offices around the world or reading their E-mail in the muddy outposts of refugee centers and disaster areas. 
 "In all my 11 years here, I've never seen so many people come to hear a Secretary General -- or anyone else," said Salim Lone of Kenya, the organization's chief of publications.
They came with a backlog of bitterness, afraid of hearing more bad news.
"We've been dumped on by the newspapers, the media, the member states, the critics -- and most of us are holding down two or three jobs," said Zuzu Tabatabai, an Iranian who works on women's affairs within the Secretariat.
"Deep down, the people who work here think they are doing something for the world, and they're clobbered every time. They were walking on eggshells. All they heard was cut, cut, cut. They wanted to hear good news."
A day after he announced a restructuring plan, the message delivered by Mr. Annan, the first Secretary General to rise through the ranks of the United Nations bureaucracy, was the talk of the organization. He told the staff that there would have to be attrition, that he would seek to lower the age of the staff, that he would turn loose on them a team of outside management experts from the private and public sectors to review work practices.
But he also told them, "It is not their reform. It is our reform."
What many heard was a reassurance that he would not allow the organization to be torn apart, that there would be no blood on the floor.
"He said, 'I'm one of you,' " Ms. Tabatabai said. "I know what you are going through. He has friends. He hears it all. He knew that the people were unhappy and scared."
Kevin Kennedy, an American who is chief of the peace and security section of the public information department, said the sense that staff members have a protector will make them much more willing to take bad medicine, if that's what is coming. Mr. Annan's predecessor, Boutros Boutros-Ghali, was once booed by employees after constraints were applied during a financial crisis.
When Mr. Annan opened the floor to questions after his talk this morning, the first one was a quip that brought down the house: The questioner wanted to know if management reform could be made retroactive.
"Like anybody who works for a large organization that's going through changes like this, I have some misgivings, and I don't necessarily agree with everything that's being proposed," Mr. Kennedy said. "But I think that most of us feel that, imperfect as the process may be, the staff trusts Kofi Annan. I think they are willing to do more than just give him the benefit of the doubt."
At Unicef, where restructuring and job cuts have already taken a toll and there are fears that grouping the agency with others in a cluster will cost the children's fund some autonomy, "some people are still focused on budget cuts and worried about whether they will keep their jobs, and how duplications will be avoided," said Matilda Weekes of Sierra Leone, an executive secretary. "But most people are saying: 'It's about time; reform is overdue.' "
It was evening in Goma in eastern Congo when Craig Sanders got his E-mail message. "It was interesting, but a long, long way from the reality we deal with on a daily basis," he said in a telephone interview. "There is violence to the east of us and violence to the west of us. Tonight I was working on a contingency plan for another crisis, another emergency."
Mr. Sanders, an American who directs the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees' office in Goma, said reform sounded like a good idea, but he would like to see it coupled with more courage on the part of member nations in providing support and security "for the people who have to run the roadblocks."
Filippo Grandi, an Italian who is the refugee organization's field coordinator in Goma, said that even stronger restructuring of the organizational bureaucracy was probably in order. He echoed some of Mr. Annan's own words about changes in the quality of performance mattering more than the mere cutting of staff.
"We think we could do our work better if things were simpler and faster," he said. "U.N. reform is not just about cutting a couple of posts in New York or Geneva. It's about making very important activities more efficient on the ground. Every layer of bureaucracy means that you diminish suffering in a slower way."

HEADLINE: Editorial Notebook;
Shevardnadze Agonistes

BYLINE: By PHILIP TAUBMAN 

 BODY:
When President Clinton welcomes Eduard Shevardnadze to the White House this evening, it will be a homecoming of sorts for the Georgian leader. Many times in the final years of the cold war, he met as Soviet Foreign Minister in the Oval Office with American Presidents and Secretaries of State, demolishing the barriers that divided East and West. For that historic statesmanship he should be honored here. But Mr. Shevardnadze is a good deal more complex than the common hagiography about him would suggest. He belongs on the short list of the world's toughest, most hardened politicians.
That is not said to diminish his accomplishments. With the approval of Mikhail Gorbachev, Mr. Shevardnadze transformed the nature of Soviet foreign policy. Because he was unschooled in the rigid traditions of Kremlin diplomacy -- his 1985 appointment to replace Andrei Gromyko as Foreign Minister was a surprise -- Mr. Shevardnadze was open to new ideas. Without his leadership, the Berlin wall probably would not have fallen so fast in 1989, German unification might not have unfolded so smoothly, Soviet troops would not have left Afghanistan in 1989 and Moscow would not have cooperated so willingly with Washington in resisting Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. 
 Nor do I mean to impeach his character. There is an infectious warmth and openness about Mr. Shevardnadze that set him apart from other Soviet officials. I watched him at close range in Moscow in the late 1980's and found him invariably candid and straightforward. By far the most informal and informative talk I had with a Politburo member was with Mr. Shevardnadze at a 1987 Kremlin reception. It didn't hurt that as a native Georgian, he spoke Russian almost as slowly as I did.
But Mr. Shevardnadze's achievements and engaging style ought to be seen in the broader context of his political career. He did not make it to the apex of Soviet power through affability, nor has he prevailed in Georgia's bloody political conflicts in recent years simply with enlightened leadership. Mr. Shevardnadze is a fierce partisan who has at times condoned the brutal practices of the police state.
Mr. Shevardnadze's credo comes not from Jefferson nor from Mr. Gorbachev but from Shota Rustaveli, the 12th-century Georgian poet who celebrated the independent spirit of his mountainous and violent land. It is a point aptly made by Carolyn McGiffert Ekedahl and Melvin Goodman, two former C.I.A. analysts, in their newly published book, "The Wars of Eduard Shevardnadze" (Penn State Press).
Georgia is a remarkably beautiful and self-destructive country. Tucked into the Caucasus, this tiny nation can claim an ancient literary tradition, a distinctive and accomplished culture and Josef Stalin. As a Soviet republic, it was long ruled and terrorized by Lavrenti Beria, Stalin's secret-police chief.
Before Mr. Shevardnadze joined Mr. Gorbachev in Moscow in 1985, he was the Communist boss of Georgia, a position he earned in part by running Georgia's internal security agencies in the 1960's with cold efficiency. He was not a notable defender of human rights in those days. But he did try to reduce corruption and ease Communist economic controls that were stifling the Georgian economy.
When he returned to Georgia in 1992 after the collapse of the Soviet Union, his homeland was near disintegration itself, convulsed by ethnic warfare and controlled by criminal gangs. Democratic governance was not a viable option, but Mr. Shevardnadze tried to exercise autocratic power in a fashion reminiscent of his days as internal affairs minister.
Mr. Shevardnadze embodies a curious blend of idealism and ruthlessness, principle and pragmatism. Clearly, a less steely man could not have held together Georgia or gone into the field to direct his supporters in combat, as he did a few years ago. He barely escaped assassination in 1995 when a car bomb exploded as he left the parliament building in Tbilisi.
Today he is the elected leader of a relatively stable, largely democratic and increasingly prosperous Georgia. It is nice to see that a bright smile has returned to his face. But it is worth remembering that Mr. Shevardnadze is not yet a candidate for canonization. PHILIP TAUBMAN

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Builders Start New Homes At Faster Pace

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 17

 BODY:
Housing starts rose 4.8 percent in June, reversing a decline in the previous month and signaling that demand for homes could rebound as the economy enters the third quarter.
The Commerce Department said today that the annual rate of housing starts climbed to 1.452 million in June. Starts rose in the South, the Midwest and the West. 
 May's decline was revised to 6.6 percent from the previously reported 4.8 percent. In April, starts rose three-tenths of 1 percent; the initial report showed a decline in April.
Analysts said June's increase was probably the first of a series because milder weather, a rebound in demand and lean inventories would prompt builders to break new ground in the third quarter.
Permits for new housing construction fell 2.6 percent in June, to an annual pace of 1.395 million.
By region, starts rose seven-tenths of 1 percent in the Midwest, to a 294,000 rate; 11.2 percent in the South, to a 683,000 rate, and 1.1 percent in the West, to a 362,000 rate. They fell 6.6 percent in the Northeast, to a 113,000 rate.
Starts on single-family housing construction rose 2.6 percent, to a 1.11 million rate, while multifamily projects rose 12.9 percent, to a 342,000 rate.
Real estate markets have been bolstered by the highest levels of consumer confidence in the economy in decades, the lowest unemployment rate in a quarter-century and historic gains in the stock market. Home builders, like economists, are optimistic about the housing industry, a survey by the National Association of Home Builders showed.
Mortgage rates have declined steadily since mid-April. The average rate on a 30-year fixed mortgage fell to 7.69 percent in June from 7.93 percent in May.
"With the fall in mortgage rates over the last few weeks, the housing sector will modestly contribute to overall economic growth" in the third quarter, said Stan Shipley, an economist at Merrill Lynch & Company in New York. Mortgage refinancings should also rise, putting more money in consumers' pockets to spend, analysts said.
Separately, the Labor Department said that fewer American workers applied for state unemployment benefits last week, after a wave of claims in the prior week caused by auto plant closings.
First-time jobless claims decreased 28,000, to a seasonally adjusted 349,000, in the week ended Saturday. The four-week average for jobless claims, a less volatile gauge, rose to 348,750, from 348,500 the previous week. The last time the four-week average reached that level was in the week ended Jan. 18, when it stood at 349,500.

GRAPHIC: Graph: "Housing Construction" shows new private housing started and permits authorized from Jan. 1996 to June 1997. (Source: Commerce Department)

HEADLINE: Eye of the Beholder, Inc.;
Middleman of Waste Material, Mistakes and Leftovers

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON 

 BODY:
John Okun stood in a dark basement in Long Island City, Queens, waiting for someone to find the light switch. But he already knew what would be revealed: something odd or forgotten, wasted or unwanted. That's why he'd been called in on the case.
Mr. Okun is a middleman of misfits, ambassador to the abandoned. He recently resold 2,000 plastic bunny pinwheel toys for a Queens importer who was left with inventory when a brief fad ended, and more than 176,000 fortune cookies. They were baked for export, with fortunes in Dutch and German, but botched by a packaging misprint. Among his projects is a warehouse full of never-used car parts for 1940's Packards, Hudsons and De Sotos, still in the original boxes, and 2,400 safety dart sets, with no pointed tips. They are safe enough, but apparently not all that much fun. 
 In the Long Island City basement, the story was yarn, tons of it. The lights came up on a large room jammed with boxes and bags and skeins and spools in every imaginable color, much of it dating from the 1960's. It had been left behind by a sweater manufacturer whose business unraveled.
"Yarn, as far as the eye can see," Mr. Okun said, awed. He assured the building's owner, Ruth Shu, that there was indeed a market for 30-year-old remnants.
He knows. From his tiny office near La Guardia Community College, Mr. Okun runs what has become in this industrial corner of Queens a commercial halfway house and trading floor for the marginally marketable. He helps companies find takers for their waste products, leftovers and mistakes.
His three-person operation, Industrial Waste Recycling and Prevention, known as Inwrap, began four years ago as a low-budget government pilot project at the Long Island City Business Development Corporation. Financed by a combination of city, state and Federal money and private grants, with an annual budget of $130,000, the goal was to act as a matchmaking service: to help companies cut costs by matching their supply of industrial detritus -- plastic scrap, or wooden packing materials -- with the needs of another company that might be looking for just that sort of raw material.
It was not environmentalism, but economic development. One company would save on disposal costs, the other would save on supply costs, and both might be more likely to remain in New York.
It has worked well enough to save the mostly small companies here an average of $900,000 a year in waste disposal costs, and to become the model for a citywide waste and product exchange program now being set up by the city's Department of Sanitation, with Mr. Okun as consultant.
It also evolved, from its early focus on traditionally defined industrial waste, to things like old car parts and bunnies and dartboards, items from an economic netherworld that Mr. Okun calls "the edge of the market."
National waste experts say there is nothing quite like Mr. Okun's Inwrap service. Many waste exchange services are passively run warehouses at which companies or individuals look for what they need. The New York City service is aggressive, combing the Internet, among other sources, for leads. Many exchanges also operate primarily out of environmental motives; here, economics is the point.
But in the movement toward the re-use of materials, the experts say, unusual is common. Unlike recycling, in which waste items are broken down into components and remade, finding new uses for old items necessarily means piecing together an idiosyncratic local universe of supply and demand.
"They all seem to have formed in their own way, that's what's interesting," said David Goldbeck, who, with his wife, Nikki, is author of "Choose to Reuse" (Ceres Press, Woodstock, N.Y., 1995), a guide for buyers and sellers in the so-called after use market.
A state program in Vermont, for instance, takes in broken electronic appliances like VCR's, trains people to fix them, then sells them. Seattle collected old paint from its residents, mixed it together and cheerfully dubbed the drab result Seattle Gray, and used it for municipal buildings. Boston, in the midst of a construction boom, resells used building materials.
In an area of warehouses and low-rise brick just across the East River from midtown Manhattan, Mr. Okun's program offers a window into an economy of survivors. The giant, vertically integrated manufacturers that only a few years ago dominated places like Long Island City -- self-contained and full of resources and probably not in need of a service like Mr. Okun's -- are mostly gone, and even middle-sized ones are endangered. Swingline, the stapler manufacturer that is just a few blocks from Mr. Okun's office, recently announced plans to move its operation to Mexico.
Most of the companies that remain are small. Many are family owned, generations old, sometimes chaotic. They're incredibly diverse in their products, but also isolated, connected with their customers and suppliers, but not with one another, or with the city.
One thing that does connect them is Mr. Okun, a 40-year-old New Yorker who was raised mostly in nearby Jackson Heights. Local business people say that beyond the exchange of waste or products, the Inwrap service is helping build a commercial community.
One Queens company, Sequins International, produces millions of tiny glittering dots, scrap left over when the tiny hole in the center of each sequin is punched. The dots were going into the Dumpster. Mr. Okun connected the company with the New York City public school system, which will use the dots for art projects.
Another company, a manufacturer of paintbrush handles, was throwing away high quality hardwood beech and oak scraps. Through Mr. Okun, the company found Gregory Anderson and Kevin Nathaniel, two artists who pick up the wood, which they use to make mbiras, the small Zimbabwean musical instruments also known as thumb pianos. The company saves $270 a month on disposal costs and the waste service collects a percentage fee of the first year's savings.
Nestor Shipping Services, a second-generation Long Island City company, builds packing cases. It uses lumber from a Brooklyn pipe company that receives its pipe material in wood frames that it used to discard.
The waste program grew awkwardly into its role as middleman. Mr. Okun said he initially resisted when he began to get calls last year about things like perfectly good plastic bunnies that weren't technically waste. But he said he was feeling pressure, as government contributions declined, to become more self-supporting, and realized that broadening the way he helped companies would also help him. The waste service now makes up about 30 percent of its budget by collecting a fee from the savings it generates for companies, up from almost nothing a few years ago. "We realized that our purpose is to assist companies with materials that the marketplace has a hard time moving," Mr. Okun said. "We're the last resort."
The odd spaces of the marketplace are nothing new to Mr. Okun. His first job, at 16, was at Larchmont Sports, a shop that did trade-ins for ice skates. Mr. Okun said he learned how to estimate a price instantly on any pair of skates, and how to bring blades back to good as new in just a few strokes of the sharpener. In a way, it's still what he does, he said.
But there is often in Mr. Okun's work a tincture of economic tragedy in the buying and selling of failed results and leftovers. And some things, he has learned, really are garbage. No one, for example, seems to want scrap left over by a local commercial window shade manufacturer, because of the odd combination of plastics. And sometimes, even the help he can give is not enough. The import company with the unsalable bunnies ultimately went out of business. Mr. Okun, who sold the toys to small discount novelty stores around the city, was able only to moderate the company's losses.
There are personal victories, though, and moments when his vision of "industrial ecology" seems close to reality. The fortune cookies in German and Dutch were given to City Harvest, which distributes food to soup kitchens and shelters.
Mr. Anderson, the mbira maker, said the program resonates in another way. He takes his mbiras into New York's schools, and always tells where the wood came from.
"I try to make the connection with the kids between man, the earth, and technology, how we can take one man's leftovers and create another useful item," he said.
"I'm trying to get all my artist friends to use his services," he added, referring to Mr. Okun.
But the line between the unusable and the invaluable is more than just individual perspective. There's a time element as well. The 1940's vintage auto parts are probably worth more for having aged. They have vaulted from the utilitarian, Mr. Okun said, past the point of salvage, all the way to the status of antique.

HEADLINE: Departure Stirs Conflicting Reactions

BYLINE: By WILLIAM H. HONAN 

 BODY:
Around New York City yesterday, reactions to the resignation of W. Ann Reynolds as Chancellor of the City University of New York reflected sharp divisions of opinions about her, both within the system and outside it. Some insisted that her departure was a healthy step; others called it an outrage.
Lewis Rudin, the real estate developer and chairman of the Association for a Better New York, a business group, said he was saddened by the news. "I came to know her through the Association for a Better New York," he said. "The city of New York is a loser and the University of Alabama is a winner." 
 John Cardinal O'Connor, speaking through Joseph Zwilling, a spokesman for the Archdiocese of New York, said that although he had not discussed the Alabama offer with Dr. Reynolds, "Her departure will be a loss to the city of New York." But Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who has been critical recently of Dr. Reynolds, said, "I don't think the CUNY system is in very good shape right now."
And Chris Murphy, 26, a history graduate student at the City University Graduate Center, said he welcomed the departure because Dr. Reynolds was part of "a lot of political infighting which didn't serve the interest of the academic community well."
Taking a longer view was James P. Murphy, a former City University board chairman who worked closely with the Chancellor for the last seven years. He said Dr. Reynolds's resignation was inevitable, given the fact that 12 of the 15 trustees were newly appointed over the last year and had not hired her.
"It's a natural kind of thing for a huge group of people like this to want their own person," he said. One of the longtime Reynolds supporters on the board, Edith Everett, said, "I've seen a lot, but this is the worst." She said that Dr. Reynolds was hounded out of office by a newly reshaped board of trustees. Ms. Everett, who has been a trustee for nearly 20 years, said that Dr. Anne A. Paolucci and Herman Badillo, the chairwoman and vice chairman of the City University board, had put Dr. Reynolds in "a horrible situation."
Dr. Paolucci and Mr. Badillo have strongly suggested in recent weeks that Dr. Reynolds resign, accusing her of withholding information from trustees, failing to uphold academic standards, tolerating grade inflation and governing in an autocratic manner. They said that they had a majority on the board to oust her, but that they would not do anything until the fall. Dr. Paolucci, an English professor from St. John's University in Queens, did not return telephone calls seeking comment. Mr. Badillo said mildly that he wished Dr. Reynolds well in Alabama.
Kenneth Sherrill, a member of the faculty senate and professor of political science at Hunter College, said the die was cast for Dr. Reynolds's departure with the election of Gov. George E. Pataki and Mayor Giuliani. "They appointed these trustees and the trustees put her in an untenable position," he said.
Professor Sherrill praised Dr. Reynolds for challenging the Governor on budget matters. "She had the courage of her convictions, and manifestly risked her job for the sake of the university," he said. "Of course it was political."
But Alfred B. Curtis Jr., another newly appointed trustee, said the conflict between Dr. Reynolds and the board was not political and that "Chancellor Reynolds could have kept her job if she had been willing to stay on." John J. Calandra, one of the newly appointed trustees, agreed, saying that "there's no Republican or Democratic way to run a university."
Several of those interviewed yesterday speculated about what might be Dr. Reynolds's legacy. Mr. Murphy, the former City University board chairman, said that her greatest achievement was the College Preparatory Initiative, aimed at increasing the number of academic courses that high school students take, to help ease pressure on City University to offer expensive remedial classes.
"It was her initiative and the board's support that made it possible," Mr. Murphy said.
Mr. Calandra, who said he thought it was "time for the Chancellor to go," nevertheless said that her "forcefulness" in such matters as requiring greater productivity by faculty members would be remembered.
Professor Sherrill, who was a sharp critic of Dr. Reynolds at first but later came to admire her, said: "She was the first chancellor to run the university as a system rather than a collection of schools. Centralizing authority is never a popular activity, but she had the strength to do it."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Microsoft Net Rises 89% But Barely Beats Forecasts
Microsoft's quarterly earnings rose 89 percent, to $1.05 billion, but that was only slightly above analysts' expectations, and the company's shares fell in after-hours trading. 
 Earnings also rose sharply at Sun Microsystems, climbing 94.3 percent, to $237 million, and beating expectations. [Page D2.]
 
Buyer Found for Builders Square
Kmart's Builders Square will be combined with another ailing home improvement retailer, Hechinger, under the ownership of Leonard Green, a buyout firm. [D6.]
 
A Stumble for High-Flying Market
A 9,000-point Dow? Not yet. One day after surging past 8,000, the index slumped along with other market indicators, falling 18.11 points, to 8,020.77. [D7.]
 
In contrast to the general market, Merck stock rose sharply after the company reported higher-than-expected earnings. Revenue from newer drugs offset slowing growth in sales of cholesterol-lowering medicines. [D6.]
 
New Agencies Selected
Ameritech selected Ammirati Puris Lintas as its new agency, and Sears Canada named Young & Rubicam for its account as the turmoil in the advertising industry continues. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D5.]
 
One-Time Gains Help Coca-Cola
Coca-Cola said that its earnings rose 25 percent, lifted by after-tax gains from the restructuring of its bottling network and by international growth. [D2.]
 
Earnings Drop at Salomon
Salomon said that its earnings fell in the second quarter, pulled down by weaker results from bond trading -- the Wall Street firm's traditional strength -- and investment banking. [D17.]

Report Shows Strength in Housing
Housing starts rose 4.8 percent in June, reversing a decline in May. [D6.]
 
Bond prices fell slightly after the report notched up fears of inflation, sending the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond up to 6.49 percent from 6.47. [D16.]
 
Clinton Promises
To Back Boeing
President Clinton, speaking at the White House, left, threatened to go to the World Trade Organization if the European Union tried to stop Boeing's acquisition of McDonnell Douglas. But Mr. Clinton said he still believed that the dispute over the merger could be solved without a trade war. [D2.]
 
Senate Approves Appointments
Eric Holder, the United States Attorney for the District of Columbia, was confirmed by the Senate as deputy attorney general after Joel Klein, who had been opposed by some Democrats, was approved as assistant attorney general for antitrust. [A16.]
 
Glitch on the Internet
A human error at Network Solutions, which maintains the equivalent of a master telephone directory for cyberspace, combined with the fragile structure of the Internet to throw some data traffic into chaos. [A19.]
 
Overseas Strength Aids McDonald's
McDonald's profits rose 4 percent as improved overseas sales offset weakness in the United States, where the company said it would scale back expansion plans. [D17.]
 
Illegal Apparel Work Discovered
Raids in California have found immigrants doing illegal work at home for apparel companies that are covered by a Federal anti-sweatshop program. The discoveries are a setback for the program, which relies on apparel companies to police factories. [A10.]

HEADLINE: Clinton, in 2 Speeches, Urges Racial Healing

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, July 17

 BODY:
In the hope of building support for his initiative on racial healing at home, President Clinton played sociology professor today, repeatedly strolling away from his prepared remarks to take two audiences on discursive tours of ethnic conflicts around the world.
Before the annual meeting of the National Association of Black Journalists here tonight, Mr. Clinton wondered at the violence between Serbs and Croatians, noting that the combatants were "interestingly enough, biologically indistinguishable." And earlier today in Pittsburgh, he told the annual convention of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People that in Northern Ireland, "my people still argue over what happened 600 years ago." 
 Along the way, the President emphasized that he expects the advisory board on race that he appointed last month to focus on differences among many races and ethnic groups. While he referred briefly tonight to the need to "deal with unfinished business" between blacks and whites, he placed far more emphasis on whether, as he put it here, "we really can become one America as we become more diverse" in the next century.
Earlier this week, John Hope Franklin, the history professor whom Mr. Clinton picked as chairman of the panel, stressed a different approach. At the panel's first meeting on Monday, Mr. Franklin demurred when another member said that the group should focus on "multiracialism" during its yearlong review. Mr. Franklin maintained that it should emphasize black-white relations because that was where "this country cut its eyeteeth."
White House aides dismissed the difference as mere nuance, saying that the panel would ultimately address both subjects. But, together with a tart comment from Mr. Franklin about Mr. Clinton's approach to promoting the race initiative, it suggested that the panel would probably try to maintain some independence from the White House.
The President's major address of the day was in Pittsburgh, where in 40 minutes he sought to encompass his hopes for improving schools, fighting crime, increasing homeownership and improving relations among racial and ethnic groups.
Indeed, Mr. Clinton delivered one of his trademark, omnivorous speeches, declaring at one point, "The last thing I want to say is that we've got to send our children to schools that are safe and drug free," before adding moments later, "And, lastly, let me say, in addition to that, if you look at what this modern economy requires, we must open the doors of college education to every single American by the year 2000."
A senior aide to the President remarked later that there were "three or four good speeches in there."
But even before he delivered his speech, Mr. Clinton was criticized by Mr. Franklin for making his first major address on his race initiative -- since announcing it in June -- to a black audience. "The white side has been in control of virtually everything, so they're the ones who need educating on what justice and equality mean," Mr. Franklin said in an interview with The Associated Press.
Asked about that criticism, Michael D. McCurry, the White House press secretary, said the President intended to deliver "the same message in front of different types of audiences."
In response to a question here, Mr. Clinton predicted a public backlash against efforts in California and Texas to roll back affirmative action because of the abrupt drop in admissions of minorities to professional schools in those states.
As he was when he addressed the N.A.A.C.P. convention during the Presidential campaign a year ago, Mr. Clinton was enthusiastically received there today. In introducing him, the organization's chairwoman, Myrlie Evers-Williams, declared, "We cherish you, we welcome you into our arms and hearts again."
He was also warmly greeted with a standing ovation by the black journalists here tonight.
Before both groups, the President dwelled on his goals for education in poor communities. In his speech to the N.A.A.C.P., he again urged national, voluntary standards in reading and math, saying that children in impoverished schools would be able to meet them.
"I am tired of being told that children cannot succeed because of the difficulties of their circumstances," he continued, to applause. "All we do is consign them to staying in the same circumstances. It is wrong."
Mr. Clinton called for a $350 million program over five years to provide scholarships and other assistance to help train teachers who agree to serve at least three years in poor urban and rural school districts.
"We will have a special emphasis on recruiting minorities into teaching, because while a third of our students are minority, only 13 percent of their teachers are," he said.
Turning to racial reconciliation, the President argued that in a "global society," the diversity of the United States would be asset. He asked his overwhelmingly black audience why the United States was well-positioned to do business in Africa, then answered his own question: "Because of you."

SECTION: Section 1; Page 30; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 355 words

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Trade and Stocks Hurt Dollar, But Upward Trend Is Still Seen

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar ended mostly lower in seesaw trading yesterday, hurt by a Japanese minister's forecast of higher Japanese interest rates, news of a swollen United States trade deficit and a selloff in the stock market.
But traders said the underlying trend for the dollar remained up. They noted the currency was rebounding as dealings ended for the week and that the dollar's levels were substantially higher than a week earlier. 
 An assertion by Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany that he was not concerned about the dollar's recent advance to six-year highs against the mark also helped underpin the dollar.
"The dollar was strengthening as we came to a close," said Debra Larsen, assistant vice president of foreign exchange at Commerzbank in New York. "The signals are still there that this is not a market ready to turn against the dollar."
The dollar settled at 115.57 yen in New York, down from 116.07 Thursday but up from 114.02 yen a week earlier. Against the mark, the dollar settled at 1.7927 marks, down from 1.7941 marks but up from 1.7744 marks a week earlier. The pound settled at $1.6777, up from $1.6722, but down from $1.6946 a week earlier.
The dollar initially weakened in early Asian dealings after Trade Minister Shinji Sato of Japan said the recovery in Japan's economy would lead to higher interest rates.
Mr. Sato also said that he did not see any benefits to the current interest rate policy, which has left Japanese rates at record lows for nearly two years. Low rates have contributed to the yen's weakness.
The dollar later strengthened briefly against the yen when the Commerce Department reported the May trade deficit with Japan fell 25 percent, to $3.6 billion, less than expected.
But the dollar quickly retreated on details of the broader trade report, which showed the overall deficit shot up to $10.2 billion on record imports and a particularly large surge of Chinese goods.
Traders said the dollar was further hurt by the first big drop in the United States stock market this month. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 130.31 points, to 7,890.46, erasing all the week's gains.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bond Prices Dip Before Greenspan Testifies

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury bond prices declined for a second consecutive session yesterday, primarily because of concern over the Humphrey-Hawkins testimony of Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, before Congress next week.
The 30-year Treasury benchmark bond dropped 15/32, to a price of 101 11/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 6.52 percent, from 6.49 percent on Thursday. 
 Supply also played a role in trading as securities firms prepared for next week's Government sale of $27 billion in two-year and five-year notes, which will be in addition to the regular weekly bill auction. The bill auctions will total $16 billion.
Mr. Greenspan will deliver his semiannual testimony on the state of the economy to the House Banking Committee on Tuesday and the Senate committee on Wednesday. In the past, his remarks have either soothed investors' fears about Fed intentions or sent them scurrying for cover.
Anthony Chan, chief economist at Banc One Investment Advisors in Columbus, Ohio, said some of the data released yesterday, particularly consumer confidence figures, had caused some concern that the strength of those figures "could lead Greenspan to hint that a late year short-term interest rate hike cannot be ruled out." He added, " With all the bullishness that has recently engulfed the market, such talk could stop the latest rally in its tracks."
"The good news, however," Mr. Chan said, "is that with inflation at the wholesale and consumer level under strict control, it is unlikely that Greenspan will deliver any bombshell announcements about a pending immediate rate hike. Instead, his comments are only likely to state that the Fed would consider raising rates only if demand pressures intensify later in the year.
"Such talk is likely to provide encouragement for both bulls and bears. The bond market bulls will conclude that since the economy is not likely to bounce back, the Fed will remain on hold, while bears will use his pronouncement as proof that the Fed is not likely to remain on hold indefinitely."
A report yesterday on consumer confidence for mid-July from the University of Michigan showed a sharp rise from June. The index provided strong evidence that the pause in consumption during the second quarter would very likely not persist much longer. The university's index of consumer sentiment in July rose to 106.4 from 104.5 in June.
Traders also said the market reacted only mildly to a report showing that the United States trade deficit widened more than expected in May to $10.2 billion because it merely confirmed earlier reports that economic growth slowed in the second quarter.
"Greenspan may talk the vigilant talk," said Alan Levenson, a senior vice president and director of research at Aubrey G. Lanston & Company, "but neither he nor the market will walk the vigilant walk until they see the whites of the eyes of economic revival."
"From a bond market perspective, it seems too late to get long," he continued, "since significantly lower interest rates depend on further economic deceleration and accompanying thoughts of a cut in the funds rate, which we do not envision."
Elsewhere, in when-issued trading ahead of next week's note sales, the two-year Treasury issue was offered at a price to yield 5.91 percent and the five-year note at a price to yield 6.14 percent. Both were a few basis points higher than the previous day. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.

HEADLINE: Gore Defends Budget Plans As a Priority

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 18

 BODY:
Criticizing "out-of-date dogmas," Vice President Gore today defended the Clinton Administration's drive for a balanced budget against liberals in his party who say that strict balance is less important than investment and economic growth.
In an appearance before the centrist Democratic Leadership Council, Mr. Gore argued that the Government needed to erase the Federal deficit both to keep interest rates in check and to send a message that Government can be responsible. 
 He called balancing the budget important "not because it's a totem to worship, but because after decades of sheer fiscal recklessness we Americans need to reaffirm our capacity for self-discipline."
While he never mentioned his rival by name, Mr. Gore was clearly answering Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the House minority leader, who is expected to challenge the Vice President for the Democratic Presidential nomination in 2000.
Mr. Gephardt has been crafting an economic policy sharply distinct from the Administration's. He has said the nation could afford a budget deficit of up to 1 percent of the gross domestic product to allow more spending to generate faster economic growth rates.
Mr. Gore sought to counter that argument on friendly ground, before a group formed in the 1980's to lobby for a more centrist Democratic Party. He spoke of those who "say the economy is so strong that we can just sit on our hands and let the budget balance itself or that 'almost' should count for budgets as well as horseshoes."
"Let's not kid ourselves," the Vice President said. "If we're really serious about restoring people's basic faith in their Government and showing that we can get a job done, if we are really serious about leading the nations of the world into an era of fiscal discipline and responsibility, then we cannot be satisfied until the deficit is brought down to zero."
Mr. Gore's address was the latest salvo in a battle to define the face of the post-Clinton Democratic Party. Today the Vice President sought to make his argument persuasive not only to his party's moderates but also to its liberals.
Noting that the retirement of the baby boom generation would begin to drain more Government dollars in the next decade, Mr. Gore said, "we must also face up to the fact that without a balanced budget today there may be no progressive activist government tomorrow."
Mr. Gore indirectly took on Mr. Gephardt over trade policy as well, calling for Congress to grant President Clinton renewed flexibility to negotiate future trade agreements.
"With 95 percent of the world's consumers living outside of our borders how can we cut ourselves off from the world?" Mr. Gore said.
Mr. Gephardt, along with organized labor, has been critical of the Administration's free trade policies.
Venturing into one area where the Democrats are united, Mr. Gore attacked the Republican approach to tax cutting, accusing Republicans of advocating tax reductions that help the wealthy.

HEADLINE: Trade Deficit Is 17% Wider: Record Imports, Dip in Exports

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 18

 BODY:
The nation's trade deficit grew 17 percent in May as the strong economy drew in a record level of imports while exports fell slightly, the Commerce Department reported today.
The gap between exports and imports grew to $10.23 billion, from $8.75 billion in April, the department said, a bigger increase in the deficit than analysts had expected. 
 The deficit with Japan narrowed for the month, but the deficits with Canada, Mexico and China all expanded, underscoring the continued political sensitivity of trade policy as the Clinton Administration pushes to eliminate more trade barriers.
The drop in exports suggested that the economy might have been growing more slowly than economists had believed in the spring. After growing 5.9 percent in the first quarter, the economy cooled off considerably in the second quarter, and probably expanded at no more than a 2 percent pace in the period, economists said.
If there was good news in the results, it was that the trade imbalance reflected in part the continuing stronger performance of the American economy relative to most of its major trading partners. Not only is the United States enjoying steady growth with low inflation and low unemployment -- factors that help create demand for imports -- but also the dollar is strong, making imports relatively cheaper and exports more expensive to foreign buyers.
"As long as we remain the strongest industrial economy in the world, we're going to have an awful lot of trouble trying to narrow this trade gap," said Joel L. Naroff, an economist at the First Union Bank in Philadelphia. "We have an insatiable demand, not just for consumer goods but for capital goods as well, and our growth rates are just not being matched by our trading partners."
Exports in May fell slightly, to $77.2 billion from $77.9 billion in April, the second consecutive monthly decline. Imports increased from $86.6 billion in April to $87.5 billion in May, the fourth consecutive month in which imports have reached a new high.
Putting a positive spin on the numbers, Commerce Secretary William M. Daley said that through the first five months of the year, overall trade balances improved for manufacturing and services, but that price swings in food and energy hurt the balances in those categories by an even greater amount.
"While we are disappointed that the overall trade deficit has widened so far this year, there are quite a few positive things to say about the trade developments in 1997," Mr. Daley said. "All in all, the U.S. remains very competitive in world trade."
The deficit with Japan, long the most politically sensitive gauge of trade performance, narrowed to $3.63 billion, from $4.84 billion in April, although the gap for the first five months of the year remained higher than it was in the first five months of last year. But the gap with China, which is rapidly overtaking the deficit with Japan both in size and political significance, rose to $3.76 billion from $3.45 billion. It was only the third time that the monthly deficit with China exceeded that with Japan.
Mr. Daley said he would travel to China in the fall in an effort to convince Chinese officials of the need to do more to open their markets if they want to join the World Trade Organization and avoid heightened economic tensions with the United States.
"China's economy has been growing at double-digit rates, but its imports from the U.S. and the rest of the world do not reflect that," Mr. Daley said. "China's market, as we have said repeatedly, is too closed to exports, and we must make every effort to open this market to U.S. goods and U.S. services."
The deficit with Canada, the nation's biggest trading partner, rose to $1.74 billion, from $853 million in April. The deficit with Mexico rose to $1.70 billion from $1.39 billion.
The expanding deficits with Canada and Mexico have become troublesome to the Administration as its seeks to expand the North American Free Trade Agreement, first to Chile and eventually to other nations.
A report to Congress from the White House last week said the trade agreement had so far brought modest economic benefits to the United States and would prove more beneficial in the long run. But labor unions, environmentalists and other critics of the pact assert that there is no case for expanding it, and point to the expansion of the deficits with Canada and Mexico as evidence that it has failed to help American interests.
Mr. Daley defended American trade with Canada as "doing quite nicely," saying exports to that country are up 12 percent this year. He said trade with Mexico was "booming," with exports up 21 percent this year as the Mexican economy showed signs of increasing growth.
The Commerce Department said the largest decreases in exports were in telecommunications equipment and industrial machinery, cars and parts and industrial supplies. The largest increases in imports came in aircraft, computer accessories, cars and parts and crude oil.

Deficit is the excess of imports over exports for goods an services. Amounts are rounded, in billion of dollars, seasonally adjusted. Chart shows imports, exports, and deficit (in billions of dollars) from December 1995 through May 1997. (Source: Commerce Department)(pg. 32)
