HEADLINE: Stanley to Cut 4,700 Jobs In Revamping

BYLINE: By DANA CANEDY 

 BODY:
Stanley Works, the hand tool and hardware products maker, announced a much-expected revamping yesterday that will cut 24 percent of its work force, or about 4,700 jobs, as it seeks to refocus its business.
The company said it would close or sell 53 of its 123 manufacturing plants and distribution centers worldwide. The company declined to identify which plants in the United States it would eliminate but said that less than 1 percent of its employees in Connecticut would be affected. The company, based in New Britain, Conn., employs 19,000 workers, 1,850 of them in Connecticut and 12,000 in the United States. 
 Stanley's chairman and chief executive, John M. Trani, indicated that there would be an overhaul when he took over the company in January.
Mr. Trani's arrival has raised expectations for Stanley, which faces much competition in a price-sensitive and fragmented market. He previously ran the General Electric Company's medical systems division for 10 years, expanding it abroad and improving revenues and profits. Indeed, since January, Stanley's stock price has risen 70 percent.
"With John Trani's arrival, I felt there was going to be a narrowing in the gap between the company's potential and its performance," said Gregory A. Nejmeh, an analyst with Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette.
But yesterday, shares of Stanley fell $2.0625, to $44.4375. Analysts said the stock fell in part because of its recent run-up and because the company also announced a loss for the second quarter.
Analysts said the job cuts were necessary as part of the streamlining but were only a start.
"Stanley has a very fine, long-term record going back many decades," said Jonathan L. Goldfarb, an analyst with Merrill Lynch. "But in the mid-to-late 80's the company's performance began to slip somewhat in part because it was so well entrenched in its markets and so insulated in New Britain, Conn., that they were really never forced into a painful and radical restructuring program that was forced on so many other companies by global and economic realities."
Stanley said yesterday that it would eliminate 110 manufacturing jobs over the next 12 months at its hardware packaging unit in New Britain, but would add 120 salaried positions at its headquarters as it consolidated some operations. The company had previously announced that 150 jobs would be lost when it transferred some production to Richmond, Va., from New Britain.
"To grow, we must be competitive," Mr. Trani said. "That starts by becoming the low-cost provider. In the case of our central Connecticut operations, this necessitates product transfers to lower-cost locations and resulting work force reductions."
Stanley plans to streamline sales, distribution and administrative operations and to increase spending on new-product development and advertising to maximize the potential of its products and brand name.
The company also said it would take $240 million in charges before taxes against second- and third-quarter earnings to pay for the revamping, including $137 million in the most recent quarter. It will also have $100 million in transaction costs related to the reorganization.
As a result of the charge, the company reported a loss of $65 million, or 72 cents a share, for the second quarter, compared with a profit of $33 million, or 37 cents, a year earlier. Sales fell to $674 million from $677 million.

HEADLINE: Stocks Tumble, Wiping Out Week's Gains

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA 

 BODY:
The stock market plunged yesterday in a broad selloff, just two days after the Dow Jones industrial average breached the 8,000-point level.
There was heavy selling throughout the day, as technology shares and blue-chip stocks closed out an historic week by reversing much of their gains. 
 The Dow plummeted 130.31 points, or 1.62 percent, to close at 7,890.46. For the week, the Dow lost 31.36 points. But for the year, the blue-chip average is up 22.3 percent.
Analysts said technology shares were upset by Microsoft, which reported earnings that were slightly better than expected after the market closed Thursday. The giant software company also said revenues could slow in the new fiscal year that began on July 1.
Microsoft, which often beats estimates by wide margins, had gained 20 points in the previous four sessions. Yesterday, its shares fell 815/16 , to 140 1/2.
A University of Michigan report, showing that consumer confidence hit record levels in the first half of July, created some inflation worries in the bond market, helping push interest rates higher.
"There's a tendency of the market to react even to the little bits of news that come out," said Ned Riley Jr., chief investment officer at BankBoston. "The consumer attitudes were a little steamy and there was some fear that might pick up into inflation."
But Mr. Riley said there was also a rising concern among some investors that inflation might dissipate into deflation, which means that pricing power could erode to the point where corporate profits will suffer.
Yesterday, the selling pressure came shortly after the opening bell. Some of the losses -- and part of the volatility that helped the Dow plunge 145 points early in the day -- were attributed to heavy program trading and "double witching," the expiration of some options on stocks and stock indexes.
But Laszlo Birinyi, president of Birinyi Associates, a research firm that tracks program trading, said program trades only accelerated a trend that was already in the market.
"There's a lot of hesitancy out there because we're at high levels and high valuations," Mr. Birinyi said. "This is a market that's down because there's widespread selling."
In the broader market, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 16.31, to 915.30, and the Russell 2000 fell 2.22, to 405.89.
The technology-heavy Nasdaq 100 -- which tracks the largest companies in the Nasdaq composite -- fell even more steeply, down 2.2 percent, as several high-flying technology stocks retreated after two weeks of soaring prices.
"The principal news may well have been the Microsoft news, where they hit their estimate but didn't exceed it," said Frederick Taylor, chief investment officer at the U.S. Trust Company. "That's a news item that did take a little energy out of the tech stocks."
Shares of Compaq Computer, Motorola and America Online were also hit hard after sharp run-ups in recent days. Compaq, which had gained 24 points in the previous two weeks, fell 315/16 , to 128 1/8. Motorola lost 7, to 82, and America Online was down 3 3/4, to 64, after being downgraded to "recommend list" from "priority list"by Goldman, Sachs.
I.B.M. was the only Dow stock to gain, climbing 4 7/8 points, to 104 1/2, after its shares were upgraded by Merrill Lynch ahead of next week's earnings report. Trading in I.B.M., at 11.6 million shares, was nearly three times the average volume.
Within the Dow, 27 stocks lost ground, with Procter & Gamble leading the way, down 45/16 , to 148 3/4. Du Pont lost 3 1/4, to 62 1/4.
Drug, financial and technology shares -- among the year's best performers -- saw heavy losses yesterday, as did energy shares. On the Big Board, losers beat winners by a margin of more than than 2 to 1.
After this week's Consumer Price Index release, which showed inflation growing at its slowest pace in 11 years, investors' attention shifted to whether the market is overvalued.
Since mid-April, when the market began rising out of a swift, monthlong downturn, the Dow and S.& P. 500 have both seen gains of 23 percent. And big-capitalization technology shares have gained even more, culminating in records for all the major indexes this week.
Indeed, when the Dow peaked on Wednesday at 8,038.88, it had gained 50 percent in 12 months, the second- sharpest rise in a one-year period. The best run ended in June 1983, when the Dow had surged 57 percent in the previous 12 months.
The recent run-up has many on Wall Street talking about a "classic blowoff," a period when prices rise too sharply, too quickly in what many consider a danger sign.
"Prices have outrun their sensible structure," said Justin Mamis, a technical analyst who has followed the market since the 1950's. "They've become emotional, speculative almost."
Although many on Wall Street are talking about an ideal economy, Mr. Mamis said he was worried about rising consumer debt, and deteriorating pricing power, or the inability of companies to raise prices.
"It isn't the best of all possible worlds," he said. "There are problems beginning to seep out."
But many analysts contend that the market is being driven by investors who continue to pour billions into mutual funds, as well as an outlook of strong earnings and low inflation.
So, yesterday's selloff, rather than being the onset of a severe downturn, is in the eyes of some analysts a time to rest and contemplate the next move. "After pushing over 8,000 we're just taking a little rest," said Mr. Taylor at U.S. Trust. "This kind of correction today is just a normal midsummer interlude."

HEADLINE: Technology's Towers Invade the Forest

BYLINE: By Keith Schneider; Keith Schneider, a former New York Times national correspondent, is executive director of the Michigan Land Use Institute.

DATELINE: BENZONIA, Mich.

 BODY:
Of all the emblems of the modern economy now invading rural America -- freeways, strip malls, giant subdivisions -- none seemed so benign as the electronic cottage.
Urban professionals who migrated to the country thought they could stay in touch with the urban world through phone, fax and Internet without disturbing their solitude or ruining the scenery. 
 How naive. Here in heavily forested northwest Michigan, the social and environmental costs of the communications revolution are quickly becoming apparent.
A regional wireless phone company, N.P.I. Wireless, has proposed building a 250-foot tower on Benzie County's most prominent forested summit. The tower is designed to carry an array of antennas and receivers for so-called personal communications services, the new wireless technology that its proponents say is superior to cellular phones.
Benzie County instituted a moratorium on such towers, and rejected the company's proposal. But the company has sued and, if a settlement is not reached, will probably win it case -- eventually.
That's because the company can cite the Telecommunications Act, which the White House and Congress teamed up with the wireless industry to pass in 1996. Hailed as the definitive statement of Washington's desire to promote flexibility, innovation and competition, the act was supposed to help speed up the development of the wireless telecommunications industry. But Washington, by taking the industry under its wing, has kicked local governments in the teeth, and created a formidable backlash to its plans.
On the way to passage, lobbyists for the wireless industry quietly made sure that local opposition to the unsightly towers would be blocked. They persuaded Congress to write new rules that drastically limited the authority local governments had to oversee land use.
The Telecommunications Act makes it illegal for local governments to reject new towers. The law also makes it difficult, and in many cases impossible, for communities to restrict the size, location, appearance or number of towers.
The law, however, includes one loophole. Congress directed communities to speed review of new tower applications.
This provision, though, was ambiguous enough to invite a successful challenge. In 1996, a Federal District judge in Washington State ruled that it was legal for the city of Medina to institute a temporary moratorium on building towers to give planners time to update the zoning ordinance.
Since then, some 300 other communities have established moratoriums. The industry has appealed the practice to the Federal Communications Commission, which is expected to issue a ruling this summer.
There are many reasons for local governments to be wary of these towers. The technology uses an extremely high frequency on the radio spectrum. As a result, signals don't travel very far and antennas generally must be within five or six miles of one another. That means, industry experts say, as many as 120,000 new antennas will be needed throughout the country.
In cities, most antennas will be hung on existing communications towers, or fixed to tall buildings. But in the countryside, thousands of new communications towers may be needed. In Benzie County, which currently has three towers, there could be perhaps as many as a dozen.
In an era when leaders of both parties have declared the end to big government, the Telecommunications Act is an old-fashioned abrogation of power. But by seeking to cut citizens out of important decisions affecting their communities, the law has led to exceedingly polarized fights. Unsurprisingly, there have been Federal court battles in Georgia, Illinois, Iowa, Washington State and Wisconsin.
And in late June, wireless providers, blaming lawsuits and other problems, notified the F.C.C. that they were in danger of defaulting on billions of dollars in government loans.
Had the decisions about the towers been handled the old-fashioned way, through public debate, maybe these delays could have been avoided. The question is, Will anyone in Washington listen?

HEADLINE: Court Sets Back F.C.C. Efforts To Open Local Phone Markets

BYLINE: By SETH SCHIESEL 

 BODY:
An appeals court struck down key elements of the Federal Communications Commission's rules for opening local telephone markets to competition yesterday, adding yet another obstacle to the already rocky landscape of telecommunications regulation.
The Federal appeals court ruling could further slow the introduction of unbridled competition -- and the lower prices expected to result from that competition -- in the nation's telecommunications business, because it would allow states to develop different mechanisms for bringing new companies into the market rather than following uniform F.C.C. guidelines. 
 The F.C.C. rules, which were issued last year and were immediately challenged by state regulators and several local telephone companies, governed the terms by which local phone companies were to let competitors connect to their networks. But yesterday the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit, in St. Louis, said the commission had overstepped the bounds of the Telecommunications Act of 1996.
The law "plainly grants the state commissions, not the F.C.C., the authority to determine the rates involved in the implementation of the local competition provisions of the act," wrote Judge David R. Hansen in the unanimous opinion. The other judges were Pasco M. Bowman and Roger L. Wollman.
The F.C.C. said it intended to appeal the decision to the Supreme Court. But if the circuit court's ruling stands, companies that want to offer local telephone service across the country will have to negotiate a potential hodgepodge of regulatory environments rather than follow a single national strategy.
The rules had not yet gone into effect, because the appeals court had put a stay on them while the appeal was pending. And so the immediate effect was simply to uphold the status quo in the local telephone marketplace.
But by rejecting the commission's guidelines, some telecommunications experts said, the ruling would indefinitely delay the introduction of full competition in local markets -- and the lower prices that were expected to result.
"This further endangers the development of competition in telecommunications," said Gene Kimmelman, co-director of the Washington office of Consumers Union. "The court ruling leaves a patchwork of state proceedings that have been cumbersome, moving slowly and not generating competitive alternatives for local phone service."
The ruling was not only a major setback for the F.C.C., but also for the big long-distance companies, like AT&T and MCI Communications, that are trying to offer local service nationwide. The F.C.C. had argued, in part, that state commissions might unfairly favor the interests of incumbent local telephone companies, which may employ thousands of local voters, over those of a long-distance company, which could be based thousands of miles away.
"The fundamental principle of a level playing field was rejected by the Eighth Circuit," said the F.C.C.'s chairman, Reed E. Hundt. "For the first time in the history of the Federal Communications Commission, a court has ruled that when Congress writes a specific statute that we do not necessarily have the authority to write a rule to implement it."
But Laurence H. Tribe, the Harvard law professor who helped the local telephone companies develop their legal strategy, said that F.C.C. rule makers had "imposed a regime that replaced the market with regulatory specification at so many points in the process that they did not really represent what Congress had in mind."
An AT&T executive said the court's ruling was a blow to local competition. "From a practical perspective, we think it's important to have as much uniformity as possible across the various states," said Mark Rosenblum, AT&T's vice president for law and public policy. "We are disappointed that the court continued to see it in a different light."
Last year's Telecommunications Act was meant to hasten the entry of long-distance companies into the local market, and vice versa. Under the terms of the law, the Bell operating companies, like Nynex in the Northeast and Ameritech in the Midwest, will be allowed to offer long-distance service within their regions once there is significant competition in their local service markets.
Trying to jump-start such competition, the F.C.C. issued a set of rules last summer that laid out how states were to determine the price new entrants into the local market would pay to connect with the existing local telephone networks.
The Bell companies and other large local operators like GTE and Southern New England Telephone rebelled against the rules, saying that the F.C.C. guidelines would not allow them to recoup the full cost of providing service. As such, the companies said, competitors would be allowed into their market with an unfair economic advantage.
State commissioners, meanwhile, argued that their right to regulate intrastate communications was being trampled by Washington.
As for Bell entry into the long-distance market, the F.C.C. has not certified that extensive local competition exists in any of the Bell company areas. That means that while many business customers can order local telephone service from alternative providers like Worldcom or Teleport Communications, most residential consumers still have only one choice: the local phone company.
William P. Barr, the former United States Attorney General who is now general counsel of GTE, was triumphant yesterday.
"There was a complete victory on the jurisdictional argument that it should be the states that should be setting the prices, not the F.C.C.," said Mr. Barr, who argued the plaintiffs' case before the Eighth Circuit in January. "The primary problem with the regulations was that it set wholesale prices in the states and that it set those prices far too low from the local companies' standpoint."
On Capitol Hill, at least one influential lawmaker, who had argued that the Telecommunications Act did not go far enough to encourage competition, saw a glimmer of hope in yesterday's ruling.
"This is a very serious setback to the F.C.C.'s overall regulatory plan and to the act itself," said Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona and chairman of the Committee on Commerce, Science and Transportation. "It may mean that we'll have to look at going back to square one or not."
"The decision was correct," he added. "But what I would like to see is a deregulated environment where nobody sets the prices, where the marketplace sets the prices."

HEADLINE: Iowa Insurer Settles Class-Action Suit

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: DES MOINES, July 18

 BODY:
The Equitable of Iowa Companies said today that it had agreed to a $22 million settlement of a lawsuit contending that it misled life insurance customers.
The company was one of several insurers nationwide named in class-action lawsuits for sales tactics that became popular in the 1980's as insurance companies faced growing competition from mutual funds, stockbrokers and other providers of financial services. 
 Equitable and other insurers were accused of promoting life insurance as a savings plan and of churning, or replacing policies, to generate new commissions. The lawsuits also contended that improper charges were imposed on policies to pay annual fees and other costs.
The lawsuits said that agents of Equitable of Iowa and other insurers made deceptive sales talks that led customers to believe that their policies would generate enough dividend income to cover annual premiums. The projections were based on overly optimistic projections of interest rates, the lawsuits contended.
Equitable of Iowa denied the accusations but agreed to settle. A court hearing on approval of the agreement is expected late this year, the company said.
Owners of about 130,000 life insurance policies issued by Equitable of Iowa from 1984 through 1996 could be eligible for benefits under the settlement. The benefits include increased interest and dividend payments, reduced-rate loans and enhanced annuities and life insurance policies.
The company said it would mail notices to affected policyholders by Sept. 30.

HEADLINE: Rockwell Sued In Patent Case

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WILMINGTON, Del., July 18

 BODY:
The Eaton Corporation has filed a patent infringement lawsuit against the Rockwell International Corporation over a gear-shift control system.
Eaton, which makes parts for the automobile and aerospace industries, is asking that Rockwell stop producing the item and pay any damages that Rockwell has caused. 
 The patent is for a vehicle shift control that provides the simplicity of a manual gear shift and the fuel economy of an automatic gear shift, according to the suit.
Rockwell, based in Seal Beach, Calif., declined to comment on the suit, which was filed in United States District Court in Wilmington.
Rockwell, which built the B-1 bomber and the United States space shuttle fleet, makes semiconductors, motors and avionics and communications systems.
Shares of Eaton, based in Cleveland, fell $1.50, to $88.25. Rockwell's shares fell 62.5 cents, to $62.

HEADLINE: Surplus Issue Puts Solution On a Budget Further Off

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

DATELINE: ALBANY, July 18

 BODY:
State leaders appear further from agreement on a state budget than they were a week or two ago, after the Pataki administration concluded that budget talks were pointing toward huge deficits in future years, and insisted on holding more than $500 million in reserve until next year.
The Governor proposed the reserve fund last week and offered a promise that all of it would be used for school aid in the 1998-99 fiscal year, said administration officials and legislative aides who spoke on condition of anonymity. Legislators of both parties objected to the plan, which would mean less money to spend right away on school aid and tax cuts. 
 A month ago, state officials were confident that it would be relatively easy to reach a 1997-98 budget agreement because this year's decisions were about how much to spend, and not what to cut, as in past years. The state is flush with cash, thanks largely to the boom on Wall Street. Budget negotiators concluded that there was $2.6 billion more available to spend than Gov. George E. Pataki had counted on when he released his proposed $66.3 billion budget in January.
But when the Governor and legislative leaders sat down to decide how to spend the money, it appeared that all of the additional money would go toward expenses, like tax cuts and school spending, whose impact on the budget would likely grow rapidly in future years. Also, the proposals for a relatively fat budget this year were based in part on a $1.7 billion surplus left over from last year, meaning that the state would spend more than it would take in this year, a formula for future deficits.
The talks, aides to Mr. Pataki said, were leading toward a $4.5 billion budget gap, or greater, in 1998-99, which would have to be closed in a gubernatorial election year. That led to the proposal, made last week, to hold back more than $500 million.
Both the Democrats who control the Assembly and the Republicans who run the Senate were furious, their aides said, and the leaders accused the Governor of reneging on tentative agreements on how much to spend in each category.
The Governor's position is similar to that of independent budget analysts, like the nonprofit Citizens Budget Commission and bond rating agencies, which argued that the state ought to keep a larger cushion for a sudden economic downturn.
The budget was supposed to be in place by the start of the fiscal year on April 1.
On another budgeting issue, the Giuliani administration and New York City Board of Education have stepped up their lobbying efforts in Albany to get the state to pay more than $600 million that it owes the city in education aid from prior years.
City officials say that they do not expect the state to repay all of the money this year, but that they want the budget to include a substantial payment. They also are pushing the state to agree on a schedule for repaying the rest, which has accumulated since 1989.
In budget negotiations, Mr. Pataki has proposed repaying $35 million in the coming year, a figure that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani is likely to reject as too low.
The unpaid school aid is for school construction, handicapped and prekindergarten students and other programs, most of which are required under state law and which the state is supposed to help finance. Board of Education officials say that unless the state pays a lot of the overdue aid in the coming year, the city will have to cut education spending.

HEADLINE: Battles Over Lawyer Advertising Divide the Bar

BYLINE: By NINA BERNSTEIN 

DATELINE: ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., July 16

 BODY:
Ron Bell's face is too big to miss on the highway billboard that advertises his legal services on one side and on the other, Pizza Hut. This year, someone shot an arrow right between his smiling eyes. For weeks it stuck there, like an emblem of the backlash over lawyer advertising that has divided the legal community here and across the country.
Mr. Bell, a personal injury lawyer whose small stature and extravagant appetite for publicity are legendary in New Mexico, was not fazed by the use of his forehead for target practice. 
 "I got great free radio on that," he recalled with glee as he drove past his sign on I-25 in a white Mercedes with NM LAW license plates. "I was the very first lawyer billboard in America." He also claims the first full-page ad in the Yellow Pages of the U S West telephone directory and the first lawyer ad on MTV.
But 20 years after the United States Supreme Court opened the door to lawyer advertising on First Amendment grounds, the establishment trial bar is trying to crack down on maverick competitors like Mr. Bell. The lawyers disciplinary board of the New Mexico Supreme Court has slapped him with a year's probation and threatened him with disbarment for violating its legal advertising rules, and he is fighting back with a Federal suit.
It is one of many such battles being waged around the country as the old-line leaders of disciplinary boards and state bar associations from Florida and Nevada to Iowa and New York try to rein in their more freewheeling colleagues. Depending on one's perspective, they are part of a last-ditch struggle for the soul of the legal profession, or a crass conflict for economic advantage by the old-boys' club, waged at the expense of free speech principles.
"Lawyer advertising adversely affects the respect the public has for the judicial system and the administration of justice," said Richard Ransom, the retired chief justice of the New Mexico Supreme Court who spearheaded the adoption of tough advertising rules in 1992.
Victor Marshall, who is representing Mr. Bell in his Federal suit against the board, which ruled that some of Mr. Bell's ads could be misleading, countered: "The rules are unconstitutional as written and even more so as applied. Members of the public have seen his ads five hundred million times without ever claiming that they were misled. The only people who actually complained are other lawyers."
A changing and even contradictory patchwork of state regulations governs lawyer advertising, but since the 1977 Bates v. State Bar of Arizona decision, the country's highest court has repeatedly held that the content of lawyer advertising cannot be constitutionally restricted except to prevent false, deceptive or misleading communication. Nevertheless, many state bar regulators have used those parameters to try to govern everything from the kind of music allowed in a lawyer commercial to the exact size of a disclaimer like "lawyer advertisement."
Lawyer advertising has grown every year since the 1977 decision, according to William Hornsby, director of the American Bar Association's Commission on Advertising. Television advertising by lawyers reached $157 million last year, and they spent $627 million on ads in Yellow Pages in 1996, up from $447 million four years earlier.
At best, the results of laying down the law to colleagues who wander in this commercial wilderness can mystify the public. A Rochester lawyer was recently allowed to use a vulgarism in an ad calling himself the meanest advocate in town, but was censured for advertising with the words "Shapiro Legal Clinic" because it could mislead people about the breadth of his practice. In Florida, where some of the country's most restrictive rules just became stricter, only instrumental music is allowed in lawyer commercials, which means ads could use Jimmy Hendrix's version of the national anthem, but not a choir's rendition of "God Bless America."
When Brad Slutsky, a lawyer at the Atlanta law firm of King & Spaulding, tried to make the firm's World Wide Web site abide by advertising rules for every state, he found many of the required disclaimers so contradictory, he said, that even his effort to compile them in a 500-word statement is out of compliance in some states. The special problems of regulating lawyer advertising on the Internet will be considered at the American Bar Association's annual meeting next month.
Among the many ads rejected by the New Mexico screening committee under the state's 1992 rules was a bumper sticker featuring an alligator and the line "Tail Gators Beware. . .My lawyer is Ron Bell!" Another rejected ad was a television dramatization showing a happy woman leaving Mr. Bell's office with an 8-by-4-foot check as the lawyer turned to the camera and said, "I can't guarantee that I can get you a check that big, but I will evaluate your case free of charge." The committee also turned down a television commercial of his showing children driving toy cars in a dramatization that warned against drunk driving. The words "lawyer advertisement" were not big enough, the committee said.
But the same committee approved "Ron's Biker Babes," an ad Mr. Bell himself calls "terrible" and "very tacky," in which the lawyer, clad in black leather, makes his pitch to accident victims beside hulking motorcycle dudes and their scantily dressed female companions.
"If it's in poor taste, that's not an issue," said Frank Spring, the former chairman of the Legal Advertising Committee of the Disciplinary Board, whose practice is part of a personal injury law partnership in a no-frills, institutional building a block from Mr. Bell's hacienda-style office that has his name etched in gothic lettering on the glass transom.
Unlike Mr. Bell, 47, who moved here from Philadelphia in a Fiat in the early 1980's, Mr. Spring is a native Southwesterner. He who grew up across the Texas border in a town of 1,200 people where his grandfather owned the general store and his father was a banker.
"My values, to be candid, are small-town values," said Mr. Spring, 54, who wore chinos and an open-collared shirt and was leaving early for a trout fishing trip in the Pecos Mountains. He called lawyer advertising "demeaning" and "distasteful" and lamented its role in fueling settlement mills where clients get short shrift.
"Are we going to become simply commercial entities or focus on getting justice for people?" he asked.
Mr. Bell's reaction to such high-minded concerns by his competitors is derisive. "They want justice, shuddup!" he said with a dismissive wave of his hand. "Our entire remedy in civil justice in America is a check. I want to get the case and I want to get the check."
Underlying the principled rhetoric of their opponents, Mr. Bell and other proponents of lawyer advertising contend, is fear of price competition which would benefit the consumer.
"Whether you make Ron back off or not, it won't matter anyway," said Mr. Bell, who likes to speak of himself in the third person, "because there's some guy who's going to come out of law school and put up a big sign that says '25 percent.' " The standard contingency fee that trial lawyers collect from the settlements or damage awards they win is now a third plus costs.
But in the Queen Anne-style house where Stephen Durkovich runs his successful law practice a block from the hospital where he was born, he and his partners denounce lawyer advertising as a corrosive trend that allows inferior lawyers to prey on the poor, the uneducated and minorities.
"It hurts my soul," said Mr. Durkovich, who specializes in suing doctors. He was one of the lawyers who represented the New Mexico Supreme Court when another lawyer, Terrence Revo, successfully challenged the disciplinary rules' total ban on targeted direct-mail solicitation by lawyers. A $60,000 poll commissioned by the State Supreme Court found that those with the least income and education were most likely to approve of Mr. Revo's letter, and to believe that lawyers who advertised were better than those who did not advertise. In reality, Mr. Durkovich contended, the opposite was true, which makes such ads inherently misleading to one segment of the population, while it makes the better educated even more critical of the legal profession.
When Mr. Revo won, the adversaries of advertising mounted an unsuccessful appeal, and even petitioned the United States Supreme Court for a review in an effort to keep the ban. Yet only nine years earlier, in Shapero v. Kentucky Bar Association, the Supreme Court had upheld the right of a lawyer to send letters of solicitation to victims of accidents whose names he collected from police reports, ruling that the First Amendment "does not permit a ban on certain speech merely because it is more efficient."
In 1995, however, in a 5-to-4 decision, the Court upheld Florida's 30-day moratorium on such direct mail solicitations in personal injury and wrongful death cases, largely on the grounds of protecting the privacy of vulnerable families. That decision has fueled hopes by the opponents of advertising that new restrictions are possible.
Virginia Ferrara, the chief disciplinary counsel who brought the complaint against Ron Bell, is far less zealous about the issue than the board that employs her.
"The bar is always saying, 'Why don't you do something about Ron Bell?' " said Ms. Ferrara, who served on the American Bar Association's commission on advertising two years ago. "But his clients do not appear to be dissatisfied with him. The more established members of the bar, it drives them crazy. But there are some people in the world who identify with tacky."

HEADLINE: Feud's Latest Salvo: Outgoing CUNY Chancellor Assailed

BYLINE: By WILLIAM H. HONAN 

 BODY:
Still angry over her long-running battle with Dr. W. Ann Reynolds, the departing Chancellor of the City University of New York, the chairwoman of the university's board yesterday accused Dr. Reynolds of "virtually lying" to the trustees, and asserted that the new chancellor would have to have "good personal chemistry" with her.
"We expect the new chancellor to be a person who respects our principles," the chairwoman, Dr. Anne A. Paolucci, said. "I want to see certain things turned around, to break down some barriers and not sweep things under the rug." 
 Dr. Paolucci promised "a massive, nationwide search" for a new chancellor to replace Dr. Reynolds, who announced on Thursday that she was leaving to become president of the University of Alabama at Birmingham. Dr. Paolucci said she had begun consulting with her fellow trustees on their next step.
Dr. Reynolds, speaking at a news conference in Birmingham hours before Dr. Paolucci made her accusation, refused to comment about the deterioration of her relations with the City University trustees, which had led some trustees to suggest that they might want a new chancellor and eventually led her to seek another job. Dr. Reynolds could not be reached last night for comment on Dr. Paolucci's accusation.
In criticizing Dr. Reynolds for "virtually lying," Dr. Paolucci was referring to a recent controversy over Hostos Community College in the Bronx. In May, the trustees learned that Hostos had waived a writing test that the Chancellor's office said was a requirement for graduation throughout the City University system. The trustees, believing they were only reinforcing existing policy, voted to make the test mandatory for all graduates, but it later emerged that other campuses had also given degrees to students who had not passed the test. Dr. Reynolds said she herself had been misled, but Dr. Paolucci was outraged.
Even before that battle, friction between the two women had become so intense that Edith B. Everett, a trustee loyal to Dr. Reynolds, accused Dr. Paolucci of "beating up" on the Chancellor.
In an interview yesterday, Dr. Paolucci made it clear that she was not looking for a new chancellor "to sit back and take it easy."
"I work tremendously hard at this and I will expect the new chancellor to do the same," she said.
Asked about priorities for the new chancellor, Dr. Paolucci said they would include "taking a look at the foundations of the university and seeing if they need to be redone." The foundations, she said, include expanding a program to improve the ability of students in reading, math and writing, finding cost efficiencies and preventing grade inflation.
Dr. Paolucci said that in consultation with other City University trustees, she had come up with a list of two or three candidates for the job of interim chancellor, to govern the university while a large-scale search seeks a new chancellor. She declined to mention names. "Ideally, the interim chancellor should be a highly placed person who is in CUNY now and can take us over the small crises that will turn up," Dr. Paolucci said.
The interim chancellor might serve for three to six months, Dr. Paolucci said. She also said that rather than set up a search committee to find an interim chancellor she would consult with Herman Badillo, the vice chairman, as well as with other trustees, and then make a recommendation that she would expect the board to approve without delay.
The transition comes at a time when City University, the largest urban university in the nation with 21 campuses and 200,000 students, struggles to cope with seriously eroded city and state financial support, a climbing enrollment and a flood of poor minority students and recent immigrants who require extra help.
Dr. Paolucci insisted that even after publicly urging Dr. Reynolds to resign on June 24, she gave no thought to who might replace her. She refused to name potential candidates, but said she would be looking for someone from a large urban public university "with the experience that can be transferred to our turf."
"But I like to be surprised," she added. "This is going to be a really massive search."
James P. Murphy, a former City University board chairman who presided over the search for Dr. Reynolds and her predecessor, said the board will be inclined to pick someone who has "a good academic background, senior experience in a large public educational system, ability to work well with elective officials and would stay for 10 years."
Mr. Murphy said he expected the new chancellor to "do some aggressive recruiting of new faculty" because a rash of early retirements had left the teaching staff thin.
Kenneth Sherrill, a member of the faculty senate and professor of political science at Hunter College, said the faculty would watch the selection process with care because "it will be a real test of the board's commitment to the mission of the university." He added: "We will be interested to know how open and how widespread the search process is."

HEADLINE: Robert C. Weaver, 89, First Black Cabinet Member, Dies

BYLINE: By JAMES BARRON 

 BODY:
Dr. Robert C. Weaver, the first Secretary of Housing and Urban Development and the first black person appointed to the Cabinet, died on Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 89.
Dr. Weaver was also one of the original directors of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, which was formed to rescue New York City from financial crisis in the 1970's. 
 "He was a catalyst with the Kennedys and then with Johnson, forging new initiatives in housing and education," said Walter E. Washington, the first elected Mayor of the nation's capital.
A portly, pedagogical man who wrote four books on urban affairs, Dr. Weaver had made a name for himself in the 1930's and 40's as an expert behind-the-scenes strategist in the civil rights movement. "Fight hard and legally," he said, "and don't blow your top."
As a part of the "Black Cabinet" in the administration of President Franklin D. Roosevelt, Dr. Weaver was one of a group of blacks who specialized in housing, education and employment. After being hired as race relations advisers in various Federal agencies, they pressured and persuaded the White House to provide more jobs, better educational opportunities and equal rights.
Dr. Weaver began in 1933 as an aide to Interior Secretary Harold L. Ickes. He later served as a special assistant in the housing division of the Works Progress Administration, the National Defense Advisory Commission, the War Production Board and the War Manpower Commission.
Shortly before the 1940 election, he devised a strategy that defused anger among blacks about Stephen T. Early, President Roosevelt's press secretary. Arriving at Pennsylvania Station in New York, Early lost his temper when a line of police officers blocked his way. Early knocked one of the officers, who happened to be black, to the ground. As word of the incident spread, a White House adviser put through a telephone call to Dr. Weaver in Washington.
The aide, worried that the incident would cost Roosevelt the black vote, told Dr. Weaver to find the other black advisers and prepare a speech that would appeal to blacks for the President to deliver the following week.
Dr. Weaver said he doubted that he could find anyone in the middle of the night, even though most of the others in the "Black Cabinet" had been playing poker in his basement when the phone rang. "And anyway," he said, "I don't think a mere speech will do it. What we need right now is something so dramatic that it will make the Negro voters forget all about Steve Early and the Negro cop too."
Within 48 hours, Benjamin O. Davis Sr. was the first black general in the Army; William H. Hastie was the first black civilian aide to the Secretary of War, and Campbell C. Johnson was the first high-ranking black aide to the head of the Selective Service.
 Robert Clifton Weaver was born on Dec. 29, 1907, in Washington. His father was a postal worker and his mother -- who he said influenced his intellectual development -- was the daughter of the first black person to graduate from Harvard with a degree in dentistry. When Dr. Weaver joined the Kennedy Administration, whose Harvard connections extended to the occupant of the Oval Office, he held more Harvard degrees -- three, including a doctorate in economics -- than anyone else in the administration's upper ranks.
In 1960, after serving as the New York State Rent Commissioner, Dr. Weaver became the national chairman of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, and President Kennedy sought Dr. Weaver's advice on civil rights. The following year, the President appointed him administrator of the Housing and Home Finance Agency, a loose combination of agencies that included the bureaucratic components of what would eventually become H.U.D., including the Federal Housing Administration to spur construction, the Urban Renewal Administration to oversee slum clearance and the Federal National Mortgage Association to line up money for new housing.
President Kennedy tried to have the agency raised to Cabinet rank, but Congress balked. Southerners led an attack against the appointment of a black to the Cabinet, and there were charges that Dr. Weaver was an extremist. Kennedy abandoned the idea of creating an urban affairs department.
Five years later, when President Johnson revived the idea and pushed it through Congress, Senators who had voted against Dr. Weaver the first time around voted for him.
Past Federal housing programs had largely dealt with bricks-and-mortar policies. Dr. Weaver said Washington needed to take a more philosophical approach. "Creative federalism stresses local initiative, local solutions to local problems," he said.
But, he added, "where the obvious needs for action to meet an urban problem are not being fulfilled, the Federal Government has a responsibility at least to generate a thorough awareness of the problem."
Dr. Weaver, who said that "you cannot have physical renewal without human renewal," pushed for better-looking public housing by offering awards for design. He also increased the amount of money for small businesses displaced by urban renewal and revived the long-dormant idea of Federal rent subsidies for the elderly.
Later in his life, he was a professor of urban affairs at Hunter College, was a member of the Visiting Committee at the School of Urban and Public Affairs at Carnegie-Mellon University and held visiting professorships at Columbia Teachers' College and the New York University School of Education. He also served as a consultant to the Ford Foundation and was the president of Baruch College in Manhattan in 1969.
His wife, Ella, died in 1991. Their son, Robert Jr., died in 1962.
